You go Kim!  I used to hate all electronic music sooooooooooooooooooooooooo
much.  I have recently gotten very much into it.  I listen to the music all
the time, and I love going to raves.  And, being a musician, I have changed
my mind from wanting to be in a band to wanting to make electronic music
(probably trance, progressive house, and maybe techno).  So does this mean
that I'm "fucking shite" and that I shouldn't be in the scene?  hak1 gets
the big WHATEVER!
					VespaRaver

Of course we ALL go to raves to hear the DJs.  But the drummers are great,
too.  In fact, the ones I have heard have all been pretty good--although, I
DO admit that I haven't heard that many.  And whistles are _okay_, as long
as they're doin' it right!
					VespaRaver




At 04:33 PM 11/30/97 -0800, you wrote:
>At 2:40 PM -0800 11/29/97, Vanessa & Miccaela wrote:
>
>Whistles are the bomb. Tweet, tweet...tweet, tweet, tweet. You're right, of
>course; they've got to be used in moderation. The occasional whistle
>exchange adds to the vibe. Fortunately constant whistling is quite rare.
>It's the drummers who are the off beat, suckerheads, who drive me away from
>the speakers. I mean, is there even one drummer, in the entire rave scene,
>who knows that there are eight beats in a measure? As I understand it, some
>people actually like the drummers: however, I myself go to raves to (among
>other reasons) hear the DJs.

WOW!  i HAVE to see a performance by these people!!!!  do they play the

dodger

> ----------
> From: 	Messiah Wannabe[SMTP:messiahw@rocketmail.com]
> Sent: 	Thursday, November 27, 1997 3:10 PM
> To: 	sfraves
> Subject: 	nrr: crash worship review
> 
> 
> 
> after seemingly endless misadventures, chris, martha stewart, pjfuzzy
> and myself finally made it to the warehouse at 2nd and jackson, only
> to wait about 3 hours for cw to start playing.  beyond race was making
> swirly arabian/ambient shadow music while a dj spun in the other room.
>  then some slacker with a distorted acoustic guitar made beckish
> beefhearty skronking noises for a while (normally i dislike anything
> that smacks of indie rock but i had to admit the guy was rather
> entertaining, whoever he was). i listened and danced till finally at
> 3:13 am crash worship stormed the warehouse.  wow.  how can you
> possibly describe a crash worship show?
> 
> dozens of torches were lit to drum swells and the germano-yiddish
> strains of a string trio.  topless dancers spun flaming batons as
> platters of semi-clad girls were hoisted around the warehouse.  a
> woman standing next to me whistled a long drone along with the
> violins, i accompanied her by whistling an indian melody as the dozen
> drumers softly banged their way through the crowd...  a 6 foot tall
> man with flaming horns threw handfuls of firecrackers into the masses,
> dousing the floor and audience with flammible liquids before burning
> his hat in a flaming pyre that mushroomed up to the wooden rafters. 
> then things started to get crazy...
> 
> the drum core beat a furious tattoo as the mosh pit started to
> writhe... band members wandered through the crowd with mylar sacks of
> red franzia, soaking the crowd in dyonesian revelry.  wine drenched
> shirts came off...  celebrating the harvest season, i scarfed half of
> a "special" cigarette with pj, then passed it off into the swirling
> masses...  the same platters that held the half-naked women now held
> fruit and spit-roasted suckling pigs.  the element of danger added a
> keen edge to my high - an orange hit me on the side of the face,
> stinging my eye - what if that had been one of the bottle rockets the
> guy with the horns was shooting into the oil soaked crowd?  a
> beautiful woman did acrobatics hanging from a rope attached to the
> ceiling as the strings lilted.  the drummers beat louder and faster as
> she spun and spun and spun...  the tempo picked up again, those guys
> could make a pretty phat beat when they put their minds to it, i was
> sucked into the crowd once again...  a semi-neud couple necked in the
> middle of it all, i lightly caressed them as i floated by, they didn't
> seem to mind...  louder, faster, louder, louder, my ears were
> splitting as the whole scene built to a crazy creshendo till suddenly
> at 4:23 the cops busted in and shut off the sound system.  but of
> course that couldn't stop the drummers, who continued to wander
> through the crowd beating furiously as the police tried to chase them
> down.  meanwhile the string quartet was now being pushed through the
> crowd by naked men on a viking ship with wheels as they handed out
> grapes to the revelers and the beautiful woman had stripped off her
> fishnets and was doing more erotic ballet hanging from another spot on
> the ceiling...  the five cops and ten security guys were still trying
> to get the 400 or so people out the door, they were arguing with the
> drummers, who (practically at gunpoint) led a bunch of us out the door
> and onto the street, where they continued to play and dance till 4:36
> am - one hour and 23 minutes later.
> 
> 
> funny thing about crash worship - the first time i saw them they did
> the same show (minus circus acts and pigs) to 13 people in a small
> club in raliegh n.c. one wednesday.  my roomate knew one of the band
> members from art school, so we invited them to stay the night at our
> 20's farmhouse in bynum (pop 223).  ALL RIGHT, i thought, THE PLACE IS
> GONNA GET TRASHED!  COOL!  you can imagine my (pleasant?) surprise
> when, upon their arrival at our house, their drummer dreike made
> herbal tea for everyone while chit-chatting with me and my wife, and
> then they all went promptly to sleep - but not before washing out all
> their mugs and placing them neatly to dry on the dishrack.  _very_
> nice people...
> 
> -messiah wannabe
> 
>  
> DO YOU YAHOO!?
> Get your free @yahoo.com address at http://mail.yahoo.com
>

From: "Break Dancer" <breaker2000@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: my weekend review in LA =)
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Mon, 01 Dec 1997 01:14:29 PST
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


  Thanksgiving Day was...... thanksgiving day... 'nuff of that ;)

Friday night my friend hooked up some tickets to see
 Goldie and Janes Addication  
play at the Universal ampitheater. We had like 5th row seats but we 
couldn't go into the pit :(
that was my first time seeing goldie... he's pretty hardcore.. i dig it 
:)
Janes Addiction was BAD ASS...they played all their all skool songs 
well....flea seemed a lot more mellow compared to his chili peppers days 
:)  the crazy dancers were gettin freaky too....
all in all.. it was dope

Saturday night i went to a hardcore/jungle party in downtown LA.
2 rooms...
Hardcore in one 
Jungle in tha other..
i REALLY liked this party.... it was called  Sideshow
i got groovy in the break circles in the ungle room, and stomped sround 
in the hardcore room...
then chilled in the big big chill room downstairs..
I really liked seeing all my so-cal raver firends and didnt realize how 
many people i knew, yet how many i didnt know.. and had just met...
things change quickly, but yet slowly at the same time...
I probably wont be able to go to another party up here until next year.. 
( that sounds weird, next year))
so when winter break is over, ill see you all at a party or gathering or 
in the streets getting funky to a toon as you wait at the busstop listen 
to the beat in your mind that does not stop even when the power is cut 
off........
peace everyone
Philip
disordr

That does put things into perspective, I've never been at a party where
someone died.  I always know the danger is there, but because I've never had
any trouble with drugs, I've never worried about it.  I guess I've been
lucky.  Makes me wonder if I walked pass that girl, passed out in the dark,
when I was looking for my friend.  Or maybe if my friend had fallen asleep
near her...  Makes me wish I had looked a little harder at all of the passed
out people.  Also makes me wonder what the people running that party think
about it...  I don't see it as their fault, in fact I saw more drugs
confiscated in that party than I have ever before by the security, so they
weren't condoning the drugs at their party, but I hate to think of the guilt
they are probably feeling.  How do you think this will drastically change the
raving scene?  Haven't there been drug related deaths at these parties
before?

Hi folks - Larry Ching here ...
 
 I've been unsubb'd from SFRaves for awhile, in order to reduce the
amount of temptation to go out dancing versus other stuff that needs
to get done in my life.
 
 Anyway, I've still kept my sub to the calendar, and I noticed
this party called _Playground_ ,
 
 "This will be an epic underground event, dedicated to the SFRaves
   family experience."
 
"This party will be in an indoor centralized SF location. Tix on sale
   December 1st. SF."
 
 There's no phone number or information about where the tickets will
be sold. Can anyone help? 

 Also - I suspect that if this is really an SFRaves planned and
executed event, that there's been tons of conversation about it on 
the list, all of which I've missed. I'd be so grateful if someone
could clue me in on what the SFRaves connections are with this
party.

 As one of the old SFRAves subscrib*rs from 1992, it'd be great to
meet and dance with the "new wave" of SFRavers! Looking forward
to meeting you folks and hearing you mix ...

okay, in light of the 'what have you done for the scene lately', and in
light of the article I just read in the Metro about how there's shit to do
down here, and because I still haven't met that many new people since I've
moved out here, and because I fucking love the music...

...I just want to let anybody/everybody know that I'd like to help out
with anything/everything involved with starting/fostering/resussitating a
scene down here in the south bay.

the handful of people I've met have all told me that the SJ area sucks, go
up to SF.  and I'm sick of it.  I've heard enough people (on this list, in
person, and in the papers) mention that there's nothing to do down
here, that I know that the potential exists to do something cool. let's
start a jungle/d'n'b night at some loser club in SJ!

comments?

-jimg

--skoop@slackers.net
--http://www.slackers.net/~skoop

	As a former south bay resident, I have to agree. 
	I have been to a few parties in the South Bay that were quite
small because no one would venture out from s.f. that we knew and also
the impression was no one would come to party in south bay but which had
a great vibe.  The opportunites for great parties, furthermore, are only
increasing  as the area continues to change and its residents are
increasingly aware of the music.  A lot of people on here I suspect are
in South Bay but can't make the parties becuse they are "car"-less.
Being more open minded about throwing parties in this area I would
suspect might take some of the competition off spaces in San Francisco
and East Bay.  Hmmm...on that note, i ask the question, is one of the
reasons more parties are not thrown in South Bay is the area is more
intolerant of parties police wise?  Have people tried before and it
wasn't successful?  

	And now that I said my word, I wouldn't mind helping you Jimg
and drumming up some old contacts of mine in South bay and seeing if
something could happen.

Okay,

WHEREAS, it appeared beforehand that nearly everyone on this list was
attending SPIRIT last Friday (or, at least, that's how it appeared from
the posts I was reading before going home on Wed); and

WHEREAS, 98% of the people actually in attendance at SPIRIT were under
18, and average age around 15 (or so it seemed); therefore,

AM I correct in drawing the conclusion that most of the folks on this
list are under 18???  Not that it's that big a deal, I just assumed 
that the average SFRave-er was in their 20's.


My short review of SPIRIT:

Have you ever known anyone who fell asleep during a rave while under
the influence of 2 (two) hits of e?  My . . . er . . . friend did.

Subject: Re: MISHAP AT BIGFLOOR
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
References: <971201003826_1571262945@mrin53.mail.aol.com> <34825032.70C3@santacruz-ca.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Why is it that everytime there is an accident at a party relating to
drugs, everyone goes into the traditional, Black-n-White view that
"Drugs are bad and thats that"?

I've taken E at two parties this month after waiting about 9 months, so
I know sober raving and I also know raving on E. And it is true that
abuse and addiction do happen with Methanpedimines. A friend of mine at
Spirit was pulling his hair out, asking me and everyone else to barrow
$20 for another hit, too blinded by his lust for that fEEling to see
what was happening to him. 

But it is ALSO true that an experience at a Rave sober can NOT compare
with being under the influence. Dancing, kissing, walking, talking all
feel better on E. I don't believe you can just as much fun sober. You
can have fun, shure. But it's not the same Kick-ass "I can see God!"
kind of fun.

Does this justify taking drugs consistently? I don't think so. My E at
Spirit wasn't as good as the one two weeks ago. Why? Because my brains
fluids that cause me to be "high" was reduced, so it wasn't as good.
This is why it's important to WAIT untill your brain has FULLY recovered
from the last time you took E. What is "Fully recovered"? Personally, my
rule of thumb is to wait about 6 months between each hit. This way,
every time you take it, it feels like the first time you took it. And
isn't that what we all want?

-=Pengo=-

>
>> 	Please respect party throwers who
>> are trying to do it right, and please respect
>> the work involved, especially when it comes
>> to finding a space in this city.
>
>I'll agree with you on this statement.  What I don't agree with is that
>you are implying that the other groups/organizers ruined this space for
>you.  The truth of the matter is that although frequent use of a space
>definitely makes it much more vulnerable to get shut down, someone called
>the police to complain about this party on Friday.

** Sorry, I didn't mean to imply that we should be the
only ones to use that space. It's just that when a good place
is found, and starts to get used every weekend, then it
is vulnerable ... to the police, to uncaring promoters, and
to party goers that might not care so much about what some
people are trying to do.
**There were some wonderful groups that used this space,
and I don't mind saying that I appreciate Macadio and the
Mantis group for doing it right and showing respect and
enthusiasm for that place. I felt more than happy to have
helped out in some way.
***You're right, the police is what I'm worried about.
When one person involved in parties, or who goes to parties,
harms one promoter or party, the effect is far greater. It
hurts everybody. I just want to keep things from getting
shut down. I don't have solutions, I'm just upset about it.
*j*
***We're very excited about our party on the 12th,
so we're gonna keep looking!
***I appreciate your comments, drenalin!

> > and myself finally made it to the warehouse at 2nd and jackson, only
> > to wait about 3 hours for cw to start playing.  beyond race was
making
> > swirly arabian/ambient shadow music while a dj spun in the other
room.
> >  then some slacker with a distorted acoustic guitar made beckish
> > beefhearty skronking noises for a while (normally i dislike anything
> > that smacks of indie rock but i had to admit the guy was rather
> > entertaining, whoever he was). i listened and danced till finally at
> > 3:13 am crash worship stormed the warehouse.  wow.  how can you
> > possibly describe a crash worship show?
> > 
> > dozens of torches were lit to drum swells and the germano-yiddish
> > strains of a string trio.  topless dancers spun flaming batons as
> > platters of semi-clad girls were hoisted around the warehouse.  a
> > woman standing next to me whistled a long drone along with the
> > violins, i accompanied her by whistling an indian melody as the
dozen
> > drumers softly banged their way through the crowd...  a 6 foot tall
> > man with flaming horns threw handfuls of firecrackers into the
masses,
> > dousing the floor and audience with flammible liquids before burning
> > his hat in a flaming pyre that mushroomed up to the wooden rafters. 
> > then things started to get crazy...
> > 
> > the drum core beat a furious tattoo as the mosh pit started to
> > writhe... band members wandered through the crowd with mylar sacks
of
> > red franzia, soaking the crowd in dyonesian revelry.  wine drenched
> > shirts came off...  celebrating the harvest season, i scarfed half
of
> > a "special" cigarette with pj, then passed it off into the swirling
> > masses...  the same platters that held the half-naked women now held
> > fruit and spit-roasted suckling pigs.  the element of danger added a
> > keen edge to my high - an orange hit me on the side of the face,
> > stinging my eye - what if that had been one of the bottle rockets
the
> > guy with the horns was shooting into the oil soaked crowd?  a
> > beautiful woman did acrobatics hanging from a rope attached to the
> > ceiling as the strings lilted.  the drummers beat louder and
faster as
> > she spun and spun and spun...  the tempo picked up again, those guys
> > could make a pretty phat beat when they put their minds to it, i was
> > sucked into the crowd once again...  a semi-neud couple necked in
the
> > middle of it all, i lightly caressed them as i floated by, they
didn't
> > seem to mind...  louder, faster, louder, louder, my ears were
> > splitting as the whole scene built to a crazy creshendo till
suddenly
> > at 4:23 the cops busted in and shut off the sound system.  but of
> > course that couldn't stop the drummers, who continued to wander
> > through the crowd beating furiously as the police tried to chase
them
> > down.  meanwhile the string quartet was now being pushed through the
> > crowd by naked men on a viking ship with wheels as they handed out
> > grapes to the revelers and the beautiful woman had stripped off her
> > fishnets and was doing more erotic ballet hanging from another
spot on
> > the ceiling...  the five cops and ten security guys were still
trying
> > to get the 400 or so people out the door, they were arguing with the
> > drummers, who (practically at gunpoint) led a bunch of us out the
door
> > and onto the street, where they continued to play and dance till
4:36
> > am - one hour and 23 minutes later.
> > 
> > 
> > funny thing about crash worship - the first time i saw them they did
> > the same show (minus circus acts and pigs) to 13 people in a small
> > club in raliegh n.c. one wednesday.  my roomate knew one of the band
> > members from art school, so we invited them to stay the night at our
> > 20's farmhouse in bynum (pop 223).  ALL RIGHT, i thought, THE
PLACE IS
> > GONNA GET TRASHED!  COOL!  you can imagine my (pleasant?) surprise
> > when, upon their arrival at our house, their drummer dreike made
> > herbal tea for everyone while chit-chatting with me and my wife, and
> > then they all went promptly to sleep - but not before washing out
all
> > their mugs and placing them neatly to dry on the dishrack.  _very_
> > nice people...
> > 
> > -messiah wannabe
> > 
> >  
> > DO YOU YAHOO!?
> > Get your free @yahoo.com address at http://mail.yahoo.com
> > 
>

OK.. I talked to the doctor in the ICU unit last night, and she is doing fine.
They were able to bring her back, and the prognoses looks positive.  She was in
very bad shape, and almost died.  her life will never be the same.

I hope that maybe this will serve as a lesson and a learning experince that drugs
are NOT save.

keep it real... Vlad

MusicBoy17@aol.com wrote:

> That does put things into perspective, I've never been at a party where
> someone died.  I always know the danger is there, but because I've never had
> any trouble with drugs, I've never worried about it.  I guess I've been
> lucky.  Makes me wonder if I walked pass that girl, passed out in the dark,
> when I was looking for my friend.  Or maybe if my friend had fallen asleep
> near her...  Makes me wish I had looked a little harder at all of the passed
> out people.  Also makes me wonder what the people running that party think
> about it...  I don't see it as their fault, in fact I saw more drugs
> confiscated in that party than I have ever before by the security, so they
> weren't condoning the drugs at their party, but I hate to think of the guilt
> they are probably feeling.  How do you think this will drastically change the
> raving scene?  Haven't there been drug related deaths at these parties
> before?

This is a good theory.  Taking E will never again feel like the first
time.  It will feel good, but your brain conditions you for each
subsequent dosage after the first.  It has to do with the response effect
and the conditioned incentive effect controlled by the basolateral
amygdala(BLA) area of the brain.  But you are right, waiting six months
will increase the feeling, but never reach the first time where you did
not know what to expect and your body was new to the introduction of the
foriegn material.
				Ken

Well I hope everyone had a safe and happy holiday? I
sure did I hope some of us took a little time to
reflect on life, the scene, future plans etc?? Well I
have to give it up to the Feel Good Family for
putting on a good party. It was on a smaller scale
then the normal events they do. It was nice plenty of
room to dance and trance etc.. Always good loud sound
and good visuals and lasers etc.. However I was not
pleased with Paucus's setup I used his equipment. I
am not sure if it was the sound guy or Paucus that
set it up but it sucked. I was a little disapointed
cause I have played for Vlad many times and the sound
has been but the utmost best. So I guess someone
other then a sound guy set up it was really low and
as a result I had a real shitty set. Well some people
said it was nice but I did not like it personally.
That is not Vlad's fault however it is the person
that hooked it up. Word of advice for DJ's out there.
DON'T buy the MOJO rane it is a piece of shit. Well I
better not be so biased it was not good for me I
should say. But the Aphex by intimadation that I
picked up a couple of weeeks ago rocks!!!. I have to
say that all the DJ's I Heard that night rocked the
house!!! My boy Vertigo was on the one. We was
ripping it up on the trancey shit. Slim was good
Moshe was playing some dope downtempo and then busted
out the Jungle stylie. I caught the end of Josh's set
and it was nice acid groovy house. Tripnotix and
paucus played some nice acid breaks. O and I scored a
new rekkid by EFX personally.. Thankx EFX even though
he is not on the list that was way dope. All and all
it was a nice party with good people. Sorry my
performance was not up to par.. 

Peace,
Macadio

Hello everyone,

Just a reminder that tonight from 9pm-2am at the Bahia Cabana is Inhabit
the Machines with special guests from Scotland: Neil Landstrumm and Tobias
Schmidt LIVE (Scandinavia, Tresor, Mosquito Records) along with Dave
Tarrida of Sativae Records.

The abrupt ending of the Space Children party at 3:55am cut Neil and Toby's
set to just 25 minutes, so this will be their only true live set in San
Francisco.  If you're into techno, I urge you all to come and check it out,
because these guys are some of the most creative minds in the genre.

The lineup will be as follows:
9-10pm sutekh
10-11:30: jon williams
11:30-12:30: neil landstrumm and tobias schmidt LIVE
12:30-2: dave tarrida

Cover charge will be $5, the Bahia is located at 1600 Market at Franklin in
SF.  It will be an 18+ event.

Hope to see you there!

Seth

Pengo wrote:
> 
> Why is it that everytime there is an accident at a party relating to
> drugs, everyone goes into the traditional, Black-n-White view that
> "Drugs are bad and thats that"?
> 
> I've taken E at two parties this month after waiting about 9 months, so
> I know sober raving and I also know raving on E. And it is true that
> abuse and addiction do happen with Methanpedimines. A friend of mine at
> Spirit was pulling his hair out, asking me and everyone else to barrow
> $20 for another hit, too blinded by his lust for that fEEling to see
> what was happening to him.
> 
> But it is ALSO true that an experience at a Rave sober can NOT compare
> with being under the influence. Dancing, kissing, walking, talking all
> feel better on E. I don't believe you can just as much fun sober. You
> can have fun, shure. But it's not the same Kick-ass "I can see God!"
> kind of fun.
> 
> Does this justify taking drugs consistently? I don't think so. My E at
> Spirit wasn't as good as the one two weeks ago. Why? Because my brains
> fluids that cause me to be "high" was reduced, so it wasn't as good.
> This is why it's important to WAIT untill your brain has FULLY recovered
> from the last time you took E. What is "Fully recovered"? Personally, my
> rule of thumb is to wait about 6 months between each hit. This way,
> every time you take it, it feels like the first time you took it. And
> isn't that what we all want?
> 
> -=Pengo=-
> SugeR wrote:
> >
> > You know this is not nearly the beginning of all this nonsense...
> >
> > kids... you got to sleep and eat... and well speed will KILL you...
> >
> > i don't care how much fun you think yer havin..... it ain't worth the
> > consequence.... i still have a good time... and i don't use hard
> > drugs... so... ummm wake up... feel the vibe...and pray they still let
> > us dance... PeAcE...
> >
> >           -SugeR

Does anyone have negative opinions of Space Children Rave, I do.  But this
weekend they did have great music.  Eat Static and Micheal Dog stole the
show, I came to see them and once they put me on their guest list those
Space Children ***** finaly let us in.  but in general I have found Space
Children raves to be much like Oakland raves:  Too crowded, angry people
just out to get money, and too many drug dealers just ready to fight in
another invades their territory.  Smaller SF raves are always the way to
go.  Sounds like SPIRIT was more fun.

Razor

>Why is it that everytime there is an accident at a party relating to
>drugs, everyone goes into the traditional, Black-n-White view that
>"Drugs are bad and thats that"?

>"drugs are not necccesarrily bad however 15 year old kids on drugs is not what
>i see as "good"."

>I've taken E at two parties this month after waiting about 9 months, so
>I know sober raving and I also know raving on E. And it is true that
>abuse and addiction do happen with Methanpedimines. A friend of mine at
>Spirit was pulling his hair out, asking me and everyone else to barrow
>$20 for another hit, too blinded by his lust for that fEEling to see
>what was happening to him.
>This  is plain and simply ...pathetic one of the main reasons why i find it
>very difficult to go out anymore. Put simply i dont realte to kids whos whole
>social scene revloves around drugs. Ive been there and done that .

>But it is ALSO true that an experience at a Rave sober can NOT compare
>with being under the influence. Dancing, kissing, walking, talking all
>feel better on E. I don't believe you can just as much fun sober. You
>can have fun, shure. But it's not the same Kick-ass "I can see God!"
>kind of fun.
>Now here is where i take umbrage(sp?). I find the notion that kids who take
>drugs at parties just have more fun than kids who dont ridiculous to the point
>of being offensive. Ive been partying for a few years now and have never taken
>drugs at a party ever. I have had your" kick ass i can see god kind of fun at
>parties" Patrying has been a very spiritual thing for me . Dancing into a
>trance,meeting wonderful people and listinging to amasing music. It seems that
>u are lacking somthing in yourself if u cant have as much fun at a party on
>drugs as without. Now im not saying the experiance is the same ,that would be
>silly im not intoxicated. Its just a bit smug and ignorant to say  its better.
>No i hve never been to a praty fucked up, A small tradegy in your eyes
>perhaps. But then again ive never shit my pants at a party,hit anyone for no
>reason,jumped into the  putrid water at point molate, made out with some one
>whom i cant remember the next day,had sex in a chill room,ran out into the
>streets in my underwear,passed out or made any more of a fool of my self than
>was delibrate. All of the afore mentioned things are things ive seen at a
>party by people on drugs. Thank god ive never had to go there ... in short
>think before you speak, u never knoe whos listining...   moshe

> > I know sober raving and I also know raving on E. And it is true that
> > abuse and addiction do happen with Methanpedimines. A friend of mine at
> > Spirit was pulling his hair out, asking me and everyone else to barrow
> > $20 for another hit, too blinded by his lust for that fEEling to see
> > what was happening to him.
> >
> > But it is ALSO true that an experience at a Rave sober can NOT compare
> > with being under the influence. Dancing, kissing, walking, talking all
> > feel better on E. I don't believe you can just as much fun sober. You
> > can have fun, shure. But it's not the same Kick-ass "I can see God!"
> > kind of fun.
> >
> > Does this justify taking drugs consistently? I don't think so. My E at
> > Spirit wasn't as good as the one two weeks ago. Why? Because my brains
> > fluids that cause me to be "high" was reduced, so it wasn't as good.
> > This is why it's important to WAIT untill your brain has FULLY recovered
> > from the last time you took E. What is "Fully recovered"? Personally, my
> > rule of thumb is to wait about 6 months between each hit. This way,
> > every time you take it, it feels like the first time you took it. And
> > isn't that what we all want?

> another invades their territory.  Smaller SF raves are always the way to
> go.  Sounds like SPIRIT was more fun.
> 
> Razor

At 11:17 AM -0800 12/1/97, vlad 008 wrote:
>>It's shit.  This is not England or Scotland, this is America and there
>is
>>no such word as "shite" in the American lexicon.  "Shit" is the proper
>>useage.

>since when is it necessary to use proper grammar and english on sfr?
>
>>  Do you own Solid Grooves?  Do you even *know* Harry?  Matters
>>little.  Solar can shop where he wants, and next time he's in Solid
>grooves
>>I bet Harry and the crew will have nothing but love for homey.  After
>all,
>>he's spending mad money in there, like everyone else.

>umm, i think hak knows harry pretty well, probly better than a lot of
>people

By doing a bit of research *this* is what I found out about this whole thing:

haK works @ solid grooves (hi Thad).  Used to be with a drum & bass crew
but is now solo.  Why I dunno.

Solar was in the store.  When Solar buys jungle it is usually because there
aren't good hosue tracks out, but Solar *does* buy jungle.

Solar was put into the jungle room @ stompy.  This was his *first official*
jungle gig (officail = being put on a flyer).

Now you can draw whatever conclusions you will from this information, but
on the surface it seems like there may, and I repeat may, be some
professional jealousy (I mean after all, I see Solar's name on all kinds of
flyers, while I rarely if ever have seen haK's name on flyers in recent
history).  I cannot guess people's motiviations for being so mean
spiritied.  Since haK works at Solid Grooves it would have been appropriate
for him to take it directly to Solar, after all, he will have more than one
opportunity to take it to his face.  Why haK chose NOT to take it direct
and do it so publicly where Solar can't defend himself is the mystery of
the ages.

The worse thing however is how this reflects upon Harry Who and Brandon who
jointly own Solid Grooves.  I do wonder if they like their employees
talking noise about a well respected figure in the house community, who
happens to be one of the people who helps keep Solid Grooves in business by
purchasing lots of records.

IMO, hak has done Solid Grooves a grave disservice, and has misrepresented
the spirit and the vibe that solid grooves is all about.  Hey if you're a
house DJ who has expanded your horizons shouldn;t you be able to flex some
of that muscle in your favorite south bay store?  I dunno.  I will ask
Harry & Brandon personally if they agree with haK's position and his
attitude.

This story has gone far outside of SFRaves.  Alot of people I know are
talking about it.  I'll let Harry & Brandon decide if they like how their
store is being represented.  If I know anything about these men after these
years, I can only guess that they will not be pleased.

If haK would've taken it to Solar's face all these unpleasantries would
have been avoided.  Cowardice never pays off.

Peace,
John




"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

to all of the loveworks family, all them lil' house babies and to anyone
who ever experienced the l o v e...

san francisco's mobile house music phenomenon,

**** loveworks dancing ****

will be taking a break from the tough life of weekly saturday nights in
order to reinvent, relax, regroup, and regenerate into a whole other thang.

we will be hosting one more party at the 111 minna street gallery on
december 13th.

then,

we can begin the new year with some serious basement house music parties
and one offs til we get an all night space that can handle the l o v e.

thanks again to everyone who has supported us over the last year and a half
and we'll look to you again in 1998.

xoxoxoxoxoxox -




the loveworks organisation

After all, I am a part of society and I obviously think differently. I
would say that members of our society today find comfort in not feeling
responsible for negative events in their life.
> 
> If someone gets shot, it is obviously the gun manufacturers fault for
> making a the gun. If someone falls through a roof while comitting a
> robbery it is obviously the owners fault, and if someone od's rather it be
> accidentally or disrespect of their own body and limits, it is obviously
> the dealers fault.
> 
> 1) What are "Methandpedimines?" :-)
You mean you don't know??? ;) (Meth and Pedimies?)

> 2) If you mean methamphetamines, yes abuse and addiction do happen with
>    them. However MDMA while related to methamphetamines is not a

This is true. Methamphetamines are often combined with MDMA as "filler",
however, and I'm shure sometimes people will sell straight speed as "E".
And unless you whipped up the batch yourself or got a lab report you
can't tell before hand. I think it's pretty common to get
Methamphetamines when some one "takes E" at a party. Heck, you could
even say this is advantagous for dealers because the addiction hooks the
customer. Even more reason to sell Methamphetamines as E with or without
combining MDMA. Ecstacy is just a word. MDMA is expensive.

-=Pengo=-

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Dec 02 02:30:13 1997

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 4316 invoked by uid 6000); 2 Dec 1997 02:30:11 -0000
Received: (qmail 4278 invoked from network); 2 Dec 1997 02:30:09 -0000
Received: from netcommunications.net (root@208.147.42.10)
  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 2 Dec 1997 02:30:09 -0000
Received: from [38.248.198.72] ([38.248.198.72] (may be forged)) by netcommunications.net (10.1/8.7.3) with ESMTP id SAA11619 for <sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org>; Mon, 1 Dec 1997 18:36:09 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <l03110705b0a91720f4f4@[38.248.198.72]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 1 Dec 1997 18:30:09 -0800
To: sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Another Spirit Review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Here are my little penny's of thoughts about Spirit ....

1 cent.  ATMOSPHERE:  Vlad really does a great job making a space for a
party.... I don't remember any lasers at all (were there any?) but every
room had cool visuals (I esp liked the wall-sized projections in the
hip-hop funky room, very cool).... and the chill room (which I never really
went in to) looked supercomfortable... and I like that it had no music...
the  better to hear you with, my dear!  Really well setup.

2 cents.  FRIENDS:  Some great people were there.  Plus I got to meet some
sfravers i've never met before (hi doreen!) and see lots of old friends....
it's always a pleasure to put faces with names, and to see how open and
friendly and unique so many of the sfravers are...  you guys rock.

3 cents.  MUSIC & DANCING:  The lineup was great, lots of variety.... and
Vlad, that projection of the lineup schedule on the wall was perfect, it
made it so easy to see who was where and when! I didn't stay late, but
every set I heard was great and got the crowd going (but i'm bummed I only
heard Moshe's triphop, I missed his jungle)...

I heard many dj's, who are notoriously hard to please, talking about some
of the sets they heard that night, and that's saying something.... Carlos'
set really blew away a lot of people especially.

4 cents.  ATTITUDES:  On the down side, and maybe it was just me and that i
was tired in the first place, but the attitude of many of the kids who were
there both annoys and depresses me!  They stand at the wall and stare as
you walk by, just pulsing out a cold street vibe... what is up with that?
Does their life require such insulation to protect them that they can
*never* just relax and have fun?

And the circles.... I'm not completely down on circles... I love to watch
people dance... probably *more* than the next person... but I just think it
really sucks to have circles that take up most of a room, where 40 guys
wearing versions of the same outfit are watching one person at a time
dance... i guess to me, dancing just isn't a spectator sport ... especially
when they start the circle by walking in a widening spiral with street
attitude, pushing people away and then turning their back on you, now that
they've seized the territory where you were dancing just moments before.
Ever notice these guys aren't smiling?  That's because, underneath, I don't
think it's about having fun to them.   It's about territory and staking a
claim, and excluding people outside your group, and that's against the
fundamental spirit of raving to me.

5 cents.  BUNK:  Nasty dealers hawking their wares, which kids then find
out were $20 aspirins, make me sick.  Want a little tip?  Never buy
anything from a someone you'd be afraid to meet in a dark alley.... in life
in general, do business with your friends... and if you can't find a
friend, maybe you should just wait for another time.  Because thugs who
stand at doors chanting "x" and "k" and "doses" aren't really going to be
looking out for you, now, are they?  Nope, so you have to look after
yourself, and never put yourself at the mercy of creeps like this.  Because
$20 aspirin would be the *least* of your worries with some of these
guys.... remember, this is your life you're talking about here, who do you
want to trust with it?

Overall, this was a good little (big) party, with a great setup and lots of
great music.... and maybe if i weren't so tired (wish i could get rid of
this danged cold!), I would have been able to get through the attitude
factor.... but even with such a strong contingent of cool ravers there, the
numbers of thugs with attitude affects my comfort level, unfortunately.
Even if boomerang *was* wearing a dress and all.  But my poinsettia
headpiece did get to make its seasonal debut, which is a good thing, and I
did get to dance a bit, and that's good too!

love, leslie

And now to dissect since I never addressed any of these issues in my other
post:


>>It's shit.  This is not England or Scotland, this is America and there
>is
>>no such word as "shite" in the American lexicon.  "Shit" is the proper
>>useage.
>
>since when is it necessary to use proper grammar and english on sfr?

It is necessary if you wish to be understood.

>
>>  Do you own Solid Grooves?  Do you even *know* Harry?  Matters
>>little.  Solar can shop where he wants, and next time he's in Solid
>grooves
>>I bet Harry and the crew will have nothing but love for homey.  After
>all,
>>he's spending mad money in there, like everyone else.
>
>umm, i think hak knows harry pretty well, probly better than a lot of
>people

I love it when people do this type of thing.  Somebody has a knowledge of
someone and quantifies it.  Ok I'll do the same.  I knew Harry when he was
throwing parties before there was a Solid Grooves.  I remeber when Harry
first opened his store.  I've known Mr. Who for a very long time (I even
know his *real* last name).  Whether he knows Harry or not, I doubt he
spoke to Harry before sending out his missive.  It is further problematoc
because haK is an associate of Solid Grooves and when he makes statements
such as "don;t ever come to solid grooves
you fool, never support the schemers........"  is a de facto banning from a
record store.  One can only ask under whose authority?  Since I *know* that
haK doesn't own one square foot of the store, and since he is acting as a
representative of the store, is he doing the store justice by his vitriol
and missives?  Furthermore is this how Hary & Brandon want their store
represented?

Lastly, knowledge of a person does not necessarily allow one to represent a
person.  Especially in the negative as haK has done.

>
>-vlad-

Your honor, I rest my case,
John

"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

Highlights:

Macadio and Micron's tag team set, with all the sfr people in front of the
decks going crazy! Ooooh the vibe was thick thick thick during their set!
That was the best part of the night!

Meeting sfr people that I haven't met yet...

Hearing that Goldie with KRS One track in the rilly stuffy room! I liked
that!

The fact that it was at Home Base and I have NEVER been there! I finnally saw
what all the fuss was about!

I have to agree with whoever said that the vibe was spotty throughout the
night. The chill room was hardly a comfy place to chill, more like a sauna to
me!

Overall, I had a pretty good time....I hope that everyone else who went did
too...

Till then...
Spread some v!be...
Keep it al!ve...

>
>And the circles.... I'm not completely down on circles... I love to 
watch
>people dance... probably *more* than the next person... but I just 
think it
>really sucks to have circles that take up most of a room, where 40 guys
>wearing versions of the same outfit are watching one person at a time
>dance... i guess to me, dancing just isn't a spectator sport ... 
especially
>when they start the circle by walking in a widening spiral with >street
>attitude, pushing people away and then turning their back on you, now 
>that
>they've seized the territory where you were dancing just moments 
>before.
>Ever notice these guys aren't smiling?  That's because, underneath, I 
>don't
>think it's about having fun to them.   It's about territory and 
>staking a
>claim, and excluding people outside your group, and that's against >the
>fundamental spirit of raving to me.
>

hmmm... i have to disagree here.....
i am one of those people that stand around the circle and watch guys 
show off their moves and I even participate once in a while ;)
BUT.....i dont think everyone in the circle especially myself are all 
about territory and staking a claim...
I agree some guys are, but they usually aren't ravers......
if the circle gets too crowded..... i go next next to the speakers where 
veryone is hugging and dancing and sweating and jumping up and down..
i guess what im trying to say is.. please dont generalize that the break 
circles do more harm than good... cause it makes me feel bad...
ok..thats all....im not one to flame much..

                CHECK OUT  www.partnercomm.com/~raveinfo/ 	


                  The RAVEDATA project needs your help!
 

 Some of you have seen our messages on the list, some can tell you how
they like using our "North American Rave Promoter Index" also known as the
"fonebook" to get connected, and still others might say how they have
enjoyed trading mixtapes and flyers with us...

 That's just the beginning!  We're making a last attempt to compile
some missing data that we would like to add before our site goes "live"
on February 1, 1998.  We're just about ready to present the result: the
world's largest rave-oriented database -- tracking all KINDS of
information,worldwide!  Why?  

	1 - To bring more talent and energy together (unity)
	2 - To recognize those in the scene who have done so much
             (respect)
	3 - To factually "set the record straight" after a lot of bad 
             news media (peace)
	4 - To bring alive those memories of our favorite events gone-by
             and our friends who were there to share them with us (love)


If that's RAVE D-A-T-A, What's this RAVE I-N-F-O stuff??
--------------------------------------------------------
 Raveinfo is what we call our attempt to ask YOU for those missing
bits and pieces of information we've missed along the way.  We can't do it 
alone... So, check out the site and e-mail us with *ANY* info you may
have!!  We've recently re-organized some things to make it even easier to
get around.

Think of this as RAVE trivial pursuit!!  Test your rave knowledge.  Many
of you have helped us before and we need you again!  This is our LAST
chance to add new information and we would like to make it as thorough as
possible to make it easier and better for you guys and gals! We have lists 
of dj's without cities, events without attendance, cost, city, promoter's
without phone numbers, phone numbers without promoters...and most of all
we have LOTS of dj's without birthdays (MM/DD/YY)!!  

Thanks!!

Love and Lollipops-
  Matt & Nicole
  (Cyphonix & Angel)


------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The RAVEDATA Project                               ravedata@partnercomm.com   
                                 flyer trades:  www.partnercomm.com/~flyers
                               mixtape trades:  www.partnercomm.com/~tapes

yeah... yeah... another review:

just want to add a little to all that's already been said...

maybe i'm being nit-picky... BUT --->

-KEEP OUR RAVES CLEAN-
as a graphic designer, i DO understand the need for really snazzy looking
flyers to advertise all of the exciting upcoming events... but do we need
hand millions out to everyone 5 times over?  what a pain it must have been
for all the people who had to clean up after that mess!  and what a waste
of paper- those poor trees!  wouldn't it work better in all aspects to
leave these flyers in piles by the door? ...grab em' on the way out- IF we
choose to?
OK- so it wouldn't make the floors completely litter free... but it would
help.  it just amazes me- i thought that everyone there, is there to dance
and have fun at 'our' party- why doesn't anyone respect the place and use
the garbage cans? (they weren't even full!)
the floors were disgusting and dangerous to dance, sit, and even walk on
due to the flyers, water bottles, bottle caps, cigarette butts, gum...
blah, blah, blah...
doesn't anyone else notice or care? 
*
-X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses,
K,-
enough already! 
5am and still dealing!  i can't imagine why anyone would need any more mind
altering substances at that hour... but then again as said in every other
post-- no logic w/ dealers... it just got really annoying, scary, and
pathetic...  p-leeeeease be careful!
*
-VIBE?-
what vibe? not much there at first... admitting it got better towards then
end... (think it was due to the incredible music- thanks!!!) a definite mix
of people- nice to see all shapes, colors, sizes, styles... although i
prefer one kind of attitude- don't we go to parties to have... fun?
at least i found PLUR on all the walls!  all was good!  
nice decor! not left unappreciated!  :)
*
-MU-SICK!-
the line up was amazing! i have to admit i had a hard time figuring out
which room was which- don't know what most of the dj's look like and the
style changes from dj ~> dj  (didn't always match up w/ room names...) but
i'm not complaining! great mix! at one point, i went from room to room...
couldn't decide where to settle- ALL AMAZING! 
wish i could have met some more sfravers... (missed e-mails verifying
meeting spot) 
... always next party! :)
-DJ's-
great to finally hear a lot of you spin! 
VERY IMPRESSIVE!
keep up the great music~~> completely changed the vibe!

megan

> > > This is why it's important to WAIT until your brain has FULLY
> > recovered
> > > from the last time you took E. What is "Fully recovered"?
> > Personally, my
> > > rule of thumb is to wait about 6 months between each hit. This
way,
> > > every time you take it, it feels like the first time you took it. 
> 
> Yeah, it's sound advice that even the guy who recommended it isn't
> following... doh...
> 
> Hi Blake...
> 


yeah, um, well, i know where he's coming from.  sometimes you just
gotta remind yourself why it's better to wait.  and a two-week break
is better than two days, i always say.  but the killer highs you get
after a nice long break from _whatever_ is always worth the wait, imho.

things you can do while you're waiting: ghb, 2cb (still lookin!),
royal jelly, thc, ketamine, ephedrine, complete absolute 100% sobriety
(takes about a month for that amazing drug-free high to kick in,
unfortunately, but it's SO cool when it does), more thc, lsd, shrooms,
peyote, fasting, caffine, cocaine (well if someone offers anyways),
adrinelin, n2o, orange/banana/spirulina smoothies, alcohol, opium,
ammyl nitrate, valium, vicodin, maybe a little more thc...  not all at
once, of course...

things i personally can't recommend doing while you're waitng: 
heroin, crystal meth, crack, robotussin...

what i'm tryin to say here is, i sorta feel like taking a wide variety
of drugs one (or maybe two) at a time, in some sort of moderation,
with a chill-out period thrown in every once in a while, is sooo much
healthier than taking any one of them over and over and over again. 
not that there aren't bad sides to taking drugs period, but lets face
it, pretty much everyone does anyway (alcohol is a drug, caffine is a
drug).  when you start doing any one of them on a regular basis you
become much more likely to get addicted, which leads you to take more
and more and feel less and less with greater frequency as time goes
by, often resulting in lost friends, lost jobs, lost s.o.'s, and
occasionally some subtle (or not-so-subtle) irreparable brain damage. 
this is bad.  so anyway, that's my
old-guy-who-still-gets-high-and-also-has-a-life advice (since you
wouldn't listen to me if i told you all to just say no, not that i
would anyway ;)  variety is the spice of life, i always say.  

-messiah wannabe

Awwwwww yeah,

Went visiting to south lake again this past weekend and I must say.

1. Heavenly has the best view I have seen but the boarding was fer shit.
   Too many people (lots of accidents and injuries) for  not even half the
   mountain being open oh well, I was meeting friends.

2. Kirkwood is the bomb.  I am not sure if its the angle or what but there   
   was still some fresh powder to be found just off the beaten track 3 days
   since the last snow.  Lots of friendly people out there.  Also ran into 
   chris and randy very kool, They hadn't slept since bigfloor the night
   before I felt their pain =)

All and all I had a great weekend but Kirkwood is great and really close.

hope to see all of you up on the slopes sooner or later

--Herb

Messiah's post got me thinking about what stuff I've found myself 
enjoying during periods of sobriety (mostly due to the fact that I drive 
myself to almost everything I go to down here).  So here are some of 
Uncle Noah's reccomendation of things to entertain yourself with while 
raving sober:

-smoothies.  yes.  I read this one and thought of many a happy night 
listening to the big beats and sipping a yummy beverage.  I think fruit 
drinks in general are good, not just smoothies. :)

-Gummi Life Savers and naturally sparkling water.  Fun sober, **VERY** 
fun on E...

-Those irritating puzzles where you have to like remove a ring from a 
string that's tied to a block of wood.  These give you something to do 
with your hands and brain and are quite fun.  Someday you figure them 
out, but then you just go buy another one.

-Mr. Potatohead.  'nuff said.

-Vibrating Mr. Potatohead.  fun for releaving those sore muscles after 
dancing for four or five hours, and really fun to put on your friends who 
are not presently abstaining.

:)

i have a few suggestions for those of you who find it hard to make a fun
night of sobriety.

-- power bars. with lots of water. they have tons of carbos, and they can
dehydrate you. but, you'll have no problem dancing your booty off. or, as
i used to, dart across a pool back and forth a few times :)

-- pacifiers. candyraver i am not, but i am also not a big fan of
cavities. i really love gum, but if i don't have sugarless gum i'd rather
suck on my pacy, which doesn't give my mouth a sticky feel OR my teeth a
sugar coating. i swear to god.

-- invest in a blank book. i did a year ago and some people have written
some incredibly rad things in it. it's fun to sit down and read it
sometimes if i'm getting a bit tired. some of the poetry in it can inspire
me to jump right back up and start groovin again.

-- take a nap. swear to god again! get a friend to wake you up, you'll
feel revived. missing a couple hours at a party won't kill you.

-- slap on a smile. people will smile right back. 

-- strike up a conversation.

-- dance your god damn ass off! then pass out in front of a speaker for
the rest of the night (ahh a whole half hour of dancing!) ;)

-- start talking and thinking in rhymes... i.e.
..."those wicked phat beats just make me think
I wonder if it's ME that stinks."
(or)
"hey boy
be my toy!"
(JUST AN EXAMPLE OK? i can't rhyme creatively on demand)
ok ok i'll stop, i'm beginning to pull things outta my ass.
anyway, hope that helped.
xo

Hiya gang,

been busy so I haven't had a chance to get in the fray lately...

Recommendation:

I just bought Pete Tong's Essential Selection (from his Radio 1 show) and it's
completely solid.

In fact, I love it.

Great selection of house, some speed garage, and the programming is tight. 

It's an import so it'll set you back 30 bucks, but it's a two CD set, so it'd
be like buying two domestic CDs.

Maybe I should give a disclaimer to this as well: I was in england for a month
back in '93 and Pete's radio show on Friday nights was one of the best things
I ran into there (bsides the clubbing, of course). Taped the shows and still
have them. (Memories all alone in the moonlight... >>>> first time I heard
Sabres of Paradise's SmokeBelch II, one of my favorite all time tracks.....)

Secondly, I'll be sending a detailed review of the Metalheadz II album. Gotta
listen to it during the day today at work, first though...

Everybody, have a great day!


rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

I did a while back but it was really kind of weird.  I usually cant
sleep at all, but at this one rave I was a dancin' and a groovin' and
then I got the feeling that I was overexerting myself because it was
soooo hot inside so I went outside to cool off, but then I started
peeking and it was too cold outside and I was cooling off waay too fast
so I found a spot inside but near the door and sat down to cool off.
While sitting there I noticed that if I closed my eyes for longer than
it takes to just blink I would instantly go into REM sleep and it was
like I would pop up inside a dream that was already in progress.  I
would do this for about 10 seconds at a time and it was pretty neat
actually because I was sitting there for about 20 minutes and when I got
back up to go dance I felt like I had just woken up from a good nights
sleep, which is something I almost never feel.  Then I danced my butt
off till they stopped playing music.

-Chris-

Hello everyone, I'd just like to add a couple more things to Mr. Noah's 
list of "what to do while partying sober", well actually it would be 
*my* little list of fun things to do while partying sober and taking 
advantage Of Noah's creative idea that I couldn't think of by myself.. 
:)

Whatever...

1)any food whatsoever, it makes me feel "happy"
2)if I go to a party by myself and I can't find any friends, I make sure 
that I bring my little ivy plant, it makes me feel not alone and he 
always listens when I have to talk.
3)Candy/gum/cigarretes for all those who are feeling left out and have a 
"notsohappy" happy face on, plus it makes you feel good. (Cigarettes are 
a false happiness though)
4)$ for water, for other people who need it more than yourself (if you 
are sure it is for water)
5)My lips are nice to bring for pecking my secure friends on the cheeck, 
or somethin' :P
6) Mad Libs are great.  Especially on the way home,  Nobody wants to 
play except for those people who are still going on whatever energy that 
their body can find (hi Jeremy! :P) Plus you can think about gross, 
nasty things without feeling guilty...  "I need a verb"
I always have to reply with "wait, what's a verb?"  So I'm usually not 
the best person to play with.
7) last, but not least, there is always my Slinky.  You can let people 
put in in their teeth and drop it on the floor for that "trippy" effect.  
You can also throw it at people who sell aspirin to your friends as 'e'  
and if anyone causes you any shit, you can strangle them and go to jail 
and meet new, and improved boyfriends...EEEWWWW!
And you can also set a slinky on a friends head who is screwed up on 
something and really confuse them...

Sorry, boredom is evil and so is evil and so are the "freaks" that were 
just on the Jenny Jones Show...

Peace,
Danny

Uncle Noah thought of this...

>Messiah's post got me thinking about what stuff I've found myself 
>enjoying during periods of sobriety (mostly due to the fact that I 
drive 
>myself to almost everything I go to down here).  So here are some of 
>Uncle Noah's reccomendation of things to entertain yourself with while 
>raving sober:
>
>-smoothies.  yes.  I read this one and thought of many a happy night 
>listening to the big beats and sipping a yummy beverage.  I think fruit 
>drinks in general are good, not just smoothies. :)
>
>-Gummi Life Savers and naturally sparkling water.  Fun sober, **VERY** 
>fun on E...
>
>-Those irritating puzzles where you have to like remove a ring from a 
>string that's tied to a block of wood.  These give you something to do 
>with your hands and brain and are quite fun.  Someday you figure them 
>out, but then you just go buy another one.
>
>-Mr. Potatohead.  'nuff said.
>
>-Vibrating Mr. Potatohead.  fun for releaving those sore muscles after 
>dancing for four or five hours, and really fun to put on your friends 
who 
>are not presently abstaining.
>
>:)
>
>

over the same thing. The debate now seems to be on  age, age limits and the
proper ages to do various things.

get different
>opinions and perspectives on different things. " Well, that's what you are
getting =)

interesting
to someone else.

I like Sober Raving =) *grin* but I don't think that is what we are talking
about any more....

I LIKE this list a lot :) I like how people have a lot to say about most
every topic and I think it's pretty interesting.

Well, I got to the party at like 11:30 or so and it was pouring down rain and
that sucked. There were so many people dancing. When DAN and DONALD GLAUDE
went on the party went off!!!!! They were so fucking tight. I haven't seen a
better set in a long time. Even my boyfriend, who usually doesn't really care
for the music said it was really good! The rave was soooo incredibaly HOT!!
Iwas dripping sweat from dancing so much!! I really had a good time. It was
kinda like an old-skool party!!! HOPe all of you had as much fun as I did!!

    I, for one, Don't see anything wrong with Break Circles.  They may take
up room, but when you average it out, the large amount of room taken up by
the dancer + the small amount of room taken up by the cramped up crowd of
spectators = the same a mount of room if they were all (spectators & dancer)
were dancing separately.  And In addition... It's their Way of Expressing
themselves.   And really no different than other peoples unique form of
personal expression.
    I'm always happy to see Break Circles at one of my parties, as much as I
am to see a Coddle Puddle of Candy Ravers crowded on a bunch of backpacks,
camped out in the middle of the dance floor... Or a Trainspotting entourage
congregate in front of the DJ... or anything else that's adds its own
diversity to the mixed up flavor of an underground party.  It's this
diversity of people that gives raving its unique appeal.

Keep it Real.... Vlad

Break Dancer wrote:

> >
> >And the circles.... I'm not completely down on circles... I love to
> watch
> >people dance... probably *more* than the next person... but I just
> think it
> >really sucks to have circles that take up most of a room, where 40 guys
> >wearing versions of the same outfit are watching one person at a time
> >dance... i guess to me, dancing just isn't a spectator sport ...
> especially
> >when they start the circle by walking in a widening spiral with >street
> >attitude, pushing people away and then turning their back on you, now
> >that
> >they've seized the territory where you were dancing just moments
> >before.
> >Ever notice these guys aren't smiling?  That's because, underneath, I
> >don't
> >think it's about having fun to them.   It's about territory and
> >staking a
> >claim, and excluding people outside your group, and that's against >the
> >fundamental spirit of raving to me.
> >
>
> hmmm... i have to disagree here.....
> i am one of those people that stand around the circle and watch guys
> show off their moves and I even participate once in a while ;)
> BUT.....i dont think everyone in the circle especially myself are all
> about territory and staking a claim...
> I agree some guys are, but they usually aren't ravers......
> if the circle gets too crowded..... i go next next to the speakers where
> veryone is hugging and dancing and sweating and jumping up and down..
> i guess what im trying to say is.. please dont generalize that the break
> circles do more harm than good... cause it makes me feel bad...
> ok..thats all....im not one to flame much..
> peace
> Philip
> disordr

Megan Hug wrote:

> -KEEP OUR RAVES CLEAN-
> as a graphic designer, i DO understand the need for really snazzy looking
> flyers to advertise all of the exciting upcoming events... but do we need
> hand millions out to everyone 5 times over?  what a pain it must have been
> for all the people who had to clean up after that mess!  and what a waste
> of paper- those poor trees!  wouldn't it work better in all aspects to
> leave these flyers in piles by the door? ...grab em' on the way out- IF we
> choose to?

I totally Agree with you about the mess.  You guys should have seen the amount
of trash after the party... its astonishing!   As far as promotion is
concerned, I have always been a very liberal about letting promoters promote
any way they want at a party.  But its usually not the promoters that are at
fault in this situation.  The problem is with the Dope Dealers.  They will go
up to a promoter an ask if they can hand out flyers for them at the party, and
most promoters are way to eager to give them a fat stack of flyers.  This
allows the Dealer to have a means of approaching people and asking them if they
want to buy *&^% while giving them a flyer.  This is why so many flyers get
thrown on the ground, and why you are handed one at every doorway, and it seems
like there are 20 people promoting the same party.    If you keep your eyes
open, you will notice that there are rarely as many FGE flyers on the ground as
other flyers.. Why.. its simple.  Firstly.. we promote hand to hand.. not stack
by stack, and I ask all our promoters to pick up our flyers of the ground if
they see them and either recycle the ones they can or throw them into a garbage
can.  I feel that it does not compliment a party if everyone walks all over
your flyers as if they were garbage... it says little about the event.  Also we
have too much pride in our parties to let our flyers get stepped all over.  And
lastly, We do not allow drug dealers to pass out our flyers.  If anyone has
ever been offered one of our flyers with drugs, then they are not an official
FGE promoter, and If they are, I would appreciate it if anyone could e-mail me
privately and tell me so we can stop using that person as a promoter, because
we do not feel that it is a proper association, nor is it the image that we
want someone to pick up as a first impression when receiving one of our flyers.

> OK- so it wouldn't make the floors completely litter free... but it would
> help.  it just amazes me- i thought that everyone there, is there to dance
> and have fun at 'our' party- why doesn't anyone respect the place and use
> the garbage cans? (they weren't even full!)
> the floors were disgusting and dangerous to dance, sit, and even walk on
> due to the flyers, water bottles, bottle caps, cigarette butts, gum...
> blah, blah, blah...
> doesn't anyone else notice or care?

You would be surprised who really cares...  :)

> -X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses,
> K,-
> enough already!
> 5am and still dealing!  i can't imagine why anyone would need any more mind
> altering substances at that hour... but then again as said in every other
> post-- no logic w/ dealers... it just got really annoying, scary, and
> pathetic...  p-leeeeease be careful!

It's called Market Share...  And yes it is pathetic, but to some people.. it's
their life... as well as a life style.   I don't know as many drug dealer as i
used to, and If I do then they are keeping it well hidden from me, so I'm at a
loss as to why there are so many of them mow days.  I was not particularly
happy with the amount of dealers at this last party.  Normally, we throw them
out, but we figured that this was a more underground party for us, and we would
let it ride out, but judging from peoples replies, we made a bad call on not
booting most of them out the front door.    FGE version of the Karma Patrol is
The P6 : Proactive Parasite Prevention and Pacification Patrol Program.  6
guards that do nothing but walk around kicking out drug dealers.  I did not
have them at Spirit, cause I did not think that there would be as big of a
problem with this at an underground party that was barley promoted, but I was
mistaken, cause there were even more drug dealers at our underground then we
have at our massives... HMMM.. Go Figure???  Next time I am not making that
mistake again.  Our P6 Unit, threw out 65 drug dealers at Megga Buzz Mania, and
there were 6000 people there.  I think that record could have been broken if I
had them at Spirit, which only had 1500 people.   I think that most of the
people on this list know my position when it comes to drugs and the lowlife
scum that sell them.

> -VIBE?-
> what vibe? not much there at first... admitting it got better towards then
> end... (think it was due to the incredible music- thanks!!!) a definite mix
> of people- nice to see all shapes, colors, sizes, styles... although i
> prefer one kind of attitude- don't we go to parties to have... fun?
> at least i found PLUR on all the walls!  all was good!
> nice decor! not left unappreciated!  :)

    The vibe was a bit on and off, but i would say more on then off depending
on were you were, and your attitude.  I would give it an overall 9/10 on the
vibe scale...  But this was by far the most fun i have ever had at one of my
own parties... It Rocked, and I saw nothing but SMILES all night long.  I think
it was just too cold outside that took away from the vibe.

> -MU-SICK!-
> the line up was amazing! i have to admit i had a hard time figuring out
> which room was which- don't know what most of the dj's look like and the
> style changes from dj ~> dj  (didn't always match up w/ room names...) but
> i'm not complaining! great mix! at one point, i went from room to room...
> couldn't decide where to settle- ALL AMAZING!

I couldn't agree with you more on this .. The music was off the hook!!!!

Glad you enjoyed it...  Keep it Real... Vlad

Ray Vonie writes...
> 
>     I, for one, Don't see anything wrong with Break Circles.  They may take
> up room, but when you average it out, the large amount of room taken up by
> the dancer + the small amount of room taken up by the cramped up crowd of
> spectators = the same a mount of room if they were all (spectators & dancer)
> were dancing separately.  And In addition... It's their Way of Expressing
> themselves.   And really no different than other peoples unique form of
> personal expression.
>     I'm always happy to see Break Circles at one of my parties, as much as I
> am to see a Coddle Puddle of Candy Ravers crowded on a bunch of backpacks,
> camped out in the middle of the dance floor... Or a Trainspotting entourage
> congregate in front of the DJ... or anything else that's adds its own
> diversity to the mixed up flavor of an underground party.  It's this
> diversity of people that gives raving its unique appeal.

You know what I hate?  I hate finding a nice spot by the speaker, getting
a nice groove on, and then being forced to move by somebody trying a
start a circle or by a circle that is getting larger.  And then repeating
this process throughout the night.  It is totally disrespectful.

You know what I also hate?  Trying to find a decent place to dance when
the dance floor is littered with backpacks and sitting bodies.  People
can get hurt!

I thought dancing all night with a large group of people to killer music
was what gave raving its unique appeal.  A dance floor is for dancing,
not sitting, showing off or spectating.

Received: from [38.248.198.55] ([38.248.198.55] (may be forged)) by netcommunications.net (10.1/8.7.3) with ESMTP id NAA12774 for <sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org>; Tue, 2 Dec 1997 13:53:58 -0800 (PST)

Mime-Version: 1.0

From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Re: Another Spirit Review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Vlad said...

>    I, for one, Don't see anything wrong with Break Circles.  They may take
>up room, but when you average it out, the large amount of room taken up by
>the dancer + the small amount of room taken up by the cramped up crowd of
>spectators = the same a mount of room if they were all (spectators & dancer)
>were dancing separately.  And In addition... It's their Way of Expressing
>themselves.   And really no different than other peoples unique form of
>personal expression.


again, I want to make it clear that I'm not *completely* down on circles...
I really like the fact that in a circle, people are watching each other, so
it not only lets people show their moves, but the attention of others also
inspires them to dance full-power, all-out for bursts at a time...  and
anything that makes you dance harder and better is a great thing... for the
person who is dancing.

But there was a point on Friday where in a room with about 200 people in
it, when you factored out the 10 trainspotters, and the 25 boys with
attitude hugging the wall, staring at the 25 people who were walking
through, then you were left with about 89 people standing in a huge circle,
watching *1* person dance.

Maybe it takes up the same amount of room, but it isn't the same... first,
only one person is dancing, and i'm sorry, but watching someone else dance
is *not* a form of personal expression, it's being a spectator.  second, a
circle is not a fluid thing... you can walk (or dance) through a crowded
dance floor (patiently and slowly of course) ... but you cannot cut through
a circle (i was virtually trapped for a chunk of time last week because i
couldn't cut through the wall of people's backs facing the center of a
circle, and had to wait 10 mins or so until it broke up before I could
leave the room)...

all i ask is that people who dance in these kinds of circles .... which are
different than smaller circles that form spontaneously and morph in and out
of existence... realize that rather than a vibe-maker, it can be a
vibe-killer... and that if you're watchin', you're not dancing, and if your
back is to the rest of the party, then you're missing a lot.

of course... i have a feeling that many of the dancers (or maybe i should
say watchers) in these big circles aren't on sfraves, because they're not
really ravers...  and maybe a lot of them just need to experience the true
power of a room of hundreds or thousands of people, all dancing at the same
time to the same beat, with the same vibe, and the same smile.... because
*that* is the power of the beat!!!

*and* lest we ever forget this one... i want to point out my most favorite
circle ever, which was last year at a feelgood party, was when lara and her
whole crew made a crazy super-raver circle outside at home base (lots of
space, lots of air), and i stood at the rail enjoying their moves for a
good long time!

love, leslie

> Megan Hug wrote:
> 
> > -KEEP OUR RAVES CLEAN-

I don't know how many times somebody came up to us at spirit and
went into a long schpiel about how great Bigfloor was going to be and
tried to get us to take a flier.  I got one weeks ago on Haight, looked
at another at Nikita, and at Phunkatek.  Anyone who was at spirit who
DIDN'T know about Bigfloor before showing up learned about it within
10 seconds of arrival.  Not to pick on Bigfloor or its promoters, but
this is symptomatic of most promotions that go on.  Leave your flier
by the door.  I will go through the stacks there and pick up the ones
that interest me.  Plus, if someone hands you a flier that you already
have, or don't want, etc, DON'T TAKE IT!!! So many people who are 
handing the things out have a veritable sea of the same flier about
their feet -- which, as has been pointed out, dosen't make the event
look good at all, plus the glossy ones are slippery!


> > -X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K,-
> > enough already!
> > 5am and still dealing!

I (I mean . . . my friend) have had good and bad luck purchasing "party
favors" at raves/clubs/on the street (fortunately none of the bad luck
has been TOO bad), but the best course is to deal with people you know
and trust.  Most of the time, though, people who have real problems
simply take too much, or too many combinations, or don't drink enough
water, etc.  Be extremely careful, puhleeeeeze!

And Vlad wrote:

I, for one, Don't see anything wrong with Break Circles.  They may take
up room, but when you average it out, the large amount of room taken up
by
the dancer + the small amount of room taken up by the cramped up crowd
of
spectators = the same a mount of room if they were all (spectators &
dancer)
were dancing separately.  And In addition... It's their Way of
Expressing
themselves.   And really no different than other peoples unique form of
personal expression.

My only problem with break circles is, like at spirit, I was grooving
one of the rooms to the trippy visuals on the screen instead of the
people inside the circle.  But then the trippy visuals disappeared, and
they showed the circle on the screen!  What a buzzkill!  Watching other
people dance inside a circle dosen't interest me, so I don't watch, but
on the screen?  Sorry.  Not my cup of darjeeling.

Just my 1/50th of a dollar.

Steve.

Eschew obfuscation.

-- 
And now, a shameless plug for my workplace!
Before you buy:
http://www.compare.net/
Information is Power

In a message dated 97-12-02 02:20:42 EST, you write:

<< I was pretty pissed that it ended at 4am...take about a gip for your
 money.  Eat Static did rock the house, and so did Micheal Dog.  Barry
 Weaver also played some nice tecno.  The DJ after Eat Static was horrible,
 IMHO.  If you are going to charge $20 for a party it had better go until
 6am at least!!
 
 drenalin >>


Any event at the Maritime Hall WILL only go until 4 am, because that is the
latest latest time that place can have a party until...I discovered this over
the summer when I went to a couple of parties there, (Transcend, Power
Crystal, etc...none of which were any special parties or anything...) when I
payed $20 and expected the party to go all nite...to my disappointment, they
would kick us all out at the early hour of 4 am. Then, when people wanted to
linger outside for a little while to talk about afterparties or anything, the
staff would yell at us to leave >=\

So people,when there is any party at Maritime Hall, it will end at 4 am, if
not earlier! Remember this when you fork your money in! ;*)~

-=~*LaUrE@*~=-

        The only reason that promoters get away with lying to you about their
parties is because they always get away with it.  If you all want this Bull Shit
to end, then YOU need to start to police your own Scene.  Many promoters have
very little integrity or self respect, and play the odds that people will either
forgive and forget, OR that the average 6 month turnaround in the scene will work
in their favor, cause after a year no one will be around to remember, and the new
people won't care.   Some promoters believe that because this is an underground
scene, then lying is accepted.  And many will say or do whatever it takes to get
the people to the parties.   These type of promoters <names suppressed> really
sicken me, cause they have no self respect and are only out for your money.   But
hay, this is the underground... If there were any sort of guarantees, then it
wouldn't be underground :)

Keep it Real... Vlad
