Megan Hug wrote:

> -KEEP OUR RAVES CLEAN-
> as a graphic designer, i DO understand the need for really snazzy looking
> flyers to advertise all of the exciting upcoming events... but do we need
> hand millions out to everyone 5 times over?  what a pain it must have been
> for all the people who had to clean up after that mess!  and what a waste
> of paper- those poor trees!  wouldn't it work better in all aspects to
> leave these flyers in piles by the door? ...grab em' on the way out- IF we
> choose to?

I totally Agree with you about the mess.  You guys should have seen the amount
of trash after the party... its astonishing!   As far as promotion is
concerned, I have always been a very liberal about letting promoters promote
any way they want at a party.  But its usually not the promoters that are at
fault in this situation.  The problem is with the Dope Dealers.  They will go
up to a promoter an ask if they can hand out flyers for them at the party, and
most promoters are way to eager to give them a fat stack of flyers.  This
allows the Dealer to have a means of approaching people and asking them if they
want to buy *&^% while giving them a flyer.  This is why so many flyers get
thrown on the ground, and why you are handed one at every doorway, and it seems
like there are 20 people promoting the same party.    If you keep your eyes
open, you will notice that there are rarely as many FGE flyers on the ground as
other flyers.. Why.. its simple.  Firstly.. we promote hand to hand.. not stack
by stack, and I ask all our promoters to pick up our flyers of the ground if
they see them and either recycle the ones they can or throw them into a garbage
can.  I feel that it does not compliment a party if everyone walks all over
your flyers as if they were garbage... it says little about the event.  Also we
have too much pride in our parties to let our flyers get stepped all over.  And
lastly, We do not allow drug dealers to pass out our flyers.  If anyone has
ever been offered one of our flyers with drugs, then they are not an official
FGE promoter, and If they are, I would appreciate it if anyone could e-mail me
privately and tell me so we can stop using that person as a promoter, because
we do not feel that it is a proper association, nor is it the image that we
want someone to pick up as a first impression when receiving one of our flyers.

> OK- so it wouldn't make the floors completely litter free... but it would
> help.  it just amazes me- i thought that everyone there, is there to dance
> and have fun at 'our' party- why doesn't anyone respect the place and use
> the garbage cans? (they weren't even full!)
> the floors were disgusting and dangerous to dance, sit, and even walk on
> due to the flyers, water bottles, bottle caps, cigarette butts, gum...
> blah, blah, blah...
> doesn't anyone else notice or care?

You would be surprised who really cares...  :)

> -X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses, K, X, doses,
> K,-
> enough already!
> 5am and still dealing!  i can't imagine why anyone would need any more mind
> altering substances at that hour... but then again as said in every other
> post-- no logic w/ dealers... it just got really annoying, scary, and
> pathetic...  p-leeeeease be careful!

It's called Market Share...  And yes it is pathetic, but to some people.. it's
their life... as well as a life style.   I don't know as many drug dealer as i
used to, and If I do then they are keeping it well hidden from me, so I'm at a
loss as to why there are so many of them mow days.  I was not particularly
happy with the amount of dealers at this last party.  Normally, we throw them
out, but we figured that this was a more underground party for us, and we would
let it ride out, but judging from peoples replies, we made a bad call on not
booting most of them out the front door.    FGE version of the Karma Patrol is
The P6 : Proactive Parasite Prevention and Pacification Patrol Program.  6
guards that do nothing but walk around kicking out drug dealers.  I did not
have them at Spirit, cause I did not think that there would be as big of a
problem with this at an underground party that was barley promoted, but I was
mistaken, cause there were even more drug dealers at our underground then we
have at our massives... HMMM.. Go Figure???  Next time I am not making that
mistake again.  Our P6 Unit, threw out 65 drug dealers at Megga Buzz Mania, and
there were 6000 people there.  I think that record could have been broken if I
had them at Spirit, which only had 1500 people.   I think that most of the
people on this list know my position when it comes to drugs and the lowlife
scum that sell them.

> -VIBE?-
> what vibe? not much there at first... admitting it got better towards then
> end... (think it was due to the incredible music- thanks!!!) a definite mix
> of people- nice to see all shapes, colors, sizes, styles... although i
> prefer one kind of attitude- don't we go to parties to have... fun?
> at least i found PLUR on all the walls!  all was good!
> nice decor! not left unappreciated!  :)

    The vibe was a bit on and off, but i would say more on then off depending
on were you were, and your attitude.  I would give it an overall 9/10 on the
vibe scale...  But this was by far the most fun i have ever had at one of my
own parties... It Rocked, and I saw nothing but SMILES all night long.  I think
it was just too cold outside that took away from the vibe.

> -MU-SICK!-
> the line up was amazing! i have to admit i had a hard time figuring out
> which room was which- don't know what most of the dj's look like and the
> style changes from dj ~> dj  (didn't always match up w/ room names...) but
> i'm not complaining! great mix! at one point, i went from room to room...
> couldn't decide where to settle- ALL AMAZING!

I couldn't agree with you more on this .. The music was off the hook!!!!

Glad you enjoyed it...  Keep it Real... Vlad

Someone over on the Analogue Heaven mailing list just posted this...

This is EXACTLY the kind of thing *I'd* like to be involved in....
I'm hoping that this 'glad hand' thing (WHEN is the next one, anyways)
is at least a little like this...

!!!

---------- Forwarded message ----------
analogue          Tuesday, December 2 1997          Volume 01 : Number 2181


Subject: Portland live elektronix/dj'ing


In defend our backwards (but progressing) city:  For the past two months,
I have been involved in organizing an electronic music weekly show (Thurs
9pm-2am) at the Jasmine Tree Lounge downtown in Portland.  The restuarant
owners are in no way against electronic instrumentation (they are somewhat
clueless-- as long as some people buy a few drinks).  Attendance has been
relatively HIGH (40-60 people peak) so this is a great opportunity for
local electronic music performers to play in the area.  Handmade (screen
printed, non-square, color) flyers are made weekly and the format is
loosely/ideally three acts a night:


1 'experimental' dj (lounge, non-electronic, any history of electronic
(pop, academic, experimental) ...incorporation of other synths/beatboxes
is encouraged and anything brought to dj'ing that is not found at raves
(scratching or dumb costumes) 

&

1 'expermental' performer (non-rhythmic and/or textural electronic music
performance) (ie. theremin, fx-based noise, modular madness,
ring-modulated violin would fit this) 

& 

1 'rhythm-based' electronic music performer (this is not exclusively
dance-music related, ie. syncopated or pattern-based electronics fits
here as well as sequencer-based modular work)

Also, we bring DAT and tape decks and have an open "local programmers play
their tracks" hour in which you can bring tracks (less than ten minutes
total) and play them for people.  but we try to make you sit on stage...

End of analogue V1 #2181
************************

-jimg


--skoop@slackers.net
--http://www.slackers.net/~skoop

We're just going off senselessly...

I equate Thad's post to the Honeymooner's "well I otta" line.  Yes, it
said what you think it said, but I don't think he meant it quite the way
everybody is interpreting it, which is very literally.

It IS frustrating when you are interested in something that people seem to
attack for a long time, and then suddenly accept and ultimately
participate in, and I know Thad is a mellow cat, a good person, and very
much in a long term loving relationship with music, people and the scene.

I'd think it better if we all sorta blew it off.  The whole "how dare he
say something like that, especially about Solar" feel of this thread makes
me wonder how differently we would have treated the issue if it was
somebody else talking about somebody else...

This thread has been too much about who knows who and credentials, and not
addressing the basic issue, which I believe is Thad could have said that
in person and had everybody in the room understand that he feels a little
slighted, and is just blowing off a little steam and making light of the
whole thing by going off... but this is E mail, where everything is
admissible as evidence, before the court of SFRaves. 

Peace,
AndyW

> anger.  has Hak even tried to defend his position, or are we just going off
> on him ceaselessly?

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Dec 03 02:31:05 1997

From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-Sender: andy@atari
Reply-To: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
To: Seth <sutekh@belief-systems.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Inhabit the Machines Review
In-Reply-To: <v04002701b0aa374aff01@[207.214.209.72]>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.96.971202164032.25916M-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


First off, thanks Seth and the rest of the gang who put this together...

It was off to the Bahia for a night I knew I would regret, seeing as I had
to be at work the next day... but worth it.

When we got there, Seth was spinning some good blocky, scratchy funky
shit.  Not too minimal, not too noisy, all of it with a really good
groove. Yum. Drank Guiness. Met Catweasel (who should be on some flyers
soon if promoters know what's good, judgin gfrom his tape)& Jen (time
seems so crappy when you meet nice people and there's good music and a
dancefloor nearby, sorry to both if I seemed distant). I thought I'd heard
Sutekh before, but his set last night really struck me as very tasteful,
reminiscent of well...  Mad (most of whom showed up to check it out
anyway), which used to be a similar style of music with the same sound
system at the same location. 

John Williams came up next with a really banging, confident, housey
flowing techno sound that progressed towards the head shrinking style I so
love about him.  It may have been early evening but it was definitely a
little before half past four inside my head.  I probably enjoyed this part
of the evening most, even though John wasn't getting too brave, it's
always a pleasure to hear him. 

Well, I heard a record spin down and perked up my ears.  A tone starts
coming out of the sound system, just screaming for a beat, and stays that
way for a minute or so until people are just dying for a beat... they got
one (big and ridiculously bassy too :)... and then a second of another in
what seemed an almost obnoxious break that had nothing to do with the
first beat, and then it would go back into it.  They used a lot of very
strange breaks through out the set, and also kept referring back to themes
from earlier in their set.  By the end of their set, they started dropping
a couple of those weird stutter beats again as breaks, and had people just
screaming for more.  Very funky, very buzzy and scratchy sounding, very
experimental (some weird samples in there too, including DBX's I'm Losing
Control which I thought I'd imagined until someone else asked me if I'd
heard it)... I wasn't into all of it, but the parts that were "on" were
really...ON.  I would recommend the Toby and Neal show for anybody who
likes to be challenged with a lot of funky ass slower techno... I can't
guarantee you'll love all of it, but it was so sweet seeing different
people going off to different parts of the performance (like parts I felt
were just noise were getting this one girl to scream and fully go off
*yes!*).

Finally, Dave Tarrida closed with a very quirky set, playing some bent
stuff with lots of theremin and drone sound in it... sounds like he wasn't
mixing in tip-top form, but the records were bold, even in light of the
live act that had just left the booth... 

I didn't stay for all of his set, but I had a really great night, and the 
music was a lot more flowing and cohesive than I thought it might be
judging from the records I'd heard from the artists on vinyl.  All in all,
a pleasant surprise, and a nice weeknight journey.

The visuals started with network television (boo) and went to some really
cool, very primitive techno-looking clips of gas burners, out of focus
digital clocks, slinkys (yes Danny, they had slinkys, okay?), and all
kinds of weird closeups of everyday phenomenon from weird angles... a nice
change from the usual visual theme of "too much is just enough".

I dug the DJs all spinning very artsy, very warped stuff, and a lot of
folks that have a real passion for music in attendance.

A fun night...

Peace,
AndyW

i feel that thad had every right to express himself on sfr.  if he feels 
that a particular dj is hypocritical he should be able to say so here in 
a public venue.  there's nothing wrong with that.  it's just like people 
who write in saying that so-n-so crew says they love the scene but 
they're actually in it for the money.  people should be able to 
criticize whoever they want.

as for the whole "people have the right to change their minds (and music 
tastes)" topic, people should be open minded.  yes, everyone should be 
able to dislike a certain music at one point in time and then start 
liking it.  that is fine.  it is a different thing when people go aggro 
dissing something.  when i first started raving, lots of people would 
say that i was totally lame and only for losers and drug addicts and 
that ravers are stupid.  Now that i see some of those people raving, it 
pisses me off even more that they used to be so anti.  if they had just 
disliked raving b4 instead of talkin lotsa shit, then i wouldn't care if 
they changed their mind.

lastly, about the whole representing solid grooves thing. i think it 
really doesn't matter because people either: 1)didn't know who hak is 
and therefore wouldn't think that he is representing Solid; or 2) knew 
thad well enough to know that he works there in which case they would 
realize that the statements were thad's opinion's and not solid grooves 
new store rules.
anyways, it just seems like his statements are being made into a way 
bigger deal than they are.
laters,
-vlad-
trip008@usa.net

we need to think of some creative solution to flyer trash

maybe promoters can offer somekind of prize to the person
who comes up with the most creative solution... something
like a yearlong free pass for two. How about it promoters?

I personally love these beautiful flyers that have been created
over the years...i collect them for the art. But i do
hate to see thousands of them laying in the trash...wasted.
(dang even the flyers get wasted at these drug parties =)

Perhaps small things can make a differnce until we find a solution.
How about some psychedlic no littering signs. We could create
a litter program...we could have a mascot
like smokey the bear or the cat in the hat or perhaps an alien.

maybe we could turn the trash into some kind of art project.
Perhaps a huge ball made entirely out of flyers that was taken from party
to party and everyone could stick there unwanted flyers on it
instead of the floor.

then when it got about ten feet in diameter we could get each 
promoter to bring their balls to the beach and we could
have a "burning balls" party...sort of a spin off of burning man.

A SMILE
         A SMILE costs nothing, but it creates much.
                It enriches those who receive
            without impoverishing those who give.
                   It happens in a flash,
        and the memory of it sometimes lasts forever.
    None are so rich that they can get along without it,
      and none are so poor but are richer for a smile.
              It creates happiness in the home,
               fosters goodwill in a business,
             and is the countersign of friends.
                  It is rest to the weary,
                daylight to the discouraged,
                    sunshine to the sad,
           and nature's best antidote for trouble.
      It cannot be bought, begged, borrowed or stolen,
   for it is something that is no earthly good to anybody
                   till it is given away.
                   And if it ever happens
  that some people should be too tired to give you a SMILE,
                 why not leave one of yours?
              For nobody needs a SMILE so much
            as those who have none left to give.



	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

yeah, beleieve me, you do not know HOW distraught i was to learn when 
I was at Transcend with my roomate yuko that the party would be ending 
at 4:00 am.  we had taken a bus to the city, kicked it on haight for 
like 4 hours, then bussed it to the party...and there were NO busses 
coming back up to the santa rosa area unil 5:00am which left us on the 
streets of downtown san fran with an hour to kill.  MAN that sucked.  
luckily some guy let us kick it in his car for about a half hour...
then we got out, walked to the bus station a few blocks down and got 
followed by some frEak in a red truck playing loud salsa music.  it 
was sCARY kids!  i seriously feared my safety.  all i can say, is 
thank god i wasn't alone, i was watching yuko's back, and she was 
watching mine...and never agian will i go to a party unless i know i 
am able to get in to a car and drive away to safety somewhere.

doreen

At 01:37 PM 12/1/97 -0800, Kenneth Zanotto wrote:
>This is a good theory.  Taking E will never again feel like the first
>time.  It will feel good, but your brain conditions you for each
>subsequent dosage after the first... waiting six months
>will increase the feeling, but never reach the first time where you did
>not know what to expect and your body was new to the introduction of the
>foriegn material.

On the other hand, the effect of dancing itself seems to increase the more
I do it, to the extent that it now swamps the effect of any substance.
Surely others must have noticed this!

I wouldn't call it "sober" raving because dancing makes me feel anything
but sober
(I must not _look_ particularly sober either, given how often people ask me
for
some of whatever they think I'm on).

Dance is the Real Drug!

The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force

talk to people, (and am somtimes guilty of it myself), that say things
like this..."yeah, and its jsut as much fun SOBER!"  Like that's a
suprise or something!  I party sober almost all the time, but for some
reason, always get that "what are YOU on?" look...<sigh> I know how
you feel Andrew!  Raving sober is every bit, if not more fun, because
you remember more names, (but never them all, its against the rulZ),
and know that everything you do is fun...plus cheaper!  Who wouldn't
LuV it?  Well, I think that's enough ranting and RaVinG!

Subject: (NRR but Life-Related) WORLD AIDS DAY

Just a slight reminder to you all to think about AIDS tonight before you
go to bed. It's World AIDS Day, whatever that's supposed to mean. Someone
told me today "happy World AIDS Day" and i just about said "fuck off,"
because it sounded almost as if it were a damn HOLIDAY we are supposed to
CELEBRATE. Anyway... Losing a relative to AIDS, and a friend, and having
another uncle living with AIDS, I take the subject VERY seriously. World
AIDS Day has been a reflective one for me.

To me, it means remembering those who have suffered, and respecting those
who ARE suffering of AIDS.

It means remembering that all the new drugs on the market that suppress
AIDS and HIV do not necessarily STOP the virus. AIDS still kills.

It means remembering that AIDS is an EPIDEMIC. It is the leading cause of
death.. LEADING CAUSE PEOPLE for people ages 22-44 in the US of A.

It means remembering to put a condom on,being monogamous, or saying now.

It means asking your partner about their sexual background no matter HOW
awkward it is.

It means acknowledging the fact that we are all mortal, and an invisible
thing could clutch onto us and suck our life away from us, just because we
are careless at one moment in our life.

It means realizing that approximately 30 million people world-wide and 1
in 300 Americans are infected with HIV and you probably work with/go to
school with/know quite a few of them. 

It means realizing that nobody... not even YOU.. is immune.

It means reminding those who you love to be careful.

It means celebrating the life you have.

It means remembering Ryan White and that in ignorance, a little boy's life
was crushed as he was refused schooling. But he stood strong.

It means respecting life.

take care of yourselves.
be aware. 
in ignorance, this disease thrived. The president of the US (Reagan) did
not acknowledge the AIDS virus to the public until 25,000 americans had
already died of it. 
in ignorance, hate thrives.
in ignorance.. lies the death of humanity.

peace.
lara

I just gotta say that Space Children always rocks my boat hard!!!
Sat night I walked in and one of my favorite DJ's on the table : TWERK.
He just knows how to hit that hard bass beat that i
love so much. Then Cesar but I seemed to get confused for a bit and but
the music still rocked hard and then Barry Weaver.....Eat Static rocked
it!!!!!  yeah!!! Then I went downstairs to listen to Galen who totally
kept my groove on. I kicked it for a while and had such a wonderful time.
Space Children always has my favorite DJ's-- always.  :) I know they
always try hard to give people a good party. Remember they had two bad run
inns and then threw a FREE party.  And also I can quote Cos when asked
if he broke even for a party that was dope but not many people were there,
"Well it's not so important to make money as it is for people to have
fun," with a grin on his face. They always fill my gut full of beautiful
rythmns....

aminita

FYI:  Did you know that 999 out of every 1000 raves do things other
than rave?  

  We all know this...and should be PROUD of it!!!  I LuV you all, and
want to chill with ya all, but maybe we should consider each other
outside of raving.  Something that my friend Alex said to Cricket will
forever stick in my mind, "You know, we both have lives outside of
raving, and one day I want to get together and talk about everything
that's NOT rave related."  I think that has to be one of the sweetest
things I have ever heard!  My proposition...with the disintegration of
City E, (WAAAAAAAA!!!! =*****(, we need a new place to chill/hang
out/have Orgys...whatever!  I know you are all LOVELY people, and
think it would be dandy for all of us to explore the other facets of
our fellow Ravers.  If there are any ideas...I would LOVE to hear
them...Hmm.....perhaps another movie night...I see a prime oppertunity
coming up after the the Party in Peoples park on the 7th.  Or anything
at all...just something for us to enjoy each others company, and have
FUN!
HugZ, LuV, and PLUR...sNIKers ;^)

Word. It's important to be careful with each + every partner no
matter what your preference. I have all too many friends who
learned this the hard way.

I definitely think this relates to raving because i unfortunately
know several friends who've been e'ing and getting their
groove on and later went home with someone to uh...get their
groove on and deeply regretted it later.

at a party i went to awhile ago in vancouver bc they were giving
out condoms...does anything like that happen in SF?

i know none of us are kids in need of sex ed - but yet i still
see people acting as if they are! in my opinion plur includes
not just respect for others, but respect for yourself......it seems
so unimportant until it happens to someone you know or to you!

love+groovin

kim

who loves to dance and swing
I often find to keep awake
It helps to take ginsing.
A natural herb 
it doesn't cost much cash
and helps me stay awake
to flip and dash =)
I also heard spirulina
(a form of seaweed)
is a healthy pick-me-up
for folks in need.
one thing about waiting
that makes it much neater
more money to party!
it is so much cheaper =)

saw a whole bunch of moving writings from fish, lara, ...  maybe it
has to do with the holidays.. 

my friend mike was particular big strong and tall
and inside he was soft gentle kind and much more
a poet composer writer anything he wanted to be
but above all he loved people and made them happy
the last valentine i found him crying along the wall
wished i were a woman whom he was looking for
he brought me on journeys to many a wonderous place
like the twin peak beach we named along the bay
on that fine spontaneous day i didn't have any gears
he carried me across the watery creek flowing for years
his footsteps across that creek had since faded away
but the ones he left in my heart remained to this days


hugssss...
hai

Up & Down is becoming a fairly reliable Sunday night
spot. Demilo and Norman both spun great sets and
started the evening off right.

Got to Spundae at about 2:15 and Terry Mullen popped
in 
for a suprise set. He played harder stuff than I
remember him playing, I liked the switch. Some kid
trainspotting asked him the name of this rekkid that
he really liked just as he was putting it in the sleeve
so he handed him the rekkid and said, "Do you spin?" 
The kid repplied, "Yes!" so he said keep it! The kid
looked at him puzzled, so Terry said, "If you really
like it I will give it to you?" So the kid bout' jumped
out of his skin with delight. Now that is what this
scene is all about.

LL

I would first like to start by extending a huge thanks to everyone that
supported and experienced 'The Spirit of Giving".  I hope you all had a
great time.

The following is a list of specifics regarding the party and the
donation.

>From the 2000 person expected attendance, there was an actual attendance
of 1200 paid attendees (1400 total attendees).   With an average ticket
price of $17.50... generating a total gross of 20K.  The event came to a
final budget of only $17K ... leaving a net profit of $3K.  Of which FGE
will Donate $2K to the Bay Area Homeless Alliance / Coalition.  The
remainder of the proceeds will go towards The Cost of Living Fund.   In
addition there was over 2000 pounds of caned food collected, as well as
several large Glad Bags full of clothing and blankets, which will be
donated to project Open Hand.

We are very happy with the outcome of this party.  It was a Solid event,
with great production and excellent music, and a Very Pleasant Vibe.
There were absolutely NO drug overdoses, no Emergency Service calls, No
Arrests, No Citations, An No Vehicle Break-ins.

However there was some Tags and Graffiti in the Porto potties and
hallway.  And the worst experience of the party was the Theft of 8
banners from our hallway.  This type of disrespectful shit really made
me loose my cool.  For someone to steal.. not one, but 8 banners, that
were hung out of reach in the hallway, was definitely premeditated and
planned out.  This added to the 6 Banners stolen at Megga Buzz Mania, to
a total of 14 banners in 2 parties.  If anyone knows were they are, or
saw anyone taking them down... Please e-mail me privately.

Everything else went very smooth.  Thanks again for your support, and
belief.

Yours in the bond of PLUR.... Vlad aka Ray Vonie.... Keep it Real! :)

From: "Chenevich, Chris" <chenevic@visa.com>

Subject: RE: Fliers, Circles, and Drugs
Date: Wed, 3 Dec 1997 12:30:46 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.995.52
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

How about...
	At a party have a projector set up to show slides of flyers onto a wall
or screen...people wishing to promote their stuff at the party bring a
slide for the projector and stack of flyers for near the door.  People
could clearly see the promotion (it's often hard or impossible to read a
flyer while on the dancefloor anyway which is why so many get chucked of
stuffed into a pocket to be read later or accidentally go through the
wash) and if interested they could pick up a flyer on the way out.  Plus
you could make creative promotions that could incorporate a couple of
slides an be very visually pleasing.
	And/Or...return all the leftover/dropped/wasted flyers to the promoter
of origin so that they can more accurately judge how many flyers to
produce in the future to lessen future waste.  Plus it will be useful to
the promoter because if they look at the flyers they can judge...
	# of leftover clean flyers = interest in design of the flyer from
partygoers.
	# of leftover flyers with footprints on them = how effective
distribution of the flyers was.
To accomplish this perhaps promoters, when leaving the stacks of flyers
at the door could leave them in an appropriately sized box with the
flyers inside and the promoters mailing address on the outside so that
after a party the leftovers could be sent back to them.

Just some quick Ideas...What do ya think?

-Chris-

a list of 400+ people. Solar isnt on this list, so he has no opportunity to
address this issue directly.  So, the people who know him who are on this list
are speaking their mind on it. 

On a similar note, the 'fucking asshole' himself, Solar will be playing this
Thursday night at The Kitchen Sink @ Blakes in Berkeley. I'm not a big drum
and bass fan, but he may very well play some. So what? Come out and see him
rock multiple styles unlike 98% of the DJ's in this scene.......
--Monty

In-Reply-To: <3485E551.610C@pacbell.net> from "ravalum@pacbell.net" at Dec 3, 97 03:03:45 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]

> have a 136 Apocalpse, it wieghs 9 lbs. w/bindings, from like 1993.  How much 
> does the average board wiegh?  I think that mine is way heavy.
> 
> Teresa
> 
I must admit that is kinda heavy.  A lot has happened with snowboards in the 
last 4 years.  I gots a 152 rossi rooster and with bindings weighs in about 7.
But you know I saw a lot of krusty boards on the mountain like some old burton's
and those kempers with the hot pink/day glo logo on the bottom that you can
see for miles.  Some people prefer them to the new fandangled models they
got out there today.  You can always demo a board (kinda expensive but worth it
if you are serious about puchasing a new board) and see if you like the new ones
are if you want to remain krusty. Even igf you decide to keep your Board at 
least check into replacing your bindings.  YOu usually can pick up a nice
set for 80-100$

Have fun and hope I see you out there,

Herb

Ohh-weeee, I totally agree with you on this one Andrew!  Dancing is so 
powerful-just by how you move with out the use of voice one can achieve his goal of 
FEEL GOOD-FEEL GREATNESS to everyone around him/her.  The music puts a smile on my 
face so B I G that I could just < < < < b   u   r   s   t > > > >! ! !  To hear the 
cheers of the crowd, to hear my inner voice scream out for more is the best feeling 
every.  

I remember at Fantasy Island a few months ago at Jack London Square Jon Bishop had 
the crowd screaming.  I could literally feel the energy /\/\/\P uL Sa Tin G/\/\/ 
from person to person.  It was like we were all in a blender and the feelings that 
one felt was what the next one felt.  People came out of the walls to get on the 
dance floor.  It was so packed, and hot-hot like *98 & hot like sweet, like never 
before had I felt so good.  Too dance and be sober all at once it was the best and 
that is how it shall stay for me.

Teresa 

(BIG SMILES & BOUNCY WALKS) =] 


Andrew Nourse wrote:
> 
> At 01:37 PM 12/1/97 -0800, Kenneth Zanotto wrote:
> >This is a good theory.  Taking E will never again feel like the first
> >time.  It will feel good, but your brain conditions you for each
> >subsequent dosage after the first... waiting six months
> >will increase the feeling, but never reach the first time where you did
> >not know what to expect and your body was new to the introduction of the
> >foriegn material.
>

> I do it, to the extent that it now swamps the effect of any substance.
> Surely others must have noticed this!
> 
> I wouldn't call it "sober" raving because dancing makes me feel anything
> but sober
> (I must not _look_ particularly sober either, given how often people ask me
> for
> some of whatever they think I'm on).

Received: from [38.248.198.50] ([38.248.198.86] (may be forged)) by netcommunications.net (10.1/8.7.3) with ESMTP id QAA14570 for <sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org>; Wed, 3 Dec 1997 16:06:07 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <l03110709b0ab9f7c97ff@[38.248.198.50]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 3 Dec 1997 15:59:06 -0800
To: sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Static (!) Review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

It's amazing that Static can seem so different on different nights... and
last night was really great!

I got there around 10:30, it was already crowded, ordered my usual martini
(one's the limit!), and started making the social rounds of people i rarely
get to see enough of....

that's one of the things I really like at Static, that there is a whole
crew of people I can count on seeing there....

Seth/Sutekh was spinning some weird experimental stuff that, after that
martini kicked in, I decided was what you would here if you were at a
party, and an alien took over the decks.  it was cool, for a minute i felt
like i was at the star wars bar...  esp. with the mix of people that come
there... quite a trip

then one of the scottish djs came on (sorry, i lost the post that had the
names of these guys on it) .....  and it was time to dance....  very
interesting stuff, it was like funky dark house filtered through a techno
soundbox, so you had the techno flavor, but the groovier beat that i
love.... what a pleasure to really find a groove at a weekly in a bar...

then it got crowded.  really crowded.  so i stopped dancing, looked over
and saw a white gilligan's hat ... and finally met messiah wannabe (whose
real name is.... duh, i forget!).. someone i've really wanted to get to
meet face to face (though of course, conversation, as always is minimal on
a dance floor!)

then, shortly before i turned into a pumpkin, i slowly made my way through
a *very* crowded bar, said my goodbyes to those i encountered, and on home
....

if you haven't made it to static, and you're over 21 and can deal with
weeknight shenanigans, get on over there, it's fully worth the lost sleep!

and ray's martinis rock, but you have to remember, only the *first* martini
is your friend, the subsequent ones are wicked stepsisters who are out to
get you!

leslie




From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Dec 04 00:03:31 1997

Subject: I speak Raver (and other deep thoughts)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
Organization: AOL (http://www.aol.com)
X-Mailer: Inet_Mail_Out (IMOv10)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Ok.. so I'm sitting in class.. bored and drifting off... when I'm thinking
about different words that have snuck into my vocabulary since I started
raving.  Aside from knowing 100 different terms for different street drugs, I
find myself saying DRAMA an awful lot. (hmm.. why could this be ;) ??)  A few
other words I can think of are also now a part of my everyday conversations
that never used to be.  Does anyone else notice this??  IS is possible that
ravers have their own jargon?? Or have I just picked up a few words here and
there over the course of this year?? 

       Also.. I have decided that from now on.. when questioned on my religion
I will definitely have to reply, Technoshaminism.  THis was from thinking
about how people were talking about other things to do at raves, and something
someone wrote in my rave book about chanting.  Then, last night I was having a
conversation with someone about chanting, and it just all pieced together.  So
from now on, when i rave, I'm going to have a goal of reaching a higher level
of spirituality.  I think I do this already, but now that I'm focusing on it,
I"m sure it will be a lot greater.  What do you get out of raving?  And does
the spirituality not seem an appealing aspect to you?  

      hugs n'stuff,
         'trice the tekno diva
  
    "when I started out.. this was for fun.  But now---  I'm on a MISSION!"

At 05:30 PM 12/1/97 -0800, Scott Nelson wrote:
>
>I was pretty pissed that it ended at 4am...take about a gip for your
>money.  Eat Static did rock the house, and so did Micheal Dog.  Barry
>Weaver also played some nice tecno.  The DJ after Eat Static was horrible,
>IMHO.  If you are going to charge $20 for a party it had better go until
>6am at least!!
>
>drenalin
>
>On Mon, 1 Dec 1997, Michael H Guddal wrote:
>
>> Does anyone have negative opinions of Space Children Rave, I do.  

Well, I feel like I should chime in for a minute here.  I have personally
never enjoyed a Space Children party.  I find their sound systems too loud,
their visuals tacky, and their lineups jumbled and unorganized.  I know
more than a few people who will not go to their parties, even if their
favorite dj/performer is here for one night only from overseas.  It's just
not worth it.  Saturday night was a perfect example.  A Guy Called Gerald,
one of the headliners, cancelled several weeks in advance and no effort was
made to replace him with someone else or to reduce the ticket price.  Even
with his absense, the lineups got pushed way back somehow.  Neil Landstrumm
and Tobias Schmidt gave their debut live performance in the western half of
the US, and their set was forcefully ended after just 25 minutes.  The
flier did not mention ANYWHERE that the party would be ending at 3:55am,
the performers themselves were not even aware of this, though it was known
by the promoters all along.  

Obviously, I have a lot of opinions on the subject, but I can state for a
fact that the Space Children promoters have more than once lied to their
guests from overseas about how much they would be paying them, and I
personally have been lied to and threatened by them over the phone for
trying to organize small weeknight clubs/parties with "their" artists,
thereby "stealing" some of their crowd and $$$.  

So, if you've had fun at their parties, then all the more power to you, but
there's more to it than meets the eye, or the E as it may be...

Seth

[Etter, Darrel] 

jimg/skoop,

I missed the glad hand thing too. Please, whoever is involved, let us
know if it happens again, and any reviews are welcome.

There was a weekly that happened a few times at Bahia Cabana that had
three live electronic acts on Wednesday nights. This was about a year
ago. I think it was called Electro something, can't remember. Liquid
Acrabat (Darrin Fossilla of sfraves) played a couple of times, Freaky
Chakra played there. One guy played there almost every time who I can't
remember the name of. He had Kawai K5, an old ensoniq sampler, and a
Cooper MIDI patch bay that he would re-route MIDI channels to different
modules to create variation in tracks. I'm sure they had at least 20
acts over their short span. I liked it!

I totally love this kind of thing, and appriciated your notes on Mouse
on Mars last week; wish I saw it. You are totally on the right track.
Here are a couple of my opinions on the subject. 

Electronic music fits into many more environments that rock music ever
did. Try Ice Cream parlors, roller rinks, fashion stores (DJ at the
Deisel store), coffee shops, skyrise lobbies, bart stations, my dreams,
etc. It's very adaptable. Acts on stage might actually be less
interesting than acts in environments. Besides, it fits the DJ as a
facilitator of the community rather than performer on a pedistal" model
held in high regard by many guru ravers. Besides, it seems harder to get
people to go see live electronic acts, but they might be more likely to
go a place for some other activities that has electronic acts as a added
bonus. 

Another critical point, in my opinion, is that you should (we, all, any)
attack this from a point of view of a group of musicians/artists,
instead of the point of view of a venue that offers entertainment. The
venues are much less dedicated and more fickle than even musicians can
be. Your heart is in the right place. A bar owners heart is pickled. 

Don't you want to perform yourself? I've heard your stuff off the web.
You're ready. I've done some tracks, and once wanted to do live
performances. I've thought long and hard about how to make my tracks
adaptable, so I could alter the music in sync with the mood of the
environment and the audience. It's a very difficult thing to do. Much
more difficult that playing a guitar chord progression.

There are other electronic artists in the area. E.A.C. (Mark Camp of
sfraves) just released two vinyls with seven tracks of excellent, very
tasty alternative techno/house, and they want to play live. ProtoLab
moved from Mountain View to SF about a year ago and have played live at
a few raves. There's some electronic group living in Sunnyvale I heard
on the radio that is really good. I'll bet there are others here on
sfraves that would like to perform. There are so many techies around,
I'm sure there are many electronic music groups and individuals. Maybe
you could ask Mr Goodwrench of KFJC what artist he knows from the area.
He's a great radio DJ, and extremely informed. 

=Darrel.
darrele@caere.com

>  - ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> analogue          Tuesday, December 2 1997          Volume 01 : Number
> 2181
> 
> 
> Subject: Portland live elektronix/dj'ing
> 
> 
> In defend our backwards (but progressing) city:  For the past two
> months,
> I have been involved in organizing an electronic music weekly show
> (Thurs
> 9pm-2am) at the Jasmine Tree Lounge downtown in Portland.  The
> restuarant
> owners are in no way against electronic instrumentation (they are
> somewhat
> clueless-- as long as some people buy a few drinks).  Attendance has
> been
> relatively HIGH (40-60 people peak) so this is a great opportunity for
> local electronic music performers to play in the area.  Handmade
> (screen
> printed, non-square, color) flyers are made weekly and the format is
> loosely/ideally three acts a night:
> 
> 
> 1 'experimental' dj (lounge, non-electronic, any history of electronic
> (pop, academic, experimental) ...incorporation of other
> synths/beatboxes
> is encouraged and anything brought to dj'ing that is not found at
> raves
> (scratching or dumb costumes) 
> 
> &
> 
> 1 'expermental' performer (non-rhythmic and/or textural electronic
> music
> performance) (ie. theremin, fx-based noise, modular madness,
> ring-modulated violin would fit this) 
> 
> & 
> 
> 1 'rhythm-based' electronic music performer (this is not exclusively
> dance-music related, ie. syncopated or pattern-based electronics fits
> here as well as sequencer-based modular work)
> 
> Also, we bring DAT and tape decks and have an open "local programmers
> play
> their tracks" hour in which you can bring tracks (less than ten
> minutes
> total) and play them for people.  but we try to make you sit on
> stage...
> 
> End of analogue V1 #2181
> ************************
> 
> - -jimg
> 
> 
> - --skoop@slackers.net
> - --http://www.slackers.net/~skoop
>

macadio ;)) at a party and asked "hey do either of you have a condom?"
boy was FUCKED UP!

pamphlet would be educational and all.. but guess what?

a pmphlet.

yanno?

Well General..last time I checked, the  Hyperreal Archives contain a 
quite comprehensive list of these terms! 

As far as Technoshamanism goes...I agree! (Biased...I think not! right 
Trice? ;^) 
Dance has always been considered a form of or used as means of 
spiritual wellbeing. I question the term used to describe it, because
it is not 
necessarily the DJ that is taking through the spiritual journey of 
enlightenment, but your own soul searching for an answer to its 
questions, pains, and misguiudences. Dance can take you away from all
the 
impurities that litter the world, or lift you to a plane of
consciousness
beyond that you could ever achieve any other way. An 
earlier issue of Lotus has an excellent article on Trance and Dance, 
(I'm not sure which issue, but I think its between 6 and 8, but don't 
quote me), and anyone interested should check that out. 
PLUR, sm:)es, HugZ, and most importantly...KEEP DANCING!!! 
sNIKers ;^* 

(I am stealing a quote from Trice that works PERFECTLY here) 
==== 
"The Rhythm is around me, the Rhythm has control... 
The Rhythm is inside me, the Rhythm has my soul."

  Michael H Guddal <guddal@ece.ucdavis.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: Space Children
In-Reply-To: <3.0.1.32.19971203173524.0143a7f4@postoffice.pacbell.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.971203231959.15622B-100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



 Oboy! It's bash Space Children time! (rubbing hands gleefully)

My only complaint with Space Children is that at Burning Man '97, myself 
and Rob Rayle put together (along with support from kind friends) the 
best dance spot on the playa (excepting of course the main stage which 
had a Trance party the night of the burn), and at some time while we were 
there, a Space Children promoter left a stack of flyers on our table.

 I have several problems with this; one- we were not asked if someone 
could dump their trash on our table (which we had to throw out for them), 
two- Burning Man is an arts festival where one is supposed to be able to 
avoid things like crass advertisment. If we wanted that we would have 
Budweised underwriting the event so the organisers wouldn't be going 
broke trying to throw this art party. Third- we didn't set up our sound 
and lights to attract customers for Space Children. Their prescence was 
highly unwanted and I will never attend one of their events. I would like 
to urge others to boycott their parties also until they learn the meaning 
of the word "respect".

hugz,




On Wed, 3 Dec 1997, Seth wrote:

> At 05:30 PM 12/1/97 -0800, Scott Nelson wrote:
> >
> >I was pretty pissed that it ended at 4am...take about a gip for your
> >money.  Eat Static did rock the house, and so did Micheal Dog.  Barry
> >Weaver also played some nice tecno.  The DJ after Eat Static was horrible,
> >IMHO.  If you are going to charge $20 for a party it had better go until
> >6am at least!!
> >
> >drenalin
> >
> >On Mon, 1 Dec 1997, Michael H Guddal wrote:
> >
> >> Does anyone have negative opinions of Space Children Rave, I do.  
> 
> Well, I feel like I should chime in for a minute here.  I have personally
> never enjoyed a Space Children party.  I find their sound systems too loud,
> their visuals tacky, and their lineups jumbled and unorganized.  I know
> more than a few people who will not go to their parties, even if their
> favorite dj/performer is here for one night only from overseas.  It's just
> not worth it.  Saturday night was a perfect example.  A Guy Called Gerald,
> one of the headliners, cancelled several weeks in advance and no effort was
> made to replace him with someone else or to reduce the ticket price.  Even
> with his absense, the lineups got pushed way back somehow.  Neil Landstrumm
> and Tobias Schmidt gave their debut live performance in the western half of
> the US, and their set was forcefully ended after just 25 minutes.  The
> flier did not mention ANYWHERE that the party would be ending at 3:55am,
> the performers themselves were not even aware of this, though it was known
> by the promoters all along.  
> 
> Obviously, I have a lot of opinions on the subject, but I can state for a
> fact that the Space Children promoters have more than once lied to their
> guests from overseas about how much they would be paying them, and I
> personally have been lied to and threatened by them over the phone for
> trying to organize small weeknight clubs/parties with "their" artists,
> thereby "stealing" some of their crowd and $$$.  
> 
> So, if you've had fun at their parties, then all the more power to you, but
> there's more to it than meets the eye, or the E as it may be...
> 
> Seth
> 
> 

Ran D. Dreams


				    (Namaste)

From: VespaRaver <ledesma@sfsu.edu>
Subject: AGE?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <971203020700_-522672907@mrin39>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Actually, age does matter because of sooooo many venues being 21+.  But
other than that, age does not matter.  For me, it's a lot more about
maturity.  I'm 18 (19 in January).  I have many friends that are far
younger, but very mature for their age.  Then there are 24 year-olds I know
that I really don't care to hang around with because of their maturity
level.  You notice this much more in college than in High School.  In High
School, you know what grade everyone is in, so you have a pretty good idea
of their age.  In college, you don't really know unless you ask.  One of my
friends was insulted by the fact that I thought he was a freshman (and
guessed he was 18 or 19) when I met him, and he's really a junior and 20.
I know another guy that's 24 that I thought was 19 or 20.  So you see, it's
all about maturity level.  And as far as youndg people on this list go,
they seem to be pretty mature for their age.  I would have never guessed
that 'trice was that young.

					VespaRaver


At 02:07 AM 12/3/97 -0500, you wrote:
>well, I don't know about the average on this list being 15. The only other 15
>year old here that I know of is 'trice. As for me, i'm going to turn 17 next
>month. does age really matter that much?
>
>
>Marq
>
>

a water booth or anything that resembles a booth there could be a bowl of
condoms or something....honestly I think if people are going to be having sex

is making sex seem cheap and gross (lying on a dirty floor ewww) sex is
supposed to beautiful.....wow, ok, anyways but if people are going to be
"grossly having sex in an unsanitary spot, then I think condoms should be
available...blah blah and so forth!!!!  <3 *MushyB!

allergic to coffee....

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hey Gang,

Got some questions for everyone. If you have the time, please take a little
bit and answer them. (Those that give me really good answers - I'll kick down
my hometown mix groove to you. ;) )

Thanks! 

O.k., here goes:

1) What would be your ultimate mix tape/CD? (like a general description..)

2) What genre? 

3) Would you love something that rocked several different styles or one
consistent throughout the whole tape?

4) Should the mix try to replicate the sound of a club/party or be made to
"bedroom listening" standards/energy level? (Maybe a better way of putting
this: Should mix tapes be more introspective/intricate or more obvious (as
live mixing usually is)?).

4) WHat are the specific tracks that would be on it (artist, title)? Why?

5) What are your all time classics that should be included in your ultimate mix?

6) Do you think that DJ mixes should be from vinyl or CD? Is one more real
than the other?

7) Do you prefer tapes for your collection or are CDs better?

8) What's more important to you: The music or who's spinning it? (If it's who,
then who are they?)

9) What would be a fair price for this mix if you had to buy it?

10) And finally: What do you think of DJs that make mixes on tape or CD that
don't get clearance/approval from labels or artists to use their music on
these tapes/CDs that are sold? 

Thanks for your input on this,

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

I replied privately to the person asking for suggestions... but since there
are other responses to the list, I want to add my input..

It is VERY important to go to experienced and responsible piercers... I
have heard tales that you would not believe about some of the places on
Haight and Telegraph that are not really professional... some don't have
trained piercers working, some don't even check id's (a responsible piercer
requires id that you are 18, or have your parents with you).... some don't
even have an autoclave to sterilize their equipment... some sell cheap
jewelry that will break or interact with your body in a bad way....

my rule of thumb is that, if they do anything OTHER than piercing there,
then you're better off finding a place where piercing is what they
specialize in...

so....  here are the shops I recommend that you can count on...

these are places I have gone to, and have taken my daughter to....

1.  Gottsi in Berkeley on Telegraph out near 65th street.... Alan makes
most of his jewelry inhouse, and has experience with quality piercing, with
a tribal and ethnic focus...  for stretched pierces (like my ears, etc.),
you must go to someone who understands that aspect of piercing....  (tell
him Leslie sent you)

2.  Nomad in SF (moved to share space with Primal Urge tattoo, I
believe)... again, a tribal focus, and Kristian has been doing piercing for
many years... (again, tell them Leslie sent you)

3.  Body Manipulations on 16th near Guerrero... not as tribal in their
focus, but excellent quality....  (you can tell them I sent you, but
they'll have no idea who i am! ;^)

some people like the Gauntlet, I find it too crowded and big and
commercial, and their focus is not the tribal-style piercing...

Remember, piercing is NOT permanent like tattooing, but you must take care
of your pierces properly, and if you have any problems or think anything's
wrong, go have the piercer help you figure out how to fix it...  they are
happy to help you keep your piercings healthy.

and NEVEr put plastic or Fimo or cheap safety pins or silver in your
piercings, please... only put inert things in your body... i.e., surgical
steel, surgical implant-grade plastics, glass, buffalo horn, amber, stone,
bone, etc...  if in doubt, any of these shops will be happy to tell you if
a material should be stable...

As far as tattooing (I've said this before on here).... it's SOOO important
to choose your design carefully so it REALLY means something to you
FOREVER... and NEVEr put cost in your criteria for choosing a piece or an
artist... if you can't afford what you really want, start saving for it
now....  you'll never regret waiting and doing it right..

now, back to work!

love, leslie

Hello!

Question:

If the party was underground (illicit, whatever..) and those that wanted to
express themselves in that manner ("doin' tha do"), it does seem appropriate
that to hand out the protection would seem to be a good idea (if indeed
handing them out promoted the idea that you could have sex at the party...) I
agree w/ Chris.

Lord knows I wouldn't put my nekkid butt anywhere near some stank nasty
warehouse floor... (grease stains on the booty!)

But anyway, is there something truly wrong with having SEX at a party? Seems
like it is one of those real basic human expression type things that should
have a place somewhere. (I don't think I could get au natural, but for those
that want to...well, I say, drop those skivies... ;)  ).
I think there is a club overseas (U.K. or something) that I was reading about
that has this sort of thing. Manumission I think its called....

On Thu, 4 Dec 1997, Robert Pointer wrote:

> Hey Gang,
> 
> Got some questions for everyone. If you have the time, please take a little
> bit and answer them. (Those that give me really good answers - I'll kick down
> my hometown mix groove to you. ;) )
> 
> Thanks! 
> 
> O.k., here goes:
> 
> 1) What would be your ultimate mix tape/CD? (like a general description..)

Juan Atkins vs. Kari Lekebush

> 2) What genre? 

I suppose that would make it techno/minimal techno.

> 3) Would you love something that rocked several different styles or one
> consistent throughout the whole tape?

Music should always be flirting with the notion of being hard to define.
Mix it up, but tastefully.

> 4) Should the mix try to replicate the sound of a club/party or be made to
> "bedroom listening" standards/energy level? (Maybe a better way of putting
> this: Should mix tapes be more introspective/intricate or more obvious (as
> live mixing usually is)?).

Both.  Think about it, you want to be throttled by long clean sinous
mixes, you also want to hear some harder cuts when the mix calls for it.
I trust a good artist to use both tastefully in a mixtape.

> 4) WHat are the specific tracks that would be on it (artist, title)? Why?

I purchase mixtapes because I trust the DJ to put what they need to say on
there.

> 5) What are your all time classics that should be included in your ultimate mix?

None.  Anthems/Classics have no place on a mixtape in my opinion, unless
it happens to be something that was played during a live set. 

> 6) Do you think that DJ mixes should be from vinyl or CD? Is one more real
> than the other?

Depends on what the DJ spins...

> 7) Do you prefer tapes for your collection or are CDs better?

There should not be mix CD's, they come a little too close to being able
to be pushed as a for demostration purposes only product, and ultimately
will cost the scene both tape and CDs.

> 8) What's more important to you: The music or who's spinning it? (If it's who,
> then who are they?)

The entire thing, both, ....

> 9) What would be a fair price for this mix if you had to buy it?

12.99 TOPS or so... no more than a usual tape.

> 10) And finally: What do you think of DJs that make mixes on tape or CD that
> don't get clearance/approval from labels or artists to use their music on
> these tapes/CDs that are sold? 

Cool if it's a cheap tape in small runs for purposes of promoting a DJs
mixing skills as a promotional tool.

> Thanks for your input on this,
> 
> rob.
> http://www.citizenmag.com
> 
Let's put it this way... there's a CD that came out from some friends of
mine, which I think is fuckin low.  It's got very few mixes, playing
almost entire tracks out.  I don't really consider that a mix, it's a
beatmatchd complilation.  A compilation should be licensed from the labels
and artists.

CD = "perfect media"  I think 'artist approved' mixes are cool, but I
don't think bootleg mixes should be put on CD its just plain fucked up.

Tape = in small runs, it's a boutique business, any DJ should be able to
make a tape and hand it out or sell it... prefereably for cheaper than the
15 bucks stopres are asking.  I've been trying to put a tape in stores,
and only one store will let me mark my price down below everyone elses...
and that's money out of "my share" of the tape so to speak.

It's a weird issue...
AndyW

I was busy composing my 'canned' response, when I read Leslie's post.
Listen to Leslie.

I get a lot of questions at parties, as the piercings and tats I have
are noticeable - if you go to trance parties, chances are you've seen my
pretty titties >;-) and arms...

I got the hood done at Gauntlet by some guy named Striker - not the Jeff
we all know and love...  I don't know if he's there anymore, but my
friend who did my breasts and now lives in Portland, Keith, always
recommended Body Manipulations.

I was at Bod Man the other day, and they're doing scarring and brandings
as well, so if you're new, these seem to be people who really know their
stuff.

As for tats - once you have a design, the best thing to do, I think, is
to ask peple who have work you like.  Because tattoos are permanent, we
have a tendency to remember very well each one, and will recommend
people with full conviction, once we find someone we like.  Bee is
fantastic, but he's splitting time between SF, LA and Europe, so he's
hard to find.  I have a number for him, though, if you want it.

Peace,

K

On Wed, 3 Dec 1997, sNIKers wrote:

> (I am stealing a quote from Trice that works PERFECTLY here) 
> ==== 
> "The Rhythm is around me, the Rhythm has control... 
> The Rhythm is inside me, the Rhythm has my soul."


And if you could, add that it's from a Peter Garbiel song (Rythym of the
Heat - from Security), inspired by the field work of a Carl Gustav Jung. 
It's in reference to some tribal rite he observed, which he noted had
significant effects - even on those who were not "conditioned" to react to
the ritual... that it tied to something deeper within the human psyche,
which ironically ties back to raving and where I see it fit in modern
culture using a concept from an actual quote from the psychologist... 

"No psychic value can disappear without being replaced by another of
equivalent intensity." C.G. Jung

It means we had to figure something to replace dancing around a fire in
loincloths... see you this weekend, kids.

peace,
AndyW

> Guarana is caffiene.
> i used to work at GNC

Minor point of correction:

Caffeine is the primary active ingredient in Guarana. Guarana *contains* 
caffeine, it is not caffeine any more than coffee is caffeine.

Subject: Re: [NRR] piercing/tatoo places
Author:  Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net> at Internet_mail
Date:    12/4/97 10:10 AM


I replied privately to the person asking for suggestions... but since there
are other responses to the list, I want to add my input..

It is VERY important to go to experienced and responsible piercers... I
have heard tales that you would not believe about some of the places on
Haight and Telegraph that are not really professional... some don't have
trained piercers working, some don't even check id's (a responsible piercer
requires id that you are 18, or have your parents with you).... some don't
even have an autoclave to sterilize their equipment... some sell cheap
jewelry that will break or interact with your body in a bad way....

my rule of thumb is that, if they do anything OTHER than piercing there,
then you're better off finding a place where piercing is what they
specialize in...

so....  here are the shops I recommend that you can count on...

these are places I have gone to, and have taken my daughter to....

1.  Gottsi in Berkeley on Telegraph out near 65th street.... Alan makes
most of his jewelry inhouse, and has experience with quality piercing, with
a tribal and ethnic focus...  for stretched pierces (like my ears, etc.),
you must go to someone who understands that aspect of piercing....  (tell
him Leslie sent you)

2.  Nomad in SF (moved to share space with Primal Urge tattoo, I
believe)... again, a tribal focus, and Kristian has been doing piercing for
many years... (again, tell them Leslie sent you)

3.  Body Manipulations on 16th near Guerrero... not as tribal in their
focus, but excellent quality....  (you can tell them I sent you, but
they'll have no idea who i am! ;^)

some people like the Gauntlet, I find it too crowded and big and
commercial, and their focus is not the tribal-style piercing...

Remember, piercing is NOT permanent like tattooing, but you must take care
of your pierces properly, and if you have any problems or think anything's
wrong, go have the piercer help you figure out how to fix it...  they are
happy to help you keep your piercings healthy.

and NEVEr put plastic or Fimo or cheap safety pins or silver in your
piercings, please... only put inert things in your body... i.e., surgical
steel, surgical implant-grade plastics, glass, buffalo horn, amber, stone,
bone, etc...  if in doubt, any of these shops will be happy to tell you if
a material should be stable...

As far as tattooing (I've said this before on here).... it's SOOO important
to choose your design carefully so it REALLY means something to you
FOREVER... and NEVEr put cost in your criteria for choosing a piece or an
artist... if you can't afford what you really want, start saving for it
now....  you'll never regret waiting and doing it right..

now, back to work!

love, leslie

>     At this site you can find some basic things everyone should know
>     BEFORE piercing their tongues

>     http://www.parentsplace.com/cgi-bin/objects/dentist/dent140.html

I checked out this website and agree with much of what is said... however,
this dentist groups tongue piercing with lip piercing and cheek piercing...
and these are entirely different types of tissues and processes...

tongue piercing is not that painful compared to other piercings... and yes,
the healing can be a bitch, because this is a body part you use all the
time, and when it's swollen, you can't eat or talk very well... i hated my
healing process and almost gave up because it took 14 days before i could
"size down" to a shorter and more comfortable barbell (if your jewelry
isn't comfortable, it doesn't fit, so go have a piercer take a look at
it... a too-tight piece of jewelry will do damage to your tongue, or lip or
other soft tissues in your mouth, and a too-loose one will get in your
way)...

and it is very important to rinse with sea salt water consistently during
the entire healing process or whenever it feels tender (as in any pierce,
sea salt water will help pull toxins out and promote faster healing)...
diluted listerine is a good germ-killer too...

one reason it is important to go to an experienced piercer is that the
placement of a tongue pierce is very VERY important... too far forward or
badly angled, and you will bite on it, and it WILL damage your teeth... i
have friends who have cracked their teeth, and that's definitely not worth
it... if you have a pierce that you easily bite on, consider taking it
out....  and possibly having it repierced...

the other thing i don't agree with is the recommendation to remove your
jewelry to clean it.... my experience is that every time you screw off the
ball on a barbell, you are wearing the threads... and are more likely to
end up with a loose ball...  which will fall off and create problems..

my preference is to have my barbell long enough to be able to push it in
each direction so that I can brush it with a toothbrush...  i have never
removed it in over 2 years, and don't see any reason to unless something
happens to the jewelry...

also, please don't be tempted to get clear plastic balls for your pierce to
make it less conspicuous at work or whatever... it is not good to have
plastic in your mouth, because it will break down from your digestive
acids...  Alan at Gottsi has some red high-quality plastic pieces if it's
that important to you... but again, that means changing the balls, and when
you do that a lot, you wear out the threads....

and one more thing .... (nag, nag, nag, after all, I'm a mom!).... you
e-head kids who get all tweaky and play with your tongue pierce constantly
are doing harm to it... you are risking stretching your pierce, as well as
nicking of chipping your teeth... you can unlearn that nervous habit....  i
swear...  (oh yeah, now that makes it rave-related, right?)

leslie

Yep... and they lie about telling you "Yeah, we need someone to do the web
page. We'll be sending you the graphics shortly."... then I get a call
from an aquaintence who says, "Hey, I'm almost done with the Space
Children site.... they said you were interested in *helping... do you want
to help maintain the HTML??".... Shhhhhhaaaaaa......   Man, I reached out
my hand to those guys and they were cool for a bit.. even envited me to
their place to kick it....   but the whole web page thing gave me a true
understanding of what they're about....   I didn't have to offer my FREE
services to them... I told them, "I just wanna help you guys out and be
part of the family"... Ha!..... 

I'm going to KEEP IT REAL......... and go to parties thrown by people who
KEEP IT REAL.

Byroni

Okay everyone, even though I already posted that I DO NOT think that having
sex at partiesis okay, I guess I would have to agree that it IS going to
happen whether I/we like it or not.  So, I guess maybe condoms SHOULD be
available.  Also, I know a lot of people have sex right AFTER parties
before going to sleep, so it would be great to have condoms at the door for
these people, too.

You know, it's kind of like how the government has programs to provide
IV-drug users with clean needles.  The users are going to use the drugs
whether the government likes it or not.  So, the government might as well
do SOMETHING (even though they do VERY LITTLE) to stop the spread of HIV.

Thoughts?

					VespaRaver

Since March, I have been developing the worlds most perfect way to honor the scene
and give others a better understanding of why we love it.  It's finally here:
CHOREOGRAPHER'S GALLERY    December 4 (8PM) & 5 (7&9PM)
This show is a collection of dances.  Mine, titled "Earthlings", is a tribute to
all of the experiences and people that have come my way thanks to raving.  Tickets
are ONLY $5!!  You can call 408-554-4015 to order or get directions.  Or you can
get tickets before the show.  However, it is general seating so come early.  The
theater is on the Santa Clara University campus.  
This is a professional show with lights, sound and all the other effects we know
and love.  I genuinely think the whole show is great and any of you would have a
fantastic time.  Make a night of it and be sure to say "hi" after the show.  Thanks
for reading this far!!

>:) Amber

in many places, like seattle, the AIDS-prevention groups give out free
condoms in all the clubs ... in bowls by the door, in bowls in the
bathroom.... with cool little match-book-like covers... i actually have a
little collection just because they're so clever and interesting, and also
have good info on them....

you all know that i don't think people should have sex in *public* at
parties... though even some of my, um, best friends, have been known to
sneak away occasionally.... which is why I *always* carry condoms with
me.... because one never knows when one will need one, do one?

better to have it and not need it than to need it and not have it, that's
what i say..

(though a few years ago on a similar thread, moonpup said he thought it was
bad luck to be prepared... but *I* think it's bad luck to need it and not
have it... and decide to do without....)

so, put 'em in your backpacks and pipebags and whatever, kiddies.... and
share 'em with your friends, because that's all good...

i just don't wanna have to watch you use it in the chill space at a party, ok?

love, leslie

(p.s.  in a pinch, ask me, too, ok?)

Hey, I was at static too. Didn't manage to meet any of the huge sfraves posse there, though. I was the one on the podium like thing at the side with long blonde hair and a goatee, dancing like a complete loon. That crazy darkside track with the dark voice talking about a couple of girls going to new york, just for the night, and ending up going clubbing, then the voice goes "Slipped her some ecstasy, and I FUCKED HER ALL NIGHT" and hits the break - that was just so completely insane. N.B. It wasn't indicative of the rest of the set, which was just good old jackin tekkno madshit mixed in with a bit of oldskool electro for measure.
And I thought SF would just be deep house and cheesy trance - how wrong was I (Or was this week just a lucky techo week?)
I shall be frequenting static often after that performance - have to meet up next time.
Overnout
C@weasel

hey hey =) on nwraves we were chatting about this and i thought
i'd see what you guys felt. my list is a bit outdated but oh well *grin*

Fave Tracks.
1. A piece of forgotten song drifting across the water - Makyo
2. Spiritool - Jay Ahem (off the Aquarhythms cd by astralwerks)
3. Lesson 6 (the lecture) - Cut Chemist

Fave Cds
1. Deep Concentration
2.  Sugarhill Gang Box Set
3. Morcheeba - Who can you trust
4. Bjork - Homogenic
5. Portishead - self-titled

Fave DJ Mix Tapes
1. Treebrother =)
2. Dan - Bring it Back to the Funk (tribute to James Brown)
I know this one is old but it is one of my favorites.
3. Thee-O  - Cosmic Journey

Fave Parties of '97 (so far) (Seattle)
1. PLUR 97 - How could a nw-raves party be anything but the best :)
2. Astral Voyage
3. Both of Mel's parties (Sea Swallow Me + Echoes of a Shallow Bay)

Favorite San Francisco Party
1. Blue Room Tour (phaaaaaat!)
2.  Free outdoor jungle party (i think it was nameless) (thrown by meeks?)

and i'm adding a new category!
Favorite Book
1. Bhagwan Rajneesh - Meditation - the Art of Ecstasy

love kim

An alternative that you might want to consider for the piercing is the Fakir
Musapher body intensive workshop. Each month they hold a workshop and need
"models" to be pierced. The piercing is free you pay only for the Jewlrey(5-15
dollars). Plus you get the opportunity to meet Fakir, who's name you may or may
not recognize from the Modern Primitives book that spurned this modern interest
in ritual activities like piercing ant tattooing. The contact number is (650)
324-0543. Just call and let them know you would be interested in being a model.

As far as tattooing goes stay away from Erno's on Fillmore and Haight. I never
had a bad experience with them but have had several friends that were less than
satisfied.
My tattoo artist of choice lives in Seattle.
JND

At 04:45 PM 12/4/97, CAT WEASEL wrote:
>Hey, I was at static too. Didn't manage to meet any of the huge sfraves
posse >there, though. I was the one on the podium like thing at the side
with long blonde >hair and a goatee, dancing like a complete loon. That
crazy darkside track with >the dark voice talking about a couple of girls
going to new york, just for the night, >and ending up going clubbing, then
the voice goes "Slipped her some ecstasy, >and I FUCKED HER ALL NIGHT" and
hits the break - that was just so >completely insane.

Hee...   that was a record by Oliver Chessler from NYC, who used to do
hardcore for Industrial Strength records.  Believe it or not, that track
was from a brand new record, though it has elements of old school techno
and industrial.  Every track has some kind of monologue, ranging from silly
to downright perverted (like the one Neil Landstrumm played).  His tracks
certainly work on the dancefloor, that's for sure...

> N.B. It wasn't indicative of the rest of the set, which was just good old
jackin >tekkno madshit mixed in with a bit of oldskool electro for measure.
>And I thought SF would just be deep house and cheesy trance - how wrong
was >I (Or was this week just a lucky techo week?)

Well, Static varies quite a bit from week to week, our resident djs play
everything from the kind of "jackin tekkno" you heard on tuesday to dark
techstep drum and bass to abstract funk and electro.  We try to keep people
on their toes...

This tuesday was certainly a treat having Neil Landstrumm and Dave Tarrida
in from Scotland.  It's not often we get to hear talent from overseas at
our $2 club, but they were much more interested in spreading their love of
music than in money (a rare occurence).  If you were at Static and liked
the music, hunt down some records on Scandinavia, Sativae, Drought, or
Mosquito (all closely related to these artists).

Thanks again everyone for coming out!

-Seth

.......................................................................

\\\ static tuesday nights at liquid. sf. ca.

Hello all you ravers!

As some of you may know The San Francisco Harmony Family will be coming
together once again this year. We are putting together one more party for
the year of '97. It has been a rather surprising year for many of us...
"Harmonics Clothing" (our store) has opened up in Santa Rosa Ca, we threw a
"massive" (by our standards... the Harmony Spring Massive), and some of us
moved away. All of these things together contributed to the lack of Harmony
parties this year. We only had 2 events this year. Hmmm... kinda wierd, but
anyways...

The S.F. Harmony Family has gone through a lot of changes in this last
year, but we are still here, and still ready to party our asses off!!! For
over four years we have partied together, and we are inviting all of you to
join us once again to have a slammin Harmony Party!!!

It gives us great pleasure to present the following...

****BEAUTIFUL PEOPLE****

Saturday night, December the 27th, 1997

Bringing us together with the slammin beats...

        *BRIAN & BRAD*                                    *LI*   -   *TRENT*
            (L.A.'s Moontribe 2X4)                 *GREG SANDLER*
						(old school Harmony techno freaks)
               **URN**
                      (The Santa Rosa Family)

Taking us for a ride...

              *J-BIRD*                                     *MAIZ*     -
*ANDY W*
                  (Pacific Sound Sys)                       (Down tempo/
ambient)

                          *RE-ACH*   -   *SCIENCE*
                                (drum n' bass maddness)

                                                  (408)486-9591

We have a huge variety of music for this party, so it is going to be a full
night of bomb ass tunes! Since this is a "Beautiful People" party, we
encourage you to dress up in costume for this party to share and spread
your beautiful positive vibes! There will be be free water and fruit
availible as well as cheap bottled water. *Look for the first ever
Harmonics Clothing booth... We will have tapes of some of the djs playing
as well as select shirts and accessories.*

The location is only 15 min away from S.F. and is a beautiful two room
facility. There will only be 400-500 presale tickets availible for this
party. Call the voice mail to get info on wher to get the tickets. The
price is $20. The reason for this high price on admission is due to the
permits. We have made sure that this party is fully permited and ready to
go off! (that just means we have to pay more $ to get in) But we are
cleared to go all the way until 6am.

Ok, so here's the scoop from us to you on this party... We are trying our
hardest to make this the most collective conscious positive atmosphere ever
at a Harmony party. We want the vibe to be so intense and so amazing, that
we can all wallk away from this party feeling and knowing that we are all a
part of a beautiful, positive, underground family. This takes all of our
energy combined, so let's make this an unforgettable night for all of us!!!
Bring your positive vibes and spread your love!!!

Hope to see ya there!!! Call (408) 486-9591

Peace, love and harmony to all,

Harmony = )
