Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Gang (Posse, Crew, Pack, Troop, Party, Mob, etc.),

I just picked up the new MixMag (U.K. Version) and it comes with a free Mix
CD. It's called "House Puts the Breaks On".

I popped it in to hear what kinda commercial stuff they were trying to
promote, but ohhhhhh, how I was mistaken in labeling it unfairly. (still
promotion, buuutttt....)

It is an amazing collection of complex house grooves with a disco root, some
well-used old skool electro drops, exciting sexy downtempo grooves (later
half), and phenomenal mixing. 

Here are some of the groups:

Assassins of Sound
Genetica
Superstars of Rock
OST
Palefield Mountain
Manitou
Desert
Innerself
Almighty Beatfreakz

That Brit pack, DAMN! =:0

I recommend it highly due to it only costing about 6 bucks (w/ cheesy magazine
if you can stomach it!).

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

p.s. I recommend this depressingly though only because I'm in the middle of my
mix creation and I'm kinda wowed by their stuff....NO MATTER THOUGH! I WILL
CONTINUE DESPITE .... HOW ....GREAT ....THE ...... ODDS ....SEEM!


mu...st... c on tin  ue ......


;)

The 4th annual 24 Hour Solstice Music Marathon will be held at Internet
Alfredo
(7th and Brannan). On December the 21st. It will actually take place
Starting at
12:01 AM and go till 11:59 PM Sunday night. This year the event will be
cybercast in RealAudio so folks all over the world should be able to hear
it.  In addition Internet Alfredo will be open for the entire event, a $6
day pass will let you come down. hang out and surf on their T1 while the
event is going on. Internet Alfredo is small, it holds about 100 people so
this isn't a full on party, there will be a small dance floor and the
espresso bar will be open for business, we'll probably have some holiday
snacks as well. The DJ Line up is as follows:

Astral Matrix			Matty B.	
Carlos				Markie Mark		
Ethan				Preston
Felix the Dogg			Spun
Galen				Sub-Cmdr. Lycos
Jeno					Tracy
Jerry Bonham			Troy TranceHall
La Ron				UnKnown

This list is not in Order and is subject to change. For further information
set your browsers to  

				http://www.cybertribe.com
				voice mail (415)541-5632
What you should bring:

			Good Vibes
			Your old Luv Phaser (for reconditioning and reattunement)
			Holiday goodies to share (We will provide free wather,fruit, and
			Punch)
			Interesting objects to place on the Yule Altar

P.S. If anyone has a leed on where we can get an FM transmitter so that we
can broadcast the event in SF so folks with radios can hear it let us know.
We intend to have two feeds, a 28.8 feed for folks who just have computers
in their homes and a 88k stereo high quality feed for folks who have ISDN
or have access to DS1 or above. The 88k feed will be suitable for recording.

If you want to help in any way:

*We need a small sound system amp,PA, (we have turntables and mixers)
*FM transmitter
*Security/crowd control
*Net geeks to help with the cybercast

e-mail me geoffw@cybertribe.com

From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Re: VSF  & Stompy...hesitant review (LONG!).
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <199712062127.AA06427@crl.crl.com>

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



About 4 years ago I was a club in downtown LA, a benefit party for Malachy
attended by and thrown by folks from SF.  Around 5am I'm in the upstairs
dance room, absolutely parched (no drinking fountains, no water being
sold), and I see a guy standing at the bar pouring a glass of water for
himself from the bar's tap.  He motions to me, I say, sure!  I pour myself
a glass and a security guard freaks and throws me out of the club, without
giving me a chance to tell the various folks I came with about the
situation.  There were at least two others who had also done it, it was
WATER, and the guard refused to stop when I demanded to speak to the
promoters and club owner (by name).  Whether he was black or white or
purple I can't recall.  Lesson?  Most security is spotty when it comes to
enforcement of any particular law (save for checking ID's at the door),
once they've decided to do something there's really nothing that will stop
them, and trying to point to an incident and calling it a trend is a, well,
stretch.  Not to say your allegations aren't true, not to say there isn't a
racial bias on the part of security there, but it's just a stretch.  Know
of any non-white security guards at VSF?  If so, what would they say,
confidentially?  If not, that's significant itself.

I eventually got back in and spend the rest of the night out of plain sight. 

	Brian

"it's a big world, with lots of records to play."-sig   brian@hyperreal.org

sorry about that...

yeah, ive had some guyz come up on me and gave me the willies.
one time i was saying hi to this guy who i *thought* was somebody i 
had me breifly once..i have him a hug and said "are you ---- ?" he 
laughed, and said "no...but you look hot".  it threw me cuz that 
wasn't the response i was expecting at all..i said "whaaat?"
then he winks and says it again..'you look HOT!'...
then i understood what was happenening..and walked away kinda 
puzzled.  
oh yeah, this is the BEST one...at that happy kidz party at the dance 
studio, i pulled my friend aside into the massive chill room to talk, 
and as i turned to walk back, this homie G comes up to me and says 
"hey, you were standing in my friend's way..." i go "i'm sorry..." i 
look over and see his homie G friend standing against the wall.
then he goes "well, you better go give him a kiss now.." witty that i 
am, i go "no, i don't think my boyfriend would like that..." he got 
all scared "oh you have a boyfriend?  nevermind....its all good ok?  
OK?"  

doreen

>them, and trying to point to an incident and calling it a trend is a, well,
>stretch.

Agreed, I was not calling it a trend however, I was calling it an incident.
However if others corroborate, then it is definitely a trend.

>  Not to say your allegations aren't true, not to say there isn't a
>racial bias on the part of security there, but it's just a stretch.  Know
>of any non-white security guards at VSF?

To my knowledge there are none.

>  If so, what would they say,
>confidentially?

I am currently trying to find out as much as I can about VSF.  What I do
know, to date, is that there are no security guards of color.  I know they
do a hip-hop thang on Wednesdays (the patrons would not like to hear of the
"choosiness" of some of the security @ VSF).

>  If not, that's significant itself.

Perhaps.  All options are open at this point.

>
>I eventually got back in and spend the rest of the night out of plain sight.

Unfortunately I did not have that option.  Suffice it to say it was not the
fun ride home, and could have been far worse. ;(

(VSF IMO SUX)

Much peace and thanks for the comments and sharing the experiences.

Security sux at plenty of places.  Funny though that in the 7+ years of
raving, this was the first time I was ejected from a club.  Weird.  Also of
note, I've been way loopy , far more so in the past (8-10 beers, and plenty
of mind altering stuff making my head float).  This time, except for the
booze (5 beers), I was straight.  THAT is what is bugging me so.

Oh well, as Ice Cube said, this ain't over.  It has just begun.

>
>	Brian
>

>"it's a big world, with lots of records to play."-sig   brian@hyperreal.org

Oak50 ravE. This homie goes up to this break dancing chick and says
something like, "Hey baby, want me to show you a real good time?" She looks
at him and says, "You best go check yourself" And the look on his face, it
was like he wanted to put a cap in her ass or something.
 We ended up having to leave early. Luciana smoked weed for the first time
that night and wasn't feeling so hot. It was funny, every guy with pot that
night tryed to get up on Lucy, so she was really stoned. My friend Tim
earlier that night said, "I'm kicking it with Luciana for now on. Doods are
coming up left and right wanting to get us high".

I just got to reply to this really quick..

 It's funny you say that. Cause when I first started raving, you know...When no
one noticed me.. I DID NOT smoke weed. The first time my dance turned heads at
FUSION, was the first time I smoked pot at a ravE! And damnit to hell if THAT
ain't enough to make you go back to your pot head ways.
 Before, I never smoked weed at social gathering because it made me too shy. But
that night, I just felt like "what the hay" and I fired it up. And thoughs
phycho bitches and miss thing DJ's were tearing it up that night! And I didn't
stop dancing for 4 hours, and when I stopped, it was like everyone was looking
at me funny. =]:..
 I swear to GOD, thoughs four hours I was in a black out or something.

Asfar as my luck goes. I gave up on a cure for it long before I gave up on the
ravE scene.

12/5/97 for immediate release:

http://www.sfstation.com/nye

california's bay area producers of underground dance events come together to
present the end of the year's dance celebration:  

97-NEW YEAR'S EVE-98

san francisco's original TOONTOWN has returned with veteran producers of
COME-UNITY & BASICS (of The Gathering), also in the same house: BY THE PEOPLE,
SUNSET/PACIFIC SOUNDSYSTEM, OTHER RECORDS UK, STEP 2K, & LOVEWORKS. gathering
top talent from around the world, along with it support from WIRED magazine,
sf station, HOUSEWARES & OTHER, this event will for sure make its mark
on the underground scene in the bay area.  we hope to re-create a space that
inspires participants to be creative and implement that creativity into new
ways of social thinking.  through the combination of fierce house music,
technology, interactive environments and diverse media we believe these goals
can be achieved, both on the night of the event and in the long term.

talent preview:
dj pierre - strictly rhythm nyc
jeno - wicked, sf
pete avila - 'your mama's house', sf
a man called adam - other records, uk
simon - come-unity records, sf
'evil' eddie richards - dy-na-mix, uk
steve loria - la
idjut boys - other records, uk
markie - wicked, sf

we will make music, culture, technology and information accessible to people
while creating a whopping, walloping, wailing, wacking, slaping, lolloping,
thumping, thundering, throbbing, bumping dance environment.

for all info, ticket / turntable give-aways and press release:

http://www.sfstation.com/nye

or leave a message on:
415.703.7107
415.646.0744

One thing that really annoyed me last week at Stompy...I was upstairs 
hangin out and the secrurity were totally hawkin everyone like prison guards.
One of them walked up to a dude who had no shirt on and made him put it 
back on!  It really bugged me, Stompy is one of the best parties left at 
a time when good parties are few indeed. It's a sad thing to happen at a 
very special party. It would be nice to be able to 
experss yourself as long as your not hurting someone, without being 
afraid of security. Is not having a shirt on a fuckin crime?  Did anyone 
see last New Years day when they kicked that English dude(Ramo?) out?

economic reason(insurance) the **Owner** thinks hardcore security is needed.

I noticed something interesting this weekend having to do with this
subject.

 I went out with my friend for 10 years, Brian. He hasn't gotten out much
the last three year's, but he is now single again and going out. Hmmm,
single = going out? New concept.
 Anyways. He is not what someone might call shy. But I beg to differ now
after actually observing his technical charm strategies. I have come to
find out, he is pretty much as shy as,, well,, me for instance.
 When a girl looks at him, all he can do is talk about it, not act on it.
Yea, what I noticed is, he actually only goes up to the ladies when their
NOT looking at him. Every girl he talked to Friday night, he had to tap
them on their shoulder to get their attention. He will not approach a girl
if their "checking him out"
 I need to still confront him on it, I wonder if he knows that's what he
does. Hmm.

Anyways. I thought that might be enlightening to some people.
 Awareness sure can be a hold up..

Night,
 Jeff

sunday night finds me putting together the J-card for my first tape mixed
by my secret alter ego, DJ 725 (oh well, not so secret anymore).  suddenly,
i realize that one of the tracks on the tape bears no identifying marks.  i
want to give credit to all the artists on the tape if possible--not to
mention i need to re-purchase the track 'cause the record has gone missing :(

so.

if any of you know the title, artist, label, whatever of a track that

--begins as a trance track with lush melodic synth lines

--starts getting more electro and adds a sped-up vocal sample that sounds
like "gimme, gimme support"

--music stops and a vocal sample of "gimme a motherfuckin' breakbeat" kicks
in the music again

--drumline changes to breakbeat and the same lush synth lines come back in

--then i would love to know what it's called.

ANYONE WHO wants a tape can send me their snailmail address and expect to
receive one shortly.  your conception of "shortly" and mine may vary, of
course.
-------------------------------
"i scream so much.  you know what i mean.  this electric stream.  and my
tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

To answer Mark Piercy's question last: let's get the real downtown low down
from Geoff White (hi Geoff :) because this is a point he has made often
in the past: there is a very tight relationship between clubs and police
in SOMA.  The relationship bleeds green, in some instances, but even more,
it is a matter of information flow and people control.  Bouncers behave
as they do because, beyond the usual correct observations about what
a tough job it is, they are *allowed* and *encouraged* to do so.

Your Honor, may the People present three exhibits well known to the
assembled jury:

1.  Trocadero.
2.  Sound Factory.
3.  174 King Street.

I want to mention the third specifically, since I among others was
subject to random harassment there over the years by "security," who
were *not* the same as those at the adjoining 177 Townsend (who are
tough but fair -- they let you know they are there, they are in charge,
and then they stay out of the way).  King Street, at certain times in
the past, epitomized what the rave scene in SF was all about -- when
we were good, we were very very good, and when we were bad, we got
down with the cosmic funk.  But as the years went on, the security
presence put a severe damper on the scene there.  Not that people were
out of hand or anything, it was a pure rent-a-cop trip.  It got to
the point where Wicked had the Hon. Geoff White presiding at the door
in order to keep things on an even keel.  

I have no doubt that John's report from the VSF is, on the whole,
accurate.  I even detect a certain embarassment at losing it a bit,
the kind of embarassment we've all felt I think.  But beyond that,
given the corroborating evidence and the personal experience I have
with VSF (my last Stompy was New Year's Day, where at least half the
crowd was probably not in any shape to drive :-), this is a very serious
matter.  What it may reflect is that even the relatively low-key places
like VSF are being stressed somehow.  Running a club is no picnic, but
you have to know that the owners are well aware of their responsibility
*and* their control, and if the bouncers behave a certain way, whatever
that way may be, you can be sure it reflects the true desire of the
management because, in fact, if you don't like one bouncer there are
others waiting in line for the gig.  Consider Ira's record at 1015.
In the many years I've gone there and heard about events there, I can't
recall one single untoward incident at the door other than fools being
shown the way out if they were being exceptionally foolish.  For all
the issues we have over how Ira runs his show, this much is clear: the
customer is important enough to management that the customer gets
respect, and that includes the door presence.

I have my issues about how Preston runs his show, too, but spaces are
scarce and there have been some really good Stompys at VSF.  All the
same, knowing the man as I do, jsl's story will become an important
data point in dealing with VSF now and in the future.  And furthermore,
now that we have been alerted, it will be quite clear that if this
incident is indicative of a real pattern, Stompy at VSF will be history.

peace out 
phred

> minh,
> are you back from your oceanographic studies?   i'd love to hear how it
> went.  maybe you could post to the list?

> regards,
> George

-->	Okay, in case you didn't know, I am most definitely back and will
be around for the next few months :)
	First off, my maiden return party was at Byroni's yesterday and I
had a wonderful time and met all you peeps:

*hugs*
Elisabeth & Jandreas (J'n'da'B hashed browns ;)
Jake Loco
Guy
Rusty (Jungle & Reno; what else is there?)
Baby Huey (I've met you before....)
Messiah
Mister E
Natasha (aka CalChemist)
Rob
Zoe's SO (forgot your name, but thanx for the tour)
Pengo
Drekster (so toasted you should've been an appliance)
Byron (smashin' pahty luv)

...and all the others I've forgotten and hey Rubilicous, I liked your
moves but was too shy to say hi--maybe next time :) I know y'all have real
names, but it takes me awhile to relearn them all after the list
identities have gotten into my head.

	Okay, now for the NRR ocean thing...since September I was with a
class in Tahiti and only got back last Sunday.  I was doing scientific
research with a marine alga, gastropods, and succession; talk about
exciting fun (for Cal students it's cross listed as IB 158, Geog. 142,
and IDS somethin'). I have one week to prepare my research paper for
ridicule and hopeful publication, but no matter what, I get semester
credit for the class :)  I had a brilliant time (and pics) on the islands
and even managed to survive cyclone Osea in a Bora-Boran warehouse. The
downside was having to live with some very non PLURy ppls in close
quarters for months and not having adequate rave access during the
weekends.  Polynesians are wonderful (as people and as eye candy) and
_definitely_ know how to have a good time. Lesse, rats and cockroaches
will rule the world, and when on Tahiti do not assume that all women were
born that way. If any of you are heading that way, I can give some more
info--there is an occassional techno night at a place I know. Well, all
and all, this city BuddahFlye is glad to be out of hibernation and back to
civilization.

:)
M&m

Quoth lara at vibe.org:
>ok ok ok jeez for fuck's sake i'm so sorry.
>
>for you super-sensitive types, let me rephrase my one-liner so that i do
>not offend anyone..

You know, I have in the past, been over sensitive, and quick to take
offense, but this ain't one of those times. NEways calling someone
sensitive is a cop out. I don't buy it here anymore than I would in a far
more extreme case, where for example a man might say "Sorry babe, all I
said was 'nice tits' it's a compliment, don't be so sensitive."

>one can also keep their thoughts off of sex.

Yeah right like that's possible, or desirable. ROTFL.

>they can keep their legs closed, or their penis in their pants.
>
>satisfed?

With the rewrite yeah, but...

>i wasn't lashing out against men.

Um????? You're confusing me. I don't recall anyone saying anything about
your lashing out against men. All I mentioned was your ignoring women. Not
mentioning women, and the importance of the things that women do, is one
the most common, and insidious forms of sexism. We've all read those old
(and not so old) history books that talk about "mankind" and stuff like
"when man discovered fire." By not mentioning women's participation in sex
you belittle women's sexuality. Thank the deities that we in our culture,
do not as some other cultures do, stifle our girls sexuality by surgical
means. However, little by little mainstream US culture sends girls message
after message throughout their youth, and on in to womanhood. Over time
these messages manifest themselves as internalized oppression. Internalized
oppression is when an oppressed group, in this case girls and women,
through years of conditioning begins to believe, and live the lies of the
oppressors, often to the point of helping to perpetuate those lies.

OK this is getting way to NRR. Damn, where's a "Your Sister's House"
discussion group when you need one?

>you people are so damn picky.

If it was just you and me talking, I wouldn't trip. But when someone drops
sexism, subtly or overtly, deliberately or accidentally, on a list that's
read by many girls, some of whom I know and love, yeah you're damn right
I'm picky.

Sir Ulrich Knight of the Turntables

naive folks it could cost you more than embarrassment.

LL

          by precipice.v-site.net (8.8.4/8.8.4) with ESMTP

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Mon, 8 Dec 1997 11:21:07 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: "John S. Lee" <jsl@twenty-hz.com>
Subject: VSF & Stompy, my lawyer speaks.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Oh boy, geez.

I hope that I've given people something to think about.  However my battel
with VSF will have to be on the public relations tip as it certainly will
not end up in court.

After talking to my attorney about this matter there is little I can do
*legally* to hurt VSF.  As far as the law in concerned, VSF is a private
club.  They made a determinitaion that I was drunk, and they ejected me for
said reason.  Since this is not a civic establishment (i.e. a public park,
courthouse, etc.), they can pretty much do whatever they wish.  They can
exclude or expel people for whatever reason they choose.  Ouch.  If they
have a "hard on" for you for *whatever* reason, it can be grounds for
dismissal.

Since I was not harmed physically, just emotionally (which btw must
manifest itself in the physical realm), there is nothing I can do.  Case
closed (not really).

I am going to write my experiences in a popular magazine and warn others of
my plight.  But for all intents and purposes, this fight, a fight about
principles won;t be done in the courts.  At least it saves me and the
taxpayers some money.  Besides I can suffer a little embarassment (hey, it
wasn't like Stompy 1996! ;)
).

I just want to give these closing words and thoughts on VSF & Stompy.

Stompy Stomp, as long as it is held @ VSF, has a serious problem with
security.  They are confiscating drugs and using them, they are throwing
out black patrons (male) who mingle with females who are not black, they
are looking for people to use substances.  this means that if you're
passing something from one person to another, even a paper, they can eject
you.  VSF is unfriendly to the rave community, and the only reason that
anyone would continue to have a party there is because they don't care
about their patrons and only care about the $$$'s made in a city where good
events are becoming increasingly difficult to find.
The only real solace I have is that I was guest listed and didn;t have to
pay.  Maybe the next person who is ejected won't be so lucky and after
having paid $15 (I beleive the new years price), you too could find
yourself ejected from the party @ VSF for trumped up and vague reasons.

For my brothers and sisters of color, beware.  If you have drink one, or
bump into anyone you might as well count the minutes before they toss you
out.

I am a man of integrity if nothing else.  If I was throwing a party and one
of my friends was mistreated, I would do everything in my power to right
the wrong.  It is obvious, and I am not naieve to this, that this is not
how others live their lives.  I do.  I will not step foot one, or encourage
people to step foot one into any event @ VSF.  They do not want people of
color at their club and I don't wish to be in a place where I am not
wanted.  I hope other people of color feel the same (one must wonder since
Preston has been made aware of this, what effect this will have on a party
that he himself has called "too vanilla".  I wonder now if he was sincere
at all...I think not).

To Stompy & Preston:  Good luck, but remember one is judged by the company
one keeps.  The $ is a strong device and only those who master it can rule
it, less it rule them as in the case here.  If you're all about diversity,
and all about *people* having a good time, one can only wonder *why* you
chose a club that practices racial exclusion to achieve your goal.  I can
only hope that entire crew wakes up and smells the coffee.  I do think
however that they would rather be lulled into a deep house sleep with the
$'s their making at that venue.  I don't go to klan rallies, and I will
never set foot at any party that has its event at VSF.  Now go on and keep
making that money.  After all, that is what this is all about, right?

VSF:  You suck.  I'll never set foot in your prejudiced club again.  You
and your high school security guards with severly handicapped commmand of
the King's English can take your former sex club and stuff it.  Flava '98.

SFRAVES:  Thank you all for your kinds words and support since I've come
out about this.  I am still gathering data to hand to P-dog (as if he'll
care) when I see him next (whenever that is).  You guys rule and you all
rock!  Much love and peace during a small tumult!  After all the words back
and forth it is good to know that I have made a few friends here on the
list.  Much love and much respect to you all.  It certainly seems that this
place has, at least, kept the last part of the spirit once found at raves
everywhere.  Keep it alive and keep it real!  Thanks again!  Much love! :)

PEACE,
John

P.S.  The fight remains, but I'm onto better things.  I guess that means my
clubbing is now restricted to: "Abstract Soul" & "Wicked". :)  Hey, at
least I still have two parties on my list! :)

"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

Are you serious?  I have tried to follow this thread (although I admit to
only briefing through a few of these posts) and it seems to me that you
have nothing to back up your claims here.  I don't know how much you had to
drink, but  just because the security decided that you appeared out of
control, is that reason to make it your mission to circulate rumors and
misrepresentations about the club? A claim of throwing out black patrons?
This didn't happen, at least from what I have read... and there are black
men on the security at VSF... there was at least one at that Stompy.  The
security may get over anxious in confiscating pipes, but at a Stompy three
months ago they took one from my friend and at the end of the night they
gave all the pipes back to people who came and asked for them.   
It seems as though this has hurt your pride and you are now looking for
some sort of revenge.  Just make sure that this is justified and based on
something real before you shoot down the venue of one of the best parties
happening these days.

At 07:59 AM 12/7/97 -0800, pj fuzzy wrote:
>So I was wondering br you boy or girl straight or gay.

>A. have you ever been hit on at a party(rave).

Yup...

>B. What was your favorite pickup line, the best or
>worst one that you ever heard.

The best line I've been handed wasn't even verbal.  A few weeks ago at Love, I was walking around upstairs, (it was at Big Heart City) looking for my friends, and I made eye contact with a cutie as I searched the corners... The next time I came through the hallway she stood up in front of me, with an evil grin on her face.  I side stepped to the left, she side stepped in front of me, I stepped back to the right, she matched me again.  Then she stepped right up to me and kissed me... not one of those little hi how are you pecks either... Talk about the direct approach.

Now for the serious part of this thread... Whenever I see some creep trying to push himself on a helplessly intoXicated girl, it makes me wonder about the validity of our scene.  Maybe it's because I'm not the kind of person who can walk away and ignore that kind of situation, but that should not be tolerated.  

Pointing out the obvious...

--ChrisP

On Mon, 8 Dec 1997, John S. Lee wrote:

> For my brothers and sisters of color, beware.  If you have drink one, or
> bump into anyone you might as well count the minutes before they toss you
> out.

John,

None of us that were not in attendance are qualified to make a judgement
on what actually occured. I won't even attempt to. 

However, given your own explanation of the story, I find your reasoning
specious, and the jump of "logic" that labels the security racists equally
so. Have you shown that they were assholes? Possibly. That's life. I have
had negative experiences with asshole security at clubs myself. Like you I
have chosen to not attend events at those clubs. 

At no time did you state that the security made *any* derogatory
remarks regarding your race, the race of those around you or your
"inter-mingling" with those of other races. 

I fail to see how this illustrates that action of VSF security was
racially motivated.

Naughty Santa's Biarre Bazaar
Dec. 21st 
3pm till 11pm

I devised Naughty Santa's to be cheap venue for all of our artists friends to be able 
to sell thier goods to US, thier friends. It got out of hand last year, we hosted more 
than 30 artists and over 500 shoppers. This year we expect more than 50 artists to be 
able to fill ALL of your shopping requirements.

We also have wall to wall entertainment. A spectacular Drag Queen show is being 
produced with some of the finest drag queens in the bizness. It is at times like this 
whenn I wish I didnt hype things up so much, because Fennel Skellyman has assembled a 
truly unique cast of Mwomen.

As you all may know we have ripped off the whole Crash Worship shtick complete with 
gallons of chocolate pudding 30 gallons of wine 2 bubble macines, rotten fruit, rotting 
vegetables, choclate syrup. 

Ohhh and Music! we will be covering thier music dressed in Santa drag.

Tiki Times' Otto will be spinning christmas tiki music, Chicken John begged for a 
spot-DJing but oh gosh we seemed to have run out of DJ slots.

 TOPH1 (red wine-XLR8R-Liquid on thursdays) is running a very special FUNK SIDE. 
A  dance culture crafts ghetto. Buy mix tapes, local clothing designers clothes, peruse 
dance zines. 

Scott Beale is doing some video screening. You will be able to sit in theatre seating 
to watch premier underground videos.   You can buy the videos to take home, or give as 
gifts.

Behind that will be a 'quiet' video lounge run by Jose of 'Museo Contempo'

There is more and as I remember it I will remind you.

If you live out of town and you always wanted to attend a list party than this would be 
 one of the biggest you could attend. Plan to fly in for this one.


For those of you who live here, save your gift buying money. Spend it here. Buy stuff 
from your favorite BM artists

ok, so i haven't been going to burning man every year since 87.  in
fact, this year was my first.  it won't be my last.  i don't have any
other burning man's to compare bm97 to, but i know this one blew my
mind.  i thought it was too cool for words, and i didn't notice any of
this commercialism everybody keeps talking about.  probably about the
least commercial event i've ever experienced in my life, actually. 
granted no one died this year - some people seem to regret that fact,
understandably.  i could see where the element of danger might make it
more exiting.  but...

maybe it's like taking a new drug - the second or third time is never
as good as the first.  although i've had this conversation more than
once - "i didn't go to burning man this year, it's gotten too
commercial."  "oh, so you've been before?"  "well, actually, no..."  

summer of 96 a friend in nc convinced me to drive out with him for the
festival, i was completely willing.  then he convinced me not to go
after all - "it's gonna be too commercial this year, i wouldn't
bother" - how he knew that is beyond me, and i wished i hadn't
listened to him. i think he out-cooled himself, and me in the process.
 don't let anyone tell you "it's not gonna be any good this year." 
find out for yourself...

-messiah

ps ran d's rave hit the spot, the technosunrise was gorgeous...

heroooow!!!!!!!!!! *huggles and kisses for everyone* Lovely monday morning
here in downtwon sf! hehe..i spent yesterday recuperating from the party on
saturday night that i feel sooooooo refreshed!!! =)
Anyway, on saturday night, a couple of us were wondering what to do..we had
no ride to Oakland to go to Byroni's b-day bash, and we didn't want to
spend $25 to go to the FTT party at maritime hall..so we were stressing (
for those of you who know me, I haven't gone partying in a loooooong
time...hehe..lack of funds )We finally found this lil ug at 11th and
howard.  I cant remember the name of the party but it was prolly one of the
BEST party I have been to this year!!! (but then again, i havent been to
many parties this year...hehehe) The vibe was great, people were friendly,
it was just one dope party and i would like to give mad props to the ones
who threw this great wonderful party!! And to all the kids that were there
for bringing such brilliant vibes!!!! =) 
I was also wondering if any of you went? If so, I was the one wif two pony
tails with a feathery grey shirt and a doraemon (japan anime) backpack =) 
Anyway, have a greeeeeeeeat week everyone!!!!!
Much Love,

with the recent discussion about vsh and stompy
i thought this was appropriate =)

> ONLY IN THE U.S. LEGAL SYSTEM!!!
>    -----------------------------------------------------
> A Charlotte, North Carolina man, having purchased a
> case of rare, very expensive cigars, insured them against
> .. get
> this ... fire. Within a  month, having smoked his entire
> stockpile
> of   fabulous cigars, and having yet to make a single
> premium payment on
> the policy, the man filed a claim against the insurance company.
> In his claim, the man stated that he had lost the cigars in
> "a
> series of small fires." The insurance company refused to
> pay, citing
> the
> obvious reason that the man had consumed the cigars in
> a normal
> fashion.
> The man sued... and won!
> In delivering his ruling, the judge stated that since the man
> held a
> policy     from the company in which it had warranted
> that the cigars were insurable, and also guaranteed that it
> would insure
> the cigars against fire, without defining what it considered
> to be
> "unacceptable fire," it was obligated to compensate the
> insured for
> his loss. Rather than endure a lengthy and costly appeal
> process,
> the insurance company accepted the judge's ruling and
> paid the man
> $15,000  for the rare cigars he lost in "the fires."
> After the man cashed his check, however, the insurance
> company had
> him arrested ... on 24 counts of arson!  With his own
> insurance claim
> and testimony from the previous case being used as
> evidence against
> him, the man was convicted of intentionally burning the
> rare cigars and
> sentenced to 24 consecutive one year terms.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish
>

	In support of raves vs. clubs, I'd have to say that I
get macked on like crazy at clubs and really not at all 
at raves...has anyone else experienced this?  Hey, maybe
I'm not too pretty in the darkness of the ravin' underground,
but clubs *are* a bit of a meatmarket.....& just so I don't get
any flames, I've worked in a few clubs and totally have
*nothing* against them...clubbing is kewl every now and
then......it's just my personal experience as of late that 
 at massives and small UG's I can thoroughly enjoy
the *musical experience*, be with and make friends & 
not have to worry about keeping as escape route open... :)

have a happy happy...

luv n hugs,
natasha

ps anyone else stressin about finals??!@?

Received: from [38.248.198.127] ([38.248.198.127] (may be forged)) by netcommunications.net (10.1/8.7.3) with ESMTP id PAA23631 for <sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org>; Mon, 8 Dec 1997 15:03:49 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <l03110705b0b217f64e41@[38.248.198.127]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 8 Dec 1997 14:54:20 -0800
To: sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Monday Thoughts...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Here are a few random Monday thoughts I wanted to share....

Deep:

THe first Deep, which will be a monthly, was last Friday at Il Pirata on
16th near Potrero...  allow me to say DO NOT MISS this party next month!
Sweet little neighborhood bar space with easy easy parking, a
super-comfortable feeling, a perfect layout with the bar separate from the
dance room, so you could hang out and talk, then go dance, then talk....
really great groovy tunes being spun by Forest then Biojeff (then I left,
who was next?) .... perfect.  Great job, Tony, Jeff/Ann and crew!

Age:

As one of the elders on this list, I'm usually amused at the occasional
threads about age ... often triggered by a young person feeling excluded
simply because of their chronological age... and often accompanied by a
statement that argues that age is not an issue at all....

But age *is* an important factor in who we are .... because the longer you
live, the more experiences you will have.... and the more you can learn
about the ways of the world.  See, it's not the *number* of your age....
it's the amount of *learning* you've had the time to do that makes the
older ones (usually) have it more together than the younger ones (usually).

Exceptions to the rule? But of course... some people just have a sense of
confidence and an ability to learn by observing others that gives them a
natural foundation of wisdom... and they may be far more mature at 20 than
others might be by 40...  and some people live their whole life in a
selfish and unaware state, so they never move beyond the petty childish
perceptions of the world around them (hey, just turn on Jerry Springer to
see exactly what I mean)...

But for those of you who are 15, 16, 17 years old...  no matter how much
you feel that you are an adult and have a lot of maturity... relax, enjoy
where you are now, don't be in such a rush to be old, because it's going to
happen fast enough anyway.... and if you're under 21 and can't go to a bar
yet, just chill, please, because it will happen soon enough, and wishing it
would be sooner... well, that's really just wishing some of your best and
most enjoyable years would hurry up and be done with, and that is wishing
your life away.


Security Thugs:

John's story of what happened at Stompy sucks...  Since I wasn't there, I
can't say whether any of the actions were in any way justified (I was a
bartender for years, and I know that sometimes situations escalate in a way
that was never intended)...  but I have a hard time imagining John creating
such a ruckus at a wild and crazy Stompy party that he'd have to be 86'd.
And the stories of security confiscating stuff from patrons and sharing it
among themselves is, to me, the scummiest of behaviors...

We must speak up as promoters and as patrons at clubs, and let the
management know that we will not allow our friends and guests to be treated
this way! And promoters must step forward and speak up to the owners of a
space about how their guests are treated....  because we go to a promoter's
event, not to a space.. John wouldn't have been there if it wasn't Stompy,
and so Preston and his crew, I believe, have a responsibility to make sure
that John and their other guests are treated appropriately, by the Stompy
crew, as well as the people who work at the venue.

Using licensed spaces is a reality of our world, because we don't have a
lot to choose from... but that doesn't mean that we can't demand to be
treated respectfully...  Security is a fact of life in clubs, but there are
plenty of clubs (like 1015) where the security people show that it's not
about a power trip to them.  Speak up, tell management when you feel poorly
treated by their staff, and let's insist that we are treated with the
respect we deserve.  By putting up with this, we are silently accepting it.


Pickup Lines:

Call me dense,or romantic, or naive, but I loved that story of the guy
staring, and the girl saying "have we met" and him saying "no, but I'd like
to know you" or whatever...  I think if more of us were a little more
direct in expressing our true attraction to others we encounter, life would
be a lot less neurotic, with fewer cat and mouse games going on.

First, though, as in most situations, you want to try to put yourself in
the other person's shoes for a minute.... and try to see if this person is
truly love-struck (yep, it can happen) and hoping you feel the same (so you
might say, "wow, that's so sweet, sorry but i have a boyfriend")...  or
maybe you sense that they're just on some automatic pilot cruise control
with canned lines and no real attention to the person they're talking to
(when you might say "excuse me, you're making me uncomfortable, can you try
that line on someone else maybe?")...

Just be careful to remember that it really is a compliment when someone is
attracted to you, so don't just turn and flee when they get the nerve to
tell you so!  After all, you never know who you might meet if you keep an
open mind and have the courage not to run away from every encounter with a
stranger (some of my very favorite people used to be strangers ;^)  ...
thank god for the ones who had the balls to say what they were thinking so
I'd know!

sorry for this disconnected ramble.... just wanted to add some things to
these threads... happy monday, all!

love, leslie

>On Mon, 8 Dec 1997, John S. Lee wrote:
>
>> For my brothers and sisters of color, beware.  If you have drink one, or
>> bump into anyone you might as well count the minutes before they toss you
>> out.
>
>John,
>
>None of us that were not in attendance are qualified to make a judgement
>on what actually occured. I won't even attempt to.

Thanks for the respect in that regard.

>
>However, given your own explanation of the story, I find your reasoning
>specious, and the jump of "logic" that labels the security racists equally
>so. Have you shown that they were assholes? Possibly. That's life. I have
>had negative experiences with asshole security at clubs myself. Like you I
>have chosen to not attend events at those clubs.

Hey, I have no conclusive evidence.  I have come to that conclusion
because, given my experiences, and now the documented experiences of others
(there has been at least 3 of these ejections to people of color at Stompy
@ VSF), I cannot rule it out.  I am still trying to figure it out, and go
over, and over in my mind *what* I did that could have cuased someone not
to like me.  I am always respectful of people, and I didn;t vibe security.
When all other options are eliminated, seek the outrageous.  Racism is such
a thing, and it is the only thing left, all things considered.  I am still
grappling with this, however, I am sticking by my conclusion given the
expereiences I have gathered.

>
>At no time did you state that the security made *any* derogatory
>remarks regarding your race, the race of those around you or your
>"inter-mingling" with those of other races.

Nope because they did not, and that in itself is no proof either of racist
intent, although a strong argument can be made.  I looked at all teh
variables and it comes down to two things:
_security @ vsf has a problem overall.
_security @ vsf has ejected brothers for highly suspect reasons.

I have been the victim of real racism before.  Often times it never hits
you face on.  The N word is never spoken, other issues are brought up.
Whether it is perfromance, attendance, or vague complaints from unnamed
people, I've seen it all.  And I do not draw these conclusions lightly.

I was listening to a radio program the other day and they were talking
about sports.  The question was brought up as to why there are so many
blacks that participate in sports, and excel.  One reason is that the rules
are very plain and very universal and applied to everyone equally.  Sports
is a 100% merit based activity.  either you're good or bad.  Same can be
said of the military to a lesser extent (for politics and favors are the
key elements as well).  But in sports everything is laid out and defined.
Now compare that to companies, where knowledge is just one small element of
the overall picture.  Politics plays a great role, association as well, and
other metrics that are difficult to quantify.  The rules , on the surface,
apply to everyone, but certainly not equally.  You can be the best
programmer in the world, but hey, you don;t bathe as often as I do.  I'm
going to apply my metric and hold you back.  This is why there are 43
million dollar players in sports, and 43,000 players in the tech field.
That is one reason why CEO's are mostly male and white, while some of the
most brillinat people who make it possible to make these salaries are
Asian, East Indian, women, etc.  The rules vary at different levels, and
the games played vary as well.  The metric in companies shifts and changes
with the administration and whose on top.  Whereas in sports the rules are
written, defined, and administered equally.  It changes the higher you rise
in sports organizations, one reason why you see fewer people of color at
the top.  But that is changing as well, thank goodness.

Nope there is not a klansman everywhere I look, there certainly isn't one
under my bed.  However, sometimes you just know that something *is* w/o it
ever being said.  You can see it in people's eyes, and you can sense it.

Funny things about senses.  I asked my attorney today while talking about
this VSF incident *how* they could tell I was drunk.  He responded "visual
cues".  Talk about subjective.  In any case, I know wassup, and that club
has alot of problems, mine is just one of them.

I'll never attend another party at VSF until they get thier house in order.
I don't care whose playing or whose party it is.


>
>I fail to see how this illustrates that action of VSF security was
>racially motivated.
>
>

You know Adder, sometimes you just *feel* it.  Question though for you to
think about:  Does someone have to say that they don;t like you for you to
know that they don;t like you?

Food for thought old friend.

Much peace and thanks for the feedback!

Peace :),
John


"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

with this is to stay away.

1,2,100, 1000.  I can give you at this point 5 examples of vague reasons
given to black ment for ejection from Stompy @ VSF.  But I figure that will
never be enough for anyone.  Suffice it to say I beleive it, and until it
happens to you you will probably not beleive me.

will, bottom line however is that security has a serious problem at VSF.

practice some form of exlcusion.  may I remind you Texaco had alot of

Nope, I am looking for an explanation so that I may enjoy the venue again
w/o fear of being ejected over nefarious conditions.  Let me clue you in,
I've knows preston for about 6-7 years, dig.  I have done things far more
embarassing than getting ejected.  Shit, I laugh with people about it
during the day and crack jokes about myself.  That however, doesn't mean
that I don;t take it personally because I do.  As for revenge, what could
that be?  Pointing out that a club has problems is a public service not
revenge.  You are making unkind characterizations and I would warn you to
do otherwise.  My ego is very large, and my life is large and complex, I
rarely go out enough for this to hinder the other fun activities in my
life, and my ego has taken worse bruisings and I've come out on top
(something about Year of The Dragon.  this is just one of those instances
where I feel I was wronged and spoke up about it.  I have not called for a
boycott.  Instead I have warned others to pay special attention.  The
*CLUB* even acknowledges that there is a problem, I cannot go into details
but there is plenty that is going on behind the scenes.  In any case, I am
not seeking revenge, get it.  I am seeking the truth so that this doesn;t
happen to someone who pays to go into a club only to find themselves
ejected for basically nothing.

People see what they want to see.

>  Just make sure that this is justified and based on

Thanks for that sage advice.  It is obvious that I feel am clear and
justified, and that is all *I* need.  tacit approval is not what I'm
seeking, I am sharing an experience, my experience with *you* and others.
The party may be all good, but it is only as good as the venue.  Preston
knows this very well, and if these problems persist, that party will cease
being anything but a pain.  If people can't relax then what's the point of
going out.

Please don't take my word for it, read about others experiences at Stompy @
VSF.

BTW, thanks for defending my friend's party.  He'll appreciate it.  I don;t
blame Preston, but I do call into question the wisdom of keeping it there

>                            L       76

>                            G       71

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Dec 09 03:52:02 1997

Subject: meat markets, vegetarian joints, and in between
To: Faro@usa.net

Precedence: bulk



i think that most clubs have that pick-up element to them, but in
degrees.  1015 is pretty much a full on meat market (though different
rooms have slightly different vibes) where you see a lot of couples
dirty dancing, and if people aren't dancing together they're scoping
unabashedly.  lots of couples leave together.

on the other end of the clubbing spectrum, i got a very different vibe
@ ultra in the currently infamous vsf.  not only were people not
dancing with each other, the nights i went i really didn't seem to see
much  pick-up action going on.  well, a little, but less than at some
raves.  people seemed to be actually dancing in their own space, not
just pretending to.  but that was my perception, i only went twice,
and the scene is quite different on different nights.

liquid, in my opinion, is a really nice sort of in between.  you see
lotsa guys n gals looking sorta spiffed up, possibly out for some sort
of action.  but you don't really see people grinding on the dance
floor, nor have i heard many complaints about groping or pestering. 
especially at static on tuesday - you don't have all these people
migrating into town to get laid.  more like people exchanging numbers
to call before the weekend.  plus there are definitely some who go
there just to dance - there are a few people i see regularly who come
in dressed super casually, dance for hours without hardly speaking a
word to anyone, then leave alone, every time.

i'm still trying to figure out the end-up, especially sunday morning. 
lots of spun clubkidz, obviously, but i can't quite figure the sexual
vibe there, though i see/feel it.  maybe i'd understand if i was a
meth head...

finally, generally speaking, any club scene on a weekday night is
bound to be less overtly sexual, and probably aimed more at an
audience interested in the music.  liquid can get pretty randy on a
friday (though it's still not as bad as 1015 on a wed, much less a
weekend nite), same with vsf.

this thread reminds me of the "how sexy is your music" post, which i
thought was hilarious and quite accurate (and reflected in the music
played at these clubs).

-messiah wannabe

ps. i think i just realized a big difference between the pickup scene
at raves and clubs.  besides sex not being the main (or at least not
the only) point at raves, the thing is that girls are much more likely
to approach you, whereas in a club usually it's the guy who makes the
approach. and by the girls reversing the normal rules, they are less
likely to get pestered alladamntime, cause the norm is more to back
off till a girl really lets you know she's interested by introducing
herself, or offering you some gum, or just walking up and kissing you
square on the puss.  hmmm, whadaya think, does this sound right?

your good!

no wonder they call you the -Messiah-...
did you study human behavior 101 or something?
;)

i prefer to make the first move myself... or at least let them know that i
AM interested; eye contact, a smile... whatever works...  that way _I_ get
to do the choosin'!  
it's hard though... i know how annoying some guys can be- starring you
down, following you around, dancing on top of you... the last thing i want
to do is put someone off like that... so it's a very challenging thing to
'pick' someone up.  
i feel most comfortable when you're past a certain point and realize that
the guy is just being friendly with no intentions or expectations.  THEN...
and only then, will i let my guard down. (unless of course my eyes were on
him before he even approached!  then he's mine!  ok- so i'm getting a
little carried away here...)  it's sad that i even have to put a 'guard
up... but after experience as a women, you have to! there are a lot of
slimey men  (and i'm sure women too!)  that are out to pick anything and
everything up... if you get my drift!  
better to be safe than sorry!

worst pick-up line- 
"you look so familiar... were you at (name any place with the same
clientele as the place you're at...) last weekend?"
duh... "no habla espanol..."

just on my way home now! 
nice post, messiah... just wanted to say hi.
meg

Its intereting to look at how a species sexual atitudes change over time.
There was one a time when sex was considered a sacred act.

It was done in the tantric temples as a way to celebrate and practice our
spirituality.

Today it has degenerated into a physical act alone...often lacking
in any spiritual aspect at all. That is why we feel shame about
it....because we have forgotten how sacred it is.

Many feel it is time we remember those sacred ways of celebrating life.

perhaps raving is an early experiment in finding new ways to 
revive that.

or maybe not...what do you think?

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

i love the rain. 
baby huey misses you all (danny) and is going thru SFR withdrawal, so drop

wrote this when i couldn't sleep last night because of how loud the rain
was when it hit my roof... ahh :)


i love it when the sound of rain
drowns you out
"i can't hear you," i say
as you scream and shout
your lips are moving
but i don't hear your words
i smile blankly and laugh
as this occurs

thank god for the sound of the rain
when it falls
i don't have to listen to
your brutal calls
when nature is silent 
my mind can't block you out
i hear your every word
your whisper, your shout
they pierce my heart 
allowing it to bleed
your hateful words
i do not need

so i love it when the sound of rain 
drowns you out
i can't hear you.. 
not your whisper..
not your hate..
not your shout..

College finals from Hell

Instructions: Read each question carefully. Answer all questions.
Time Limit: 4 hours.
----------------------------------------------------------------------

HISTORY
     Describe the history of the papacy from its origins to the 
present day, concentrating especially, but not exclusively, on its 
social, political, economic, religious, and philosophical impact on 
Europe, Asia, America, and Africa. Be brief, concise, and specific.
MEDICINE
    You have been provided with a razor blade, a piece of gauze, and a
bottle of Scotch. Remove your appendix. Do not suture until your work
has been inspected. You have 15 minutes.
PUBLIC SPEAKING
     Twenty-five hundred riot-crazed aborigines are storming the 
classroom.  Calm them. You may use any ancient language except Latin 
or Greek.
BIOLOGY
     Create life. Estimate the differences in subsequent human culture 
if this form of life had developed 500 million years earlier, with
special attention to its probable effect on the English parliamentary
system. Prove your thesis.
MUSIC
     Write a piano concerto. Orchestrate and perform it with flute and
drum. You will find a piano under your seat.
PSYCHOLOGY
     Based on your degree of knowledge of their works, evaluate the
emotional stability, degree of adjustment, and repressed frustrations
of each of the following: Alexander of Aphrodisias, Rameses II,
Gregory of Nicea, Hammurabi. Support your evaluations with quotations
from each man's work, making appropriate references. It is not
necessary to translate.
SOCIOLOGY
     Estimate the sociological problems which might accompany the end 
of the world. Construct an experiment to test your theory.
MANAGEMENT SCIENCE
     Define management. Define science. How do they relate? Why? 
Create a generalized algorithm to optimize all managerial decisions. 
Assuming an 1130 CPU supporting 50 terminals, each terminal to 
activate your algorithm; design the communications interface and all 
necessary control programs.
ENGINEERING
     The disassembled parts of a high-powered rifle have been placed 
in a box on your desk. You will also find an instruction manual, 
printed in Swahili. In ten minutes a hungry Bengal tiger will be 
admitted to the room. Take whatever action you feel is appropriate. Be 
prepared to justify your decision.
ECONOMICS
    Develop a realistic plan for refinancing the national debt. Trace 
the possible effects of your plan in the following areas: Cubism, the
Donatist controversy, the wave theory of light. Outline a method for
preventing these effects. Criticize this method from all possible
points of view. Point out the deficiencies in your point of view, as
demonstrated in your answer to the last question.
POLITICAL SCIENCE
     There is a red telephone on the desk beside you. Start World War 
III.  Report at length on its socio-political effects, if any.
EPISTEMOLOGY
    Take a position for or against truth. Prove the validity of your
position.
PHYSICS
    Explain the nature of matter. Include in your answer an evaluation 
of the impact of the development of mathematics on science.
PHILOSOPHY
     Sketch the development of human thought; estimate its 
significance. Compare with the development of any other kind of 
thought.
GENERAL KNOWLEDGE
     Describe in detail. Be objective and specific.
*** EXTRA CREDIT ***
    Define the universe; give three examples.

Received: (qmail 27801 invoked by uid 6000); 9 Dec 1997 06:53:13 -0000

Best parties:

(SF)
Cloud Factory's 7
Superlove 
True Love 
Grumpy Kids (man-o-man I loved that location!)
the first Sunset of the season

(SoCal)
Dune3
Best Friends
Funky Shit Happens 1.5 (well, it was fun while it lasted!)
The Legend of Sleepy Hollow

Best Records:
Jedi Knights "Catch the Break"
Uberzone "the freaks believe in beats"
Dub Pistols "Anarchy"

Best place to melt your Adidas while trying to warm your feet by the fire:
Panther Beach

Best location that I'll never get to spin at again:
Cyborganic

Best DJ product:
Stanton Groovemaster cartridge

Best sampling CD:
Pitbull Jungle (Ilio)

Best side of a mixtape:
side one of DJ Huda Hudia's "live" from Hallo-Funkin'-Ween

Best live act:
tie - Bassland & Skylab 2000

Best new techno genre that I really can't stand:
"Speed Garage"

Best toy:
tie - Vibrating Mr. Potatohead & Tomagotchi

Best waste of $100:
Dr. Freecloud's Mixing Lab parking lot sale

Hey peeps...

I just wanted to send you some shit that happened to me on saturday.  I
went to a party in oakland near homebase...don't remember the name, and
i'll tell you why!  I bought some X from this chickie at the door...
unknowingly there was something wrong w/ it.
Finally after dancing for about an hour or so... is started feeling all
fuck up, and it wasn't the usual X feelings.  I started trippin out, and
seeing wierd shit.  The music was so intense that I started going crazy,
and I had to leave... by then I figured out I was candyflipping(x/acid)
I have never done acid befor, and I was at this party by myself(dumb
idea) well any ways I left the party and walked over to tacobell where I
saw some other people leaveing... I walked up to them and told them my
situation... I was so scared... These nice party goers lived in hayward
and they drove me all the way back to SF from oakland... I don't really
remember who they were, but I will never forget what they did for me...
that is why i love this scene so much... even though we could all be
complete stranger... we are never able to turn any one down for help, as
if we are all best-friends. That night was to be an unforgettable
night... that i will always take into consideration before buying drugs
again... I'm not going to stop, but I am going to be alot more
caucious.  Please feel free to reply to this post.  I will try to go
more indepth w/ you if you write back... But I just want to thank those
people who helped me out... and I want to thank the sfrave scene for
being there when i needed you most...

Andrew
(c)andyraver

-->PS  You also mentioned the military as an equal opportunity employer in
connection with sports...er...the military is more an equal opportunity
exploiter in using any possible human fodder that might come its way, 
think about it; who runs the show?  That's right, it's an old WASP men's
country club and any form of advancement in the country club corps is
mutually exclusive to women, gays, and all token minorities that are not
useful for PR purposes.  
	Don't even get me started about sports...do you think it's fair
that top athletes and fashion models get paid more than neurosurgeons or
theoretical physicists?  But then again, it's all a question of relativity
isn't it?  Will the innerstreet kid basketball whiz ever have access to a
top university education without a sports scholarship, or how many times
have you heard the old adage of the pretty girl next door leavin
everything to go to LA or NYC to make it big but end up as a junkie
prostitute? Life is neutral, the world doesn't care, only humanity has the
gall to give everything value judgements--good and bad only exist in your
reality.


Live and let live,
M&m

On Mon, 8 Dec 1997 fish1111@pacbell.net wrote:

> Its intereting to look at how a species sexual atitudes change over time.
> There was one a time when sex was considered a sacred act.
> 
> It was done in the tantric temples as a way to celebrate and practice our
> spirituality.
> 
> Today it has degenerated into a physical act alone...often lacking
> in any spiritual aspect at all. That is why we feel shame about
> it....because we have forgotten how sacred it is.
> 
> Many feel it is time we remember those sacred ways of celebrating life.
> 
> perhaps raving is an early experiment in finding new ways to 
> revive that.
> 
> or maybe not...what do you think?
> 
> 	><{{{">  <"}}}><
> 
> 		foolish fish
> 
> 

-->  I don't like attaching the term "sacred" to things; sacredness is
purely subjective and smacks too much of religion--whether mine or yours.
Some people like empty fast emergency love; I personally don't care for it
too much, but it is sometimes fun :)  For me sex is much more significant
(and better) when I care for my partner, but who am I to reject the
occassional vagaries of karma...there have been instances when random
trysts have been...er...exceptional.  Okay, let's get one thing clear,
I am not a loose person, nor am I a walking hormone ready to jump any
passing hoochie; after examining the laws of probability as related to me,
I know what to expect under certain circumstances.  If only I was lucky or
regimented enough to only have mind boggingly soul satisfyingly epiphanous
encounters all the time, how would I be able to differentiate the good
from the mediocre?  When you make sex (a basic biological instinct) sacred
there is always the risk of taboos and personally, I feel that the US is
too Puritanical with hang-ups as it is.  The reason sex has lost its
meaning for some is because they have lost themselves along the way and
are not able or willing to see the relationship between sex and love.  Sex
does not equal love and love does not equal sex, sex may come from love
and love may come from sex, but sex cannot replace love and love cannot
replace sex; whatever the situation may be, just know where you stand and
don't blind yourself from the truth.  


Just my opinion,
M&m

and don't back down, who _do_ have the ambition. bite your tongue, mr.
fish!

At 1:32 AM -0800 12/9/97, Minh Q. Le wrote:
><snip>
>
>>"The first casualty of war is truth" --Rudyard Kipling
>
>-->This was supposed to be ironic, right?  Kipling isn't exactly my
>first choice to use concerning issues of racial diversity and acceptance.
>
>

>M&m

Interesting.  Then I guess the Constitution is suspect since it's authors
were all slave owners.  I also would suggest that Darwin be dismissed
because of his view of European superiority.  What of Ghandi?  He wasn't
exactly the great equalizer when it came to women.

The point here is that we see what we want to see.  Adn dwell on what is
important to us.  Fact is the words Kipling used are as true now as then.
When applied to Kiplings time (remember India was occupied by Britian), his
words ring especially true and ironic.

I am glad that I used the quote and will continue to do so.

Truth is truth.

Peace,
John

"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

---Messiah Wannabe <messiahw@rocketmail.com> wrote:

> i think that most clubs have that pick-up element
to them, but in
> degrees.  1015 is pretty much a full on meat market
(though different
> rooms have slightly different vibes) where you see
a lot of couples
> dirty dancing, and if people aren't dancing
together they're scoping
> unabashedly.  lots of couples leave together.


Karsten, I believe this is totally relative to the
night and to what music is being played. Go on a 
Thursday  (Anthem) I bet you won't see too many
ladies bumbin' and gridin'.


>  but that was my perception, i only went twice,
> and the scene is quite different on different nights.

Precisely, every club in the city is different on
different nights, I'm not trying to justify clubs
against raves - they are different in many respects.

 
> liquid, in my opinion, is a really nice sort of in
between.  you see
> lotsa guys n gals looking sorta spiffed up,
possibly out for some sort
> of action.  but you don't really see people
grinding on the dance
> floor, nor have i heard many complaints about
groping or pestering. 
> especially at static on tuesday - you don't have
all these people
> migrating into town to get laid.  more like people
exchanging numbers
> to call before the weekend.  plus there are
definitely some who go
> there just to dance - there are a few people i see
regularly who come
> in dressed super casually, dance for hours without
hardly speaking a
> word to anyone, then leave alone, every time.


Never been, can't comment.


> i'm still trying to figure out the end-up,
especially sunday morning. 
> lots of spun clubkidz, obviously, but i can't quite
figure the sexual
> vibe there, though i see/feel it.  maybe i'd
>understand if i was a
> meth head...

Buddy, the End-up is probably the longest standing
club in the City. I think saying,"I'd understand if I
was a meth head" is like saying I'd understand raves
if I was an E-head, don't generalize. Not everyone
there is Cracked-on and its probably one of the most
diverse crowds you will find in any club. Why do you
find the need to define it - go and have fun - if your
not having fun - don't go!
 

> finally, generally speaking, any club scene on a
weekday night is
> bound to be less overtly sexual, and probably aimed
more at an
> audience interested in the music.  liquid can get 
pretty randy on a
> friday (though it's still not as bad as 1015 on a
wed, much less a
> weekend nite), same with vsf.

True! (IMHO)

 
> this thread reminds me of the "how sexy is your
music" post, which i
> thought was hilarious and quite accurate (and
reflected in the music
> played at these clubs).
> 
> -messiah wannabe
> 
> ps. i think i just realized a big difference
between the pickup scene
> at raves and clubs.  besides sex not being the main
(or at least not
> the only) point at raves, the thing is that girls
are much more likely
> to approach you, whereas in a club usually it's the
guy who makes the
> approach. and by the girls reversing the normal
rules, they are less
> likely to get pestered alladamntime, cause the norm
is more to back
> off till a girl really lets you know she's
interested by introducing
> herself, or offering you some gum, or just walking
up and kissing you
> square on the puss.  hmmm, whadaya think, does this
sound right?  

I'm not to sure about that - give me some proof, I have
been approached equally in both environments (and have
done some of my own approaching 80).

To: sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Re: meat markets, vegetarian joints, and in between
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

oh my god, megan says that this is her....

>worst pick-up line-
>"you look so familiar... were you at (name any place with the same
>clientele as the place you're at...) last weekend?"


now i'm really freaking out, cuz sometimes when i'm out, i see someone who,
you know, looks really familiar, and i, you know, think maybe i saw them
somewhere else that i was the weekend before.... and i might actually say
to them.... "you look so familiar, were you at .....  last weekend"

and, you know, there is probably absolutely NO scamming intended, because
these are simple English words that express an idea from one human being to
another....   and it really saddens me that to some, this is a pickup line.

not to jump on you megan, since i'm sure there was some inflection
somewhere in this line that didn't translate in writing (i hope) .....  but
i do worry that we sometimes become so defensive that in fact we have put
up barriers that do not work to our benefit....

yes, clubs are often meat markets, but you don't have to play that game...

to me, when i go to a club and don't want to be bothered, i wear a hat with
a brim that shields my eyes.... works fine for me... and i dress down or
dress a little weird, and usually find that the guys who are cruising for
the girlies with the tight black pants and high-heeled black sandals and
the half-shirts and handbags and perfect lipstick and shit... these guys
know that you're not one of those girlies and they generally leave you
alone....

and if they don't leave you alone, then you look them in the eye, and you
smile and you shake your head and say in a very clear voice "no, thank you,
i'd appreciate if you'd leave me to dance alone in peace" ....  and if they
don't, then you ignore them or move to another part of the room, or if
necessary, you ask security to help you out.

because women have a right to go out without being hassled.... but
sometimes that requires speaking up for yourself and claiming your space
and your right to say no to someone's advances...

but let's not forget that there are nice people out there, too, who might
change our lives when we get to know them, and you can't get to meet them
with all your defenses up....  and some of those people might come up to
you and say "you look really familiar, weren't you at............ last
weekend?"

leslie

hello.

I'm in a band called Her Ear Eth Efact Syo Urequested.  We are an
experimental, psychedelic
avant backasswards rock and roll outfit...

                        guitars                 c   e   l   l   i   s   t
            DJ
                    drummers &
                                          his machines.

We are getting ready to release a CD, and we plan on doing a lot of shows
to promote the album,
starting in the spring.  We are looking for a dependable, serious visual
artist to light our stages with a  luminary collage.  preferably someone
who is studying or has experience with visual art.  Or at least, someone
with a Vision.

Films, slides, overhead projectors.  Fans blowing bubbles.   Mazzola and
food coloring.

We currently cannot offer pay.  We are looking for someone who wants to
create art for art's sake,   (until we all get famous and can afford to
build swimming pools inside of swimming pools.)

In the meantime,  we just want to have a good time and put on serious shows
in collaboration with you and your ideas.

We often gig  to the Burning Man crowd.  Art galleries, clubs, private
parties, usually with  people
who have a sense of the absurd.

While we are not an electronic band, at least one of us :o) is a raver, and
many of our themes are ravelike

                        p r e n a t a l    c o n s c i o u s n e s s
                                                                organized
spontaneity
        ailedehcysp
                           music as mood control

      ... and the way your head is a hat for your body,
                the way your body is a hat-stand for your head.

please check out our website, and contact me.  or spread this around to friends.

Ok fish this is absurd!!!!!!!  

Being considered equal has  more to  do with  being treated  as something
 less than equal. What I  mean by this,  women and everybody else should
be treated as you would treat yourself (even though you are a male)(I am
just kidding)  Do you think you yourself are not able to make it in a
careers that you choose, do you think that you are not intelligent enough
to vote,  do you believe that if you chose to be in a ring with large
gloves on your hands that you would not  be capable of defending yourself
against your aggressor, just because you have certain genitalia?  What
gives those that treat women as less than equal the inclination to make
those absurd generalizations for women.  The point is that people are
people and should be treated as that.  We are not your dog, your car or
your computer we are your  other half.

Those that speak out against the absurdity of sexism are not the ones
without the ambition.  Those that let others decide what they can do with
their life are the unambitious ones in my book.  Who has the right to
chose my life and what I want to do with it?  Me!


I care not that you might be a half crazed man, that is losing your hair,
that has nothing to do with you treating me with the respect any other
living being deserves.


I hope I got my point across

RLove

Subject: Sexuality and Sexism

Precedence: bulk

though i see where the foolish fish is coming from (sort of), I have to
take exception to the sweeping generality that sex has "degenerated into a
physical act alone"...  Tantra/ sacred sex is still practiced today, and
there is a great resurgence of interest in tantra throughout the western
world ....  and frankly, i don't think that most of western civilation
*ever* thought of sex as a truly sacred act.

and while i agree that raving is an amazing way to celebrate life, the
thought of reviving conscious sacred sexuality in the rave environment is
sorta funny to me...

because tantra is about focusing attention and energy to increase the
sexual energy to new levels.... but raving is about multiple sensory
stimulation that goes beyond sexual activities... it is about interacting
with many different people to create a vibe, and that cannot be done
through sex...  a room full of people practicing tantric sex would be an
entirely different vibe than a room full of people dancing...

my favorite quote  is "Dancing is a vertical expression of a horizontal
desire" .... and i while think that sex and dancing have similarities in
their power over us and our personal energy... i don't think that tantra
and raving can really overlap...

unless we had a really special chill space with a workshop going on... hmmmm...

and on the other teaser that foolish fish offered to get us arguing about
the obvious... ("equality" has nothing to do with wanting to *be* the other
person... it is about having the same *opportunities* as the other
person)...  i won't even be pulled into that silly discussion, i got enough
problems without adding losing my hair to the list....

leslie




>Its intereting to look at how a species sexual atitudes change over time.
>There was one a time when sex was considered a sacred act.
>
>It was done in the tantric temples as a way to celebrate and practice our
>spirituality.
>
>Today it has degenerated into a physical act alone...often lacking
>in any spiritual aspect at all. That is why we feel shame about
>it....because we have forgotten how sacred it is.
>
>Many feel it is time we remember those sacred ways of celebrating life.
>
>perhaps raving is an early experiment in finding new ways to
>revive that.
>
>or maybe not...what do you think?
>
>	><{{{">  <"}}}><
>
>		foolish fish

I don't think raving has anyting to do with sex.  I didn't get into it
with the chance that I might score with some cute little candy raver, I
like the music.  Actually they didn't even exist then(~'91).  I have been
to Nakita even back when it was Mecca, and it has been a meat market ever
since.  But that is a club, a true rave has tons of cool people dancing
and talking to each other.  Sharing candy or whatever and just having fun. 
Some people on E loose all interest in sex and just enjoy the sensuality
of being close to like minded people and feeling the music.  I think
raving has more to do with a closenss and family with stangers then some
kind of sexual ritual. But we are all human and most people think about
sex a shit load of the time, so I don't blame your preoccupation with this
thread. 

Razor


On Mon, 8 Dec 1997 fish1111@pacbell.net wrote:
> Its intereting to look at how a species sexual atitudes change over time.
> There was one a time when sex was considered a sacred act.
> 
> It was done in the tantric temples as a way to celebrate and practice our
> spirituality.
> 
> Today it has degenerated into a physical act alone...often lacking
> in any spiritual aspect at all. That is why we feel shame about
> it....because we have forgotten how sacred it is.
> 
> Many feel it is time we remember those sacred ways of celebrating life.
> perhaps raving is an early experiment in finding new ways to 
> revive that.
> or maybe not...what do you think?
