Leslie Ayres wrote:
> 
> oh my god, megan says that this is her....
> 
> >worst pick-up line-
> >"you look so familiar... were you at (name any place with the same
> >clientele as the place you're at...) last weekend?"
> 
> now i'm really freaking out, cuz sometimes when i'm out, i see someone who,
> you know, looks really familiar, and i, you know, think maybe i saw them
> somewhere else that i was the weekend before.... and i might actually say
> to them.... "you look so familiar, were you at .....  last weekend"
> 
> and, you know, there is probably absolutely NO scamming intended, because
> these are simple English words that express an idea from one human being to
> another....   and it really saddens me that to some, this is a pickup line.


I do this too...i have a a very poor memory and have often asked
people the same question out of honesty. I am very much in love and 
basically out of the dating game and have been for a while. Actually
its
kind of irritating when you approach someone and they automatically
assume that because you are talking to them that I want to have sex
with them. I rememeber a time recently where i saw a woman at a rave
and knew she looked familiar but couldnt remember where from so after
watching her for a while trying to remember i went over and asked 
using the above line. She looked at me like i was a piece of scum
for saying that. Over the coarse of the day i kept running into
her and she kept giving me those wierd looks. Finally i remembered
and went up and told her. Then she completely changed and gave me 
a big, big hug and every thing was fine and we had a nice conversation.

Of course im very aware that "dont i know you from somewhere'
is a very old and silly pickup line but i still use it on both 
women and men not as a pickup but as an honest statement.
If anyone can suggest a better way of saying that i would love to hear
it so i wont embarass myself too much anymore.

and just as a side note,since i have had this situation arise
several times at partys and online...im not dating or even looking
so dont assume that just because im talking to you that 
im trying to hit on you.

happy holidays all

	><{{{"> <"}}}><

		foolish fish

Leslie Ayres wrote:
> 
> though i see where the foolish fish is coming from (sort of), I have to
> take exception to the sweeping generality that sex has "degenerated into a
> physical act alone"...  Tantra/ sacred sex is still practiced today, and
> there is a great resurgence of interest in tantra throughout the western
> world ....  and frankly, i don't think that most of western civilation
> *ever* thought of sex as a truly sacred act.

With all due respect i feel like you dont quite understand where im coming
from. I always have a problem explaining some of my less mainstream ideas
and often wind up in trouble like this or the blue angels post.
Yes the statement was a generalization but let me ask you this
to clarify. IF i come up to you and tell you that i want
to make love with you...is your first interpretaion of that
question that i want physical intercourse or that i want 
have a spiritual connection with you.? Most people would think
of genital sex. Tantra is a spiritual act that doesnt even
require you to touch another person. 

tantra as it is being praticed today in western society and
now by these newagers is very different from what was practiced
in the goddess societies. So i agree that western society
has never treated sex as sacred.

> 
> and while i agree that raving is an amazing way to celebrate life, the
> thought of reviving conscious sacred sexuality in the rave environment is
> sorta funny to me...

Again i agree, sort of.
I think that a new way of imtimate relating is being explored
at raves, sometimes. I feel that we as a society have lost
many things that are important to life like the tribal
rituals for example. I think people are looking for 
ways to revive some of what we have lost yet do it
in a way that fits today.
Dancing with the devine such as the sufis or in the goddess
temples is very similar to raves and i know many who
believe they were part of the goddess societies that dance
at raves because it produces that same experiences of the ancient
temples. But as you say raves and tantric temples are probably
not the best mix...but there are some connections there.

> 
> because tantra is about focusing attention and energy to increase the
> sexual energy to new levels.... but raving is about multiple sensory
> stimulation that goes beyond sexual activities... it is about interacting
> with many different people to create a vibe, and that cannot be done
> through sex...  a room full of people practicing tantric sex would be an
> entirely different vibe than a room full of people dancing...


Actually in real tantra a room full of dancing people is exactly
what you have. Tantra does not always include intercourse. And
actually the vibe is very similar if the rave is about group 
conciousness and becoming one with something larger. Tantra 
is also a "multiple sensory stimulation that goes beyond
sexual activities" and it is sometimes "about interacting
with many different peole to create a vibe" ( not nessesarily sexual)
If you alter your sentence a little...you could say "raving
is about focusing attention and energy to increase the
 energy to new levels"


> and on the other teaser that foolish fish offered to get us arguing about
> the obvious... ("equality" has nothing to do with wanting to *be* the other
> person... it is about having the same *opportunities* as the other
> person)... 

ok i guess i have to explain this one too.

Yes equal opportunities for everyone...i agree.
That post was have serious...i thought that was clear, guess not.
 
I have always thought that people liked to be treated with respect
and like intelligent sane people. 
Based on the response to my post it appears that some women 
here would prefer to be treated as crazy and lacking in intelligence
because that is how i am treated and they want equal treatment.
SO now im confused on this one =)

I believe that women and men are different and need to be treated
differently. I havent quite worked out exactly what that means
because i do believe that we all deserve equal treatment
and respect but how do we do that if we are different?

Hi all!  ]=}


 One of my big gripes about the Space Children flyers IS that BM is a 
non-commercial arts festival. No sponsership by Coors and the ilk is 
allowed. Having people advertise a commercial event (ie Space Children) 
is totally against what many are trying to experience at BM. Creativity 
and human surrealism without commercials. It is a noble cause which (I 
feel) deserves full support from artists. I know I walked away feeling 
more inspired and charged up than i have in a  l o n g  time.

Over the last couple of months I've been meaning to post about something.
I'm trying to find a particular person that used to call a BBS I ran in
the past. He may or may not be on the list but I thought it wouldn't hurt
to post about it. You see I used to run a BBS called "The Infinity
Gauntlet" in Martinez back in the early late 80s/early 90s... and on this
BBS I had a message base topic about raving and techno. I believe I called
it "Tekno". Well, to make a long story short there was a guy who called
and posted a lot, who was active in the rave scene around here. I'd like
to locate this guy just to say "what's up" and to meet in person. Just a
little blast from the past.... I shut the board down pretty ubruptly for
reasons I'm not going to go into here.... but if you're this person please
e-mail me....   pretty vague post but if you're on here you'll know what

From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Re: Sexuality and Sexism
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

>Yes the statement was a generalization but let me ask you this
>to clarify. IF i come up to you and tell you that i want
>to make love with you...is your first interpretaion of that
>question that i want physical intercourse or that i want
>have a spiritual connection with you.? Most people would think
>of genital sex. Tantra is a spiritual act that doesnt even
>require you to touch another person.

most people would think of what you call "genital sex" because in our
english language "make love" is a phrase that is used to mean "have sex"
(with some semantic differentiation, of course, and this phrase is chosen
to usually describe a more "connected" and "love-oriented" act of sex)....

therefore my thinking you mean you want to have physical sex is completely
understandable and expected... and that is separate from whether i think
you also meant to include a spiritual connection (which, i believe, is
present in most consenting sex)...

and if you i knew that you were a student of tantra (many of my friends are
both students and teachers of tantra), i would *still* assume you meant
physical sex.... tantra is *also* a physical act .... tantra is NOT simply
a spiritual practice, it can be tied in very real ways to the expansion of
physical sexual practice and energy.... and it's physical aspects are,
well, very cool.

>tantra as it is being praticed today in western society and
>now by these newagers is very different from what was practiced
>in the goddess societies. So i agree that western society
>has never treated sex as sacred.

i think there's a bit of a non sequiter here (your first sentence does not
support your conclusion).

in my reality, i *AM* a member of western society, and of the "new age" of
western society, my experiences are of that realm... i personally do not
feel connected to the "goddess" societies, I feel connected to the society
in which i live... and i integrate the philosophies of many past societies
into my world view.... that's sort of what "new age" is to me... a point
where we have information and teachings from many cultures and practices,
and are working to integrate those into a different way of viewing the
world...  i get a little tired of phrases like "these newagers" that seem
to dismiss the transformational power of having thousands and millions of
people integrate ancient and/or metaphysical thoughts and beliefs into
their daily lives.... thank god for "these newagers" I say, because they're
changing how modern society views the world.


>Dancing with the devine such as the sufis or in the goddess
>temples is very similar to raves and i know many who
>believe they were part of the goddess societies that dance
>at raves because it produces that same experiences of the ancient
>temples. But as you say raves and tantric temples are probably
>not the best mix...but there are some connections there.


i agree that dancing is definitely a way to reach those levels and
experiences... that is especially clear in the psytrance community, where
you often see people spinning for long periods of time...

>.you could say "raving
>is about focusing attention and energy to increase the
> energy to new levels"

true... and i do see the commonality in process...


>ok i guess i have to explain this one too.
>Yes equal opportunities for everyone...i agree.
>That post was have serious...i thought that was clear, guess not.
>
>I have always thought that people liked to be treated with respect
>and like intelligent sane people.
>Based on the response to my post it appears that some women
>here would prefer to be treated as crazy and lacking in intelligence
>because that is how i am treated and they want equal treatment.
>SO now im confused on this one =)

duane, you made a "half-serious" remark.... (which half do you mean??) ...
but maybe it would be helpful to stop and see it from the other
perspective... because you know that women aren't saying they want to be
treated as crazy and lacking in intelligence... (though women are often
treated as moody, told "don't worry your little head about it," asked if
they have pms when they're angry about something, ignored when making
certain decisions, gawked at in public... things that you probably have
never experienced in this specific way, because these are things that
happen purely and simply because one is a woman)

issues of sexual equality aren't about you, they're about everyone.... and
so an example that uses just you, while cute and humorous, has little to do
with the reality that women are not guaranteed equal treatment, and that is
wrong.  equal access and equal rights FOR EVERYONE (even funny old fish who
are losing their hair) is an important thing, and though that doesn't mean
we can't ever make jokes about it, it does mean that what may seem
half-funny to you may not seem so funny to others who are looking from the
other side of that fence.

>I believe that women and men are different and need to be treated
>differently. I havent quite worked out exactly what that means
>because i do believe that we all deserve equal treatment
>and respect but how do we do that if we are different?

we *are* all different... and I do believe that in certain ways, women *in
general* are different from men *in general*.... but men and women "need to
be treated differently?"  .... come on, get over it, dude.

you want to treat individuals differently depending on who they are and
what they are all about?  that is wonderful, i think that's how it should
be.  However, if you are saying that I should be treated in a certain way
(good, bad or indifferent) simply because of my sex, that is patently
ridiculous, and sorry, and it ain't even 10 percent funny.

Believing that men *should* be one way and women *should* be another is a
trap and a cage... you can escape it, but you first have to acknowledge
that it's there.

Unless of course, you're really talking about physical tantric sex, in
which case one *would* treat me differently than a man, being as i have the
girlie parts and all.

leslie

Michael H Guddal wrote:
> 
> I don't think raving has anyting to do with sex.  I didn't get into it
> with the chance that I might score with some cute little candy raver, I
> like the music.  Actually they didn't even exist then(~'91).  I have been
> to Nakita even back when it was Mecca, and it has been a meat market ever
> since.  But that is a club, a true rave has tons of cool people dancing
> and talking to each other.  Sharing candy or whatever and just having fun.


I tend to agree with most of this but am wondering about the 
connections between raving and sex. While my personal preference
are the raves you describe that are not about "finding a cute
guy or some little raver chick"

However there is definately an element of sexuallity in raves
which some like and some dont. And we have been talking
more about sex than raves on sfraves for the past two weeks.

I really like the fact that the best raves(my taste) are ones where 
people are there for something besides getting laid, i know
that others really prefer raves where there is more sexaul freedom
and there is room for both i think.

This is another one of those things im still confused about
with raves...just what is sexualities place. I see some
who only go to find that special guy or girl and some
who go for other reasons. I havent really made up my mind
on this yet so i appreciate those that have shared their
opinions.

>now i'm really freaking out, cuz sometimes when i'm out, i see someone who,
>you know, looks really familiar, and i, you know, think maybe i saw them
>somewhere else that i was the weekend before.... and i might actually say
>to them.... "you look so familiar, were you at .....  last weekend"

leslie... honestly, i was going to add to that post that it's a complete
catch 22; i have also had that experience as well!   seeing someone that
you honestly think looks familiar... and i have to laugh at the fact!  How
can i then judge someone who says that to me? well, because the likely hood
of me truly looking familiar to the amount of people who approach me with
that query has to be relatively low... in no exaggeration- i've had about 7
different people ask me this question in the last 6 months!  and it usually
doesn't seem like a sincere question... it always has that 'pick-up line
sound'  you know what i mean? i think a lot of it has to do with scene
too... this has happened mostly at clubs/bars,  not raves/ugs/on the
street.  i usually comes with the whole meat market vibe...  
maybe i just have a really familiar face? possibly...  it just seems to
happen way too frequently!

>yes, clubs are often meat markets, but you don't have to play that game...
>
>to me, when i go to a club and don't want to be bothered, i wear a hat with
>a brim that shields my eyes.... works fine for me... and i dress down or
>dress a little weird, and usually find that the guys who are cruising for
>the girlies with the tight black pants and high-heeled black sandals and
>the half-shirts and handbags and perfect lipstick and shit... 
that's one great way of dealing with that situation... but personally i
don't want to dress down just i so don't get hit on... if i'm going to go
out to a club, a rave, the supermarket, or the gym...i'm going to dress how
i want to dress. 
and sometime i do actually go out to meet people!   yeah- i know that those
aren't the best places to meet someone... but why not???  i LOVE dancing
and music! and i'd love to meet someone else who loves that sort of thing
like i do...  BUT it's not meeting people that's the problem... it's the
insincere bullshit,  the person with 50 hands, or the person who keeps
blowing on your neck! it's disgusting, annoying, and rude! and i'm not
asking or signaling for any of that!  all i ask for is a little respect...
not only as a woman, but as another human being.

>
>because women have a right to go out without being hassled.... but
>sometimes that requires speaking up for yourself and claiming your space
>and your right to say no to someone's advances...
Here, Here!


>but let's not forget that there are nice people out there, too, who might
>change our lives when we get to know them, and you can't get to meet them
>with all your defenses up....  and some of those people might come up to
>you and say "you look really familiar, weren't you at............ last
>weekend?"
:)
yeah- i usually give people the benefit of the doubt... but that's gotten
me into some unusual situations.  i try to go with my intuition, because
some people just give off bad vibes!  maybe it's unjust to be depending on
a 7th sense... but what else is there to go on?  
Ed Bundy -seemed- like a really nice guy- to lots of different types of
girls... go figure?
you can never be too careful.  i'd rather miss out on the love of my life,
then end up a victim.

actually me favorite pick up line:
"how would you two american foxes with large american breasts,  like to
hang out with two swingin', wild and crazy guys?"

Leslie Ayres wrote:

> most people would think of what you call "genital sex" because in our
> english language "make love" is a phrase that is used to mean "have sex"
> (with some semantic differentiation, of course, and this phrase is chosen
> to usually describe a more "connected" and "love-oriented" act of sex)....
> therefore my thinking you mean you want to have physical sex is completely
> understandable and expected... and that is separate from whether i think
> you also meant to include a spiritual connection (which, i believe, is
> present in most consenting sex)...

that was exactly the point i was trying to make.
That sex has degenerated into a physical act. In our culture
making love is a phrase used to mean have sex. It used to mean more.
And  many people engage in quickies that have nothing to do 
with spirituality, although one could argue that everything is spiritual.


>  tantra is NOT simply
> a spiritual practice, it can be tied in very real ways to the expansion of
> physical sexual practice and energy.... and it's physical aspects are,
> well, very cool.

 Yes tantra can and usually includes the physical but not always.


> 
> >tantra as it is being praticed today in western society and
> >now by these newagers is very different from what was practiced
> >in the goddess societies. So i agree that western society
> >has never treated sex as sacred.
> 
> i think there's a bit of a non sequiter here (your first sentence does not
> support your conclusion).

Dang even when i agree with you you disagree =)



> i get a little tired of phrases like "these newagers" that seem
> to dismiss the transformational power of having thousands and millions of
> people integrate ancient and/or metaphysical thoughts and beliefs into
> their daily lives.... thank god for "these newagers" I say, because they're
> changing how modern society views the world.

there is nothing new about the new age...just new packaging of old ideas
unless we are lost in semantic misunderstandings again? I was a new ager
for years and moved onto what i consider to be really new and different.


> 
> >I believe that women and men are different and need to be treated
> >differently. I havent quite worked out exactly what that means
> >because i do believe that we all deserve equal treatment
> >and respect but how do we do that if we are different?
> 
> we *are* all different... and I do believe that in certain ways, women *in
> general* are different from men *in general*.... but men and women "need to
> be treated differently?"  .... come on, get over it, dude.

get over what? Do women need different treatment when they are pregnant
or should we treat them like a man and expect them to be at 
work like every one else? I think in some situations women need
special treatment because of there gender such as pregnancy.
ANd the same can be said of men in certain situation. 
My point to all of this is that equal is not as simple as it sounds.
Because there are major differences in women and men you cant
make blanket statements that we all need to be treated the same.
Things like equal pay and equal rights are pretty obvious but
i feel we need to look at our differences also if we are going to create
a society where everyones need are met.
> 

>  However, if you are saying that I should be treated in a certain way
> (good, bad or indifferent) simply because of my sex, that is patently
> ridiculous, and sorry, and it ain't even 10 percent funny.

No that is not what i was saying.

> 
> Believing that men *should* be one way and women *should* be another is a
> trap and a cage... you can escape it, but you first have to acknowledge
> that it's there.
> 
> Unless of course, you're really talking about physical tantric sex, in
> which case one *would* treat me differently than a man, being as i have the
> girlie parts and all.

now put those last two statements together and you might understand what im 
saying. In some situations we need different treatment(pregnancy and sex for 
example) 
and in some we need 
equal( such as pay and respect)
Im just trying to figure it all out.

megan made some good points...

.(snippets).......

>maybe i just have a really familiar face? possibly...  it just seems to
>happen way too frequently!

>i don't want to dress down just i so don't get hit on... if i'm going to go
>out to a club, a rave, the supermarket, or the gym...i'm going to dress how
>i want to dress.

>it's the insincere bullshit,  the person with 50 hands, or the person who
>keeps
>blowing on your neck! it's disgusting, annoying, and rude! and i'm not
>asking or signaling for any of that!  all i ask for is a little respect...
>not only as a woman, but as another human being.

.(snip)...................

i fully agree... and i know that we do develop a sixth sense of who is
being genuine and who is not (this goes back to the age and maturity
theme... the more experience a person has in dealing in the world, the
faster that he or she can accurately read a situation intuitively)...

and i think that someone following you around, or blowing on your neck,
touching you or whatever, is completely out of line...  and i believe that
women MUST LEARN to speak up for themselves... to turn and face the
harrasser and say "do not do that, stop it now" and do that without
embarrassment or timidity... because you have a right to protect your
personal space.

if someone is hassling you, then stand up for yourself....  (and still keep
in mind that even the obnoxious people will be grateful if you don't
publicly embarrass them.... maybe there's a way to say what you need to and
still educate them in the process)...

>yeah- i usually give people the benefit of the doubt... but that's gotten
>me into some unusual situations.  i try to go with my intuition, because
>some people just give off bad vibes!  maybe it's unjust to be depending on
>a 7th sense... but what else is there to go on?
>Ed Bundy -seemed- like a really nice guy- to lots of different types of
>girls... go figure?

i think you mean Ted Bundy.... (for a second there, i was thinking of Al
Bundy, and wondering which girls thought he was nice guy!  ;^) .... and in
cases of true danger, i agree that you must err on the side of caution...
which  means don't go home with strangers, don't hitchhike, and listen to
your intuition...

but don't let it make you suspect everyone you meet and color how you
perceive the world you live in... because chances are that the people
you're going to be meeting are not serial killers...

>you can never be too careful.  i'd rather miss out on the love of my life,
>then end up a victim.

but it doesn't have to be all or nothing... there is a huge middle ground
here... being trusting without being naive, being respectful without being
disrespected, and being open without being foolish.

and i would hope that when the love of your life comes up and says "have we
met before, you look familiar" ... your intuition will tell you that it's
coming from someone you need to know, and you hopefully haven't let the
annoying clubster mackers make you so cynical and distrustful that you blow
him off.....  because i think it's better to not be victimized by fear than
to miss the love of your life.

maybe i'm just a romantic at heart.

leslie

STATIC

I will most likely be wearing a Detroit Red Wings jersey (white w/
red trim) and #19 and "Yzerman" on the back.

NEW YEARS QUANDARY

New Years Resolution is going on new years, and looks good (Derrick
May, Spacetime Continuum, Astral Matrix, Funky TT, etc.), but it's 
also co-sponsored by Spacechildren (Spice Children?), and everything
I've ever heard about them (this list and elsewhere) makes it sound
like they're total hacks in it for the money only.  I guess the 
question here is whether or not to take the big chance on this party
or find elsewhere to celebrate.  Ideas?

Cheers,
Steve.

there is a big difference between sensuality and sex or sexuality.  I
think raves are very sensualy, if sex comes from it that is ok.  With me
that is usually days down the road or back at my place and not on the spot
it would be too anticlimatic. At a rave I want to experience the person's
mind and play with the atmosphere.  If people at a rave dropped down and
had sex right next to me I might laugh and just go on with whatever I was
doing, to each their own.  But over all I think sensuality has a much
bigger palce at a rave then sex.

Razor 


On Tue, 9 Dec 1997 fish1111@pacbell.net wrote:

> Michael H Guddal wrote:
> > 
> > I don't think raving has anyting to do with sex.  I didn't get into it
> > with the chance that I might score with some cute little candy raver, I
> > like the music.  Actually they didn't even exist then(~'91).  I have been
> > to Nakita even back when it was Mecca, and it has been a meat market ever
> > since.  But that is a club, a true rave has tons of cool people dancing
> > and talking to each other.  Sharing candy or whatever and just having fun.
> 
> 
> I tend to agree with most of this but am wondering about the 
> connections between raving and sex. While my personal preference
> are the raves you describe that are not about "finding a cute
> guy or some little raver chick"
> 
> However there is definately an element of sexuallity in raves
> which some like and some dont. And we have been talking
> more about sex than raves on sfraves for the past two weeks.
> 
> I really like the fact that the best raves(my taste) are ones where 
> people are there for something besides getting laid, i know
> that others really prefer raves where there is more sexaul freedom
> and there is room for both i think.
> 
> This is another one of those things im still confused about
> with raves...just what is sexualities place. I see some
> who only go to find that special guy or girl and some
> who go for other reasons. I havent really made up my mind
> on this yet so i appreciate those that have shared their
> opinions.

Foolish Fish wrote:


Its intereting to look at how a species sexual atitudes change over time.
There was one a time when sex was considered a sacred act.

It was done in the tantric temples as a way to celebrate and practice our
spirituality.

Today it has degenerated into a physical act alone...often lacking
in any spiritual aspect at all. That is why we feel shame about
it....because we have forgotten how sacred it is.

Many feel it is time we remember those sacred ways of celebrating life.

perhaps raving is an early experiment in finding new ways to
revive that.


Many feel it is time we remember those sacred ways of celebrating life.

perhaps raving is an early experiment in finding new ways to
revive that.

or maybe not...what do you think?

I think that sex lies within the eye of the individual.
I Personally feel that sex can be EITHER physical,
sacred, or flat out Kinky.  The relationship that you
have with a person is directly reflected through the 
intimate moments that you have.  

Those are my thoughts and that's about it folks


MOlly

Mushiness ahead... :)

Sex is "Physical", Making love is "Spiritual" and "Deeply Emotional". This
is where I define the two. *Making love* is what it's all about. The
connection you make with the person you love. The way that physical
world and time fades away,.. and all that matters is the two of you as
you become one. Your human eyes are shut, your spiritual eyes are open 
to the beauties within yourself and the other person. You're both there for 
eachother as well as for yourselves. You're thinking of the other person's
feelings and how to make them reach higher levels of pleasure..... this
is making love. Sex is getting off, anyone can have sex, but only special 
people can trully make love. This is my opinion... and why I don't pick up 
people from clubs, raves, etc. If you want to see the true meaning you
have to respect yourself, the other person and everything that you both
stand for. Take the time to know the person and see how beautiful they
truly are. Then when you reach the point at which you want to take it to
that level it will be so beautiful... nothing on Earth compares to this.
"Let it happen naturally".. what's the rush??.. if you really care for
that person there is no need to hurry... appreciate them and everything
about them....  

Falling asleep with the one one you love (all warm and cuddly) while
"making spoons"(as Favian from Pulp Fiction put it) is the greatest
Ecastcy you could ever feel.....   sigh. :)

Byroni

ps. The sky looks so beautiful today....... no smog... thanks El Nino.

> 
> Interesting.  Then I guess the Constitution is suspect since it's authors
> were all slave owners.  I also would suggest that Darwin be dismissed
> because of his view of European superiority.  What of Ghandi?  He wasn't
> exactly the great equalizer when it came to women.

-->The constitution was originally meant to apply to land owning white
male citizens of the US only, excluding women, slaves, and indentured
servants--why do you think the whole equal rights and feminist movements
began; because the interpretations of the constitution were so narrow.
That's why amendments were passed; to make the document more applicable to
modern views.  There is still debate concerning interpretations of certain
passages of the constitution as the national rifle association likes to
point out (e.g. the gun ownership clause for national defense).  The
constitution is only a figurehead, it has changed and evolved so much over
the passage of time that it really isn't what it was before.  And like I
said, its original purpose and drafting was meant to protect the interests
of the American elite.
	Yes, Darwin is suspect; not to mention Cpt. Cook, Columbus, and
Vasco de Gamma in "discovering" new worlds inhabited by "savages". How's
that for an equalizer?  In the same vein, Nazi experiments on
concentration camp victims has advanced medical knowledge dramatically
from what it was before (in respect to pre-WWII medical knowledge); yeah
you can pick and choose were you get your facts from and what you want to
see, just be sure to realize that sometimes the facts aren't as sterile
and clean as they appear--the marks of a good indoctrination program.

M&m

email's a tough one. speaking for myself, i often read very quickly, and
respond just as quickly. not that this is a good thing. it's also hard to
see/read nuances that the voice and facial expression usually communicate.
add the two together - you're more than likely to get misunderstood. the
thing about email, too, tho is that it's (at least for me) just as easy to
see where i've gone wrong (ie flamorama) and just as easy to correct
myself.

-->Sorry about the confusion B.A., but I meant it as a reply to John Lee's
post; I just replied to the post and didn't notice it was addressed to you
until too late.  
	I don't subscribe to the whole "whitey is out to get you"
mentality.  People are people and people tend to congegrate with people
sharing similar traits; whether it be America, Germany, or Japan,
outsiders will have more challenges to face than the endemic population in
reaching success.  From personal experience, being different is difficult
and you have to be damn strong to withstand all the bullshit that comes
with it.  I might as well be speaking about skin color, but I am talking
about something as inoxious as hair color; I have always followed my own
pjerogative in issues of image...and when I had technicolor hair people
thought I was a social deviant and anything I had to say was meaningless,
not to mention that my intelligence was questionable. I still keep my own
counsel about my issues of identity, and I periodically change chameleon
colors, but I have learned how people think, and I realize how valuable my
self-integrity really is...no matter what other people say.


:)
M&m

chivalry out the window? in a way, i see chivalry as a high respect for a
woman. you know, i think it's this country. european women (check out the
french) can be extremely powerful, command respect, and yet still be a
_woman_ - sexy, strong, intelligent, beautiful - and turns heads for all of
those reasons. i don't see that as hypocritical at all. just as you show
respect for an elder differently than you might a colleague, you can show
respect differently for women than you would for a man. it's also
situational. in any case, i don't see chivalry as being sexist. (but i
don't see placing a hand on my ass as being chivalrous, either... :P) what
is it they say - celebrate diversity - no shit. and respect it. has
_nothing_ to do with equal rights.

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Dec 10 01:34:28 1997

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 10 Dec 1997 01:34:26 -0000
Received: (from radon@localhost) by kzsu.Stanford.EDU (8.8.5/8.6.9) id RAA11235; Tue, 9 Dec 1997 17:33:26 -0800 (PST)
Date: Tue, 9 Dec 1997 17:33:25 -0800 (PST)
From: dj radon <radon@kzsu.Stanford.EDU>
To: sfravers <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: NRR: my weekend in vegas
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.971209172435.11127A-100000@kzsu.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

[preface: every year my dad and his friends go to Las Vegas for the 
National Finals Rodeo. This year they invited me. This is highly NRR, 
although I did try go clubbing, as discussed below]

So, Las Vegas.

I think Las Vegas is absolutely amazing. It's so impressively American to 
take a desolated stretch of sand and gravel, and turn it into a 
+destination+ for all types of people, and to turn it into one of the 
most economically vibrant cities in the world despite having no natural 
resources. Not to mention turning it into an eeriliy beautiful place 
despite having very little natural beauty.

On Saturday night I went to the National Finals Rodeo (which is the 
grand puba of rodeos, held every year in UNLV's basketball stadium) with 
my dad, uncle Steve, and four of their wanna-be-cowboy friends/business 
associatess from Alberta. Everybody was pretty drunk, and all seven of us 
crammed into a rental car, everyone making jokes about each others' 
wives/sexual dysfunctions, and everyone giving my dad a hard time 
about his driving.

Got to the rodeo. everybody was wearing a comboy hat (save me,  who 
borrowed a cowboy shirt to try to fit in, but my jenkos 
were a giveaway, and would actually come back to haunt me again later 
that same night). The rodeo was rad, a lot like a circus, in that 
it was men doing tricks and battling animals. Except of course there was 
a shiny new belt buckle in it for the most impressive performances.

Racially poignant note: the only black man I saw the whole night was the 
rodeo clown in the barrel, who's responsible for distracting the steers 
during the bronc-riding competition (that's the one where there's lots of 
cowboys gored and trampled). hmmm......

After the rodeo, we went to some sort of rodeo awards ceremony at the 
Gold Coast Casino... lots of twenty-somethings. The most surprising thing 
to me was that the women wore reasonable and often really sexy clothes, 
but most also had big golden belt buckles. Including the ladies at the 
table next to us. Talk about strange parity: at one table a cute, 
21-year-old cowgirl, her mom and her mom's trashy friend, and right next 
door, me, my dad, and my dad's crazy 
gentleman/redneck/comedian/hard-drinking/50-year-old friend, this guy 
Laverne. Laverne is totally flirting with the trashy friend, and gets her 
two-stepping out on the dance floor, and it's the most natural thing in 
the world that I need to ask the cute cowgirl to dance too, except I 
haven't two-stepped in years, so I have to phrase it in terms of "will 
you teach me to dance like that". 

Of course, I have a natural groove-on, so in no time we're swirling 
through the crowd of cow folk, my jenkos sailing gracefully through the 
sea of uber-tight Wranglers (official sponsor of the NFR, of course).

Laverne and I, lady killers that we are, wore out all the competition. By 
4:30am my dad, uncle, their friends, and pretty much everyone else had 
cleared out. Unfortunately, Laverne, with his continual stream of 
hand-kissing and off-color jokes, also wore out the ladies, and so we 
were left listening to an Albertan country band in the wee hours.

(digression: The steel guitair is the most amazing instrument in the 
world. I remember me and all my friends used to make fun of it in high 
school because it had so many "hick" associations. I've now decided that 
it's just waiting to be repurposed for drum 'n' bass glory.)

On my way into town from the airport, the taxi driver told me the _only_ 
club in Vegas was at the Rio, so Laverne and I staggered over there. 
Totally different scene, really cosmopolitan club fashions. We got to the 
door, and of course, my "loose pants" violated the dress code, and they 
wouldn't let me in. Bastards. I wonder if a "no-loose-pants" rule is 
specifically aimed at ravers? I mean, who else wears loose pants?

Anyhow, that was pretty much my trip. Came back to the hotel at day-break, 
slept a couple hours, and then jetted back to SFO. 

-cowboy radon

ps. anyone know of the existence of a rave scene in Nevada? (meant to ask 
that before I went, but I'm still curious...)

Foolish Fish wrote:
> get over what? Do women need different treatment when they are pregnant
> or should we treat them like a man and expect them to be at 
> work like every one else? I think in some situations women need
> special treatment because of there gender such as pregnancy.
> ANd the same can be said of men in certain situation. 
> My point to all of this is that equal is not as simple as it sounds.
> Because there are major differences in women and men you cant
> make blanket statements that we all need to be treated the same.
> Things like equal pay and equal rights are pretty obvious but
> i feel we need to look at our differences also if we are going to create
> a society where everyones need are met.

Being pregnant is something that during early phases of it, even the woman
is often unsure.  People used to use the "monthly visitor" & pregnancy
arguements to keep women out of the workplace or assert differences
between the sexes to warrant other unequal treatment...  get wise. You're
spouting the party line as fed to us by the people we inherited this
bullshit from.

Pregnancy is NOT part of being a woman, it is part of being a biological
mother, it is an option, and in modern society a condition of choice... 
so treating all women differently because some might CHOOSE to get
pregnant is pretty damn backwards.  My mother, 2 pregnancies included, has
probably taken less sick days off than most people in her field of work,
and fought uphill all the way to get where she is, because it's so easy
for a sexist VP to decide between mommaW and Mr. Man when that critical
management position opens up and they're mumbling in the urinal stalls
about mommaW taking off for maternity leave or some other "crazy woman
thing" (eventually, years later, she got it, and hasn't let anyone down,
cause she's my mom, and she rocks).

We just had a programmer work until the day she went into labor, and the
child was like, turbo healthy (despite the "where is the water going to
break" office betting pool). She and her husband are now taking turns
staying home with the baby, both raising what should be a most loved and
cared for opportunity for the growth of a bright, strong individual, just
like his parents.  And, thanks to her career choice of being a coder, we
still get work from her when she's at home, so she's still getting paid
the same, and baby gets to play with mommy OR daddy (depending on the day)
and get held and all that good stuff.

To advance, sometimes we need to let go of the old ideas... 

Peace,
AndyW

p.s. I think I understand what you meant about diversity and differences,
I wouldn't yell "go long" and throw her a soda from the lunch truck, or
ask her to play softball in the company tournament this year, but I wanted
to point out that even being pregnant can have a negligible effect on job
performance in many fields, or a great majority of the other metrics we
use to establish personal worth in modern society.  Without uniformity we
cannot be equal in every aspect, but we should be given equal opportunity
and not base our perception of a set on the attributes of a subset (i.e.
using pregnant women to make arguements about women in general). 
     If PLUR is what the scene is about, which letter stands for Music?

---blkadder@value.net wrote:

> > mutually exclusive to women, gays, and all token minorities that
are not
> > useful for PR purposes.  
> 
> Perhaps you have me confused with someone else. I never mentioned
any such
> thing, and yes, whitey is out to get you. 
> 

you know, being a white male from the south, i have to admit - and it
pains me to say this because it's not at all what i'm about - but yes
indeed, whitey _is_ out to get you.  i heard shit all the time from
average joe whiteguys that made me cringe.  and i don't really think
it's all that different outside of the south. 

of course, the flip side to this is that, despite this sad fact, the
u.s. has to be one of the least racist places in the entire world.  i
mean, in india, if you look hard enough, you can tell what kind of job
a person has just by looking at their facial structure and the subtle
differences in skin shade - it's that segregated (at least that's what
i perceived after nearly a year there).  whereas the u.s. must have
been one of, if not _the_ first place in the world to pass something
like the civil rights act (not to mention women's suffrage).  imagine,
a democratically elected government passing a law that made racism
_illegal_.  what a grand concept!  i'd venture to say it's somewhat
unique to this country.  and while it doesn't surprise me that the
problem hasn't been solved in the last 30 years, i have great hopes
that the ideal will be realized one day.

i see it this way - if you grew up say, maybe 500 years ago, and you
saw a group of people approaching with even slightly different facial
features than you, well, chances were pretty good they were going to
try to kill you.  and even if they weren't, you needed to keep your
guard up, the bottom line was they were from another tribe.  this is a
broad generalization, and i know some of you could point out
exceptions etc, but i honestly believe that this was the reality for
most people when dealing with people of other races.  so basically, i
think fear of other races goes back very deeply into just about
everyone's culture, perhaps to the point of instinct.

i mean, in europe 50 years ago french were still killing germans were
still killing english were still killing over RACE (even though they
were all white).  meanwhile in america, does anyone _really_ still
give a shit if your parents were italian or irish or french german
whatever?  hell most of us are all racially mixed mutts at this point.
 and i see the same thing continuing to happen with immigrants
entering the country now, even though most of them aren't european.

my country strikes me as a grand experiment at this point - take
humans of all different races, people who since they first became
different have been warring with each other, and stick 'em in the same
country.  preferably in the same neighborhood.  can we all get along? 
will we all one day truly melt together in one big pot?  personally i
think it's inevitable - it's harder to hate someone when you see them
and talk to them every day. 

it obviously hasn't happened yet.  but i think discussions like these
are an integral part of the process.

christ i should write speeches.  this sounds like something the
valedictorian would read at his graduation.  oh well, i've been
reading the invisible man and this stuff has been on my mind...

-messiah wannabe

wow, glad to know i'm not the only one out there with SEX on my mind...

hmmmm, so many SEX discussions i hardly know where to start.  

tantric SEX and SEXy ravers...  well, i see a big connection here. 
for centuries the christian church has been telling us that dancing
was evil.  it's been frowned on in this culture for ages.  it's low,
uncultured, dirty.  well thankfully we're (western culture) beginning
to discover that dancing is actually lots of fun.  the more the
better, all night long.  and as we loose our hangups about dancing we
begin to realize that its not dirty at all.  in fact, it can be quite
spiritual.  it can change your life.  it can make you SEE GOD. 
especially if you're candyflipping.  well, the same goes for SEX.

and i think i see this realization reflected in raver culture as well.
 you can't deny that there's a big sexy vibe at a lot of raves (and
i'm not just saying that cause of the ginseng) people kissing hugging
necking speakerhumping massaging dancing fucking...  i think all those
tight little sexy outfits girls wear reflect a celebration of SEX. 
it's ok to be SEXy, you don't have to hide it.  it's ok to walk up and
kiss some guy you think is attractive, it's natural, SEX is natural,
it's not dirty it's the most amazing thing imaginable...

that doesn't mean that raves are all about getting laid, mind you.  i
think clubs are like these places where people who want sex are
segregated to.  and it's seen as sort of nasty to go there.  "1015? 
ech, that place is a meat market."  even when you go through the
accepted outlets to sate your natural desire, it's still unclean.  i
want to have SEX, therefore i am a piece of meat.

at raves SEX is just accepted as something thats not only ok, but
good.  the fact that there's such a SEXual atmosphere without it
turning into some big, well, meatmarket, shows a level of maturity
towards SEX that i suspect most people over 30 will never reach in
their lifetimes...

did you know that many other countries consider the u.s. to be one of
the most UPTIGHT places in the world?  bad enough being christians, we
had to be founded by _puritans_.  the hang-ups still linger on today. 
if we think SEX is dirty, how does that make us feel about babies?  do
we hate ourselves because we are "born of sin"?  how sad, it's
surprising we haven't just died out and left the world to people who
know how good SEX is...

that's THE main reason i decided that the we all need a new religion
(and i'm the guy to found it).  it's high time we stopped thinking
that sex was dirty.  when i start my own church, it's gonna be about
seeing god first hand, through meditation, dancing, drugs, isolation
tanks, surfing, and generaly throwing big parties.

but mostly through SEX.

-messiah wannabe

is about to move into aquarius and we have just had
a unique lineup of all the planets and jupiter
is moving into pisces. We are about to witness
something truely incredible.

Mercury just went retrograde so communications will be screwwy
for the next three weeks and people will be very strange and tense.
Stick to routine and take lots of deep breathes and dont get freaked
when things dont work out as planned. If you are traveling, even
short distances allow some extra time. This is a great time for
introspection.

as i have been trying to limit my astological postings here.

Subject: VSF & Stompy: That dog might hunt.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Geez,

At this point this is like a soap opera.  But you know what?  I'm glad I've
spoken up about it, and plan to continue to do so until there is justice.
I'm not only talking about myself.  As I said before my problem is but one
of a myriad of problems at VSF.  I know this much.  The dialog we have had
here has gone *far* beyond this list.  It has reached the owner and plenty
of party people on and off the list.  Like I said when I started this is
far from over.

Anyway I talked with preston this evening (remember I am not adressing the
other problems, he is well aware of them, I am addressing *my* predicament
and looking for a solution/answer), and he indicated, in certain ways, the
noise was getting to him.  He will be talking with VSF, the security and
it's owners next week Tuesday.  Afterwhich , he promised, to call me up
thereafter (i.e. right after the meeting).  He still thinks that the
problem isn;t so much a racil one as it is a general security problem, and
I have no reason to doubt he beleives this.  I, on the other hand am
looking for one thing, and answer as to why *I*, out of the hundreds of
crackerjacks, was seen as too drunk.  At a Stompy?  The thing is Stompy is
a very, very, propular party.  People, like myself, go to Stompy to relax,
be themselves, and blow off some steam in what is considered to be a safe,
and very fun environment.  This security incident casts a deep pall with
VSF, and by virtue of he and his crew having a party there, Stompy as well.

I told Preston that I would not step foot one in his club until I could
have assurances that I would be left alone.  I can't step into his party
always looking over my shoulder, being overly concious of everything I do,
and generally not being able to relax due to a fear of being thrown out
(It's would be like walking the Haight at 3 a.m.).  Hell, Stompy is *my*
party too, and if I can't feel at home there why come?  I think others feel
the same way.  If security is looking for problems then  how can anyone
relax?  Like I said it is a larger issue, and it is concerns Stompy's goal.
If the goal is to provide a space for people to have a good time, then they
must be extra vigilant in creating a vibe conducive for people to do so.
Security shouldn't impede the fun, period.  Fights never break out at
Stompy, you'll never see more smiles and laughing people.  You'll never see
more beautiful people there to see other beautiful people (why do people go
to stompy, to see everyone else who went to stompy, a voyeurs delight).  I
mean Stompy is a people party.  VSF, in it's current state, completely
ruins that vibe.  If not now, certainly when the next party comes (are they
gonna be that hard assed during New Year's?  I hope not).  Security should
have a very light hand, unfortunately for some patrons we have seen the
opposite.

I will keep you all tuned in to what is going on behind the scenes with
this.  Hopefully Stompy & VSF can get their collective act together.
Preston understands how vital this is.  I await  next Tuesday with baited
breath.

As for me, I would paraphrase a certain something I heard the other day,
quite appropriate, "I'm not innocent, but I am far from being guilty!"

peace,
John

"Everyday above ground is a good day." - Mel Bernstein, Chief Detective
Narcotics

On Sun, 7 Dec 1997, pj fuzzy wrote:

> So I was wondering br you boy or girl straight or gay.
>
> A. have you ever been hit on at a party(rave).
> B. What was your favorite pickup line, the best or
> worst one that you ever heard.
>
> indulge my craving for gossip.
>
> pj fuzzy

I was recently at a party wearing a dress and dancing, and when I went to
get a drink some guy hit on me by asking me about my orientation and
telling me I looked really good in the dress -- then he got flustered and
said it really worked for him.

I was actually going to go for it until I heard him talking to someone
about how he'd punched someone that day... and then he started getting
agressive and, needless to say, I didn't go with him (he kept talking
about getting a limo and going to some party, somewhere, he wasn't sure
where or what -- probably another bad sign).

That's actually the only time I've been hit on at a party or rave (not
that I've been to many... yet).

My favorite "pickup" line (I'm not sure this really counts, but...) is the
one my partner used on me -- we were talking about hanging out and watching
a movie, which we'd done before, and she told me "You know, this is going
to be a date."   I really like honesty and directness...

-Ed

brief synopsis of what I read of this conversation:

>>From Steve:
>>New Years Resolution...looks good (Derrick
>>May, Spacetime Continuum, Astral Matrix, Funky TT, etc.), but it's
>>also co-sponsored by Spacechildren...sound
>>like they're total hacks in it for the money only....

Indeed, Space Children (or at least one of two people behind it, who may as
well remain nameless) does seem misgiuded. Even in talking to him, though,
I'm unwilling to judge and say the evil two words (sell-out). He does seem
opportunistic, but he has good taste, charges "industry-standard" prices
and has not made the gargantuan sums of cash you might expect...he makes a
living, from what I can tell. And anybody else in the scene does the
same...That kind-heartedness aside, they sometimes totally fuck up the vibe
of a party, but a word to the wise: Derrick May NEVER lets a crowd down,
whether that crowd is 10,000 people, 5000, 500 or a dozen. He is the Vibe
Master, the best DJ I've ever heard/seen/felt/dug...and even in the face of
a failing sound system can resurrect the vibe within minutes. When people
say, "It's all about the music" which I think most of us who believe in the
scene feel, then Derrick is a living example of that philosophy.

>100% benefit for Dennis Peron's campaign for
>governor (founder of the Cannabis Buyers Club).  A much better way to spend
>your money than for greedy rave promoters.

Agreed: Promotion of marijuana causes is a delightfully intelligent and
good way to
spend money. But there are plenty of good people doing that who are doing
it within a mindset of practicality (including Dennis Peron himself in
other of his activities). In other words (oh no, classic pessimist argument
coming up) he stands no chance in the governor's race. Obviously. But what
CAN be achieved, (so this classic and perrenial train of thought goes)  is
a wider awareness for the issues of marijuana law reform. Unfortunately,
the rest of California is not as enlightened as we in the
Beautiful Bay and will squash it as a governor's campaign. Ah, but the
myriad other pro-pot groups (both underground as well as NORML) could stand
to profit if the money was given to them, instead of potentially
squandering it on a perfectly intentioned but probably futile political
race that
could take votes away from mainstream, admittedly dull and essentially
conservative liberals who could then lose to the likes of another Pete
Wilson (aghghghghghgh!!!).

All this aside, it's only a New Years party...but 1) I would put my
pot-law-reform money elsewhere for greater effect (maybe even other of
Peron's activities!) and 2) wouldn't miss out on the techno vibe wizardry
of 3 hours of Derrick May with a view of SF in the background.

Kylen See

Only ten bucks!!

Received: from yog-sothoth.HIP.Berkeley.EDU (yog-sothoth.HIP.Berkeley.EDU [136.152.29.227]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.8.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id BAA23821 for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Wed, 10 Dec 1997 01:05:49 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <3.0.32.19971210010247.0071b3b8@uclink4.berkeley.edu>

Date: Wed, 10 Dec 1997 01:02:55 -0800

From: josh sorkin <case@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: wonderful things occuring continuously
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

and now i'm in a really good mood despite my extremely dangerous set of
final examinations because XGrRLsTrX has identified the track i have so
desperately racked my brain for.

Komakino's "Outface," in case anyone else was puzzled as well.

nothing left to do but:

<><><><><><><><>
Shout out!  for the long lives you've lived before this day and the things
you've done and the beautiful tender kisses you've given!

Stare at a dusty window watching the rain mercilessly hack at the ground
and admire its cold chaotic rhythmic drumline.

Very quietly go insane while waiting to hear from the one you love, and
jumping with delicious tension at every ear-piercing ring of the laughing,
all-knowing telephone.

Cast a spell and summon dark forces from dimensions beyond ours to do your
nefarious bidding, only to be foiled by the heroic efforts of a
spandex-clad superhero.

Slump against a speaker and hug someone so tightly and cry the happiest
tears as the 303's filters open so wide and the BPM climbs to infinity.

Sit on the now-empty bed and watch the plumes of smoke rising from two
cigarettes, one smoldering in the ashtray with lipstick on its filter, look
at the open door and listen to Bauhaus telling you just how dead Bela
Lugosi is while you wonder if maybe you shouldn't have made love to her
quite so soon and watching the sun come up and people just starting to go
to work as your cigarette sends up a strand of pyrolized tobacco that at
some perfect absolute moment undergoes a wondrous chaotic change and
becomes a plethora of silky swirls and think to yourself that sooner or
later you'll go outside but for now it's just time to sit quietly and
breathe in the fading aroma of perfume on your sheets as the sound of auto
noise starts to rise inexorably and monday starts up with a vengeance.

Skip stones all day and finally get a four-skipper.  Roll in the sand for a
bit, then go home to start setting up the sound system.

But most importantly, run outside with a fistful of #2 pencils, throw them
as far as you can and yell

"I'M DONE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!"

<><><><><><><><><><><>

soon enough, beautiful wonderful and ultimately really stressed people,
soon enough.
-------------------------------
"i scream so much.  you know what i mean.  this electric stream.  and my
tears in league with the wires and energy and my machine."

> On Sun, 7 Dec 1997, pj fuzzy wrote:
> 
> > So I was wondering br you boy or girl straight or gay.
> >
> > A. have you ever been hit on at a party(rave).
> > B. What was your favorite pickup line, the best or
> > worst one that you ever heard.
> >
> > indulge my craving for gossip.
> >
> > pj fuzzy

I decided to add the pick-up line that really worked on me..

I was having a pretty bad week.. and was Dancing for much needed 
therapy. It was still early in the evening, and the dance floor was 
pretty empty. Next time I look up three girls have surrounded me on 
the dance floor..  and one of them comes up and asks.. "We were just 
wondering. How much are they (the club) paying you to dance here?"

That just made my day.. The troubles from the week before vanished, 
forgotten for the duration of the evening. I was finaly free to enjoy 
the evening.

-Faro
Faro@usa.net

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

------=_NextPart_000_0013_01BD0513.929381E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


THE 12 DAYS OF CHRISTMAS....


December 14th


Dearest John:

I went to the door today and the postman delivered a partridge in a pear =
tree. What a delightful gift. I couldn't have been more surprised.


With dearest love and affection, Agnes
--------------------------------------
December 15th

Dearest John:


Today the postman brought your very sweet gift. Just imagine, two turtle =
doves.... I'm just delighted at your very thoughtful gift. They are just =
adorable.

All my love, Agnes
------------------
December 16th
Dear John:

Oh, aren't you the extravagant one! Now I must protest. I don't deserve =
such generosity. Three french hens. They are just darling but I must =
insist.... you're just too kind.

Love Agnes
---------
December 17th

Today the postman delivered four calling birds. Now really! They are =
beautiful, but don't you think enough is enough? You're being too =
romantic.

Affectionately, Agnes
---------------------
December 18th

Dearest John:

What a surprise! Today the postman delivered five golden rings. One for =
each finger. You're just impossible, but I love it. Frankly, John, all =
those squawking birds were beginning to get on my nerves.


All my love, Agnes
------------------
December 19th

Dear John:

When I opened the door there were actually six geese a-laying on my =
front steps. So you're back to the birds again, huh? Those geese are =
huge. Where will I ever keep them? The neighbors are complaining and I =
can't sleep through the racket. PLEASE STOP!

Cordially, Agnes
----------------

December 20th

John:

What's with you and those fucking birds???? Seven swans a-swimming. What =
kind of goddam joke is this? There's bird shit all over the house and =
they never stop the racket. I'm a nervous wreck and I can't sleep all =
night. IT'S NOT FUNNY.......So stop with those fucking birds.

Sincerely, Agnes
----------------
December 21st

OK Buster:

I think I prefer the birds. What the hell am I going to do with eight =
maids a-milking? It's not enough with all those birds and eight maids =
a-milking, but they had to bring their own goddam cows. There is shit =
all over the lawn and I can't move into my own house. Just lay off me. =
SMART ASS.

Ag
----------------
December 22nd


Hey Shithead:

What are you? Some kind of sadist? Now there's nine pipers playing. And =
Christ - do they play. They never stopped chasing those maids since they =
got here yesterday morning. The cows are upset are stepping all over =
those screeching birds. No wonder they screeh. What am I going to do? =
The neighbors have started a petetion to evict me. You'll get yours.


>From Ag
----------------
December 23rd

You Rotten Prick:

Now there's ten ladies dancing - I don't know why I call those sluts =
ladies. They've been balling those nine pipers all night long. Now the =
cows can't sleep and they've got diarrhea. My living room is a river of =
shit. The commisioner of buildings has subpoenaed me to give cause why =
the building shouldn't be condemned. I'm sicking the police on you.

One who means it, Ag
--------------------
December 24th

Listen Fuckhead:


What's with the eleven lords a-leaping on those maids and aforementioned =
"ladies"? Some of those broads will never walk again. Those pipers ran =
through the maids and have been commiting sodomy with the cows. All 234 =
of the birds are dead. They have been trampled to death in the orgy. I =
hope you're satisfied, you rotten swine.


Your sworn enemy, Miss Agnes McCallister
--------------------------------------








December 25th (From the law offices Taeker, Spredar, and Baegar)

Dear Sir:


This is to acknowledge your latest gift of tweleve drummers drumming, =
which you have seen fit to inflict on our client, Miss Agnes =
McCallister. The destruction, of course, was total. All correspondence =
should come to our
attention. If you should attempt to reach Miss McCallister at Happy Dale =
Sanitarium, the attendants have instructions to shoot you on sight. With =
this letter, please find attached a warrant for your arrest.

On Tue, 9 Dec 1997, Megan Hug wrote:

> >because that is how i am treated and they want equal treatment.
> >SO now im confused on this one =)
> >
> >I believe that women and men are different and need to be treated
> >differently. I havent quite worked out exactly what that means
> >because i do believe that we all deserve equal treatment
> >and respect but how do we do that if we are different?
> >
> >	><{{{">   <"}}}><
> >
> >		foolish fish
> >
>  i completely agree with you on this one.... there is no doubt about men
> and women being different! it's physically obvious... and i also believe
> that we're spiritually (yin-yang) and mentally different (scientifically
> proven... whether that's nature/nurture... that's another whole story! :).
> and that's where the dichotomy lies... we can be different AND equal.
> we've proven this in race- why is gender such a difficult thing to deal with?
> my problem is that yes "i am an equal"... but i there are times i like to
> be treated like a lady.  what's that supposed to mean? i'm not quite sure.
> maybe i'm a hypocrite?  i still find it pleasing when a man opens a door
> for me... 
> however- i feel quite pleased to do the same for him on occasion!

There's also no doubt that individual men and women are different from
other men and women resp..

The variance (or even the st. dev.) within each gender is much larger than
the differences between them -- so we could, rather than talking about
statistical differences, talk about similarities in terms of the range
of behavior.  Especially if you consider many of the statistical
differences to be socially constructed rather than biologically
inhereted...

I'm quite dubious of different-but-equal arguments -- while I agree
with them in principal, I've seen little to convince me that our
society (specifically the USA, late 90s) is capable of respecting
them... the closest thing you can see is the use of 'exchange value'
to put people (employees) within a social structure which
theoretically gives them equal opportunities.  Of course,
statistically speaking, people of different gender and racial or
class backgrounds do not have equal opportunities, so I don't buy
this either.

Also, like it or not, different-but-equal arguments are easily used
by those who agree that men and women are different but feel this
means they should be treated differently -- consider the Promise
Keepers (and, generally, the religious right, amoung others, not all
of them conservative).

I'm not saying there's anything wrong with enjoying gender -- I get a
kick out of playing both butch and femme, as well as watching others
perform these roles... I just prefer to see them as socially constructed
roles (rather than anything biological) which people of either biological
gender can perform.

-Ed

I agree with Molly. while it's a wonderful and beautiful moment
when you can acheive something more, i don't see anything
wrong with just having fun.

actually, i don't see anything in general wrong with having fun.
it seems to me that people look at life so seriously when in
reality it is pretty bizarre and silly.

something can be sacred depending on the individual - to one
person a quick fling might be sacred while to another a loving
experience......

i think perhaps it's the word "sacred" that i'm having a problem
with.....because that implies that people do not treat sex that
way now....but how can you say what is "sacred" and what is not?
maybe to them, their casual attitudes about sex are better than
treating it as something more than the physical......

our society has such a huge hang-up about sex- they censor
discussions of it in school and the media, yet use it to sell
products......you can't have condoms in schools, but you
can have cheerleaders with short-short skirts....seems
to me that everything in our culture makes a big deal out
of sex in its own way

anyway i'm kinda rambling here so will shut up now 

-kim

I guess I am all alone here, but I honestly do not believe there
is any difference between men and women other than their
physical bodies. It is my belief that the reason they act "differently"
is due to how they are raised from birth and the expectations that
other people/our society has of them.

For example, I do not believe that women just have a natural desire
to play with barbies, or that boys just have an instinct to get matchbox
cars, yet their parents often act as though they do.

I do not agree at all that they should be treated differently. It's all
a sort of big cycle. You treat people differently, so they act as though
they are different from each other, when in fact they are not, so you
assume that their behavior is an innate quality, and then treat them
differently.

I'm not denying their are physical differences, but I do not consider
one's physical form to be very relevant to how you treat their Mind.

I definitely do not agree in the phrase "different but equal". That is like
saying kids in special education are looked on as "different but equal"
or that people of color are treated as "different but equal". I guess I am
opening up a big can of worms so to speak but that phrase really
bothers me!!!!

-kim
.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.

Subject: RE: NRR Re: Sexuality and Sexism - Absolutely NOT!
Date: Wed, 10 Dec 1997 10:41:53 -0800
X-Priority: 3
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.0.1457.3)
Content-Type: text/plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



> I guess I am all alone here, but I honestly do not believe there
> is any difference between men and women other than their
> physical bodies. It is my belief that the reason they act
> "differently"
> is due to how they are raised from birth and the expectations that
> other people/our society has of them.
> 
you have a point. or part of one. i don't think anyone could make an
argument against societal "programming" have an absolute influence over
the lives of those born into the society. however what you ignore is
nature. males and females exist to perpetuate the continued existance of
a species. same with humans. male and females in "natural" enviornments
follow certain instinctual behavioral patterns which differ between
genders. you can't have it both ways, being one with nature and at the
same time above it. if we are to be part of the natural order of things
we need to accept what intellectually speaking may be less desirable
charactaristics. and in accepting this i believe it just might be
possible for an indiviual or a society (maybe) to move closer towards an
ideal. but if you pretend try to sweep the dirty mess under the carpet,
it's still going to be there.

> For example, I do not believe that women just have a natural desire
> to play with barbies, or that boys just have an instinct to get
> matchbox
> cars, yet their parents often act as though they do.
> 
i agree. partially. play in humans and animals is a mirror of the
society that they're learning from. so are the toys aren't they.
however, i believe that girls and boys will gravitate to the activities
that will define them in their gender roles.

> I do not agree at all that they should be treated differently. It's
> all
> a sort of big cycle. You treat people differently, so they act as
> though
> they are different from each other, when in fact they are not, so you
> assume that their behavior is an innate quality, and then treat them
> differently.
> 
again, i agree, especially when teaching kids to accept the world around
them and those who populate it. they will emmulate or develope
prejudices based on what they're shown.

> I'm not denying their are physical differences, but I do not consider
> one's physical form to be very relevant to how you treat their Mind.
> 
> I definitely do not agree in the phrase "different but equal". That is
> like
> saying kids in special education are looked on as "different but
> equal"
> or that people of color are treated as "different but equal". I guess
> I am
> opening up a big can of worms so to speak but that phrase really
> bothers me!!!!
> 
for the sake of symantics and open discussion i don't think it's
appropriate to avoid defining phrasology because it's uncomfortable,
particularly when it just may be an accurate summary. i'm not just
playing devil's advocate here, i do believe that genetic differences in
gender make up for psycho-social behavior differences as well.

From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Re: NRR Sexuality and Sexism
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

megan said....

>>my problem is that yes "i am an equal"... but i there are times i like to
>>be treated like a lady.  what's that supposed to mean? i'm not quite sure.
>>maybe i'm a hypocrite?  i still find it pleasing when a man opens a door
>>for me...
>>however- i feel quite pleased to do the same for him on occasion!

and elizabeth said...

>why does wanting equal *rights* automatically throw
>chivalry out the window? in a way, i see chivalry as a high respect for a
>woman. you know, i think it's this country. european women (check out the
>french) can be extremely powerful, command respect, and yet still be a
>_woman_ - sexy, strong, intelligent, beautiful - and turns heads for all of
>those reasons. i don't see that as hypocritical at all.


sometimes i think we just have to weigh the positives and the negatives and
the price of sexual inequality...

and frankly, i'd be very willing to trade in a couple of million times of
having some man hold open a door for me ....

if only my mother's life could have been as important in my family as my
father's, so she could have had a career like he did and not have been left
to work a minimum wage job when he moved on to someone else...

or if my 89-year-old friend could have expected to learn to handle the
finances and investments before her husband died and left her a potential
victim to people who would scam her....

or if i could feel secure that no matter what someone thought of me, they
didn't start of by making blanket assumptions about what i can and cannot
do because i am a woman, and who i am and am not, based on my gender.

bottom line, sexism and sexist behavior and expectations hold people back,
and therefore we're better off without it...

and that's why it is important to me to be vigilant about sexist comments
and seemingly innocent sexist behavior... because we're talking about
something that may seem trivial ("hey, i was only joking, you know"), but
in reality has profound effects on the ability for women to succeed in
their lives.

and it ain't about opening doors and lighting cigarettes.... holding a door
open for someone is about respectful behavior, that's a no-brainer...  i'll
hold a door or a lighter for a man or another woman without thinking twice
if that's what's called for... sheez.  that's just manners.


and, by the way, static was great again last night... i got to meet hai and
megan hug and steve and aminita/shira.... plus see lots of other
sfravers... but those martinis, man, are craaazy!  maybe i should just plan
to stay in the city on tuesday nights!

leslie
