Kylen Campbell wrote:
> 
> brief synopsis of what I read of this conversation:
> 
> >>From Steve:
> >>New Years Resolution...looks good (Derrick
> >>May, Spacetime Continuum, Astral Matrix, Funky TT, etc.), but it's
> >>also co-sponsored by Spacechildren...sound
> >>like they're total hacks in it for the money only....
> 
> Indeed, Space Children (or at least one of two people behind it, who may as
> well remain nameless) does seem misgiuded. Even in talking to him, though,
> I'm unwilling to judge and say the evil two words (sell-out). He does seem
> opportunistic, but he has good taste, charges "industry-standard" prices
> and has not made the gargantuan sums of cash you might expect...he makes a
> living, from what I can tell. And anybody else in the scene does the
> same...That kind-heartedness aside, they sometimes totally fuck up the vibe
> of a party, but a word to the wise: Derrick May NEVER lets a crowd down,
> whether that crowd is 10,000 people, 5000, 500 or a dozen. He is the Vibe
> Master, the best DJ I've ever heard/seen/felt/dug...and even in the face of
> a failing sound system can resurrect the vibe within minutes. When people
> say, "It's all about the music" which I think most of us who believe in the
> scene feel, then Derrick is a living example of that philosophy.

That's great, until you show up at the gig and pay your $25 (or
whatever)
only to find out that they cancelled Derrick May weeks ago, and then
kick you out at 4:00am.  I have no problem with oppornusm, and I don't
think anyone here does.  It's just that when somebody promises
something and then dosen't deliver, they should make at least an
attempt at reparations (ie. refunds, notice at the door before you buy
tickets that an artist isn't there, simple apology, etc.).  Not doing
so goes a bit beyond the boundaries of mere opportunism.

> 
> >100% benefit for Dennis Peron's campaign for
> >governor (founder of the Cannabis Buyers Club).  A much better way to spend
> >your money than for greedy rave promoters.
> 
> Agreed: Promotion of marijuana causes is a delightfully intelligent and
> good way to
> spend money. But there are plenty of good people doing that who are doing
> it within a mindset of practicality (including Dennis Peron himself in
> other of his activities). In other words (oh no, classic pessimist argument
> coming up) he stands no chance in the governor's race. Obviously. But what
> CAN be achieved, (so this classic and perrenial train of thought goes)  is
> a wider awareness for the issues of marijuana law reform. Unfortunately,
> the rest of California is not as enlightened as we in the
> Beautiful Bay and will squash it as a governor's campaign. Ah, but the
> myriad other pro-pot groups (both underground as well as NORML) could stand
> to profit if the money was given to them, instead of potentially
> squandering it on a perfectly intentioned but probably futile political
> race that
> could take votes away from mainstream, admittedly dull and essentially
> conservative liberals who could then lose to the likes of another Pete
> Wilson (aghghghghghgh!!!).

The idea in any election is to vote for the person who you think would
do the best job, NOT the guy you think is going to win.  If you think
Dennis Peron or Jerry Brown or Ross Perot (shudder) would be the best
for a particular job, then vote for him, even if there is no realistic
chance that he will win.  Granted, most people are sheep who do as 
they're told by a particular party dogma, but there will never be any
change in the way things work if the "fringe" candidates aren't around.
Dennis Peron may split the "liberal" vote, but he's also putting what
I see as a very important issue on the table for public debate.  I 
don't want to start a legalize/demonize pot thread here, so check
out http://www.norml.org.

> 
> All this aside, it's only a New Years party...but 1) I would put my
> pot-law-reform money elsewhere for greater effect (maybe even other of
> Peron's activities!) and 2) wouldn't miss out on the techno vibe wizardry
> of 3 hours of Derrick May with a view of SF in the background.

Sounds great if it happens, but I'm glad I didn't go to a few
previous SpaceChildren deals, given the horror stories I've heard
(and so have you).

PLURM(Music!),
Steve.

At 09:20 AM 12/10/97 -0800, .oOo.oOo.oOo. wrote:
>I guess I am all alone here, but I honestly do not believe there
>is any difference between men and women other than their
>physical bodies. 
well... physical bodies dictate how the brain has been formed... no, they
are not shaped differently... but i believe that studies have shown that
they do indeed work differently.  wish i could give you some actual
references... (wrote a term paper on the differences/similarities of
men/women- these resources may have been old, but i don't think THAT much
has changed in these sort of studies since 1991).
I will admit that these studies may have been swayed due to nurture... but
i don't believe that environment has that much of an impact on a persons
sexuality... i think that genetics play a much larger roll in our
personalities and sexual behavior than you think!  
look at the studies of twins; same genetic make-up, seperated at birth, yet
when they've met up after 30 years? they show up in the same outfit, have
the same occupations, the same dreams... different environments... same
genetic make-up...

>It is my belief that the reason they act "differently"
>is due to how they are raised from birth and the expectations that
>other people/our society has of them.
ah... but where did all of these expectations come from???
if we started the same... why are we so different now? 
and if we started different... why do you think that is?

>For example, I do not believe that women just have a natural desire
>to play with barbies, or that boys just have an instinct to get matchbox
>cars, yet their parents often act as though they do.
i'll agree with you there... to some extent.
BUT do you think toy manufacturers package their products to target adults?
no, they do study upon study to see what children like... and i just so
happens that girls go for the pink toys and boys go for the blue (a rough
generalization)... have you ever looked down a girls toy isle? a boys?
completely different!  and i don't believe that parents/society instill
this into their child... baby toys are all colors of the rainbow... no
premeditated sexism there.  but once they are old enough to walk down the
isles themselves... you see what children their age and sex like.  (i'm not
saying every child fits into these stereotypes... this is all just a
generalization... and i personally believe it's 40% nurture and 60%
nature... and once again- i know i am no scientist... just formed my own
educated hypothesis)

>I definitely do not agree in the phrase "different but equal". That is like
>saying kids in special education are looked on as "different but equal"
WHOA!
i _would_ say that...  whose to say that intelligence quantifies greater than?
you ask the parent of a special ed. student... and i bet they will say that
he/she is just as special as any other child... of course, we all have our
strengths and weaknesses... we are different.
i think we _are_ all equal! one may be more intelligent... but the other
may be more ________.

>or that people of color are treated as "different but equal". 
well why not?!!!

very, very basic example--> all fruits are equal... right? 
(ok, ok... just work w/ me here! :)
apples and oranges are different... right?
but whose to say that one is intrinsically better than the other?

DISCLAIMER:
all of the information mentioned above is a mish-mash of my
beliefs/veiws/thoughts... 
they may be different from kim's... but by no means more or less equal!

megan

as an ex (and disgrunteled) employee of spaced children i have been 
avoiding this thread. This last show was the final straw for me.
I always worked there with the attitude that this was just a job just like
working for bill grahm or any other concert producer. I got into raving
for reasons that spaced children never supported but i thought 
that was ok, because it was just like any other job to me.
I also naievely thought i could perhaps influence things there
and maybe help move it in a different direction. I was wrong.

This last show really was just too much. I think two things 
that really opened my eyes were the fact that any woman
that wanted in free only had to flash her breasts and she got in
while the slightest hesitation of a male to pay full price was met
with security guards tossing him out the door. And then after
it was over and nobody got paid again i was told by one of the 
produceres that "its not about the money...just look at all
the hot women"

Plus i saw so many people leave with angry sad faces at being 
ripped off. The thing that really hit me most was seeing
two young people come in, lay down the $25 a piece, which 
was obviously a stain on a 18 year olds budget and then 
seeing them leave 5 min later with a look of disgust on their face.

I have treated so many people rudely at the door because "it
was my job to squeeze" every little dollar out of people and
feel horrible about some of the things i did there. I hope none
of you were victims of this and i apologize if if happened to any of you.

I knew there were problems there but i was unaware of a lot
of the things that have been discussed here. 

so i have finally decided after this last show that i will no longer
be working for them or attending any of their parties. I feel
sorry for the hundreds of people that have been ripped off by them.
 
this new years eve party is bound to be another disaster...it doesnt
take a financial wizard to figure that one out. I guess if you have 
big breasts and want a free party or want to ogle these women 
them this is the party  for you....otherwise i would suggest
you try one of the many other partys that night. And even tho
some big dj's are scheduled does not mean they will actually be there
as the word is out about the lack of payments so many performers
ask for money before they go on stage. Since there probably wont be more
than 3-400 ppl there its doughtful that there will be any money 
to pay these people.

yeah im bitter and disgruntled but facts are facts.

Actually there are some really good ppl there and potential for
them to turn things around. I really hope they wake up and do so.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

i see what you're saying black adder.  i get some "racist" (i believe)
hassle walking past valencia gardens (a public housing project one
block from my apartment) on my way home sometimes.  however, currently
most power in this country is held by a small number of white males,
and i personally doubt that many of them hold the loftiest intentions
when it comes to opening that power structure to outsiders.  an
attitude which i think is all too human, and probably holds true for
just about any group at the top of any social hierarchy.  but the
thing is, i rarely hear to many of us admit to this fact.

like i was saying, i've heard some pretty bad things said by white
people regarding people of different races.  and while no one i hang
out with talks like that, i've heard it enough that i think it
reflects a very common viewpoint among "my people".  common enough
that i think the phrase "whitey is out to get you" doesn't sound as
ridiculous as it's supposed to.

-mw

On Dec 10,  1:33pm, Messiah Wannabe wrote:
> Subject: Re: VSF & Stompy...hesitant review.
->
->
-> i see what you're saying black adder.  i get some "racist" (i believe)
-> hassle walking past valencia gardens (a public housing project one
-> block from my apartment) on my way home sometimes.  however, currently
-> most power in this country is held by a small number of white males,
-> and i personally doubt that many of them hold the loftiest intentions
-> when it comes to opening that power structure to outsiders.  an
-> attitude which i think is all too human, and probably holds true for
-> just about any group at the top of any social hierarchy.  but the
-> thing is, i rarely hear to many of us admit to this fact.
->
-> like i was saying, i've heard some pretty bad things said by white
-> people regarding people of different races.  and while no one i hang
-> out with talks like that, i've heard it enough that i think it
-> reflects a very common viewpoint among "my people".  common enough
-> that i think the phrase "whitey is out to get you" doesn't sound as
-> ridiculous as it's supposed to.
->
True - but there's the other side of racism that a lot of people fail to
see.  It's interesting to note that race seems to be a property determined
solely by skin tone and complexion - rather than true heritage.  I won't
get into discrimination based on sexual orientation - but the more subtle
racism that I have experienced based on the difference between my genetic
heritage and my outward appearance.

I am Irish and Amerind (American Indian - Lakota Sioux), yet I appear to
be quite "white".  I have been active with several organizations to try
and preserve and teach traditional Amerind cultural values to youths of
both Amerind extraction and those who are simply interested in learning.
 Yet when I try to approach people who are potentially distant relatives,
I find hostility and anger directed towards me, as a "white guy trying to
press in on something that doesn't belong to him," even though I DO have a
right to this by lineage.

The ironic part is when I'm confronted by activists for other racial
groups - particularly those of African extraction.  I truly resent being
told that "my kind" was responsible the speaker's family's heritage in
slavery - when my own ancestors were victims of "imperialist" policies of
both British and American design, with the intent on at least one side
being genocide.

Race has become, in the words of a few journalists, a quality possesed by
anyone who is not white.  Visibly white people do not have a race - they
are simply the oppressors.  The problem this engenders is that all white
people are treated as a single class, a monolithic entity, when in fact
this is very far from the truth.

"Race" is not some club you are born into because of skin color - it is an
issue of us and them.  The solution to the "racial divide" is to stop
thinking of an us and them that is based upon appearances.  One of the
things that first drove me to pursue the rave culture, etc., was the
multi-ethnic background - how race didn't seem to be an issue.  People got
together for a different purpose, and for a moment appearances become
meaningless, melted away by the combination of music, dance, and in some
cases drugs.

When you discuss racism, consider this:  Are you talking about racism in
one person or a small group, or areyou trying to condemn the "white man"
as a whole.  And then consider those of us who are between two worlds -
too white to be permitted to learn of and experience our heritage, yet not
white enough to have the advantages of centuries of being the top dog.

Not all white guys are racist dogs out to climb a ladder greased with
minority blood.  Not all Amerinds are drunken wife-beaters that live in
tipis and hunt buffalo.  Not all Asians are brainy eggheads who take life
too seriously.  Not all Hispanics are migrant workers or drug smugglers.
 Not all Africans are gangstas or welfare mothers, living off society's
largess.

After following this thread for a while, I had to bring this up.
 Remember, plUr - Unity is VERY important.  We have transcended these
boundaries before - we can do it again.  Don't dwell too much on one
incident, though do not dismiss it too lightly.  Deal with it, and move
on.  The solution to racism is not to point fingers and shout out where
you believe racism to be - it sounds like crying wolf.  FIght racism by
building communities that cross racial boundaries, like the rave community
has been traditionally.  Focus on things, properties, interests and
achievements that bring us together, not drive us apart.  Save the
condemnation for individuals who can't embrace a new way of thinking - and
walk away from racist thought.

Racism is not just a property of the white psyche - it is a part of the
human psyche.  It can be repaired, and the damage put behind us - if we
refuse to look at the world through racially-installed filters.

(I know what's being considered - being "white" I don't know what it's
like.  Being gay, though, I do.  Wondering if a negative performance
review is a reflection of your own performance, or of your boss's dislike
of who and what you do in your own home.  I was driven out of college for
religious and sexuality-related reasons - I've walked this talk in the
past.  I won't say I know what it's like, but I've experienced similar
effects.  Common ground.)

-Corey

--

                -- Salvor Hardin, "Foundation"

	-- Anonymous

Mike Althouse wrote:
> 
> First, ask your Internet Provider to mail you an Unsubscribing Kit. Then
> follow these directions.
> 
> The kit will most likely be the standard no-fault type. Depending
> on requirements, System A and/or System B can be used. When
> operating System A, depress lever and a plastic dalkron unsubscriber will
> be dispensed through the slot immediately underneath. When you
> have fastened the adhesive lip, attach connection marked by the
> large "X" outlet hose. Twist the silver-colored ring one inch
> below the connection point until you feel it lock.
> 
> The kit is now ready for use. The Cin-Eliminator is activated by
> the small switch on the lip. When securing, twist the ring back to
> its initial condition, so that the two orange lines meet.
> Disconnect. Place the dalkron unsubscriber in the vacuum receptacle
> to the rear. Activate by pressing the blue button.
> 
> The controls for System B are located on the opposite side. The red
> release switch places the Cin-Eliminator into position; it can be
> adjusted manually up or down by pressing the blue manual release button.
> The opening is self-adjusting. To secure after use, press the green
> button, which simultaneously activates the evaporator and returns the
> Cin-Eliminator to its storage position.
> 
> You may log off if the green exit light is on over the evaporator.
> If the red light is illuminated, one of the Cin-Eliminator
> requirements has not been properly implemented. Press the "List
> Guy" call button on the right of the evaporator. He will secure
> all facilities from his control panel.
> 
> To use the Auto-Unsub, first undress and place all your clothes in
> the clothes rack. Put on the Velcro slippers located in the cabinet
> immediately below. Enter the shower, taking the entire kit with
> you. On the control panel to your upper right upon entering you
> will see a "Shower seal" button. Press to activate. A green light
> will then be illuminated immediately below. On the intensity knob,
> select the desired setting. Now depress the Auto-Unsub activation
> lever. Bathe normally.
> 
> The Auto-Unsub will automatically go off after three minutes unless
> you activate the "Manual off" override switch by flipping it up.
> When you are ready to leave, press the blue "Shower seal" release
> button. The door will open and you may leave. Please remove the
> Velcro slippers and place them in their container.
> 
> If you prefer the ultrasonic log-off mode, press the indicated blue
> button.  When the twin panels open, pull forward by rings A & B.
> The knob to the left, just below the blue light, has three settings,
> low, medium or high. For normal use, the medium setting is
> suggested.
> 
> After these settings have been made, you can activate the device by
> switching to the "ON" position the clearly marked red switch. If
> during the unsubscribing operation, you wish to change the settings,
> place the "manual off" override switch in the "OFF" position. You
> may now make the change and repeat the cycle. When the green exit
> light goes on, you may log off and have lunch. Please close the
> door behind you.
> 
> It is imperative to follow these instructions explicitly.
> 
> Or, you could read the flippin' FAQ like a normal person, and find
> how to signoff there.
> 
> Mike Althouse
> althousm@vrinet.com
> REDWING List Cop & Keeper O' The FAQ

--

http://www.compare.net/

a silly thread about "s" gets out of control... I think the joke was
that "s" was sex... but whatever...  social-raves should be socal-raves.

---------

I don't know if anyone else on the list reads MUZIK, a British clubbing,
music and scene mag, but socal raves actually showed up in the pages of
this month's issue.
The subject?...
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
"S BY GUM"
  Los Angeles-based e-mail site Social(sic) Raves caused mass hysteria
among clubbers in
California last month by announcing that a new triangular-shaped wonder
drug called "S"
had arrived on the scene. Apparently dealers were inundated with
requests for the drug
following claims that it caused an intense five minute peak in mental
processes which then left the user feeling completely refreshed.
  Pill-hungry types were dissapointed, however, when Social Raves
eventually came clean,
revealing that the drug didn't exist and that the triangular shaped
tablets were in fact
Sucrets mints. Very bloody funny...
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Congrats kids, you made the world news.
Albeit with spelling errors and misinformation, but then without that,
it just wouldn't
be socal-raves, would it? :)

MikeD
milkdud
"...as American as apple pie and black-ops."

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Dec 11 00:30:41 1997

ok ok i tried not to get involved but seeing as how i am helping to put
this party on (with my posse,nexus)i suppose i had no choice. First of all

children,and NEXUS(bsp)and it will be out of control(in a good way)tthe
talent and the location will make this a party to truly remember. Also its
kinda historic all these diffrent crews working together. Second ive never
been to a space children party that promised derrik may and didnt deliver
the goods they have booked him at least three times and he has shown at all
of these parties. They have also gotten a good number of the transmat crew
at their parties including, juan atkins,kevin saunderson and stacy pullen
and all opf these artist have shown. I remember a party for their 1  year
aniv. that juan played at and it was a ug and cheap. THirdly i know scott
and coz. I know they love the music and the scene and i know that they have
lost ALOT of money at a few odf their parties but they continue to throw
them big or small. THis leads me to belive that they are not in it strictly
for the money. If they were i would think they wouldnt focus on techno as
the main form of music at their parties (house just draws abigger crowd in
san fran). Ran d dreams  reasoning for boycotting space children was one of
the most petty i have ever heard of. Mr dreams would u have boycotted if it
was harmony dropping flyers without asking u first i doubt it. They
definately mad a big tabbo mistake by not coming back and making sure their
flyers were cleaned up but who are u to make rules of what u can and cant
do at burning  man. last time i checked that was the antithesis of what
burning man is. I dont justify everything space children has ever done
they, like alot of people have made mistakes in promoting.(like each and
every promoter, ug and massive)  My final point is this , and it s quite a
heated one.... i dont know if there is anything wrong with promoters who
thorw parties for money as long as they take care of busniess(i know that
one of the points made was that space children dosent but still) Promoters
dont have to be rave kids they are  promoters and fed up with the scene for
the most part so do u guys think that throwing a party for money is
wrong... i dont think i do (but i will always love the music and all
promoters should love it too.)      NEW YEARS ON TREASURE ISLAND  WILL
FUCKIN ROCK!!!!!!!(OH YEA IM PLAYING THERE)......MOSHE

From: Messiah Wannabe <messiahw@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Re: NRR Re: Sexuality, Sexism, and Pigeons
To: Megan Hug <megan@medialive.com>

Precedence: bulk



i have hobby, i call it "fishtanking" - when i'm at a club or a party,
at some point during the evening, i find a secluded place set back
from the main area.  picture windows at house parties are good, you
get a good unobstructed view, and the glass adds to the fishtank
effect.  at 1015 there's a balcony overlooking the main dance floor,
it's usually fairly deserted up there, and it's a perfect vantage
point to watch what's going on.  there's almost always a good spot to
do this at any party, the idea is that you get a good view of
everybody as they all move from place to place around the room...

it's always fascinating to watch a group of people interact with each
other.  so many drama's unfold, and often you can tell exactly what's
going on even though the dialogue is removed - peoples facial
expressions and body language speak volumes.  i always look for
anything interesting, but whenever i do this i find most of what i'm
observing seems to be the human mating ritual.

funny but more than anything it reminds me of watching pigeons picking
up on each other in the park.  the male puffs up his neck feathers,
accentuating his subtle irridescent sheen.  the female coos
appreciatively, ruffles her feathers, then flies away.  but not too
far.  the male pigeon struts around a little, then flies over near the
female, usually behind her.  and struts around a little more.  then
tries to mount her.  but ms. pigeon is not that kind of girl, and
flies off again.  this process is repeated until a)the female decides
the male is a loser after all, and takes off for parts unknown, or
b)they make love in front of god and everyone else, cooing unabashedly.

now i'm sure you all consider me a pigeonphile, which i will neither
confirm nor deny.  but what i'm trying to get at is, we're all
animals. i believe that to deny that there are roles we were born to
play is to deny our connection with nature.  yet at the same time, i
believe from bottom of my heart that we all deserve the same
opportunities, regardless of sex, skin color, sexual orientation etc. 
and reconciling these two seemingly opposing points of view is just
one of the many philosophical juggling acts i find myself doing every
day.

-messiah w



---Megan Hug <megan@medialive.com> wrote:
>
> At 09:20 AM 12/10/97 -0800, .oOo.oOo.oOo. wrote:
> >I guess I am all alone here, but I honestly do not believe there
> >is any difference between men and women other than their
> >physical bodies. 
> well... physical bodies dictate how the brain has been formed... no,
they
> are not shaped differently... but i believe that studies have shown
that
> they do indeed work differently.  wish i could give you some actual
> references... (wrote a term paper on the differences/similarities of
> men/women- these resources may have been old, but i don't think THAT
much
> has changed in these sort of studies since 1991).
> I will admit that these studies may have been swayed due to
nurture... but
> i don't believe that environment has that much of an impact on a
persons
> sexuality... i think that genetics play a much larger roll in our
> personalities and sexual behavior than you think!  
> look at the studies of twins; same genetic make-up, seperated at
birth, yet
> when they've met up after 30 years? they show up in the same outfit,
have
> the same occupations, the same dreams... different environments...
same
> genetic make-up...
> 
> >It is my belief that the reason they act "differently"
> >is due to how they are raised from birth and the expectations that
> >other people/our society has of them.
> ah... but where did all of these expectations come from???
> if we started the same... why are we so different now? 
> and if we started different... why do you think that is?
> 
> >For example, I do not believe that women just have a natural desire
> >to play with barbies, or that boys just have an instinct to get
matchbox
> >cars, yet their parents often act as though they do.
> i'll agree with you there... to some extent.
> BUT do you think toy manufacturers package their products to target
adults?
> no, they do study upon study to see what children like... and i just
so
> happens that girls go for the pink toys and boys go for the blue (a
rough
> generalization)... have you ever looked down a girls toy isle? a boys?
> completely different!  and i don't believe that parents/society
instill
> this into their child... baby toys are all colors of the rainbow... no
> premeditated sexism there.  but once they are old enough to walk
down the
> isles themselves... you see what children their age and sex like. 
(i'm not
> saying every child fits into these stereotypes... this is all just a
> generalization... and i personally believe it's 40% nurture and 60%
> nature... and once again- i know i am no scientist... just formed my
own
> educated hypothesis)
> 
> >I definitely do not agree in the phrase "different but equal". That
is like
> >saying kids in special education are looked on as "different but
equal"
> WHOA!
> i _would_ say that...  whose to say that intelligence quantifies
greater than?
> you ask the parent of a special ed. student... and i bet they will
say that
> he/she is just as special as any other child... of course, we all
have our
> strengths and weaknesses... we are different.
> i think we _are_ all equal! one may be more intelligent... but the
other
> may be more ________.
> 
> >or that people of color are treated as "different but equal". 
> well why not?!!!
> 
> very, very basic example--> all fruits are equal... right? 
> (ok, ok... just work w/ me here! :)
> apples and oranges are different... right?
> but whose to say that one is intrinsically better than the other?
> 
> DISCLAIMER:
> all of the information mentioned above is a mish-mash of my
> beliefs/veiws/thoughts... 
> they may be different from kim's... but by no means more or less
equal!

> though i see where the foolish fish is coming from (sort of), I have to
> take exception to the sweeping generality that sex has "degenerated into a
> physical act alone"...  Tantra/ sacred sex is still practiced today, and
> there is a great resurgence of interest in tantra throughout the western
> world ....  and frankly, i don't think that most of western civilation
> *ever* thought of sex as a truly sacred act.

Um, for a little clarification.  There are different types of tantra that
focus on stimulating, or improving different aspects of life, Red tantra
is one type which focus on the second chakra and consequently sex,
reproduction, etc.  And yes tantra is still widely practised, though white
tantra primarily.

> 
> because tantra is about focusing attention and energy to increase the
> sexual energy to new levels.... but raving is about multiple sensory
> stimulation that goes beyond sexual activities... it is about interacting
> with many different people to create a vibe, and that cannot be done
> through sex...  a room full of people practicing tantric sex would be an
> entirely different vibe than a room full of people dancing...

Um sex and tantra are very seperate.  The way to keep sex beautiful or
"sacred" is through the conciousness of the people involved and the
attitude with which they approach it. > 

> my favorite quote  is "Dancing is a vertical expression of a horizontal
> desire" .... and i while think that sex and dancing have similarities in
> their power over us and our personal energy... i don't think that tantra
> and raving can really overlap...
> 
When i did tantra, i felt a type of bliss that kept me feeling balanced
aware and happy, a good rave can leave me feeling close enough to that to
keep going, sometimes especially to be up lifted. (personal opinion)

> 
sat kriya
> 
> >Its intereting to look at how a species sexual atitudes change over time.
> >There was one a time when sex was considered a sacred act.
> >
> >It was done in the tantric temples as a way to celebrate and practice our
> >spirituality.
> >
> >Today it has degenerated into a physical act alone...often lacking
> >in any spiritual aspect at all. That is why we feel shame about
> >it....because we have forgotten how sacred it is.
> >
> >Many feel it is time we remember those sacred ways of celebrating life.
> >
> >perhaps raving is an early experiment in finding new ways to
> >revive that.
> >
> >or maybe not...what do you think?

From: "Minh Q. Le" <mlowdrma@OCF.Berkeley.EDU>
X-Sender: mlowdrma@apocalypse
To: Corey Alambar <corey@ncd.com>
cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: NRRe: OTP: The racism discussion
In-Reply-To: <971210140404.ZM15691@ivanova.ncd.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.96.971210185336.17140B-100000@apocalypse>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


-->	I have experienced many forms of racism, but as a rhetorical
question I don't know which one is more damaging, taxing, or "preferable".
In other countries there is open racism and strong anti-foreigner
sentiment (sometimes state sponsored), and I have found that living in
such a situation is unbearable because you can't "ignore" it or "forget"
about it because it is always there.  I came to realize that keeping my
guard up 24-7 was wearing me down mentally, physically, and emotionaly.
To clarify, I had to be _very_ careful where I was, who was around me, and
what possible sticky situations might develop because I was the "visible
minority".  On the other hand, I was thankful that the situation was so
obvious that if something unpleasant did arise, I would be somewhat
prepared--better a visible "enemy" than a hidden one.  In the US, I have
felt that there is more hidden racism...kind of like walking into a room
and getting a feeling that the interrupted conversation was about you, and
it wasn't a very positive conversation either.  This might be different in
other parts of the country; that's just my impression of California and
mass media.  The good thing is that you can lead a relatively normal
existance ignoring it, but occassionaly, there will be a devastating
encounter "out of the blue" which just screws up your whole week because
you weren't prepared for it.  Issues like the "glass ceiling" and
preferential hiring practices are real and frustrating because they are
obstacles which you can't (or which are really difficult to) pin down.  I
am not a paranoid person, but neither am I a dense person...these are my
observations and I would be interested to read what others have to say
about them. 


:)
M&m

I have been extremely lucky, I have not experienced or at least noticed
any racism.  Though I did get many curious looks and interesting comments
when I used to wear a turban and bana (sikh dress).  However, I found it
funny when a friend of mine from England said that if I went there I would
definatly be discriminated against.  He told me that Indians are more
discriminted against more than other people of colour.  He said that
"black" people were hassled alot, but they fought back, so people left
them alone, where as Indians just took it.


Sat Kriya

>megan said....

>>>my problem is that yes "i am an equal"... but i there are times i like to

>>>for me...

>>why does wanting equal *rights* automatically throw
>>chivalry out the window? in a way, i see chivalry as a high respect for a
>>woman. you know, i think it's this country. european women (check out the
>>french) can be extremely powerful, command respect, and yet still be a
>>_woman_ - sexy, strong, intelligent, beautiful - and turns heads for all of
>>those reasons. i don't see that as hypocritical at all.

>
>sometimes i think we just have to weigh the positives and the negatives and
>the price of sexual inequality...
>
>and frankly, i'd be very willing to trade in a couple of million times of
>having some man hold open a door for me ....

(snip)

>and it ain't about opening doors and lighting cigarettes.... holding a door
>open for someone is about respectful behavior, that's a no-brainer...  i'll
>hold a door or a lighter for a man or another woman without thinking twice
>if that's what's called for... sheez.  that's just manners.

uhhhhh... to me this seems a bit contradictory. if being chivalrous is
"just manners", where does it fall in weighing the pros and cons of sexual
inequality? it shouldn't. in fact, it ought to be the other way around: as
women get more respect in society as equals, shouldn't men be *more*
chivalrous towards us?

so what's up, _b o i z_ ?????

Subject: drug addiction
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII

ok, i dont mean to start ANOTHER drug thread, but heres my problem:

one of my best friends for the past 2 years has been an avid cocaine user ever
since i first met her. she has always been able to convince people, even
herself that she never had an addiction, and she was so convincing that i dont
think she really had a problem. when a friend told her that she was worried
about her, she was able to stop for 2 months to prove that she wasnt addicted.
but now, i think that even she realizes that things are getting out of hand,
but wont/cant stop by herself.  She is using more often than ever before and
all of her friends are scared for her. so here is where i need help. she is
showing some of the addiction signs that i have learned to look for and i have
talked with some of her other friends and we pretty much agree that something
must be said, so.....
what should we say to her? should we approach her alone or should we do one of
those group intervention thingees? what if she turns away from us? then what.
i dunno, i'm not even really sure what i should ask you guys. i guess that any
tips or recomendations any one has ( since i know there are a lot of us out
there that have been through some tough times with drugs)  i will be eternally
thankful.
-blake

At 11:19 AM 12/10/97, Megan Hug wrote:
>well... physical bodies dictate how the brain has been formed... no, they
>are not shaped differently... but i believe that studies have shown that
>they do indeed work differently.  wish i could give you some actual
>references... (wrote a term paper on the differences/similarities of
>men/women- these resources may have been old, but i don't think THAT much
>has changed in these sort of studies since 1991).

wait, wait! i know what you're talking about! (reaching back through the
cobwebs that have formed over the past few years) there's that grey mass in
the center of the brain that dictates which side of the brain you're using
at a given time. and the one in women gear us to use *both* at the same
time (ie: women are better multi-taskers supposedly) where as men tend to
use only one side at a time.

whether or not this part of the brain developed over time (millions of
years, tho) due to need rather than it having been there since cell-day one
is another question tho....

>I will admit that these studies may have been swayed due to nurture... but
>i don't believe that environment has that much of an impact on a persons
>sexuality... i think that genetics play a much larger roll in our
>personalities and sexual behavior than you think!

hell yeah.


>>It is my belief that the reason they act "differently"
>>is due to how they are raised from birth and the expectations that
>>other people/our society has of them.
>ah... but where did all of these expectations come from???
>if we started the same... why are we so different now?
>and if we started different... why do you think that is?

it's hard to say how much of a person is that way due to genetics and how
much due to environment. can't agrue either side.... they're both such huge
contributors! :P
>
>>For example, I do not believe that women just have a natural desire
>>to play with barbies, or that boys just have an instinct to get matchbox
>>cars, yet their parents often act as though they do.
>i'll agree with you there... to some extent.
>BUT do you think toy manufacturers package their products to target adults?
>no, they do study upon study to see what children like... and i just so
>happens that girls go for the pink toys and boys go for the blue (a rough
>generalization)... have you ever looked down a girls toy isle? a boys?
>completely different!  and i don't believe that parents/society instill
>this into their child... baby toys are all colors of the rainbow... no
>premeditated sexism there.  but once they are old enough to walk down the
>isles themselves... you see what children their age and sex like.  (i'm not
>saying every child fits into these stereotypes... this is all just a
>generalization... and i personally believe it's 40% nurture and 60%
>nature... and once again- i know i am no scientist... just formed my own
>educated hypothesis)

toys, i think, i'll have to argue on the side of socialization. from day
one so many influences are telling us what to be, how to be, what to like,
how to look, what to want (welcome to ameri(k)a), what to buy. i know there
are certain stages at which a child can comprehend things (visually), but
i'm pretty sure preferences are (aside from those life and death related
ones) instilled in us.

>>I definitely do not agree in the phrase "different but equal". That is like
>>saying kids in special education are looked on as "different but equal"
>WHOA!
>i _would_ say that...  whose to say that intelligence quantifies greater than?
>you ask the parent of a special ed. student... and i bet they will say that
>he/she is just as special as any other child... of course, we all have our
>strengths and weaknesses... we are different.
>i think we _are_ all equal! one may be more intelligent... but the other
>may be more ________.

i know! why can't you respect someone that is totally different than you?
all the more reason to be awed, i'd think.... granted sometimes you have to
respect something that you might not agree with, but does that mean the
different viewpoint/race/gender/sexual orientation doesn't deserve the same
(meaning equal) basic rights as the most common (or dictated, "chosen")
one?

>>or that people of color are treated as "different but equal".
>well why not?!!!

not that they _are_, but _shouldn't_ they be?!?  and in the same light,
shouldn't women/views/sexual orientations be treated as "different but
equal" as well?

>very, very basic example--> all fruits are equal... right?
>(ok, ok... just work w/ me here! :)
>apples and oranges are different... right?
>but whose to say that one is intrinsically better than the other?
>
>DISCLAIMER:
>all of the information mentioned above is a mish-mash of my
>beliefs/veiws/thoughts...
>they may be different from kim's... but by no means more or less equal!
>
funny. :)

ditto. (what was it i said about sometimes tolerating.... doh. :P)

e. :)

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Dec 11 06:02:10 1997

From: ".oOo.oOo.oOo." <groovinkim@connectexpress.com>

  "Ravers 'Round the Bay" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Re: NRR Re: Sexuality and Sexism - Part Two :)
Date: Wed, 10 Dec 1997 21:54:25 -0800
Message-ID: <01bd05f9$3c8b4e40$d656dad0@groovinkim.connectexpress.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0

	charset="iso-8859-1"

>At 09:20 AM 12/10/97 -0800, .oOo.oOo.oOo. wrote:
>>I guess I am all alone here, but I honestly do not believe there
>>is any difference between men and women other than their
>>physical bodies.
>well... physical bodies dictate how the brain has been formed... no, they
>are not shaped differently... but i believe that studies have shown that
>they do indeed work differently.

I guess it depends on what you consider significant mental differences.
I think our current understanding of the mind is limited, and therefore
people try and make generalizations about things.....I don't think they
work differently in any significant way.....I think that even the people who
are doing the studying already have an idea that they work differently,
so they set out to prove that theory.....

>>For example, I do not believe that women just have a natural desire
>>to play with barbies, or that boys just have an instinct to get matchbox
>>cars, yet their parents often act as though they do.
>i'll agree with you there... to some extent.
>BUT do you think toy manufacturers package their products to target adults?
>no, they do study upon study to see what children like... and i just so
>happens that girls go for the pink toys and boys go for the blue (a rough
>generalization)... have you ever looked down a girls toy isle? a boys?
>completely different!  and i don't believe that parents/society instill
>this into their child...

Of course they are targeting adults, children don't have money!
If a child saw a toy they wanted and the parent looks at it and thinks
"eew..i don't want my kid to have that" then it won't get bought.
Here's the thing - the kids they are doing those studies on have already
been taught by their parents what is appropriate behavior. From birth
kids grow rapidly, observe their parents, and attempt to copy them.
If parents dress girls in pink from birth,  naturally at age 5 or so they
think that they are supposed to pick pink.

I don't know about every family, but from age 2 on my parents had the
TV on when i was in the room. (i sure hate television, but that's another
rant.) Anyway, so from age 2 on I watched Sesame Street, etc. etc. as
well as cartoons and advertisements on TV. What did I see? I saw
little girls playing with dolls, and wearing pink. Hmm. I wonder what kind
of toys I thought  I should get?

Being that children are natural learners, they tend to internalize what
they see around them...this is just one example....

baby toys are all colors of the rainbow... no premeditated sexism there.

I'm not saying that this is sexism necessarily....it's just the way our
society
looks at men and women.....sexism implies it is bad.....well, i guess i must
admit i think we would be healthier and far more advanced if we didn't pay
so much attention to gender differences.....but i'm not saying our present
society is premeditating to be sexist...i think they just don't realize it!

But I have to disagree, I think that even as young as babies boys and girls
are treated differently - maybe not in the colors of their toys, but in more
subtle
ways......

but once they are old enough to walk down the
>isles themselves... you see what children their age and sex like.

I see products of our society and culture (and especially media!)

>>I definitely do not agree in the phrase "different but equal". That is
like
>>saying kids in special education are looked on as "different but equal"
>WHOA!
>i _would_ say that...  whose to say that intelligence quantifies greater
than?
>you ask the parent of a special ed. student... and i bet they will say that
>he/she is just as special as any other child... of course, we all have our
>strengths and weaknesses... we are different.

I know. *sigh* That was my point! Okay, I should'nt have mentioned it
because
now I must explain in length. I feel that the system of separating children
into different classes (i.e. a special ed class, a regular class, and a AP
class)
is not healthy for learning. When special ed kids are on the playground,
the other kids tease them, call them "stupid" etc. etc.

While it may be true that the intentions of the people who are separating
them is for them to learn better, I feel that it actually harms their
learning.

In the same way, i feel that separating men and women and treating them
differently even as children not only harms the people, I think it limits
people by confining them into certain labels and boundaries.

I agree that each individual person is different - that is why I think that
grouping people into broad categories like special ed or AP, or even
male or female, limits them. We all have some masculine and some
feminine characteristics no matter what our biological gender. By
expecting people to think differently, act differently, dress differently,
etc.
due to their gender, it limits their behavior and how they can interact.

>>or that people of color are treated as "different but equal".
>well why not?!!!
>
>very, very basic example--> all fruits are equal... right?
>(ok, ok... just work w/ me here! :)
>apples and oranges are different... right?
>but whose to say that one is intrinsically better than the other?

Word.  Neither is better. So in a perfect world, it shouldn't matter.
But, in our society, what ethnicity you have, what gender you have, etc.
DOES matter. You are treated differently!  That is what I am trying to
say...
I feel that treating people differently for their race, gender, or way of
learning
is limiting them.....and unfair!

love kim

e.menon wrote:

> 
> >and it ain't about opening doors and lighting cigarettes.... holding a door
> >open for someone is about respectful behavior, that's a no-brainer...  i'll
> >hold a door or a lighter for a man or another woman without thinking twice
> >if that's what's called for... sheez.  that's just manners.
> 
> uhhhhh... to me this seems a bit contradictory. if being chivalrous is
> "just manners", where does it fall in weighing the pros and cons of sexual
> inequality? it shouldn't. in fact, it ought to be the other way around: as
> women get more respect in society as equals, shouldn't men be *more*
> chivalrous towards us?
> 
> so what's up, _b o i z_ ?????
> 

the usual thing is up  =)

Well this is why i believe we need to toss out this idea of uniform rights
for all. I feel that each person is unique and each likes
to be treated uniquely. So I like to find out how a person likes to be treated
and then treat them as such. Some like it when i open doors or
bring them warm slippers and coffee in bed on a cold morning
and i am happy to do that for women or men if that is what makes them 
happy. I will not do those things for those who wish to not be treated that 
way. I know a woman that says she hates the equal rights movement
because she wants to be "treated like a lady by a man". Thats her
choice and i respect it while i treat others as they wish to be treated.

Each of us has different needs for many different reasons whether
that be gender, race religion etc...so we each need something 
more than equal rights. Sounds complicated but i think we can 
eventually find a system that is free of any type of discrimination
and provide evryone with what they need. I think raving and the interactions
that it produces including the discussions that go on here
in sfrave land are a way to learn to  respect each other no matter
how much we diasgree and feel we are different from each other.
I think when we really ask ourselves how we can make sure everyone we 
come in contact with is getting what they need then we will
ALL be pretty happy one day...dont you?

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

  my dream is that everyones dream come true.

Hi Moshe!  ]=}

 About time *someone* leaped to SC's defense. I was beggining to think no 
one liked them.

On Wed, 10 Dec 1997, Moshe Kasher wrote:

> Ran d dreams  reasoning for boycotting space children was one of
> the most petty i have ever heard of.



 You need to get out more son.


 
> Mr dreams would u have boycotted if it
> was harmony dropping flyers without asking u first i doubt it.


 I called for a boycott for a number of reasons. If Harmony had dropped 
the flyers off, uninvited at BM I would have given Greg shit for it. I 
think most people who know me (including Greg) wouldn't doubt that for a 
minute.


> They
> definately mad a big tabbo mistake by not coming back and making sure their
> flyers were cleaned up


 Mearly one of many mistakes these folks have made.


 
> but who are u to make rules of what u can and cant
> do at burning  man.

 I don't make any rules. I do, however have respect for the producers of 
Burning Man and what (they seem) to try to be doing with it. Nor did I 
say anyone *should* do anything because of what Space Children did. I said 
I was not going and *asked* (more courtesy than the SC gang showed me) 
for others to do the same for the reasons I outlined. I was expressing my 
viewpoint and was always clear that it was my viewpoint only.

 BTW it was my table the flyers were placed on. I do make the rules for 
what can be placed there. It is called taking responsibility.


> last time i checked that was the antithesis of what
> burning man is.


 Wrong. The antithesis (as far as I can tell) is commercialism and 
especially commercially raped art. There are rules there and for a 
reason. It is not about total anarchy. There is structure there more 
strange and beautiful (in some ways anyway) than anywhere else in the world.


 
> I dont justify everything space children has ever done
> they, like alot of people have made mistakes in promoting.(like each and
> every promoter, ug and massive)


 Everyone makes mistakes and hopefully we learn from them. My biggest 
disapointment was not getting an apology from Space Children. Perhaps I 
dealt with the subject in such a way as to make it difficult for them do 
make amends without losing face. Perhaps they don't care.


Happy Hplidaze everyone,


Ran D. Dreams

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 11 Dec 1997 17:36:25 -0000

Message-Id: <l03110702b0b5cfdd1204@[38.248.198.56]>
In-Reply-To: <v01540b00b0b51881e8e2@[205.134.235.62]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 11 Dec 1997 09:36:06 -0800
To: sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Re: NRR Sexuality and Sexism
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


>>and it ain't about opening doors and lighting cigarettes.... holding a door
>>open for someone is about respectful behavior, that's a no-brainer...  i'll
>>hold a door or a lighter for a man or another woman without thinking twice
>>if that's what's called for... sheez.  that's just manners.
>
>uhhhhh... to me this seems a bit contradictory. if being chivalrous is
>"just manners", where does it fall in weighing the pros and cons of sexual
>inequality? it shouldn't. in fact, it ought to be the other way around: as
>women get more respect in society as equals, shouldn't men be *more*
>chivalrous towards us?
>
>so what's up, _b o i z_ ?????
>


the term "chivalry" triggers the image of the strong manly knight throwing
down his cape over the mud so the delicate maiden who must be kept clean
and protected at all costs can gently step over it, so as not to soil her
clean white embroidered shoes...

and elizabeth, that is connected to the same behavior patterns that over
the centuries has kept women from realizing the power and potential that
they have.  (i hope you read my comments about my mother and my 89-year old
friend and how these attitudes affected their entire lives, that was the
real point of my post)...

Holding the door and lighting that cigarette is a modern version... and as
a traditional behavior pattern, it goes hand in hand with expecting women
to follow different (and lesser) paths than men.

if it's so important having men open doors for you that you're willing to
trade in their true respect for your true abilities, then go for it, and
enjoy it.

but i don't want to be treated like a princess, i don't need simple things
done for me just because i'm a girl. I just want to be treated respectfully
as an equal.... and i will do the same in return.. that's the difference i
mean between "manners" and "chivalry"

if you think the "boiz" should have better manners and behave more
respectfully to you and everyone else, then i'm with you all the way...
but that isn't about gender.   just like giving your seat to a pregnant
woman on the bus isn't because she's a woman, it's because she's
pregnant... it is very important to think carefully enough to see the real
reasons for certain behaviors.  you should give your seat to any elderly
person on a bus, not just women, because it's easier for a young person to
ride standing up.  that's common sense, and it's manners.

my dream is to live in a world where we treat everyone respectfully and
with consideration of the individual person they are, regardless of their
gender, race, age, etc,  because that's the way it should be.  no princes,
no princesses.

leslie

i'm wondering you people,,,

what the hell is going on on this list?

i mean, i leave, i subscirbe to the sfravEs digest (burp!) and i look at my
mbox and it's filled with sex!
well let's schedule a tantric mutual masturbation ceremony one night when
we're all home in the wee hours of the night.  we'll all play a rave tape
at home too so this will be double rave related.  then it will enhance our
spirituality and we'll all feel connected more in a way.

i mean, i thought i was the sex fiend.  the dirty old deepfog.  but now i
wonder!  =]  actually though the fish (the foolish one) had a good point in
talking about sex being like a ritual.  i think a lot of things in life
should be treated as such including,

-eating
-ingesting any substances
-raving itself

i mean we have such an automated society like we can get 99 cent whoppers
w/o even having to blink.  the 25 cent sex booths. we live in an instant
breakfast society.  well slow down everyone.

i leave my soapbox now for some other bright cheery mind.

slow change for equality that may not just stop at a sexual equlibrium...

this ever does happen,  it would be extremely interesting to see how
different things are (technology aside) in the world.  i think that the
strengths and weekness of a female dominant society would be very unique
from what we have today!

just a thought...

There was once a time, before people kept much in the way of historical
records, when women WERE the dominant sex.  Before anyone knew how
babies were made, women were considered to have the magical power of
creation, and men were just big and strong and could kill things.

Here's a tip:  If women want to be the dominant gender, all they have
to do is withhold sex worldwide for one week and bring male-dominated
society to its knees.

Steve.

Actually (IMO),

Sexism/racism/etc. will become less and less prominant in our world as the
information age begins to take root in all aspects of our lives.
The haves and have nots will be determined by who has the information and who
is "in the know" rather than by color, sex, etc.
Superiority will be completely determined by who consistently has the right
information at the right time.

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

Hi all!  ]=}

 I'm almost sorry for spamming three lists!  ;) Saw an article in the SF 
Chronicle (page A7, 12/10/97) talking about Solar Flares. Essientially 
they are very powerful and can affect (in some ways) life and 
telecommunications here on Earth due to the IMMENSE amount of 
electro-magnetic energy they spew at the Earth (is it just me or does the 
Sun seem a bit "male" in this respect ;).

 The interesting aspect (for me anyways) is that the peak output of these 
solar flare cycles happens every 11 years-- the next peak is due 2001. 
 That means the one after that will happen on 2012. 2012 is a year with 
much signifigance if you listen to Jose Argulles who interpets Mayan 
Prophecies. Coincidence?

(getting out the solar umbrella)


hugz



Ran D. Dreams


				    (Namaste)

At 11:37 AM 12/11/97 -0800, Thomas, Cassandra wrote:
>But what would be the cause for such a  shift...i think it would have to
>be something more than simply "it is our turn now"...megan, do you see
>women gaining dominance out of control of reproduction...because you see
>"female identified" values gaining dominance....why do you see this
>happening?
no, i don't see it happening from any of the reasons you mentioned...
and i really don't have all that much backing up my statement (just a
thought to start a thread...) BUT since you really shouldn't say anything
on this list without a valid reason behind it...

i guess i'd have to say that i see things working in cycles-
as steve mentioned, women were the dominant sex way back when... 
at this moment (whether we like it or not) it's men in the dominant role... 
and i see a great potential for women in our future.  all this fighting for
equality could end up giving us more responsibility than we had anticipated...
and you know what? i'm ready for a change!  and it's true that women don't
need men for the same reason we used to (food, shelter, clothing,
protection...) we can do it all on our own now.  
and i also see that once something has a lot of momentum... it is often
difficult to slow it down.

Robert Pointer wrote:
> 
> Actually (IMO),
> 
> Sexism/racism/etc. will become less and less prominant in our world as the
> information age begins to take root in all aspects of our lives.
> The haves and have nots will be determined by who has the information and who
> is "in the know" rather than by color, sex, etc.
> Superiority will be completely determined by who consistently has the right
> information at the right time.


When i go to these camping raves i always love seeing
people working and playing together regardless of race,
gender religion politics or color of our tails and stripes.
 I know there are occasional traces of discrimination but
i think they are rare or at least much less present
than in everyday life. I have seen occasional
things like "oh i cant lift that heavy speaker
or climb up there cause im a girl...lets get a man"
But those are rare exceptions. 

I often wonder why we cant take this out to the rest of the world
which is why i think massives have the potential to expose the
rest of the world to this new way of peaceful and equal 
coexistence.

The real source of a lot of our problems today are that a handful
(13 to be precise) have control of our resourses and pretty much
control the world. By fighting among our selves over issues
of gender bias or racial issues or any other subgroups
we dont have the focus or resourses to deal with the real issues.
 If we can find  ways to unite, then we can deal with the real power issues 
and redistribute it in a more uniform way so that we all 
have equal opportunities to get what we need and want. Raving,
i feel provides that opportunity. Isnt that what plur is about?

Im not saying that we dont have discrimination problems any more,
just that we need to also look at the bigger picture. And i think
that as robert said, the internet is also providing a tool
that is allowing us to move beyond these old boundaries
that seperate us and cause us to struggle for power over others
rather than power with others.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

At 09:36 AM 12/11/97 -0800, Leslie Ayres wrote:
>
>the term "chivalry" triggers the image of the strong manly knight throwing
>down his cape over the mud so the delicate maiden who must be kept clean
>and protected at all costs can gently step over it, so as not to soil her
>clean white embroidered shoes...

And get wet, and cold, and get sick, and die 'cause antibiotics and clothes dryers wouldn't be invented for hundreds of years...  

What I always find interesting about this recurring thread, is that chivalry is only remembered as it was/is applied to women.  Chivalry was a code of conduct that governed ones behavior towards both sexes, in all aspects of life.  Example, during a fight, if you disarmed your opponent, you would discard your weapon before continuing the fight... 

I've always wondered why men no longer think to treat each other like this, but we feel guilty if we don't act chivalrous towards women.

And yes, I do know that the code of chivalry served to enforce the idea that some men were intrinsically better than others... The commoners weren't expected to act nobly, blah blah blah.   I didn't say chivalry was all good, blah blah...

I've *always* thought this planet would be much more peaceful and
enjoyable if women had more power then men. Men are basically *jerks* and
in most cases and are all about being *better* and having *more clout*
then othe guys. This is apparent in everything. I deal with so-called
"professional males" all day long on the phone. It makes me sick sometimes
when I realize their mentality and their level of maturity. It also makes
me scared to think that there are people such as these running the planet.

I'm not saying all guys are jerks, but you have to admit that a very large
percentage of us are. It's sadening too, because the nice guys (like most
of us here) are overshadowed by the bad ones.

this is my own opinion....

Byron

At 09:36 AM 12/11/97 -0800, you wrote:
>real point of my post)...
****
a powerful one it was.

>Holding the door and lighting that cigarette is a modern version... and as
>a traditional behavior pattern, it goes hand in hand with expecting women
>to follow different (and lesser) paths than men.
****
whoa. being kind and courteous, having a bit of manners... noticing that
the end of someone's cigarette is cold, while you're holding a lighter...
ok, granted... i don't open doors for men, but i hold it open until they
put a hand on it if they are right behind me.. 
I open doors for little kids, and will stand with a door open for 3 or 4
women to go through if they are in an obvious group.  NEVER, never did it
cross my mind that they were incapable of opening the door for themselves
[in most cases], nor did I think them any less for not opening it for me Or
that they should take a lesser path, on the contrary, i am letting them go
before me, therefore giving them the lead, upper path, or whatever [cant
think of the right word].

If you are walking with someone, or arrive at a door just before someone,
it is just plain courteous to open the door and let them pass instead of
trying to get through it quicker than them, and let the door swing shut on
them. Has nothing to do with their position in life.

>but i don't want to be treated like a princess, i don't need simple things
****
why not?  everyone enjoys a little pampering.

>done for me just because i'm a girl. I just want to be treated respectfully
>as an equal.... and i will do the same in return.. that's the difference i
>mean between "manners" and "chivalry"
****
i can't recall having had a door opened for me by a girl.  not to say that
they expect it to be done for them.. there *is* a shortage of Doormen these
days at the local shops, but what i am trying to say is... if i ask you out
to dinner... we're not going dutch.  If we are walking together, and we
come accross a door, i will be momentarily confused if you open the door
for me... but will dismiss is as quickly with a thank you... [although i
think from then on, you will find it hard to get to the door before me].

>but that isn't about gender.   just like giving your seat to a pregnant
>woman on the bus isn't because she's a woman, it's because she's
****
it's not likely i would give up my seat to a woman on a bus.  who would?
she can find  her own damn seat. [there, happy?] when she gives up her seat
to me.. then we'll see.

>my dream is to live in a world where we treat everyone respectfully and
>with consideration of the individual person they are, regardless of their
>gender, race, age, etc,  because that's the way it should be.  no princes,
>no princesses.
****
I do what I do, may it be chivalric in anyway, because it makes me feel
good to do it.  Opening a door and getting a smile out of someone is more
than enough thanks for me... I may live in a mostly thankless world, but it
doesn't mean I'm going to be any less courteous.

love it when you get like this Leslie,
peace,
-SolR

At 11:32 AM 12/11/97 -0800, steve wrote:
>There was once a time, before people kept much in the way of historical
>records, when women WERE the dominant sex.  Before anyone knew how
>babies were made, women were considered to have the magical power of
>creation, and men were just big and strong and could kill things.

Just read Clan of the Cave Bear or something?  :)  

Seriously, my girlfriend has an interesting observation:  All the traditional matriarchal societies (that we could think of) occurred among peoples that had... well... MAN sized women.  Samoans, Hawaiians, some Native Americans, women of these societies are certainly not frail in appearance, nor lacking in physical stature.  No offence to these people, my girlfriend's family tree has both Samoan and Hawaiian roots, and I have Cherokee grandparents.  Contrast that with European women... Viking Babes (humor) notwithstanding, generally not as imposing size wise.  Hmmm.... 

>Here's a tip:  If women want to be the dominant gender, all they have
>to do is withhold sex worldwide for one week and bring male-dominated
>society to its knees.

In the UK, the cheer "long live the Queen" would change to "long live the goats!"   

Sorry!  That was Ba-a-a-a-ad...

--ChrisP

women deal with it.  They are stronger then we give them credit.

heya,

I agree. I did not make a reference to whether it was better or worse, but
rather how things will really be in the future.
There will always be inequity. Some will have more than others in all things.
The real issue should be this:
Its not that all should have equality in all things, but rather, that all
should have the equal chance at acquiring things.
The field should be level for those that want to strive towards their
particular goals (assuming they are good ones anyway), however it is not good
when spoils of one's labor be spread out amongst those who may not deserve the
fruits of your hard-earned labor.

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

Exactly. But within our society and how we're *supposed* to be raised, and
all the BS that goes with that.... what can you expect from the average
Tom, Dick, or Harry?

I would like to think that my son(s) and daughter(s) will grow up in a way
that's much different from the method that was used with my parents. Blue
and pink can be worn by both boys and girls... and my daughter shouldn't
have to wear a dress if she feels like wearing jeans...   all those
stereotyplical BS that's written into our minds from the very beginning.

It makes me sad to think of how far we *really* are from true equality
between the sexes. There are so many people my age that are so
*unevolved*.... I want to strangle them and tell them what's up. We need
to start admiring eachother more and excepting our differences...
respecting eachother for these differences.... and getting past this
physical layer...

Yep... I was raised by "3 women".. :)  Thanks Mom, Grandma and Auntie...
hehe...

Byron

p.s. Really tho. It is really only about humans attracted to other other
humans. The whole thing about races mixing is quite a notion. Race, as most
commonly use it, only reinforces the superficial differences between people
rather than allowing for an understanding of the real (and important)
fundamental similarities between all humans.
We need to get over this race thing.

On Thu, 11 Dec 1997, Christopher Porter wrote:

> Seriously, my girlfriend has an interesting observation:  All the 
traditional matriarchal societies (that we could think of) occurred 
among peoples that had... well... MAN sized women.  

-->Boy, you're gonna get blasted for that comment.

>Samoans, Hawaiians, some Native Americans, women of these societies 
>are certainly not frail in appearance, nor lacking in physical stature.
 > No offence to these people, my girlfriend's family tree has both Samoan
> and Hawaiian roots, and I have Cherokee grandparents.  Contrast that 
>with European women... Viking Babes (humor) notwithstanding, generally 
>not as imposing size wise.  Hmmm.... 
> 


-->I don't think I agree with your observation;  there have been numerous
examples of matriarchial societies in the past and I don't think I was
especially struck by the robust stature of the women. Since the accepted
theory states that Amerids migrated from Asia via an icy land bridge, and
human colonization of Pacific Islands originated from Southeast Asia there
is a possible suggestion of strong matriarchial antecedents passed on from
the Asian continent.  Samoans, Hawaiians, and Amerids display impressive
physical characteristics because both sexes lead an existance close to the
land and nature which dictates an active physical lifestyle.  I don't
think the women of these cultures are arguably bigger than their male
counterparts per say, but if you do a physical comparison of these women
with Japanese, German, and Peruvian women of course you are going to see
morphological differences since these people live in differing
environments. True, European women in the middle ages were forced indoors
to do embroidery, Japanese women were cosetted into doll-like
configurations, and Peruvian women into weaving textiles; these are faulty
arguments since they only apply to certain socially striated classes that
are not representative of the whole cross-section.
	Besides that, political power is quite distinct from physical
power and the fact that males tend to be physically stronger than females
is an undeniable factor that needs to be considered into such arguments.
There are examples of matriarchial lines in various Amazonian and African
tribes and when many of these subsistence cultures are examined,
traditional gender roles are present, but there also tend to be separate
spheres of power wielded only by males over other males and women over
other women (which kinda reminds me of "secret" male societies in western
culture, e.g. Promisekeepers, Masons, Robert Blythe inspired bongo beaters,
 women's tupper and society parties, collegiate greek systems, etc.). And
like much in politics, much has to do with symbolism, and even though clan
leadership might be passed down to a sister's daughter, the real power
might reside within the male dominated circle of elders.  

	But my point is, I don't think the size of a woman is any
indication of her strength and "woman-ness". Thinking so is not only
dangerous and presumptous in the size-ist sense, but she might just kick
your ass before you know it. 


	Oh, and I also wanted to add to Mr N'Stuff's thread: Interracial
crossing is very good in the biological and cultural exchange sense; too
bad social mores are still so primitive.


:)
J'rambling,
M&m

>On Thu, 11 Dec 1997, I noted:


>> Seriously, my girlfriend has an interesting observation:  All the 

>traditional matriarchal societies (that we could think of) occurred 

>among peoples that had... well... MAN sized women....  


At 02:48 PM 12/11/97 -0800, Minh Q. Le wrote:

>-->Boy, you're gonna get blasted for that comment.


Am I?  I drew no conclusions, made no inferences.  I suggest you sharpen
your reading skills.  I simply relayed an observation about the
matriarchal cultures that I have knowledge of.  If you're looking for an
excuse to make long rambling posts, please find someone else's mouth to
stick words in...


>>Samoans, Hawaiians, some Native Americans, women of these societies 

>>are certainly not frail in appearance, nor lacking in physical
stature.

[rest of my original post snipped]


First you say: : "I don't think I agree with your observation"  then you
confirm my observation by saying: "Samoans, Hawaiians, and Amerids
display impressive physical characteristics"... What?


>there have been numerous

>examples of matriarchial societies in the past and I don't think I was

>especially struck by the robust stature of the women. 


Please, give examples!  I was hoping someone would add to the list of
female led cultures...  I'm sure there are many I haven't considered. 
Again, all I said was that in matriarchal societies I know of, the women
tend to be<italic> physically</italic> more robust... 


[Lots of good scrabble words deleted]

Minh, with such an impressive vocabulary, you could make a good writer,
if you understood the concept or COHESION.  


>But my point is, I don't think the size of a woman is any

>indication of her strength and "woman-ness". Thinking so is not only

>dangerous and presumptous in the size-ist sense, but she might just
kick

>your ass before you know it.

Precedence: bulk


 I have seen shows on Discovery about this and some mention in my history 
classes, too.  It was never speculated whether the females were dominant for 
their reproductive abilities, so I can't really speculate on Steve's idea.

However, to contradict byroni's original thread, these societies were not 
all 'peaceful and loving' as we might like to fantasize.  In these societies 
(I learned about two, one on an island north of France and one somewhere in 
central/southern Europe - i think) the women were not only the dominate 
gender, but the warriors.  These women were some of the fiercest fighters of 
the times, tales say.
Also, in grave excavations, the female bones were the one's found with the 
swords, tools, ornaments, etc buried with them.  From this, the 
anthropologists suggest that women held much power and stature in the 
society.  I don't remember what they speculated the man's role to have been.

I feel that there will always be a dominant sex.  It may switch over time, 
but looking at different social groups in society, I think it would be hard 
to find a group of people that co-exist entirely as equals; somebody has to 
lead.  Somebody has to fill social roles and with these social roles, over 
time traditions will be formed.  etc etc

my $.02
Thomas
B-)

 ----------
From: steve
To: sfraves
Subject: Re: NRR: WOMEN ruling the WORLD?
Date: Thursday, December 11, 1997 3:05PM

There was once a time, before people kept much in the way of historical
records, when women WERE the dominant sex.  Before anyone knew how
babies were made, women were considered to have the magical power of
creation, and men were just big and strong and could kill things.

Here's a tip:  If women want to be the dominant gender, all they have
to do is withhold sex worldwide for one week and bring male-dominated
society to its knees.

Steve.
>>Now running for cover<<
