Name (or Nickname) = josh
                   or 725 if you will (and perhaps you might)

What is your Age= time is just another illusion of 20 years' length

Birthday= 30 November, class of '77 

What is your Sign= sagitarrrrrrrrius

Are you Married= no.

Have Kids= "have" as in "sleep with"?  "have" as in "cheat"?  "have" as in
"eat"?  oh, "have" as in "possess"!  no.  

Are you Single= i prefer the term "non-dualistic", but yes.

Do you Dj = why yes i do.  thank you for asking.

What is your most listened to Style of Music? = psychedelic trance, artsy
punk rock, metal, and dem funky L.A. Acid Breaks!!!

Musician / Artist= Autechre. Underworld. Cop Shoot Cop. Atari Teenage Riot.
the Jesus Lizard. nin. Pantera. Juno Reactor.

Hobbies= writing; spinning; entheogens.

Favorite Sexual Position= 

Ideal Party Linup= Christopher Lawrence, Trance, Sandra Collins, Ron D.
Core, Fester & Oscure on the 2 x 4...in no particular order...

Favorite Food= small pieces of paper, capsules, and a generous helping of
salad.

Favorite DJ= whoever's spinning as the sun rises over the desert and washes
the entire party with a lush wave of golden light.

Do you represent the Scene Negatively or Positively? = i don't represent
the scene.  the scene is an emergent property from a group effort and i'm
an individual.

How? = how am i an individual?  well, my ego gets in the way from time to
time.  so no eternal bliss for me (yet).

Do you go to parties to hear the music or hook up with the oposite sex? =
it's yin and yang, man.  true harmony is achieved with a mixture of both.
but too much lechery or too much self-absorption can throw everything into
koyaanisquatsi.

long live the new flesh, kiddies.

night transmitting cars across the room.
these things sent to dance across the room.
eye watching from your bed. returning to you."

Name (or Nickname): Uncle Noah

What is your Age:23

Birthday:2-25-74

What is your Sign: Pisces

Are you Married: God No

Have Kids: Nope.  But I do have 2 nieces!

Are you Single: Actually I'm PLURal :D :D :D

Official Mascot:  Mr. Potatohead

Do you Dj: yep

What do you spin:  Breakbeat and maybe a jungle track here or there.

What is your most listened to Style of Music?: Late 50's / early 60's 
instrumental grooves... Booker T. & the MGs, the Bar-Kays, anything on 
Stax, etc.

Musician / Artist:  I play keyboards and write techno from time to time.

Hobbies: Writing music, talking to animals and inanimate objects, cooking

Ideal Party Lineup: Herbie Hancock, Thomas Dolby, Art of Noise, 
Skylab2000, Bassland, Uberzone and me. :D

Favorite Food: is this a trick question?  Mexican. (duh!)
2nd Favorite Food:  Root Beer :)

Mission In Life:  La Purisima.  Beautiful Mission.  If  you haven't been 
there, go.

Favorite DJs:  Jam Master J, Grandmaster Flash

Do you represent the Scene Negatively or Positively?:  Positively, I guess.

How?: By bringing music to the masses (and mouthing off on the Internet).

Do you go to parties to hear the music or hook up with the opposite 
sex?:  Music.

Favorite E-Toy:  Vibrating Mr. Potatohead
2nd Favorite E-Toy:  Ravergurlies

Favorite thing that The Scene has brought to me:  E-Kisses :) :) :) :)

*BONUS*
How/why did you start Raving?:  I always knew my love of electronic 
music would draw me to the rave scene, but I got into raving after 
spinning techno on my KDVS radio show and then getting invited to spin 
at local parties.

>      Not long ago and not far away Santa was getting ready
>      for his annual trip...but there were problems every where...  four of
>     the
>      elves got sick, and the trainee elves did not produce the toys as
>     fast as
>      the regular ones so Santa was beginning to feel the pressure of being
>      behind schedule....then Mrs. Claus told Santa that her mom was coming
>     to
>      visit...this stressed Santa even more...when he went to harness the
>      reindeer he found that three of them were about to give birth and two
>     had
>      jumped the fence and were out heaven knows where...more stress...and
>         then when he began to load the sleigh one of the boards on the
>     sleigh
>      cracked and the toy bag fell to the ground and scattered all the
>     toys...so,
>      frustrated Santa went into the house for a cup of coffee and a shot
>     of
>      whiskey...but he found that the elves had hit the liquor cupboard and
>      there was nothing there to drink...and in his frustration he dropped
>     the
>      coffee pot and it broke into hundreds of little pieces all over the
>      kitchen floor...  he went to get the broom and found that mice had
>     eaten
>      the straw it was made from...just then the doorbell rang and Santa
>     cussed
>      on his way to the door...he opened the door and there was a little
>     angel
>      with a great big Christmas tree. And the angel said:  Santa, where
>     would
>      you like to put this Christmas tree??
>
>      And that, my friend, is how the little angel came to be
>      on top of the Christmas tree....

Those who don't feel this Love
pulling them like a river,
those who don't drink dawn
like a cup of spring water
or take in sunset like a supper,
those who don't want to change,

let them sleep,

This Love is beyond the study of theology,
that old trickery and hypocrisy,
If you want to improve your mind that way,

sleep on.

I've given up on my brain.
I've torn the cloth to shreds
and thrown it away.

If you're not completely naked,
wrap your beautiful robe of words
around you,

and sleep.

-Rumi

--
n8

The X(mas) Files
>
>  Mulder: We're too late. It's already been here.
>
>  Scully: Mulder, I hope you know what you are doing.
>
>  Mulder: Look, Scully, just like the other homes: Douglas fir,
>  truncated, mounted, transformed into some sort of shrine; halls
>  decked with boughs of holly; stockings hung by the chimney,
>  with care.
>
>  Scully: You really think someone's been here?
>
>  Mulder: Someone or some THING.
>
>  Scully: Mulder, over here -- it's fruitcake.
>
>  Mulder: Don't touch it! Those things can be lethal.
>
>  Scully: It's O.K. There's a note attached: "Gonna find out
>  who's naughty and nice."
>
>  Mulder: It's judging them, Scully. It's making a list.
>
>  Scully: Who? What are you talking about?
>
>  Mulder: Ancient mythology tells of an obese humanoid entity
>  who could travel at great speed in a craft powered by
>  antlered servants. Once each year, near the winter solstice,
>  this creature is said to descend from the heavens to reward
>  its followers and punish its disbelievers with jagged chunks of
>  anthracite.
>
>  Scully: But that's legend, Mulder -- a story told by parents
>  to frighten children.    Surely, you don't believe it?
>
>  Mulder: Something was here tonite, Scully. Check out the bite
>  marks on this gingerbread man. Whatever tore through this plate
>  of cookies was massive -- and in a hurry.
>
>  Scully: It left crumbs everywhere. And look, Mulder, this milk
>  glass has been completely drained.
>
>  Mulder: It gorged itself, Scully. It fed without remorse.
>
>  Scully: But why would they leave it milk and cookies?
>
>  Mulder: Appeasement. Tonight is the Eve, and nothing can stop
>  its wilding.
>
>  Scully: But if this thing does exist, how did it get in? The
>  doors and windows were locked. There's no sign of forced entry.
>
>  Mulder: Unless I miss my guess, it came through the fireplace.
>
>  Scully: Wait a minute, Mulder. If you are saying some huge
>  creature landed on the roof and came down the chimney, you're
>  crazy. The flue is barely six inches wide. Nothing could get
>  through there.
>
>  Mulder: But what if it could alter its shape, move in all
> directions.
>
>  Scully: You mean, like a bowl full of jelly?
>
>  Mulder: Exactly. Scully, I've never told anyone this, but when I
>  was a child my home was visited. I saw the creature. It had long
>  white strips of fur surrounding its ruddy, misshapen head. Its
>  bloated torso was red and white. I'll never forget the horror. I
>  turned away, and when I looked back it had somehow taken on the
>  facial features of my father.
>
>  Scully: Impossible.
>
>  Mulder: I know what I saw. And that night it read my mind. It
>  brought me a Mr. Potato Head, Scully. IT KNEW I WANTED A
>  MR. POTATO HEAD.
>
>  Scully: I'm sorry, Mulder, but you're asking me to disregard the
>  laws of physics. You want me to believe in some supernatural being
>
>  who soars across the skies and brings gifts to good little girls
>  and boys. Listen to what you are saying. Do you understand the
>  repercussions? If this gets out, they'll close the X-files.
>
>  Mulder: Scully, listen to me: It knows when you are sleeping. It
>  knows when you're awake.
>
>  Scully: But we have no proof.
>
>  Mulder: Last year, on this exact date, S.E.T.I. radio telescopes
>  detected bogeys in the airspace over twenty-seven states. The
>  White House ordered a Condition Red.
>
>  Scully: But that was a meteor shower.
>
>  Mulder: Officially. Two days ago, eight prized Scandinavian
> reindeer
>  vanished from the National Zoo in Washington, D.C.  Nobody - not
>  even the zookeeper - was told about it. The government doesn't
> want
>  people to know about Project Kringle. They fear that if this thing
>
>  is proved to exist, then the public would stop spending half its
>  annual income in a holiday shopping frenzy. Retail markets will
>  collapse. Scully,they cannot let the world believe this creature
>  lives. There's too much at stake. They'll do whatever it takes to
>  insure another silent night.
>
>  Scully: Mulder, I --
>
>  Mulder: Sh-h-h! Do you hear what I hear?
>
>  Scully: On the roof. It sounds like . . . a clatter.
>
>  Mulder: The truth is up there. 

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

A man walks in to a doctor's office with an ear of corn up his nose and
a carrot sticking out his ear.

The man pleads to the doctor, "I need help, Doc, what's wrong with me?"

The doctor quickly replies...

"You aren't eating properly".

rrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr

A cab driver reaches the Pearly Gates and announces his presence to St.
Peter, who looks him up in his Big Book. Upon reading the entry for the
cabby, St. Peter invites him to grab a silk robe and a golden staff and to
proceed into Heaven.

A preacher is next in line behind the cabby and has been watching these
proceedings with interest. He announces himself to St. Peter.  Upon scanning
the preacher's entry in the Big Book, St. Peter furrows his brow and says,
"Okay, we'll let you in, but take that cloth robe and wooden staff."

The preacher is astonished and replies, "But I am a man of the cloth.  You
gave that cab driver a gold staff and a silk robe. Surely I rate higher than
a cabby."

St. Peter responded matter-of-factly: "Here we are interested in results.
When you preached, people slept. When the cabby drove his taxi, people
prayed."


	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

At 02:26 AM 12/13/97 -0500, lara at vibe.org wrote:
>not to be a pro-technology person, i'm pretty uninterested in this debate
>but to make a point:
>
>if it weren't for technology.
>jungle wouldn't be jack shit.
>:)
>xo
>lara

I'm pro-technology when it is used in an altruisic way.  I love the
internet, but would rather be without chemical warfare.

In any case, with or without technology, nothing (for me) beats hammering
away on traditional drums for a Haitian dance class.  Rhythm is ageless and
universal.  I've found it best to look to technology for production, and
look to the past for music.

42,

Leonardo

There are enough witnesses at Stompy to verify that this happened on Dec.
1, 1997.  It didn't happen at your club.  It does not mean it didn't happen
at other people's events.

> Several times a night the club is visited by undercover SFPD and
>for security to turn their heads the other way would be to sacrifice a
>space that has been very friendly to our scene (Stompy, Pablo's Sugar
>Shack, Pure Space, Ultra) in a city that is becoming increasingly
>after-hours intolerant.

Good to know.  Now people know that they had better be careful doing
anything at VSF or any other club in the city.  Not a bad thing IMO.

>
>As for mistreatment of patrons by VSF security, I personally forwarded
>several of the e-mails that recently appeared on SFRaves to the owner of
>VSF.

Thanks for doing that, although I would have like to be asked permission to
do so.  This is a forum for *us* the rave community.  If you wish to snatch
somethinghere and present it at least have the decency to ask permission.
Do we know that things were handed off in sequence, or that they weren't
edited.  I don't know, and I own my words.  In any case, it would be good
to know next time.  My .02.

>  While I haven't personally witnessed any of the problems that Mr.
>Lee has (I use some of my own security on my night) the owner of VSF has
>told security to become less "intrusive." As for the accusations of
>racism, that's a tough call. I've never seen it, which is not to say
>that it does not exist.

Thank you.

>But when a person has admittedly had several
>drinks, uses foul language, and ethnic curses, it's tough to defend
>their position no matter how righteous.

So what was I to do?  Exit like a sheep?  Quietly?  Then the question would
be that I was too drunk anyway.  Being told that somehow I had broken a
norm I was not aware of.  Or did the people on the danceflorr sleeping have
some greater right than I to be there.  Why was not my word given eaul
value as anyone elses?  Was I that unreasonable?  Why canp;t anyone tell me
what *I* actually did, since nobody has come forward with any information
contrary to my position?  WHy is everyone I know asking, well you must have
done something but are remiss to tell me what?

This reminds me of the sexual harassment suits.  A woman is asked to mop
floors, when that is not nearly her job.  Get coffee when she's an
executive.  Patted on the ass, or massaged.  Often the publics *initial*
reaction is "What did she do wrong?"  or "How was she dressed?".  The last
and final straw to add insult to injury is "They had to do something wrong
to warrant some behavior!".  Same with rape victims.  Their past is
flaunted for the public and often the person is painted to be some whore
for the public to crucify.

Now what happened to me was far from aa rape, or even sexual harassment,
Iand I do not want to belittle my sisters who struggles are too well
documetned to argue or to take as my own.  The point is, until you're on
the receiving end you'll never know.

These days you need a videotape for anyone to beleive yopu and even that is
not 100%, as Rodney King.

Don;t defend my position.  I don;t care.  All I do care about is that the
club community takes care fo thier own.  You're in this for $$$'s and to
have fun.  We know that.  But with those $$$'s and fun, you have a
responsibility to your patrons who are trsuting you with their hard earned
dollars and time to take good care of them.  Providce a positive space, and
ensure a good time.

Whether or not I cursed is immaterial; it was ex post facto to my ejection.
My Drinking is immaterial, since I had 5 drinks in 4 hours, and there were
others far more plastered than I.  The fact is I was not treated well, for
whatever reason, and I wish to have an apology, publicly or otherwise.  I
will not rest until this occurs.

You and otehr promoters may want to smokescreen this, but that will not
happen.  Rest assured.  The only thing you can do, honestly is make sure
your bases are covered and that it doesn;t happen at your club.  Be good to
the people that support you and you will thrive.  Ignore them and wither
into the past.

VSF is now known for having a problem, and people are looking every which
way to  see if it's true.  The club has a rep. and now has to live it down.

All character assasinations notwithstanding, I am the only outspoken one.
Unfortunately for VSF, they've picked the wrong person to mess with.


> Security is security and a lot
>of the security at VSF work at 1015, Sound Factory, 177 Townsend, and
>Cat's Grill as well.

Big deal.  They are also very, green.  Working at several places does not
qualify you as a verteran.  Mature and seasoned security, I have had no
problem with for some 15 years.  Greenhorn security, like that at VSF,
everyone, even Preston has had trouble with.

This seems to me like this promoter, like many others, scared of the
negative publicity that this incident offers.  The scarcity of spaces in
teh city adds to this anxiety.  Let's face it, if a club is known for
people noit having a good time, or the security, for whatever reason, being
overbearing, the news will get out, and atttendance will suffer.  It would
be better for VSf to fix it's house, so that people going there can have a
good time, in a safe, fun environment.  I am holding them to a flame, not
only because I can, but because I feel that I have been wronged.

>On the streets you argue with a cop you're gonna
>lose.

These are not cops.  Illogical.

> In a club you argue with a security guard you're gonna lose.
>Sucks but it's true.

No kidding.  The point was to find out why I was being ejected.  They have
yet to provide and asnwer, which leaves them totally suspect.  You may
dismiss this, but once this goes even more public, and is in the public eye
even more, they will not just have me to answer to , but every patron who
comes in thier.  No matter who they are.

> It's best not to get into a situation like that in
>the first place.

So tell me, and I'm sure otheres want to know.  What could I have done to
avoid this?

I'm listening.


>-SUNNY

-John S. Lee

"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

I went to Music Works in El Cerrito (11225 san pablo ave) and they let me
rent-to-own a keyboard... you only have to pay 5% of the price of the
keyboard each month, and after 20 months you own it!  no interest charged,
you can't beat that!  got a roland xp-10 for $35 a month, sweet!

good luck,

> 
> Why should it be one or the other? I hope to live to be 100 (or more!)
> and make the most of every minute!!!
>

ok, lemme explain myself further..what i'm saying is i am not relying 
on the possibility of living to a hundred to live my life to the 
fullest.  i think that can be done by age 60 or so (VERY biased 
opinion...i know...) cuz if living to be 100 means being decrepid and 
invalid, then i don't want it, just to be alive and say that fact that 
i am 100 years old because i AM.  most of my friends will probably be 
dead when i'm a hundred (if) and more than likey i will have outlived 
many precious family members.  since i am one to cling to the past a 
lot, i don't see it fit that i live to be a hundred.  i think i can 
get the MOST out of life if i continue to live as i do...but i don't 
wanna let it DRAG out if that's what living to a hundred means.  i 
think a lot of ppl THINK they can make the most of every minute of 
life, but why wait until your a hundred? (i'm not saying you ARE 
waiting...i think a lot of us actually ARE living life to the fullest)
besides, age is just a number.  to me, it seems to be a relatively 
HIGH number and i question what MY life would be if i was 
hundred...life is what you make of it.  i don't see it NECESSARY for 
MYSELF to live to be a hundred for these reasons.  
from a darwinian perspective, with the population growing like a j 
curve, people living hella old only overpopulates and slows down the 
natural order of things...(NOT that these lives are not 
valuable..that's a whole other arguement...)
oh hell, now i'm going off on tangents...

doreen

Huh?  I was only pointeing out police brutality which often has a racial
component.  No matter *who* the perpetrators are.

> Again, by your
>own account, race was never mentioned in any way, shape, or forum. You
>*may* have shown that you were improperly picked on.

One can only ask what would convince ye?

>
>> Whether or not I cursed is immaterial; it was ex post facto to my ejection.
>> My Drinking is immaterial, since I had 5 drinks in 4 hours, and there were
>> others far more plastered than I.  The fact is I was not treated well, for
>> whatever reason, and I wish to have an apology, publicly or otherwise.  I
>> will not rest until this occurs.
>
>"But officer, everyone else was going 90 MPH too."
>
>Setting aside whatever occured, other people being more inebriated
>than you isn't a valid argument...

Adder,

You insist on people being treated on merit alone.  You also should insist
that people be treated equally.

These are not officers of the law.  Officers of the law will have their own
say, as will be proven shortly.

Despite what has been given, you and others have chosen to ignore this.
ABC will not ignore this, nor will others.  Once again, I did not mention
race in my post, I have said whatever if anything.  Please be accurate.  I
am saying that if anything they were arbitrary, and in this instance, they
have , unfortunately for them, picked on the wrong person.  Why has been
left up to them to answer, and to date they have been silent.

I have given them ample time.  Too bad that IMO they have chosen to spend
such time in an unwise fashion.  The rest will be left to those people who
really do have a say.

Wait and watch.  I am not the person you ever want to make an example of,
for whatever reason.

They just happened to pick on the wrong person.

"Officer, I am not just anyone, I am a person with clout.  You will pay for
this!"

And that is how this is shaping up.

This isn't make beleive, this is real life, with a real person, with a real
voice.

This will not stand, until *I* am satisfied.

I find it interesting that you would dismiss so gladhandedly and yet wonder
what it would take to convince you of my feelings:
-must I be called the *N* word?
-must I have been treated badly an acted in response as the submissive (I
do wonder why people abhor the rebel and insist on MLK analogies to meet
some criteria, instead of Cinque's, Haitians, or Malcolm X's).
-should my death prove to be that wrongdoing has occurred.

Sir, what is your standard for injustice?  What does it take to prove to
you that a wrong has been done.  Enumerate or hush dear sir.  For I and
others would surely like to know.

The problem here is  that they in thier misjudgement have picked on a
person who votes, is 33 years old, has never been ejected, has world
experience, political experience (I met, personally, more than one
President in my time mind you), and knows how to get a message across, and
most importantly feels wronged.

Basically the wrong Negro to fuck with.  My race is just an accent at this
point.  This is a raver who will not stand for bullshit, in a scene i
*helped to build!*! G*ddamit.  More than some, less than others.

So offer whatever excuses you may, there are other Af-Am's who can account
for said greivances, and other ravers of non-African descent who are
standing by me, and plenty of others who will be watching until an
explanation is offered.

Until then sir, it is nothing more than tainted parties held at VSF at best.

Rationalizations and excuses aside, they have fucked up , and will be
called to the carpet for it.

If you or others think that I'm going to be intimidated to let this go due
to your interpretation of events, with VSF being very silent (except for
it's cronies who continue to throw parties there), it only leaves them and
your motives suspect.

As I said before this is not over, and won't be over until I am offered
nothing more or less than an explanation of events.

Ravers:

You spend some $25-25 to get into a party.  What are YOUR expectations for
said dollars spent?  Do you exopect undercover cops trolling (as is the
case in Sugar Shack)?  Do you expect to be spied upon even when innocent?
Do you expect that you will be ejected for no other reason than talking to
other ravers?

What do *you* expect when you spend you hard earned $$$'s for a weekend of fun?

Most importantly, how do you expect to be treated, when you are acting like
everyone else?

Adder, you weren't there.  VSF has made no claims contradicting mine.  Why
then do you defend their actions so?

Does anyone expect hassle free partying , like in the *day* any more, or do
many of you expect problems with overzealous security?

Your thoughts are greatly appreciated.

Peace,
John

> >But when a person has admittedly had several
> >drinks, uses foul language, and ethnic curses, it's tough to defend
> >their position no matter how righteous.

Ah, yes, those damned ethnic curses. Use good old american curses like
"Hey, fuck you, you fucking fuck" and you're just peachy. But mutter
something in Turkish about said security p*kker-head being an
amermenian sheep farmer who spent too much time with his pants down
behind the barn, and ... well... all bets are off.

> So what was I to do?  Exit like a sheep?

Huhuh. He said sheep. Huhuhuhuh. Whatever you do, don't exit like a
sheep. And don't let 'em put their arms around you and call you
"fluffy" either. After all, they may understand Turkish and your
armenian sheep-farmer joke may be taken as suggestive.  Would never
stand up in an amerikkkan court-o-law.

More seriously here, it's interesting to note the multiplicity of
voices here that immediately decided to blame the victim, and sided
against the underdog -- people that weren't there and figured that JSL
must have done something wrong to get evicted and that VSF's
wonder-goons couldn't have possibly misjudged anything. After all,
security is deputized to act in the interests of the safety of all, and
since they are so empowered, they must be right. Ah, images of a modern
rome (falling) dance in my head.... Whatever you do fellow romans and
countrymen, don't question authority or you might end up in the modern
equivalent of being another neo-roman US citizen thrown-to-the
Nielsen-lions on COPS or True Stories of the Highway Patrol.  Don't
worry, they already got gladiator fights at corcoran prison for the
aspiring misfits out there. Your duty now for the future begins with a
strict diet of dangerous steroids, methamphetamines, and twinkies.

Ahem...

PS: My conspiracy-theory is that some SFR PLUR wanker decided to get
even for getting flamed by JSL on SFR and thought-up some
ecstacy-addled fantasy that would spur the security-goons into action
(he pinched my teddy bear's ass! he fellated my fairy wand! he spooged
on my fuzzy pants!) ... Moral of the story -- never trust anybody that
utters the word "PLUR" without snickering or howling with derisive
laughter.

I just got back from working in Bangalore (Karnataka, India) for the
last 10 days... the weird thing about Bangalore is that there is
*nothing* going on in that town 'cept the
rent/work/shopping/restaurants and "social" parties where people show
off how rich and powerful they've become ... I'd ask around  where the
concerts are happning and they'd say "what concerts?"; I'd ask where
the parties are and they'd tell me about some bars where people get
drunk and sing silly english lyrics to songs I wish I'd never heard in
the first place.... I guess I'm just hangin' with too many compu-geeks
to find out where the cool parties are happening.  I hear the more
cosmo cities in India, e.g. Delhi, or Mumbai (bombay) are a *lot*
cooler... all I know is that  I've seen better Indian music record
selections in little shops in Cupertino than in BLR, so...

... so, anywayws, it was quite exciting to come home and find this
thread going.

My 2 paise:

* For people that enjoy the beat, I strongly second the recommendations of 
	-- Talvin Singh
	-- Bally Sagoo (heard something good off a new/upcoming album
	   of his recently, newer than his debut album).

* For a raggamuffin / hip-hop take on the indian thing, check
	-- Apache Indian

* For an interesting mix of Indian and Western musics, I used to listen
to UK/indian groups like (back in the late 80's....):
	-- Monsoon
	-- Sheila Chandra

* One of my most favorite albums recently was orchestrated and directed
by my brother in law Brian Woodbury and his friend Chris Rael. It's an
album of classic Indian film music from director S.D.Burman remade and
modernized with an interesting combination of western and eastern
musical styles.  It's sung by the popular English/Indian songstress
Najma.
	-- Najma, "Forbidden Kiss" the music of S.D. Burman
	   on Shanachie records (avail. "world music" section of tower).

* If you're interested in hearing a storm of tabla rhythm, check out
Zakir Hussain, who has many recordings on CD, and plays often in the
bay area. (Last spotted at the SF Jazz fest playing w/ John
McLaughlin).

* Since I work in India for 2-4 weeks every few months, I've picked up
a  bunch of interesting/weird/cheez CD's. I'd be up for swapping
recordings of these (I have an audio CD recorder) in exchange for
high-quality cassette or DAT copies of interesting musics you all have:
	-- Tick Tack Toe Dance Tracks from Tamil Films
		(some great, some cheeze)
	-- Super Hits of S.P. Bala & Harihran
		(ditto)
	-- Kadhal Desam, Sundara Prushan, Andhimantharan
		(cheeze, but interesting nonetheless)
	-- Golden Collections of A.R. Rahman, vols 1 + 2
		(some really interesting modern indian film/dance
		 music on here).
	-- Daler Mehndi, "Dardi Rab Rab" (the CD someone sold me
	   when I asked for Bhangra, thinking I'd get indian hip hop
	   rather than a pop-version of traditional Bhangra dance music.)
	-- Polygram India "Dance Attack"
	  	(mostly cheeze but has a few interesting Bally Sagoo,
		 an Asha Bhosle remix, and some Apache Indian choons).

Nice thing about buying CD's in India is that the new ones cost $5.00
(which makes sense, since it costs less than $1.00 to make a CD). In
other words, the $10-$30 you pay in the US per CD is pure PROFIT
(robbery) on the part of the music companies.

I'd still like to hear some good Indian-techno/house (which isn't trance,
most of the stuff I've heard doesn't quite schwang my thang...).

"Love means never having to wear your sari"...

--I absolutely _adore_ pets.  I had a kitty once, but my dad gave him
away. I have had numerous dogs over the years (double entendre?) but am
doggless at the moment. I've also had birds, fishies, rodents, reptiles,
and the like.  I am presently living a lifestyle (I travel too much) and
in a place that isn't conducive to having pets :(  I miss them soooo much,
but I sometimes find satisfaction in plants.  Maybe it's a nurturing
thing, but I think it's just nice affectionate company that does not
require constant conversation. My favorite pets are fishies; i've been
keeping tropical fish for ages (since third grade) and always manage to
have a fresh or saltwater tank somewhere (not for the last couple of years
though). Fishes are so colorful and graceful, and I just spend hours
watching them; probably why I didn't buckle under stress more often. 
This has probably already been discussed, but what pets do you all have
("$20 a month will feed this child" and other kids not allowed to be
considered as pets--those toddler leashes are abominable)?

don't eat your papers first.

> > Why should it be one or the other? I hope to live to be 100 (or more!)
> > and make the most of every minute!!!
> > 
> > - Martin
> > 
> 
> 
> ok, lemme explain myself further..what i'm saying is i am not relying 
> on the possibility of living to a hundred to live my life to the 
> fullest.  i think that can be done by age 60 or so (VERY biased 
> opinion...i know...) cuz if living to be 100 means being decrepid and 
> invalid, then i don't want it, just to be alive and say that fact that 
> i am 100 years old because i AM.  most of my friends will probably be 
> dead when i'm a hundred (if) and more than likey i will have outlived 
> many precious family members.  since i am one to cling to the past a 
(snip)


-->Don't you think the American attitude towards aging is somewhat
worrisome?  Being old does not necessarily imply being decrepit.  There
are many old people out there that have enough spunk to wear us young
things out to nothin'.  My maternal grandmother is 70 (80?) something and
still is  very active with friends, gardening, keeping toddlers, running
the house, etc. (until her stroke, but  that wasn't entirely due to age
mind you, it was due to internal strife-like thirtysomething people).  In
my culture the older the individual is, the more unconditional respect
that person deserves.  I know that sometimes sucks for the younger
generation, but we all will  get old and it's nice when the kids don't  go
around calling you Gramps and shoving yah of into the retirement home
(okay, go ahead, flame me for  that one :). IMHO, the key to having a good
life in the twilight years is to respect your body now in your youth and
taking care of it.  Occassional decadence and depravity is all nice and
well, but moderation should be everybody's mission.  I look at myself now
and I realize I need to get out more often for physical activity (I know
dancing for  12 hours straight every weekend  is excercise, but what about
the other  five  days, you know?), I should lay of all the Lay's and
Nabisco, and Pepsi-cola, and caffeine, and processed sugar, and fast food
lard that is my ever so healthy student diet and start preparing real
balanced meals again, and blah, blah, blah, and yaddy-yaddy-yaddy...and
join a convent and start a bread and water vow of silence in a nettle
shift, and oh, sorry, your not the alt.recreation.masochist.guilt group
are you? Well, you get the drift...age is not evil,  and all those rich
femmes getting face lifts and tucking sags and wearing Gucci micro-minies
should know that by now since they've been on this earth since the
Pre-cambrian period. Today's obsessive youth culture will come back and
bite you in the ass one of these days...as for me, I love being young and
gawjeous dahlink, but I wouldn't mind it when my sides turn argent either
(besides, I've done it already and it looks good  :)

Thoughts for pen*E*s,
M&m

   


> lot, i don't see it fit that i live to be a hundred.  i think i can 
> get the MOST out of life if i continue to live as i do...but i don't 
> wanna let it DRAG out if that's what living to a hundred means.  i 
> think a lot of ppl THINK they can make the most of every minute of 
> life, but why wait until your a hundred? (i'm not saying you ARE 
> waiting...i think a lot of us actually ARE living life to the fullest)
> besides, age is just a number.  to me, it seems to be a relatively 
> HIGH number and i question what MY life would be if i was 
> hundred...life is what you make of it.  i don't see it NECESSARY for 
> MYSELF to live to be a hundred for these reasons.  
> from a darwinian perspective, with the population growing like a j 
> curve, people living hella old only overpopulates and slows down the 
> natural order of things...(NOT that these lives are not 
> valuable..that's a whole other arguement...)
> oh hell, now i'm going off on tangents...
> 
> doreen
>

I just heard a report about some new experiments similar 
to the transporter on star trek. They managed to read the info
of a photon and transmit that (*) info so that a flash of light
that occured at one point was transmitted to another point. Not
an actual tansfer of matter but close since energy =matter

So perhaps one day we will be able to download our spirits
into electromagnetic waves just like the indian shamans
 become an eagle. We  could trannmit ourselves to (*) any place
 or time that uses win95.

Or even duplicate ourselves on another planet and reproduce ourselves
as many times as our liscensing agreement allowed. We could 
achieve imortality thru silicon(*) instead of carbon based bodies.

We probably couldnt drink coke(*) tho as it would errode our servos.

But we could however (*)dance for weeks to out internal dj's.

Maybe the world wide web is like a giant cocoon that we will soon 
wrap ourselves in like a catapillar and then emerge as
something beyond the organic worm or the techo-cocoon.

Maybe the (*)butterfly we are about to become is beyond human or machine...

Maybe aliens are infecting our email with subliminal(*) mesages that 
activate a mutation of our DNA to prepare us for the transformation....
maybe you should send(*) this to all your friends and warn them
before we all become little grey borgs or something.

Destroy the machine!...but lets wait till i finish my term paper ok?  

	><(((*)>   <(*)))><

> >Don't you think the American attitude towards aging is somewhat
> worrisome?  

oh, i'm not worried about growing old.  i'm not worrying about dying 
either, they are both inevitable.  i must admit, that my opinion stems 
from observing my grandparents.  a couple of years back, i visited my 
grandmother in a convelescent hospital and saw the 'other' end of 
life.  it saddened me quite a bit.  i say to myself..."i don't wanna 
end up HERE in the last years of MY life.." but what about the ppl 
that WERE there?  did THEY think they'd end up where they are NOW?  i 
bet atleast SOME of them were a bunch of young hellraisers that liked 
to party in their day.  have they lived their lives to the fullest by 
being hand fed three times a day by hired staff?
hmm...i question this...
we only end up how we CHOOSE to end up.
and honestly, from a stupid, american post teenage perspective, i 
think i'd kind of rather be dead at that point.
when me living MY life to the fullest becomes a burden upon other 
people, then i think i'm no longer living life to the fullest, only 
the minimal.

doreen

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 15 Dec 1997 17:23:49 -0000
Message-ID: <19971215172124.8437.rocketmail@web4.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [204.94.209.1] by web4; Mon, 15 Dec 1997 09:21:24 PST
Date: Mon, 15 Dec 1997 09:21:24 -0800 (PST)
From: Layne Loomis <lucke@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Review: DJ Icey@ Nikita Complete
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Mornin'

O.K. lets see got to Nikita early (11:00pm). Scott
DeKastano s/p was up first in the big room since
Jeno decided not to show (for the third time in two
weeks). I was busy chattin' with some folks so I 
couldn't really tell you anything but that he sounded
good from my spot and he's a pretty nice guy as well.

Around 12:00 Scott came walking up to me kinda' pissed
and said well Jeno finally showed and for some reason
they let him come on? Now correct me if I am wrong
promoters, but if you show up an hour late for a set
your ass should sit down and you shouldn't spin that
night. I think Jeno is a great DJ but thats pretty
dis-respectful to everyone. Once, I can see, under
certain circumstances, but three times in two weeks?

Jeno, needless to say tore shit up, a nice hard one
hour set. Then on to the real deal.

Not really knowing what to expect (I had heard good and
bad about Icey) but seeing his records around for
10 or more years and loving breakbeat I had to see for
myself.

I positioned myself right in front of the booth (sorry
to anyone who was there and trying to talk to me I 
was in class that night 8) and he started rollin' out
the beats. Every song was better than the next with
insane build-ups and just incredible beats. As my
buddies and I were trying to figure out this a+r label
that every other record was, Icey turns down the
monitor and says its my label out of Dallas now. They
are on Acetate? so they can only be used Like 20
times then you throw-em out. We were bummed, guess we
can't
get those 8) 

During the four hour set he played three
records that he didn't make! How can you compete with
someone who creates all the records he spins and knows
the music inside out? YOU CAN'T!!! He was in constant
contact with the lighting folks so when he was bringing
on the build-ups they new how many beats were left
fuck it was amazing. At one point the lights all
dropped and the beat lazed into this beautiful Diva's
voice singing and he throws his hands up in the air
and starts singing with her getting the crowd into 
a frenzy before dropping back into yet another
break-down. He was in constant conection with the crowd
grooving his ass off and he truly looked like he was
having a blast. By about the third hour he looked up
at me and pointed to tables asking if I spin, and I
nodded my head, then he smiled and went back to
spinning. As my friends and I were looking at the 
records he was spinning saying "I've never seen that
Icey,You!!?" He pulled this particular record off
the platter, turned down the monitor and handed it to
me. "This is one of a kind, there are no other copies!"
I said thanks with a huge smile and my friends looked
at me like, you dick!  He ended the set with Rollin'
Gear - I know - mixed with Low Down Good Girl. Fuck he
rocked 1015 big time!! After the show I rapped with
him for a few, just an all around cool guy. 

Hi to the SFRaves folks out there Liz, Meg, Diana,
Byron, Josh sorry I wasn't more talk-a-tive but
like I said I was in school 8)


Note: To DJ's who just sit there and
stare at the tables looking super intense and
expressionless- it says a lot to a crowd when its
obvious that you are enjoying what your doing and its
a hell of a lot more fun.


Laters
Layne

There's a fantasitc book out about this sort of thing, dealing with
mostly the internet and stuff, but it is about technology in general
and its effects on the way things work.  Good?  Bad?  We'll see . . .

It's called "Silicon Snake Oil: Second Thoughts on the Information
Highway" by Clifford Stoll.

Check it out.  (Advanced warning: he's a bit of a nut case, but he
knows his stuff!)

Steve.

b e n c h u n wrote:
> 
> i wrote:
> >>> Mission In Life= to make the world better through technology.
> 
> then Lady Linz wrote:
> >OUCH! Do you really think that the world could get any better through
> >the use of technology? I mean, shit, our technology is surpassing our
> >humanity! Technology is creating a huge division in our society that
> >will not be able to be fixed. I think that most of our problems today
> >can be attributed to the technological advances of the 20th century, and
> >it makes me sick. If we're going to make our world better, we need to
> >focus on PEOPLE, not  TECHNOLOGY!
> 
> this could easily become a war, so i'll try to just present the reasoning
> behind my above response and leave it at that... let me give some examples
> of the ways i think that the world is made better through technology: my
> life span is now about double what it was before modern medicine. i can call
> my mom on the phone and, even though i'm 3000 miles away, hear her voice. i
> can access information in libraries, encyclopedias, and academic journals
> all over the world from my computer. i can listen to TECHNO on a huge sound
> system.
> 
> in my mind, part of what it means to be human is to learn to use and improve
> the tools we have, be that a simple stone tied to a stick or a
> supercomputer. of course there are many issues that deal with the
> responsible and beneficial USE of these tools, but decrying the advance of
> technology is not only misguided but nonproductive. if you feel we need to
> focus on people, then do so. but attacking technology as the source of our
> modern problems is foolish. we can never unlearn what we learn as a species,
> we can never return to the days of the past, as quaint as they might seem.
> we must accept inevitable progress and do our best to use what we learn and
> create to improve our world. which returns me to my mission in life...
> 
> . . . . . . .
> ben_chun@community.net
> ben_chun@technologist.com
> 
> www.community.net/~ben_chun/

--

http://www.compare.net/
Information is Power

HERE, HERE!

My grandfather (and grandmother) are in their 80's and they just bought a 5th
wheel and is traveling all over the united states. He still builds houses (he
is a carpenter) and he is still mentally sharp (although very opinionated.) :)

I love talking to him because he is interested in my lifestyle (raves,
technology, interactivity, etc.) and likes to prove to me how little things
actually change. He likens it to perception.

Anyway, I agree w/ Minh. Our attitude (Western) is very skewed when it comes
to our elders and aging.

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com


> 
> -->Don't you think the American attitude towards aging is somewhat
> worrisome?  Being old does not necessarily imply being decrepit.  There
> are many old people out there that have enough spunk to wear us young
> things out to nothin'.  My maternal grandmother is 70 (80?) something and
> still is  very active with friends, gardening, keeping toddlers, running
> the house, etc. (until her stroke, but  that wasn't entirely due to age
> mind you, it was due to internal strife-like thirtysomething people).

Date: Mon, 15 Dec 1997 10:07:06 -0800 (PST)
From: macadio <macadio6@rocketmail.com>
Subject: My Weekend in review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Well my weekend started off at 1015 Folsom on Friday
night. The guest for the evening was DJ Icey.. Now I
kind of wanted to see him but he is not really my
thing but anybody that can press a rekkid every other
week I thought but be interesting to see. After a
long sketchy misson of trying to get to different
locations to meet up with me crew. (Running on raver
time of course) I finally hook up with Byroni and
crew and we head out. We step in and it is wall to
wall packed people grooving out to ICey and lasers
everywhere and the nice 6 way digitial sound was
great. However let me just say that I respect all
DJ's and Rekkid producer but He threw a Fucking
Brick... He was totally on and is good Technically
but the tracks he dropped were shitty (IMO) it was
like the cheezy rekkids he prouduces but as someone
posted prior to me they were his acetates that he
made. I can appreciate some good acid breaks but
there are like certain degrees and his were really
cheezie and I was not into it. In addition to that
the crowd at 1015 has to be the worst. For those of
you that have been to that meat market know what im
talking about. There was a lot of pushy rude people.
But Icey gets off and David Michael gets on and
totally rocks my world. This kid is so good. He was
dropping Phat Acid/Tribal/Breaky House it was all
mixed up and it was crazy good. I don't know why this
kid does not get any other play outside 1015 we was
good Technically and his choice of tracks were nice
and smooth very buildy floaty he takes you on that
trip. BTW he is the kewliest guy you will ever meet
he is a nice humble guy I have had the pleasure to
play at his weekly gig that he use to do and also I
have played at a party with him before. If you get a
chance to hear him DO he rocks!! over all I had a
decent time. Saturday I Played with Vertigo at a
small house party at the "EBF house" Hello Tony... it
was kewl really packed if you have ever been to the
EBF house you know what im talking about very small.
There was like 50 peeps there real hot but nice
peeps. From there I went to Thomas Troubles party. It
was at the T&J factory I like that space. You would
hav thought it would get busted in 2 seconds but it
did not very low key. Only about 200 peeps. nice and
roomy good traks being played Thomas has a nice sound
system no too loud but loud enough. visuals and
little lasers and such. Nice crowd lots of smilling
faces, family type of vibey atmosphere. Hung out
there for a while chit chatted then I got way to
tired and it was really rainy so I headed out. Then
sunday I going to work on my tape but I felt lazy so
I did not. I know <Bad DJ boy, Bad>
I will be working on that this week so stay tuned.

Peace,love, and cyber sex..  P.S. Don't take last
line literally...
Macadio (Mack-Audio)


===

"Smack my bitch up"  -Prodigy

Layne,

I didn't like it very much..... thought it was cheesy and didn't have
enough rhythm for full funkdom....  I can't dig breaks too much... they're
cool to chill to for a little while, but to dance to them for 3 hours is a
bit of a "challenge"... I need music that has intensity, progression,
soul, jazziness...... it was up-down-up-down.....  I agree with macadio...
too many cheezy tracks.....   I was on E and still couldn't feel it.....
which says a lot.....  normally when you're on E and music is half way
descent it can be danced to.... it was an effort.....  but i enjoyed David
Michael.... :) And when I say "E" I'm refering to the Vitamin. :)

This is just my opinion... as a guy who liks a lot of soul, jazz and
deep emotion in his music....  I love retroy disco too.... so I'm just a
bird of a nother feather..... what I see as soulful, jazzy and deep is my
own taste.... so I'm not saying his tracks lacked these qualities for
others... just me.

Believe me tho... there are TONNNNNS of people who like DJ ICEY and went
nuts....  so don't let a few people's opinions spoil your taste in music. 

Byron
Deep Chicago House Fiend

From: jameSpark <jamesp@netscape.com>

X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.04 [en] (X11; U; SunOS 5.5 sun4u)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: trainspotting Doctor Martin
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-2022-jp
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hello everyone,

I was able to experience the complete set of Doctor Martin on Saturday
at Big Heart City. I enjoyed his set very much.

His setup that night were two technics 1200mk2 and a rane MP24x. He
plugged in his own phones, Sony V6, I think.

Doctor Martin came in with two flight cases, one hard, one soft. He
organized the records into two bins (different styles of music? one bin
per turntable?) and kept an empty one off to the side to put the records
he was done with in. If he wanted to reuse a record, he would just lay
it on top of one of the bins. He usually kept the left turntable dark
while the right one kept it's guide light on.

His records were good. DAMN good. A lot of them switched their rhythm
halfway through the song which helped keep things interesting. He
usually dropped the other platter around these transitions; pretty good
timing, letting the songs run their course while giving himself plenty
of time to beatmatch.

He played a few acappella vox records over his records. One that I liked
was a record which was going on about how "House is a vibe, a soul, etc"
and then dropped the "I am the creator" vox on top of that. Strong
female staccato vox over quieter reflective male vox. Simply beautiful.

Doctor Martin did do his upside down record thing. He got out a big
plastic base thing and put that on the turntable, then the record, then
some kinda endcap to keep the record down. He too the needle and turned
it over, adjusted the weight, and placed the needle on the underside of
the record. He did take some time setting the needle, but after it was
there, he didn't wind the record or anything to catch the music phrase
at the beginning, he just beatmatched and faded it in. A really, really
nice sound. The record he chose was perfect to play backwards soundwise.
4/4 time, minimal, clean, enough ride and bass to let you know what was
going on. I wonder where you can get those plastic base things, or if he
made it himself...

He knew his songs really damn well. The most magic I experienced from
his set would probably be his eq manipulation. Even when playing the
same record, he knew when other instruments would be coming in, when the
breakbeat or tempo change would occur, and used this knowledge for the
Forces of Good, making the same song sound different in 24 different
ways (4! combinations for 4 dials, I think).

He had to end a bit early for some kinda Big Heart City policy reason.
He was kinda bummed about it but worked with the BHC crew and ended it
when he had to. He mentioned he played there (first?) in 1990 NYE.

Some tips I picked up from his set:
* When beatmatching, start the record fast then slow it down. That way
you know your record is fast and have only one way to adjust
accordingly.
* If you have time, try listening to the record for awhile. This way,
you will be more sure what the tempo difference is and can pick up the
phrasing of the music easily and know when and where to wind the record
to for best mixing.
* Have really damn good records ;) Also pick up a few acappella vox
records if you can. Records which change in the middle of the song is a
goodness as well.

Doc Martin had a great set, the people really liked it, it wasn't too
crazy but the energy level was nice. He was friendly, but did
concentrate mostly on the music during his set. Doc Martin was very
consistent throughout the set and he was into the music. For house, he's
the greatest I've seen so far.

Cheers,
james

> > I totally agree with this. I much prefer to die at 60, having led a full
> > life as opposed to living to 100 having missed many of the simple(and not
> > so simple) pleasures...
> > 
> > 					Black Adder
> 
> Why should it be one or the other? I hope to live to be 100 (or more!)
> and make the most of every minute!!!

Because I knowingly choose to do things that are "bad" for me. Such as the
food I eat. My diet would make a health-food nut scream. However, I enjoy
what I eat. Given the choice of eating what I want, as opposed to living
off of nut n' berries and soy milk so I can live longer, I much prefer the
former to the latter. 

					Black Adder

Message-Id: <3.0.32.19971215144859.009109a0@po7.mit.edu>

From: Leonardo Gonzalez <lion@MIT.EDU>
Subject: (NRR) nut n' berries and soy milk and cognitive
  self-instruction
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Don't be fooled into thinking that you like certain kinds of food, so
that's what you should continue to have to enjoy yourself.  Taste is rich
in information, a very sensual sense indeed.  But it is ultimately up to
YOU to decide what to "like" and what to hate.

I bet it would only take you a couple weeks of eating a new food, knowing
that it's healthy for you, before you begin to actually like it.  The brain
is a very programmable thing, and such self-preserving tasks as
establishing healthy eating patterns can't be that hard to accomplish.  I
remember "forcing" myself to switch to nonfat milk when I was cutting
weight for wrestling in high school.  Only a few weeks later, lowfat milk
was too creamy and whole milk was simply disgustin.  To this day, I can't
stand the taste of whole milk; I must have conditioned myself pretty well,
seeing as how I used to love drinking fresh milk with the warm foam.

I used to hate garlic and onions; they're taste seemed horrendous.  One day
I decided to TRY to like them, knowing it would be good for my blood.
Ignoring the taste was not possible, so I just kind of sat back and
observed it.  I saw taste as information that I could use to create a
sensation of my own choosing.  I came to associate the intense taste of raw
garlic with a that feeling of wellness you get when you take vitamins, the
feeling that you are doing your body a favor.  I soon came to love the
intensity of garlic; after eating a clove I would relish in the
light-headedness that followed.

Food is one of the greatest pleasures in this material world.  I think it's
important to guide and nurture that pleasure in the right direction.  The
pleasure from knowing you're fostering healthy growth/maintenance of your
body far surpasses the "quickie" thrill of eating a candy bar or a bag of
potato chips.

Peace, love, and granola,

Magos

On Mon, 15 Dec 1997, Leonardo Gonzalez wrote:

> I bet it would only take you a couple weeks of eating a new food, knowing
> that it's healthy for you, before you begin to actually like it.  

The question is, why? I like what I eat, and it tastes great.  

> The brain is a very programmable thing, and such self-preserving tasks
> as establishing healthy eating patterns can't be that hard to
> accomplish.  I remember "forcing" myself to switch to nonfat milk when I
> was cutting weight for wrestling in high school.  Only a few weeks
> later, lowfat milk was too creamy and whole milk was simply disgustin.
> To this day, I can't stand the taste of whole milk; I must have
> conditioned myself pretty well, seeing as how I used to love drinking
> fresh milk with the warm foam.

Perhaps if you took some of your own advice, in a couple of weeks you'd be
drinking cream straight from the carton.

> I used to hate garlic and onions; they're taste seemed horrendous.  

Blashhemer! ;-) Garlic&Onions are two of the greatest things known to
(wo)man. Sauteed in plenty of artery-clogging butter of course. 

> important to guide and nurture that pleasure in the right direction.  The
> pleasure from knowing you're fostering healthy growth/maintenance of your
> body far surpasses the "quickie" thrill of eating a candy bar or a bag of
> potato chips.

Again, it is a basic difference in philosophy. I don't question the choice
of those that choose to eat as healthy as they want. I don't turn an
upturned nose towards them and talk to them about how they should be more
decadent. It's my choice and I am happy with it. 

On the other hand, I have noticed many health-food fanatics do tend to
look down on others who do not share their "enlightened" viewpoints, and
tend to lecture them ad nauseum about their choice in diet. I rank them
somewhere around Jehovah's Witnesses in both their zeal and the import I
give their words. 

Live and let live.

					Blak Adder

were more intoxicated doesn't "excuse" the fact that jslee had a few
drinks.  I'd rather ask, what was the excuse of "security" for ejecting
him rather than those who were more out of it (even asleep, for whatever
reason)?  Did John aggressively demand that the bartender put another lime
in his drink?  Did he shake a hand or hug someone
without the approved angle of rotation?  Did he accost the DJ and
demand a rewind of "Move Your Body"?  Did he do the John Travolta Dance
on the way to the bathroom?  Did he build an 18-storey Cup Tower of Pisa
out of upside-down plastic cups and then knock it all over the dancefloor?

Or was he just someone the "security" decided to make an example of?

phred

On Mon, 15 Dec 1997, Fred Heutte wrote:

> Black Adder's logic doesn't add up.  He says that just because others
> were more intoxicated doesn't "excuse" the fact that jslee had a few
> drinks.  

John stated that his drinking was immaterial to his ejection because
others around him were more inebriated. I find a large flaw in that
reasoning. Even if everyone else had 10 drinks more than you it does not
make you sober. I was not and am not stating that John acted the drunken
fool. Just that the logic in reaching the conclusion that his drinking
was immaterial is flawed. And it is. And I utilized an analogy to point
this out.  

> I'd rather ask, what was the excuse of "security" for ejecting
> him rather than those who were more out of it (even asleep, for whatever
> reason)?  

Oh I agree wholeheartedly. Again, my comments were in no way intended to
"take sides" with VSF security over John. All I am doing is pointing out
what is in my opinion poor reasoning on John's part. If you utilize
erroneous reasoning in reaching a conclusion, then barring dumb luck, that
conclusion is most likely erroneous as well. 

> Or was he just someone the "security" decided to make an example of?

Quite possibly. And I would be most interested in knowing this as well.
Given John's version of the story, and Geoff and Megan backing it up, I
do find their actions suspect and one that warrants explanation. And I
really hope he gets it. From what I have witnessed in my years as a
concert/party goer I think that all too often security is not held
accountable for questionable actions, allowing them to play "little
dictator." 


					Black Adder

I have a american indian cd called dance to trance moon spirits.
It comes from england on logic records and produced by bmg.

Its similar to east indian but defiantely from turtle island.
Really good mix of tribal music and trance.

A couple other that are similar:
 A world without rules by paul heslinger and
  Tantric Steps by technova

mancia marco a wrote:
> 
> if  I should try to check out  Treasure  Island,  or  stay in LA for New
> Year's .................

I feel sorry for any that gets conned into going to treasure island.
With space children involved you know it will be a big disapointment
compared to the dozens of other choices for that evening.

Even on a good night with no competition space children cant even get a 
thousand people any more, there lucky if they get 200. With so many 
other choices and the price they are charging and the thousands who
are very upset at their recent behavior you can easily see this party
will be a waste and then you are not only stuck on the freezing island
but you've wasted your new years and your money.

The word is out that they are not paying their bills and most dj's
wont go on until they get paid up front and with no ticket sales
there will be no cash to pay these people. I was the guy that had to deal with 
all the angry people wanting there money back from there other recent
parties so i do know what im talking about. 

Sorry to be so negative on this beautiful monday morning
but i do hope no one falls for the hype and wastes their 
new years eve on this concert. They have had some great parties
in the past but things have Definately changed in the last few months.

The people that give you the gatherings are also doing a massive
that night if a massive is what you are looking for. Plus
all the great smaller parties.



From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Dec 15 22:51:21 1997

blkadder@value.net wrote:

> Again, it is a basic difference in philosophy. I don't question the choice
> of those that choose to eat as healthy as they want. I don't turn an
> upturned nose towards them and talk to them about how they should be more
> decadent. It's my choice and I am happy with it.
> 
> On the other hand, I have noticed many health-food fanatics do tend to
> look down on others who do not share their "enlightened" viewpoints, and
> tend to lecture them ad nauseum about their choice in diet. I rank them
> somewhere around Jehovah's Witnesses in both their zeal and the import I
> give their words.
> 
> Live and let live.
> 
>                                         Blak Adder


I think each person needs to make their own choice as to what they eat.
One mans (or womans) poison is anothers pudding.

I used to feel the same way as Black adder about eating what 
ever feels good and i think that is still a good philosophy.

My difference is when i say "feels good" i tend tend to think of 
that in longer terms. For instance i used to love coffee
because it felt good in the moment but over a period of
time it made me feel jittery and even sick at times.
I  generally chose the long term feeling of pleasure over the
short term. Not that this choice is better...just the one
i made. I certainly like the instant feel good response
of various substances but i also look at the long term feelings.
Take cigarettes...i used to love them because they felt good.
I eventually quit not because they were "bad" but because of 
the long term pain...like gaging and choking in the morning
made me feel worse that the momentary pleasure they brought.

But i still feel we all need to make our own choices and
keep the freedom to do as we choose. And we need to respect those
that choose something else.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

ps..is any one else addicted to the vegi satay and other wonderful
vegi food at veechas on haight st? That would be a great place
to have a sfraves dinner and they also have dead animals there
for those that eat them =)

you are what you eat...so eat live food if you want to feel alive.


From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Dec 15 22:53:28 1997
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 2832 invoked by uid 6000); 15 Dec 1997 22:53:24 -0000
Received: (qmail 2823 invoked from network); 15 Dec 1997 22:53:23 -0000
Received: from web2.rocketmail.com (205.180.57.68)
  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 15 Dec 1997 22:53:23 -0000
Message-ID: <19971215225622.10168.rocketmail@web2.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [206.80.9.221] by web2; Mon, 15 Dec 1997 14:56:22 PST
Date: Mon, 15 Dec 1997 14:56:22 -0800 (PST)
From: Messiah Wannabe <messiahw@rocketmail.com>
Subject: nrr: santacon97 review
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk





we headed to the oakland airport pretty early as we weren't sure how
bad traffic would be.  besides, it's hard to get much work done in a
santa suit - for some reason the women in the office kept sitting in
my lap and telling me what they wanted for christmas.  4 other santas
were arriving in a limo as we walked into the lobby, and as we had
over an hour to kill we all headed straight for the bar.  i started my
downward spiral into drunken debauchery by downing a shot of bourbon
with a beer chaser.  followed by more beer.  as the alcohol flowed, a
few more santas and ms clauses arrived.  then a few more.  and a few
more still.  within thirty minutes there were 40 of us at least,
rapidly getting trashed as bewildered travelers looked on in
bemusement and disgust.  someone passed out presents wrapped in pages
from porno magazines.  "be careful who you give these to, last year
one of the santa's went to jail for giving a couple of copulating
dinosaurs to a five year old..."

there were probably 100 santas on the flight to burbank, needless to
say we were fairly boisterous.  luckily the flight staff decided not
to press charges.  upon arrival we hooked up with some of the l.a.
santas, and we all piled into four large busses and headed to a kitchy
german-american bar on sunset, conveniently located near the seedy
motel where most of us were staying.  as we gathered on the rooftop
patio, i realized what a scary, bizzare sight we made.  the space,
which was fairly large, was wall to wall santa's and mz. santas. 
there must have been about 250 of us.  while most santas were dressed
in the traditional red suit and white beard, they all looked slightly,
well... off.  green hair spilled from underneath red hats, tatoos
peeked out from the sleeves.  one mrs santa with bright red hair wore
red fishnets, white fur-lined lingerie, and not much else.  guess the
la nighttime chill was mild compared to the north pole.  we all downed
multiple massive stiens of german beer.  eventually i made my way
downstairs, where santa's were harassing the regulars to the strains
of cheesy christmas carols played by the oh-so-suave lounge
keyboardist in the corner.  after we all got kicked out of the bar,
many of us wound up at a party in the surrounding hills.  eventually
at 5:30 or so my five friends and i wandered back to crash in our
hotel room.

the next morning, i ate a proper santa breakfast of pancakes, coffee
and beer at the farmers market, while trying to explain the santa
onslaught to a couple of tourists in a cigarette-stained morning after
voice.  "this is a tough time of year for us santas.  you know -
endless malls, parades and tv spots.  sittin on some cardboard throne
for enless hours while little brats shamelessly beg for some stupid
toy they saw on tv.  then they piss on your lap.  god i hate kids. 
we're just lettin off a little steam, that's all..."  i'd never been
to l.a. before, so i was hyped to check out all the sights.  the
afternoon blurred together in an alcoholic haze: buff black queer men
bench pressing mrs santas on muscle beach...  the santa pile-up on the
lone l. ron. hubbard winter wonderland santa...  at some point i
vaguely remember talking to a trio of girls, who looked to be about 15
years old.  "ho ho ho, you girls been good this year?"  "um, yeah,
giggle giggle"  "well, now, let's just make sure, whats your name?" 
"uh, kim, tee hee hee..."  "well, now kim,  are you sure you haven't
been naughty this year?  maybe just a little bit?"  "well, not _too_
naughty, giggle giggle"  "well, just remember - i see you when your
sleeping, i know when your awake...  as a matter of fact, i saw you
getting out of the shower this morning...  enjoyed it so much i
rewound it and watched it again..."  "SANTA!  (hee hee hee giggle
giggle)"  "so hey, why don't you give me your phone number, maybe we
could hook up a little later.  aww come on now, doncha remember when i
gave you that barbie dreamhouse when you were seven?  i wont tell your
parents..."  finally wound up at the observatory overlooking the
glowing la sprawl as fireworks exploded in the distance.  a santa with
a megaphone announced to the santas and children milling about the
pendulum: "come on santas, we've got to leave in 5 minutes if we want
to get into the titty bar for free!"  "YYYYYEEEAAAHHH! HO! HO! HO! HO!
HO!"

the sight of all those santas lining up to get into "sunset strip" was
funnier than anything i'd seen all day, but that was nothing compared
to the carnage occurring inside.  i got a gin and tonic, downed it,
then a beer, and some change for tips.  i offered the stripper on
stage a finsky with my teeth.  she sucked on it for a minute, grabbed
it with her teeth, then stuck her tongue down my throat.  "no
pictures, all santas please stop taking pictures of the strippers!"  i
got a birthday lapdance for one of my santa friends, then got one
myself.  then watched as more santas and mrs santas lined up to rub
groins with the strippers on the leather couches in the dimly lit back
room.  then i had another drink or two.  after several more girls got
nasty on the main stage, the dj kicked in "hell's bells" by ac/dc, and
about two dozen ms clauses stormed the stage.  i stuffed a ten-spot
down the red haired santa's bra with my teeth.  then she licked my
face.  bills bras and santa suits littered the stage, i think i must
have blown $100 in an hour, and i'm sure i wasn't the only one, but we
were still so rowdy they turned off the music and kicked us out,
threatening to call the cops.  there were already a couple of santas
in jail for crystal meth possession, so we all got while the gettin
was good.

after dinner in a plush but disgusting mexican restaurant, all the
santas headed to the palace to storm the mosh pit at a punk rock show.
 fights ensued, the cops were called again.  finally at midnight we
ritually hung a santa at a rockabilly club as the santa hordes chanted
"naughty!  naughty!  naughty!"  afterwards many of the santas headed
back to the stadium motel to crash, but i managed to drag seven other
santas and santa-ettes to after hours at "club lingerie".

the club was nice, all metal and film loops, the clubbers clean, cool,
and beautiful.  we headed straight to the dance floor.  hmmm, seven
bedraggled santas dancing like maniacs, and everyone's pretending not
to notice.  well, maybe they'd notice if we jumped up on the main
stage in at the front of the room with the strobe lights flashing from
underneath the glass floor?  nope, somehow we're still invisible. 
well, surely they'd notice a shirtless tatooed santa in dark
sunglasses dirty dancing with mrs cluas on top of the bass bin 12 feet
above the crowd?  "no, we don't see you, there is no santa claus, it
was just our parents..."  hmmm, tough crowd those la clubbers. 
whatever...  we got a $30 cab ride back to the motel, and mrs claus
and i lay in bed listening to my friends stumbling around, laughing,
jumping on the bed and falling over in the room over ours till after
sunrise...

after beer and brunch the next morning we headed to the airport.  "i
wonder if i'd get in trouble if i called in sick tommorrow?" i asked
the ms santa sitting next to me.  "i dunno?  are you sick?"  "well... 
i'm sitting at an airport bar in burbank surrounded by fifty other
santas, drinking boilermakers at two in the afternoon, broke, covered
in sand and woodchips, reeking of booze, barf, reefer and sex.  i've
slept maybe 4 hours in the last two days, i'm hung over, my arms hurt
from lifting too much at muscle beach, and the bartender just cut me
off.  suppose i must be..."

the plane flight home was even more out of control than the flight
down, the stewardesses were really getting mad this time.  someone
passed out free drink cupons, "HO HO HO!  MORE BOOZE, MORE BOOZE!" 
several santa's at the front of the aisle entertained us with an
impromptu "barf bag puppet theatre".  it was amusing.  as we flew in
through the turbulence for a rough landing several santa's started
chanting "end up! end up! end up!"  well, it made perfect sense,
really.  so the end up it was, i was utterly exhausted, but as i
danced my white beard glowed like a new pair of white shoelaces in the
black light...

-messiah wannabe

Hello folks,

For the time being I'm gonna go back on the list, but only for the 
purpose of hearing what my beloved friends have to say...That I miss . I 
finally finished all my graduation requirments at UCSC...it was quite 
excrusiating (sp?) Well, it's over and I have some time off before I 
start towards rl life, so despite the all the flaming, and just general 
making people feel bad here (ie bad vibes...whatever,) I'd kinda like to 
be able to comunicate with all of my friends here, so here I am. *doh!*

Anywayz, just in case any of you are wondering about the whole 
"playground" incident, I'll fill you all in. As many know we had 
posponed the party due to losing our location because of some "broken 
promises." Which for any of you who know what I'm talking about...I'm 
not as sour as you might think...a simple apology would be 
excepted...but I havent heard it yet. Anywayz, the Psychofunk crew, has 
kinda lost it's motivation...and therefore I've decided to go out on my 
own, and throw a smaller party, with hopefully one room being the same 
main room as we had in "playground." I'm actively seeking a "smaller" 
location for it now so if any of you have any leads...let me know. As 
always, I'll keep everyone updated on that through the list.
Also, if anyone is interested, in the next few weeks I'm going to be 
recording a mix tape of myself, (Hard--acid--cybertrance type stuff) and 
should have copies ready in about a month. 

I was also wondering if any here has Boy Wonder (Aaron's) phone or pager 
number...I need to get in touch with him and I'm not sure if he's on the 
list.  

Alrighty...that's all folks, hopefully i'll be seeing most of you 
soon...if not, have a happy holiday :-P

-matt-

Subject: Parties and shows this weekend...
Date: Mon, 15 Dec 1997 15:56:41 -0800

I went out all weekend!  I went to that KMFDM show and really dug Rammstein. 
 Much better, IMO, than KMFDM.  Sure Nivek Ogre was a sight, but I preferred 
the dancer and Raymond Watts.  Anybody else out there agree with me?  It wasn't 
until the end did they play anything good (KMFDM).  Is it just me or did they 
majorly take a trip downhill?  I love their old stuff and I can't stand their 
new stuff!

Anybody go to Atari Teenage Riot at Slim's on Friday?  I got to see a very 
influential Digital Hardcore badn and some others on Alec Empire's label.  The 
show was fabulous!  I missed EC8OR but I did catch Shizuo.  They were ok, but I 
didn't really care for that dancer.  She was wearing a little black dress, 
black lace stockings and a garter belt.  She flashed the audience from time to 
time and kept most of the eyes on stage while they tore up the stage.  They are 
nice guys but they don't get a groove going to say the least!  I really want to 
know what that dancer was dancing too!  The music was a bit difficult to pick 
up any kind of rhythm but she went at it slowly and without any sort of pace. 
 It kept me interested for about 5 minutes because I couldn't believe what i 
was seeing!  But anyways, back to ATR.  ATR rocked the house with some phat ass 
phast ass beats!  Riot sound effects can produce riots!  Damn, that Alec Empire 
really knows how to kick some ass!  It was strange to see Carl Crack with hair! 
 Hanin was a sweetie.  She was so friendly.  At least after the show.  I got to 
meet them all.  Alec Empire!  I love his solo DJing stuff.  He's great.  Jello 
Biafra was there as well.  He came to talk to Alec about some funky shit! 
 German Porn soundtracks and some other stuff I wasn't too clear on.  Strange 
guy that Biafra!  New ATR should be out next year if anyone is interested!

I also went to BT on Sunday.  Boy was that a mistake.  $15 bucks and the crowd 
didn't gather until 1am!  I had to work the next day and let me tell you, I 
haven't slept in like 3 days as it is!  I am dying here at work!  I came in at 
6:30 in the morning and I haven't taken a lunch or any kind of break!  I feel 
like crap!
I was supposed to meet some friends there but they decided not to show...  But 
that's ok.  One had finals and another had a birthday party for his granddad. 
 And another one decided she had better plans!  You know who you are!  But 
don't worry, I don't hold grudges.  ~Blowing Kisses!!!  Did you catch them?  BT 
played a nice set and got more people dancing.  It was pretty bare in the 
beginning!  I was too shy to talk to anybody but my friends.  I was sitting 
down while they danced for a while.  But I got something to drink and started 
to strut my stuff!  He played a good set too.  I was expecting a party though. 
 Ooops!

And my weekend is extended one more day!  I haven't been to sleep and I feel 
like passing out.  I am so famished!  I need nourishment!  Gotta get some 
sleep!  I had a great weekend...  I just wish I could have met some of you!

Your Jedi Bitch,
Jedi666Boy

~jedi's head is propped up with a chia pet
