Name (or Nickname) um, Leslie  (the artist formerly known as the fairy rave
mother)

What is your Age= 44, a nice symmetrical number, don't you think?

Birthday 11-21

What is your Sign=  Scorpio ... with Gemini moon, Aries rising, and lots of
other strong Scorpio influences

Are you Married= used to be, for a long long time, to a super-nice artist
who looks like an elf

Have Kids= come meet my daughter Emily (she's 19) at Harmony's Beautiful
People if you haven't met her yet  (kids are the happiest thing that can
ever happen in your life!)

Are you Single= Yep

Do you Dj = No, I leave that to the ones who have the urge, and who are
strong enough to lug those damned record cases .... I'd rather dance, and
as we all know, most djs just don't dance (except in their head, right, G?)

What is your most listened to Style of Music?  I like funky shit... whether
it's trance or house or jungle, give me a funky bassline and let me go!

Musician / Artist= let's see, i played the violin for 10 years in school,
and studied art in school... does that count?

Hobbies= I study astrology and tarot, read odd anthropological accounts of
life with the pygmies and such, love baseball and the Giants, watch too
much tv, scour the thrift stores for crazy clothes, collect and make hats,
collect antiques and paintings and bizarre things.

Mission In Life= I've learned that my true mission here is to inspire
others to express who they are, to reinforce their own confidence that they
can change the world, and that you don't have to buy into someone else's
ideas of what you're "supposed" to be or do because of your gender, age,
family background, whatever.  And I can do that through my own actions and
choices, cuz if it works for me, then it will work for anyone!

Do you represent the Scene Negatively or Positively? = I like to think that
I represent the scene realistically, hoping that I am at the positive tip
of it, but helping us to keep our eyes open to the other side, which is a
real one.

How? I make it a point to not hide the fact that I'm a "raver" even when
I'm talking to people from that other world who previously thought we're
all cracked-out freaks... because unless we show them the truth, how will
they learn?

Do you go to parties to hear the music or hook up with the oposite
sex? You mean you can go to parties to hook up with the opposite sex?
Geez, that's why I go to clubs!  I go to parties to dance and hang out with
my friends!

As for racism, mentioning of race is only one indicator.  I do not have
recordings of what was said between the guards.  All I know is that at
Stompy's held at VSF there have been several incidents of black males being
ejected for various vague reasons.  This may not prove racist intent, but
it's good enough for me.  I could care less if they're racist or not.  My
feeling is that I was singled out for behaving as one should at a party.
That is why I'm pissed.  The race issue is just icing on the cake.  Take
that away, I'm still angry.

>
>> >"But officer, everyone else was going 90 MPH too."
>> >
>> >Setting aside whatever occured, other people being more inebriated
>> >than you isn't a valid argument...
>>
>> Adder,
>>

>else is doing something, it does not excuse you from liability from doing
>the same thing.

My reasoning has no shortcomings.  How about this, please tell me *your*
reasons why I was ejected.

That is all I'm asking of VSF.  But thier silence is more telling than all
of this banter back and forth over race.

>

Nope, it's just one of the factors.  Strong or weak, you cannot ignore
patterns Adder.

>have said, is that by your own account, you have proven absolutely nothing
>of the sort to me at least..

I am not out to prove anything, so your proceed from a false premise.  I
only want an explanation then an apology from VSF.

Pretty easy.  It seems you are looking for even more than I.  I do not need
to make anyone believe me, all *I* know is that I was wronged, and *I* will
right it by various means.

> If you have changed your tack to having just
>been ejected unfairly, then again from *your* account it sounds like your
>claims might have serious merit, and I wish you the best of luck in
>bringing attention to the issue of security and the mistreatment of
>patrons at clubs/concerts/etc.

That is the overall larger issue I've been talking about.  The mistreatment
of those who make VSF money and who make it possible for them to have the
crowds they do, spending the money they do in that place.  Race, in the
overall big picture , is just another artifact of VSF's poor security.

>

Then quit asking me to present both sides.  Talk to the people at VSF and
get their side.  All I can offer is my view of events, which can be
corroborated by many of the people in attendance.  Too bad you weren't
there to witness it yourself.  Next time, I'll bring in a hidden camera and
videotape the events.

Sheesh.

>

Nope.  You have mentioned race more than I at this point.  Dig, if I see
racism I do not need to clear it with you in order to be convinced.  In
life things are not so clearly defined, and you are far from being the
final arbiter of truth.  Situtations happen that leave suspect the notion
of merit.

Unless you were there then no amount of recounting or convincing will prove
race was a factopr unless I have a tape of them saying things.

So to continue with this argument for argument sake is tedious.  I cannot
convince you of my feelings, after all they are my feelings, and I need not
prove them to anybody to consider them real.

In real court cases of harassment, sexual or otherwise, it is not only
intent, but perceptions.  Since this is not a court, and since you are not
judge, I see no need in going farther with this argument.

>
>> So offer whatever excuses you may, there are other Af-Am's who can account

Then what sir is your point?  If you want the other side, *call VSF*.  My

Wrong again.  You often engage in tedious debate to no end.  I am looking
for answers, and that fact seems to be lost on you.  For one who doesn't
even like the concept of race, you have certainly brought it up more than
I, as if you're trying to prove that race is never a factor in real life.
I think that is your axe.  I merely stated that it was a facotr in my
ejection as it was for others.  Sorry you don;t buy it, but I'm not trying
to convince you.

You can disagree, but for what?  What are you disagreeing with, my
feelings?  My version of the story? What other side is there since the
other side has been very, very silent. Since you only have one side, mine,
and since you weren;t there, all one can ask is what actually happened.
Instead you have gone on about why I think there is a racial component and
I've already explained that to death.

I could care less if you agree or disagree, but this much is for certain:
There is something wrong with VSF security, and the scene is becoming aware
of it.  Mgmt. of VSF is aware of it, and I think they are taking some small
steps to curb the abuses, whatever they may be.

And *THAT* Adder is the point, that VSF security be brought in line with
reality and allow people to party.

THAT is the only issue here.  So if you want to have a racial discussion we
can continue, but that is not where my head is at with VSF at this point.

Funny, I cited in the original post my feelings and how I felt about the
whole thing.  You will recall that I also mentioned other problems of VSF
security, and other issues.  Race was my small piece of the pie
(signifigant from my emotional pov) but I mentioned other negative
behaviors.  Yours has been to focus on my race comment leaving out the
other infractions.  If anyone has an axe to grind it certainly seems to be
you and the race thing at this point.

Nuff said,
John

P.S.  VSF security is out of control.  Be careful when partying there and
excersize extreme caution.  No pipes, no weed, no passing, no problems.

Been thinking about things I do using popularity as a motive.

    Went back & forth, is it good, is it bad?

    I decided it's okay, because popular means you have to deal with a lot
of people and that's definetly better than being hidden.

        You know what I'm sayin?

        So just for me (actually just for you if you think about):

        Do your best to be the most popular being.

        Humble people do not ravers make.

> At 12:30 AM 12/15/97, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> >I just got back from working in Bangalore (Karnataka, India) for the
> >last 10 days... the weird thing about Bangalore is that there is
> >*nothing* going on in that town 'cept the
> >rent/work/shopping/restaurants and "social" parties where people show
off how rich and powerful they've become ... I'd ask around  where the
concerts are happning and they'd say "what concerts?"; I'd ask where
the parties are and they'd tell me about some bars where people get
drunk and sing silly english lyrics to songs I wish I'd never heard in
the first place....>>>>

you must have checked out NASA then - all done up in 60's style space
station decor.  it used to be a dance club, but then the city
government banned western-style dancing (about a month before i
arrived on the scene hoping to put together an indian/american techno
group to play in the previously numerous dance clubs there - sheesh!)
so now (or then, anyway) it's just a bar with a bunch of old guys
sitting around drinking expensive beers.  although they still turn on
the fog machine/ lazer-light show every night from 8 to 8:15...


---and "e.menon" <emdash@sirius.com> wrote:
> 
> wow. i have relatives there....  haven't been tho. funny thing - my
> (ex)hubby laughed when i mentioned 'goa trance' - he never heard any
techno
> over there and he lived there 'til he was 26.... so maybe its an
extremely
> underground thing, or something (likely) brought over by some mad
partying
> europeans.... :P who knows....

goa trance is made more or less exclusively by europeans on the party
scene in goa (a small state on the west coast), at least as far as i
know.  though i hear a big techno influence on some of the hindi film
soundtracks released since goa took off (like "rangeela" or the
soundtrack that "telephone wallah" is on - btw does anyone out there
know what film that song is from?)

> i'll have to check out some of your other recomendations. anyone
else have
> any for ppl mixing indian (or any other traditional eastern sounds)
into
> their stuff?

i've got a couple of exellent bhangra albums from the "extra-hot"
series put out on the mulitone labels (#8&9, specifically).  though
they're kinda old so the rave influence has that '91 flava.  btw the
techno style of bhangra is mostly made by british kids of indian
descent...
there's a cool store in berkely (on university ave i think) that sells
all sorts of stuff like that (along with every hindifilm soundtrack
ever made), including some ug mixes by west coast indian dj's.  the
clerk there was totally cool and pointed me too some good cd's.  

- messiah wannabe

In-Reply-To: <19971216032503.15537.qmail@hyperreal.org>

> >*ANY* mention of race whatsoever when ejecting you. Any offhanded remarks
> >made by any of the staff towards you or any of your friends. *ANYTHING* to
> >substanciate your claim.
> 
> Interesting.  Once again the point here is that I was singled out, for
> reasons unknown.  The only delta is my race.  That pretty much sums it up.
> As for racism, mentioning of race is only one indicator.  I do not have
> recordings of what was said between the guards.  All I know is that at
> Stompy's held at VSF there have been several incidents of black males being
> ejected for various vague reasons.  This may not prove racist intent, but
> it's good enough for me.

  I wasn't there, and I don't know what happened, but I do want to say
something, for what it's worth. When I lived in Chicago, I worked with a
lot of black folks and I hung out with a bunch too, and one thing I learnt
is this: young black American males have more stories about people
screwing them over for no explicitly stated reason than any other
demographic I know of. Every one of these guys had a story - usually
several stories. And here's the important part: race was NEVER mentioned. 
Not once. Maybe racists are ashamed of themselves. Maybe they're cowards. 
Maybe an entire ethnic group just happens to be cursed with consistently
bad luck and it's just this amazing coincidence. But race never gets
explicitly mentioned until after the story's been told and people are
talking about what happened. Then someone says, "And you know why..." and
everyone nods. That's about as explicit as it gets.
  This Stompy's thing could have taken place because of racial reasons; it
could have taken place because the security guy broke up with his
girlfriend and he wanted to take out his stress on somebody. I don't know.
But I do know that if it was racial, you just plain wouldn't hear
anything. No mention of race, no offhand remarks, and nothing to
substantiate any claim. You never do.

> I could care less if they're racist or not.  My
> feeling is that I was singled out for behaving as one should at a party.
> That is why I'm pissed.  The race issue is just icing on the cake.  Take
> that away, I'm still angry.

//                                     connect -> [giles@|www.]bowkett.com

From: Messiah Wannabe <messiahw@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Re: popularity as a motive
To: still elf <elf@sirius.com>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk




---still elf <elf@sirius.com> wrote:
>
> Been thinking about things I do using popularity as a motive.
> 
>     Went back & forth, is it good, is it bad?
> 
>     I decided it's okay, because popular means you have to deal with
a lot
> of people and that's definetly better than being hidden.

i've thought about this a lot lately, especially at the santacon gig. 
now before i step on any multiple-listed cacophanyclub people's toes,
i should state for the record that _almost_ all of santa's i met were
quite friendly, open, fun, and cool.  cool in the good way, that is. 
but then there's this other kind of cool.  the kind of cool where you
drop a lot of names and snub people who can't (or won't) do the same. 
or who don't dress right or didn't go to that hip party last weekend
or whatever.  not that i've never dropped names, or tried to be cool
or anything.  but generally i try to avoid that sort of game, and i
really really try hard not to snub people, no matter how they dress or
whether they know the same bands as me or whatever.  just strikes me
as mean.

> 
>         Humble people do not ravers make.
>

after spending a lot of time living the slacker lifestyle (rock band
going nowhere, retail job in a store fulla freaks etc.) i noticed
that, while every culture, fringe or otherwise, has an element of self
hype, the gen x indie rock scene seemed to be composed almost
exclusively of these hipper-than-thou name dropper types.  so i came
up with this theory (perhaps after a bit of soul searching):  many
people who got out of school around the time of the '91 recession
found themselves in these crummy jobs, when all through college we
were expecting to graduate and get a big salary and drive beamers like
everyone else (well i never thought i'd drive a bmw but you know what
i mean).  deprived of the financial means to impress anyone, we found
other ways of letting the world know how cool we were.  "yeah, i was
hanging out at mac's house the other day..."  "oh i get in for free,
the doorman knows me"  "yeah we opened for [name of trendy band] last
week...  what's your number?"

i dunno, maybe i shouldn't criticize.  i probably still do it myself
sometimes.  and there were things i really liked about the gen x crowd
- hell, some of my best friends are slackers.  but one of the things i
like about raves is the way that people are so open and friendly.  i
just seem to feel a lot less of this "too-cool-for-you" vibe.  

-mw

ps. and of course that goes double for sfraves.

I appreciate others who can create as well.

beastie boys, rage against the machine and lucious jackson.

matter how little self worth they believe they have, they are worth it and
they are loved.  Well, unless they aren't then I really don't give a f*ck
about them.  But those are the chronic liars, the backstabbing bitches and the
fuckhead playaz we all know and love anyway.  Even that isn't hate, or even
dislike, it's just indifference.  And which is worse.

or positively, depends on my mood.

How? See, I have this _idea_ and this idea is that there are two types of
people who go to raves.  Candy ravers and those who rave.  Candy ravers annoy
me.  All that glitter and bright jewelry is just...  just... UGH!!  Those are
the type of people who feel the more people they love, the cooler they are,
right> you all know who I am talking about.  The kids fuct up on so much e
that night, every night you see them, 7 hits, okay, I am  exaggerating, but
you know what I mean.  Then there are those who rave.  Go for the music
(jungle jungle jungle). See a brotha or a sista and chillen kick it with the
one's they can really love.  And I love all my brotha's and sista's out there.

Do you go to parties to hear the music or hook up with the oposite sex? It's
all bout the music.  I do love to look, but I never hook.  It's tha funk,
yanno? I don't wanna be hookin with someone if I smell like funk and they do
to right? so fukkit, if we gonna hook it, it be not too ralated to one of
those RAVE thingies.

Ms. K1dd has left the building

-->Well, I don't think the majority of the legumes you consume are
"alive".  They might be viable, but seeds were meant to store energy for a
later date when the conditions are right for the embryo to start sprouting
and actually living.  Seeds are actually in stasis--just like the frozen
meat I eat; the difference is that one stasis is the pause before life and
the other is the pause before decay :)


...I read a great quote the other day from Naomi Campbell; she was one of
those supermodels that was a part of those PETA antifur campaigns and to
justify her turncoat behaviour she said, "...I eat meat, I wear leather, I
will wear fur...."  Isn't it funny that not only did someone think her
opinions as a walking mannequin have significance and deserve published
ink, but in publishing such a non-sequitur the mag. was undermining its
credibility as anything _but_ a secondary cosmetics peddler and all
articles that attempted to be the least intellectual were questionable?
I am sure all of Ms. Campbell's furs aren't made of cow only, and all of
her leather accessories aren't made solely of lamb, and I am sure she
doesn't regularly have mink served on her dinner plate either.  Don't
editors read these things anymore?


:)
M&m

Ummm, here goes...

Name: Matt Schwartz

Age: 23

Sign: Scorpio, but because I really dont quite fit with any astrological 
sign I would much rather be recognized with my chinese zodiac sign which 
is the tiger.

Married: nope, was engaged once though

Kids: Not till I can afford em :-P

DJ: I guess so, I have my own equipment...my mixtape will be out soon!

Musician Artist: Let see...I've done theater all my life, majored in it 
for three years in college. I've directed over 20 plays throughout that 
time. I play the Trombone, the Drums, the Tuba, The baritone...I can 
also play the trumpet and piano from time to time, I also used to play 
the Bass guitar in my school's jazz band. I write poetry...*ssshhhhhh* 
you didnt hear me say that :-P and I'm extremely into sci-fi...fantasy 
worlds..D&D whatever...yeah I think I can say I'm somewhat of an 
artist...but all that stuff is just different hobbies.

Hobbies: All of the above ;-), Hockey, Pool, Reading, watching 
movies...dunno etc..


Favorite style of music: Hard and Harder Trance :-P, Really progressive 
breakbeat...like the sh*t David Micheal threw at nakita friday 
night...he WENT OFF!, basically...I like anything as long as it doesn't 
suck :-P

Mission in life: Wow, interesting, I think my "mission" in life would 
have to be always striving to live it to the fullest. Enjoy as much as I 
possibly can while I have it, and to make as many awsome friends as I 
can along the way. 

Pos/Neg on the scene: I'd hope that I'd have a positive effect, 
although, sometimes it's really difficult when I get caught up in all of 
the BS. A note to any of you who read this...just remember one 
thing...keep faithful to your friends!...that is what this scene is all 
about...dont go off in another direction just to try and get ahead in 
the rat race. Stick with the ones who love you because not all really 
do.

How do you represent the scene: does it really matter?

Do you go to parties to listen to music or pick up on people:
Well...plain and simple...I go to parties to have fun. Whether that 
means listening to my favorite DJ, dancing all night, hanging out with 
my friends, doing drugs, or even picking up on people really depends on 
the circumstances. But I have a problem with people who look down upon 
anyone who, at that time, just might be looking for another cool person 
to spend time with...I mean come on, I would seriously doubt that there 
is one single person here who wouldn't mind hooking up with another 
really cool, other single person at a party. I dunno...if it happens, it 
happens...I dont go looking for it...but yes...I do like it when it 
happens to me.

Favorite UG DJ's

Trance/breakbeat-Vertigo
Techno - Macadio
Jungle - This is really tough!...four way tie I'd have to say 
          with Meeks,Science,Siphon,and Hak

Favorite thing about the internet: MUD's

>From a non dj's perspective.

The Playhouse release party was incredible.  Our tribe got there really
early, the commute from davis not being as bad as expected, and we chatted
it up out side before finally entering around 10:45.  The vibe was a bit
odd at first.  Everyone was just milling around checking the place out as
the tables were being set up.  We took up residence on the stairs and got
some drinks.  Almost 5 min later a security guard came up to one of my
friend and asked him what he was drinking (my friend did not have a lovely
little arm band.) when we told him it was water he told us that there were
undercover cops in the club that were looking for underage drinking and to
be careful.  The security kept an eye on us, we were a group of mixed ages
so we could always sneak drinks, but they were also very cool.  They
understood the intention of the party and were not going to be assholes.  
Hell, they even felt my pipe when they patted me down at the door and did
not say a word.  

Buck eventually started his set, and it got good fast.  Around 12, six
plain clothed 40ish looking people left the club together and the party
really got going.

The rest of the event was really a blur of lights, strobe vision and
uncontrollable dancing that was interrupted only once in awhile with an
omygodthisissoofuckinggooood!!!!.

I was too into my own trip to say hi to any sfravers there so a belated
hello from me. (I was the one going off in the red&white polo and white
jenkos, with pig tails).  And a thank you must go out to the security at
Big Heart for looking out for us.

tabs

> > wow. i have relatives there....  haven't been tho. funny thing - my
> > (ex)hubby laughed when i mentioned 'goa trance' - he never heard any techno
> . over there and he lived there 'til he was 26.... so maybe its an extremely
> > underground thing, or something (likely) brought over by some mad partying
> > europeans.... :P who knows....
> 
> that's exactly what goa trance is, IMHO. bunch of scungy-eurotrash in
> fluorescent clothing scouring india trying to find enlightenment and or
> refuge from their or their culture's sphinctricity, by completely
> ignoring India's culture and "creating their own"... in reality they
> just pissing of the locals with drugs and nudity and public sex  that
> are seen as being neither spiritual nor enlightened, just tacky.

Goa trance is not indian made or really inspired.  True it is a european
way of taking spirituallity into techno.  But there are indian raves that
are not just europeans, raves that the indian people themselves
participate in and create.  I have a tape of a full moon rave in goa from
96.  The rave had 15000 people attending and the music is anything but goa
trance.  It is a mixture of indian film music and synth beats with tablas,
sitars and bagpipes of all things.  It also has indian rapping and reggae.
If anyone wants a copy i can send or give it to you.  I must warn you
though that it is a bootleg so the quality is not that good(to saythe
least) 
> > I guess i'd be more charitable w/ my descriptions if I actually found
> trance music enjoyable, but i don't. and i have heard "the
> establishment" in India complaining about it (i've hung w/ some pretty
> snooty circles in past trips to BLR and got to heard some people unload
> about euro-travellers and goa-trance-ravers).
> 
Despite the false advertising of goa trance, i do love it. not necessarily
because it is supposed to be spiritual or indian, but because it is
relentless and very noisy.  If you like acid lines and non stop music to
bring you into any trance state you may want to reach, goa can do that for
you.  Besides there are different types of goa, like anything else.  And
if you only listen to the GG style you are missing out on some very well
made techno.  TIP has produced some very well designed goa that well,
kicks ass!  Sorry to preach, just wanted to get my point across.

> To me, it's weird that trance can even be likened to *ANY* form of
> Indian music, which seems so full of soul and life. Trance, to me, is
> the exact opposite. Like a parched and lifeless skeleton of music whose
> soul has long since uncoilled mortally.
> 
Don't go there,  I can only type so many words per minute.  Besides people
find what they are looking for in different things, some people cannot
stand house, and I think that trance is completely full of soul.  Hell I
had to leave a room once when mystr-E and mars were tag teaming because
the music was so overwhelming i thought I was going to cry!  Seriously!
(ps, it was an incredible feeling to hear music so beautiful that it moved
me that much)

> On the other hand, I'm always down for a good party, but in my cynical
> moments, I imagine the Goa scene as some ravified extended fraternity
> road trip with repetitive-beats e-music instead of rock or the dead.
> 
> Also, I've heard that the Goatrancers have pissed of the locals to the
> extent that their parties have been pushed underground again, since the
> local authorities didn't take too kindly to a bunch of white-folks trashing
> their beaches, increasing drug trade and crime, while not contributing much
> to the local economy (not as much as real club-med tourists, anyways).
> 
Believe me people have been pissing off the goa locals for along time,
even before goa came to fruition.  I was one of them.

> 
> By shakti, you mean that tagi-tagi-tagi-tagay-tagita-tagita stuff that
> tabla players do to enumerate the rhythm/cycle they'll be playing prior
> to playing it? Sheila Chandra has an album that is entirely such
> drum-like vocals, and you'll hear it in performances by Allarakha Khan,
> Zakir Hussein, and other great tablaists.

IF it sounded anything like the above or perhaps ta din nak a din etc. or
sporadic repetitions of Sa Re Ga Ma etc.  Then it is a pattern that will
articulate the beat they are going to play on the tablas or the melody
they are going to play on the harmonium.


sat kriya

---jameSpark <jamesp@netscape.com> wrote:
>
> Hello everyone,
> 
> I was able to experience the complete set of Doctor Martin on Saturday
> at Big Heart City. I enjoyed his set very much.
> 
> His setup that night were two technics 1200mk2 and a rane MP24x. He
> plugged in his own phones, Sony V6, I think.
> 
> Doctor Martin came in with two flight cases, one hard, one soft. He
> organized the records into two bins (different styles of music? one
bin
> per turntable?) and kept an empty one off to the side to put the
records
> he was done with in. If he wanted to reuse a record, he would just lay
> it on top of one of the bins. He usually kept the left turntable dark
> while the right one kept it's guide light on.
> 
> His records were good. DAMN good. A lot of them switched their rhythm
> halfway through the song which helped keep things interesting. He
> usually dropped the other platter around these transitions; pretty
good
> timing, letting the songs run their course while giving himself plenty
> of time to beatmatch.
> 
> He played a few acappella vox records over his records. One that I
liked
> was a record which was going on about how "House is a vibe, a soul,
etc"
> and then dropped the "I am the creator" vox on top of that. Strong
> female staccato vox over quieter reflective male vox. Simply
beautiful.
> 
> Doctor Martin did do his upside down record thing. He got out a big
> plastic base thing and put that on the turntable, then the record,
then
> some kinda endcap to keep the record down. He too the needle and
turned
> it over, adjusted the weight, and placed the needle on the underside
of
> the record. He did take some time setting the needle, but after it was
> there, he didn't wind the record or anything to catch the music phrase
> at the beginning, he just beatmatched and faded it in. A really,
really
> nice sound. The record he chose was perfect to play backwards
soundwise.
> 4/4 time, minimal, clean, enough ride and bass to let you know what
was
> going on. I wonder where you can get those plastic base things, or
if he
> made it himself...
> 
> He knew his songs really damn well. The most magic I experienced from
> his set would probably be his eq manipulation. Even when playing the
> same record, he knew when other instruments would be coming in, when
the
> breakbeat or tempo change would occur, and used this knowledge for the
> Forces of Good, making the same song sound different in 24 different
> ways (4! combinations for 4 dials, I think).
> 
> He had to end a bit early for some kinda Big Heart City policy reason.
> He was kinda bummed about it but worked with the BHC crew and ended it
> when he had to. He mentioned he played there (first?) in 1990 NYE.
> 
> Some tips I picked up from his set:
> * When beatmatching, start the record fast then slow it down. That way
> you know your record is fast and have only one way to adjust
> accordingly.
> * If you have time, try listening to the record for awhile. This way,
> you will be more sure what the tempo difference is and can pick up the
> phrasing of the music easily and know when and where to wind the
record
> to for best mixing.
> * Have really damn good records ;) Also pick up a few acappella vox
> records if you can. Records which change in the middle of the song
is a
> goodness as well.
> 
> Doc Martin had a great set, the people really liked it, it wasn't too
> crazy but the energy level was nice. He was friendly, but did
> concentrate mostly on the music during his set. Doc Martin was very
> consistent throughout the set and he was into the music. For house,
he's
> the greatest I've seen so far.
> 
> Cheers,
> james
> 
>

Or the poor lads who rely on a simple smile and an unassuming "Hi",
only to be scoffed at because the female thinks that the guy can't 
come up with anything better, when all he's trying to do is be
friendly and try and meet her.  Of course, the same woman would also
scoff at any sort of obvious pick-up line (ie. don't I know you . . .)
and would never dance next to someone/strike up a conversation/smile
and wave, because . . .  well, whatever reason it is that (many)
women don't do that sort of thing.

Here's a tip:  Guys LIKE it when women come up and strike up a
conversation.  And most guys don't assume that you're trying to
get them in the sack just because you say "Hi".

Steve.

On Mon, 15 Dec 1997, John S. Lee wrote:

> Interesting.  Once again the point here is that I was singled out, for
> reasons unknown.  The only delta is my race.  

Delta from what? Not from other partygoers according to your account.

> As for racism, mentioning of race is only one indicator.  I do not have
> recordings of what was said between the guards.  All I know is that at
> Stompy's held at VSF there have been several incidents of black males being
> ejected for various vague reasons.  

And no one else has ever been ejected from VSF that wasn't black for
"various vague reasons?" 

> This may not prove racist intent, but it's good enough for me.  

I am sorry to see your standard of proof set so low.

> I could care less if they're racist or not.  

Odd, that isn't the impression I got from all of your other posts on the
subject.

> My feeling is that I was singled out for behaving as one should at a
> party. That is why I'm pissed.  The race issue is just icing on the
> cake.  Take that away, I'm still angry.

Fair enough.

> >> These are not officers of the law.  Officers of the law will have their own
> >> say, as will be proven shortly.
> >
> >I was just pointing out the shortcoming of your reasoning. Because someone
> >else is doing something, it does not excuse you from liability from doing
> >the same thing.
> 
> My reasoning has no shortcomings.  How about this, please tell me *your*
> reasons why I was ejected.

Nice try. However I will not be misdirected in that fashion. The reasoning
that I find a shortcoming in was that your drinking was irrelevant to your
ejection because others around you were more intoxicated. The drinking of
others around you has *0* effect on *your* level of intoxication. Now, if
you were to say that "I was not acting drunk" (which I believe you
did) that's another matter. I am only taking issue with your statement
regarding your level of intoxication being irrelvent for the reason you
gave. 

> That is all I'm asking of VSF..  But thier silence is more telling than all
> of this banter back and forth over race.

And I hope you get your answer. 


> > What I
> >have said, is that by your own account, you have proven absolutely nothing
> >of the sort to me at least..
> 
> I am not out to prove anything, so your proceed from a false premise.  

Am I? You are leveling accusations. I would hope that accusations would
require proof before they were taken seriously. 

> I only want an explanation then an apology from VSF.
> Pretty easy.  It seems you are looking for even more than I.  I do not need
> to make anyone believe me, all *I* know is that I was wronged, and *I* will
> right it by various means.

And if an apology is not forthcoming? 


> >> I find it interesting that you would dismiss so gladhandedly and yet wonder
> >> what it would take to convince you of my feelings:
> >> -must I be called the *N* word?
> >
> >Now you are contradicting yourself. Please look at the above where you
> >state that you never mentioned race. I just get the overwhelming feeling
> >that you *want* this to be a racial issue.
> 
> You are wrong.

I truly hope so. 

> >> Sir, what is your standard for injustice?  What does it take to prove to
> >> you that a wrong has been done.  Enumerate or hush dear sir.  For I and
> >> others would surely like to know.
> >
> >For one, both sides of the story. There are always two(or more.) You are
> >leveling some very grave charges.
> 
> Then quit asking me to present both sides.  

You asked me what it takes to prove to *me* a wrong has been done.
I never asked you to present both sides of the story. 

> Talk to the people at VSF and get their side.  All I can offer is my
> view of events, which can be corroborated by many of the people in
> attendance.  Too bad you weren't there to witness it yourself.  Next
> time, I'll bring in a hidden camera and videotape the events.
> 
> Sheesh.

I agree that the events require explanation. I just don't agree with
some of the reasoning behind your explanation for the events. I must ask
though, is it an explanation you want, or evidence to support the
conclusion(s) you seem to have reached? 


> >If in addition you are stating that the reason for this is racial in
> >nature, *and* all the evidence you have to offer is what you have provided
> >already, then you haven't proven this point.
> 
> Nope.  You have mentioned race more than I at this point.  

Doubtful. Define "point." If I remember correctly I wasn't the one making
claims about VSF security being racist.

> Dig, if I see racism I do not need to clear it with you in order to be
> convinced.  

Absolutely not. However, you are labeling people racists in a public
forum. If you are going to make such accusations, you should be ready to
provide evidence that point to that conclusion. 

I don't know about you, but I abhor racism. I can't stand it, and have
little tolerance for it(in case you haven't noticed.) And because of the
gravity with which I view the subject, I make damn well sure that if I am
going to label someone such that I have proof to back it up. And my
standard for proof is much higher than "a feeling," or "because 3 other
people that belong to the same racial group I do have been ejected from a 
club."  

> Unless you were there then no amount of recounting or convincing will prove
> race was a factopr unless I have a tape of them saying things.

Oh no, I will take you at your word. If they made any statements to that
effect, I would believe your statement to that effect. 

> So to continue with this argument for argument sake is tedious.  I cannot
> convince you of my feelings, after all they are my feelings, and I need not
> prove them to anybody to consider them real.
> 
> In real court cases of harassment, sexual or otherwise, it is not only
> intent, but perceptions.  Since this is not a court, and since you are not
> judge, I see no need in going farther with this argument.

In a real court, you would have no case.. I think your lawyer pointed that
out to you.

> >> So offer whatever excuses you may, there are other Af-Am's who can account
> >> for said greivances, and other ravers of non-African descent who are
> >> standing by me, and plenty of others who will be watching until an
> >> explanation is offered.
> >
> >I don't offer excuses or explanations. All I am doing is pointing out the
> >fairly large flaws in your logic. I haven't denied that these things
> >occured for the exact reasons you purport. I cannot do that.
> 
> Then what is this banter all about?  Moot court practice again huh
> Adder...tsk , tsk.

This "banter" is about the use of flawed reasoning to reach a conclusion.
I think it also involves asking for an explanation of an event, but
already having reached your own. 

> >> Ravers:
> >>
> >> You spend some $25-25 to get into a party.
> >
> >Maybe you do. I don't.
> 
> Now you're being nasty, and biting.  I will ignore this, less we go down in
> flames.

How? I don't pay $25 to get into a party. I haven't since 1994. You are
addressing "ravers" and I am pointing out that all "ravers" do not
necessarily pay $25 to go to a party.

Further, barring front-door security, I haven't been to a party since
then that has felt the need to have indoor security. I imagine at this point 
in time I would feel very uncomfortable being at such an event. 

> >> Adder, you weren't there.  VSF has made no claims contradicting mine.  Why
> >> then do you defend their actions so?
> >
> >For about the third time(in just this post), I do not defend their
> >actions. As you say, I wasn't there.
> 
> Then what sir is your point?  

As I have stated numerous times before, to point out the flaws in you
reasoning to reach a fairly grave conclusion. 

> >> Your thoughts are greatly appreciated.
> >
> >Sometimes I think, only when they are in agreement with yours...
> 
> Wrong again.  You often engage in tedious debate to no end.  

Oh they end eventually. I think right around the time I let you have the
last word. 

> I am looking for answers, and that fact seems to be lost on you.  For
> one who doesn't even like the concept of race, you have certainly
> brought it up more than I, as if you're trying to prove that race is
> never a factor in real life.

You are seriously mistaken. I have no problem whatsoever with the concept
of race. What I do have a serious problem is the misuse of race as an
excuse or a weapon. 

> I think that is your axe.  I merely stated that it was a facotr in my
> ejection as it was for others.  Sorry you don;t buy it, but I'm not trying
> to convince you.

Really? From your original post:

" I am no longer puzzled.  VSF has a very serious problem with their
security, and their security has problems with people of color at raves."

and 

" Brothers and sisters be warned.  If you are a person of color at that
  club, be very careful of what you do and who you do it with.  Security
  is watching, and they've got a job to do! ;("

Seems a little more like some very strong allegations to me. 

> You can disagree, but for what?  What are you disagreeing with, my
> feelings?  

I am disagreeing with the reasoning used in reaching the conclusions you
have. I am disagreeing with your off-handed labeling of people as
prejudiced without the evidence to back it up. And I question rather it is
an explanation you seek, or evidence to support the conclusion you have
already reached. 

> And *THAT* Adder is the point, that VSF security be brought in line with
> reality and allow people to party.
> 
> THAT is the only issue here.  So if you want to have a racial discussion we
> can continue, but that is not where my head is at with VSF at this point.

Unless you have something else to add to the information you have already
provided, I don't see the point. 

> Funny, I cited in the original post my feelings and how I felt about the
> whole thing.  You will recall that I also mentioned other problems of VSF
> security, and other issues.  

Yes, and they sound like very valid issues. 

> Race was my small piece of the pie (signifigant from my emotional pov)

From: pj fuzzy <pjfuzzy@rocketmail.com>
Subject: NRR but SFR related

raverette #1 if I was an icecream cone what topping
would you be....:) hehehehehe

I definately like the forms that we have been posting
on the net.  I admit to being a consumate voyeur.  I
could very well be a Ferengi for the ears I have for
gossip.

And basically that is why I joined sfraves to join a
vitrual community and make connections.  

It is really fascinating and wonderful how the
internet has filled in some of the void in today's
world.  If you think about it today's society is so
volatile that there are few institutions like church,
family, location to enable people to form ties.
Take me for example.  I never went to church, and
while I do not miss the innoculation of religion, one
would have to admit that there is a definite support
group there.

Also, I picked up and left my hometown and most of my
friends back in May.  And yet I am able to remain as
close to my friends back home,at least spiritually,
as I would have if I had stayed there- and I am also
able to make new ones through news groups like this
one.

Someone suggested that we send pix with our profiles.
 I for one am glad that we have to resort to text to
communicate.  Its not even that I don't want people
to know what I look like.  It's just kinda more
intimate when you don't have to worry about outward
appearances- more like a mental hot tub.  Do you
think people would have said half the things on this
list if they had to actually verbalize them?

Gosh am I rambling? I'm not even drunk.  I guess I
have been feeling the warm fuzzies of joining a crazy
group of Santas for their wacky adventures, which for
me was as fulfilling as joining some cult, club, or
religion.

PJF

Your message got through...

I have to agree that it is hard to relate to people in person.
I'm a pretty shy person, I had a crush on a girl who would
never know it for about 4 years and the most I said to her
was, "what did you get on the test?"  My mind is a muse
but my mouth is concrete.  I may think some really great 
stuff but when it comes to verbalizing... Good Luck!!!!
Like the other night in Big Heart for BT...
I was sitting next to a grrrl who would make eye contact
and then look away...  I don't know what to say!!!  Then
some guy came by and sat down next to her and started
talking to her.  =(  I have no guts when it comes down to it.

I have met a few people from the list and have had a great 
time.  The list also provides a way to meet up with people
that have the same interests...  Sure sometimes I feel kinda
left out because some of you get more replies but I'm learnin!
But I am an open-minded person and can deal with stuff.  
I am happy to be on this list.  It keeps me informed and
entertained...  You guys are da bomb!!!

Your Jedi Bitch,
Jedi666Boy

---"Minh Q. Le" <mlowdrma@OCF.Berkeley.EDU> wrote:

> -->Well, I don't think the majority of the legumes you consume are
> "alive".  They might be viable, but seeds were meant to store energy
for a
> later date when the conditions are right for the embryo to start
sprouting
> and actually living.  Seeds are actually in stasis--just like the
frozen
> meat I eat; the difference is that one stasis is the pause before
life and
> the other is the pause before decay :)

well, while legumes are seeds and therefore possibly not "dead" per
se...

the thing that i disagree with "morality" based vegitarians about is: 
plants are alive.  i've always felt sure (though i'll never _know_)
that plants have no more desire to "die" than any other living being,
although they may not be able to express this to us humans.  i mean,
how would YOU feel if you were just sittin there soaking up the rays,
when something came along and cut off your feet, picked up what was
left, and stuffed you in it's mouth.

so how not to starve, if "vegetables are murder"?  well the hardcore
jainists (sp?), i believe, only eat fruit that's fallen from trees. 
or something like that.  personally, i figure every living organism,
with the exeption perhaps of some single celled planktons at the very
bottom of the food chain, kills other living things to survive.  hell,
even plants compete for sunlight, with the losers dying in the shade
of the larger, faster growing winners.  just the way nature works.

of course there's a good argument to be made against all the meat
factories, the way we grow cows and chickens like plants in some
horrible bovine ausvitch.  like if we took all the grain fed to the
cows grown for american consumption, we could feed the whole planet. 
but if you go with that argument, you could argue against farming
period.  i mean, look at the places where people have been farming the
longest - i'm thinking ancient persia, the "cradle of civilization",
now the middle east.  all barren desert now.  if i ruled the world, i
would prefer to see the population shrink, perhaps by imposing a
one-child-per couple limit like china does (a draconian but highly
neccesary law, imo) until we could let most of the planet revert back
to forest.

of course, if i ruled the world i'd also make it a law that you had to
go to a strip club dressed as santa claus at least once in your life...

-messiah w

MYASS

A great new software announcement!!! This memo is to
announce the development of a new software system....myass
We are currently building a data center that will contain
all firm data that is Year 2000 compliant.  The program is referred to as 
the
"Millennia Year Application Software System" (MYASS).
 Next Monday at 9:00 there will be a meeting in which I will
show MYASS to everyone.  We will continue to hold demonstrations throughout
the month so that all employees will have an opportunity to get a good look
at MYASS.
As for the status of the implementation of the program, I
have not addressed the networking aspects so currently only one person at a 
time can use MYASS.
This restriction will be removed after MYASS expands.

 Several people are using the program already and have come
to depend on it.
 Just this morning I walked into a subordinate's office and was
not surprised to find that he had his nose buried in MYASS.  I've noticed
that some of the less technical personnel are somewhat afraid of MYASS.
         Just last week, when asked to enter some information into
the program, I had a secretary say to me "I'm a little nervous, I've never  
put anything in MYASS before."  I volunteered to help her through her first 
time and when we were through she admitted that it was relatively painless 
and she was actually looking forward to doing it again. She went so far as 
to say that after using SAP and Oracle,  she was ready to kiss MYASS.

  I know there are concerns over the virus that was found in
MYASS upon initial installation, but I am pleased to say the virus has
been eliminated and we were able to save MYASS.   In the future, however,
protection will be required prior to entering MYASS.
        >
  We planned this database to encompass all information
associated with the business. So as you begin using the program, feel free 
to put anything you want into MYASS.  As MYASS grows larger, we envision a 
time when it will be commonplace to walk by an office and see a manager hand 
a paper to an employee and say "Here, stick this in MYASS."
          This program has already demonstrated great benefit to the
company during recent OSHA and EPA audits. After requesting certain
historical data the agency representatives were amazed at how quickly we 
provided the information.
 When asked how the numbers could be retrieved so rapidly our
 Environmental Manager proudly stated "Simple, I just pulled them out of
MYASS."
       
	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

I have to agree that I support the one-child thing.  
Who really needs more than that?  

I also agree with you on vegetarians.  I don't 
have a problem with them.  But they can be just
as pushy as some Bible-thumping Christians! 
All my g-friends have been vegetarians.  This
leads to trouble if you can't deal well under pressure.
I don't consider myself in anyway, better or worse 
than anybody else.  What I lack in one respect, I
make up for in another... You know, the whole 
Yin-Yang balance deal.  For instance.  One of my
x-g-friends was vegetarian because of the whole
morality issue and because of Skinny Puppy.  
But she wore Doc Martens, a leather jacket and
ate eggs and drink milk.  She tried to make me
become a vegetarian.  But I can argue too well.
I am too logical and unrelenting.  That is my virgo
qualifications and I'm a good lover.  She said so!
Vegetarians taste better too.  That's all I seem to go 
out with!  I can be very convincing, if you know what
I mean!  =)  But anyway, back to my point.  
I'm not a carnivore and I am open to new foods.  
Why do I have to be vegetarian?  I can't cook meat 
dishes whatsoever.  When I cook, which is often,
I cook vegetarian.  I just do.  But I enjoy the dead
animal cuisine just as much.  Nature has a way of 
reclaiming what is hers if left to her own devices.  
Humans can never live with the earth in harmony 
enough for this to happen.  We are too greedy a
species.  

So...when are we going to gather and go to a strip 
club dressed as Santa?  I'm game!  Jedi Santa 
has a nice ring to it!  Anyone want to see MY
lightsaber?

Your Jedi Bitch,
Jedi666Boy

about the candy thing - I don't like it when people act fake/plastic
either or feel that they need to be that way.
However, I personally wear clothes that could be labeled as "candy raver".
Big pants with fabric inserts, glitter, glow-in-the-dark bracelets, fur,
fuzzy
hats, etc.
I almost never do drugs at parties (last time was 1/2 year ago) and actually
don't do them much at all.
I just like dressing brightly and glittery..i think it adds fun to the
world. Especially
up here in Seattle when it is continuously raining, gray and drab. I have
never
understood why people dress in darker colors when it turns to winter...I
dress
the same way when I am at work, school, or at a party (granted, i get some
strange
looks, but that's okay =)
so, just know that not all "candy-ravers" are 7 hit freaks.

love kim

Looks like I'm on the tail end of this thread...

Name (or Nickname)= dave (dj radon)

What is your Age= 23.

Birthday= January 10th, 1974

What is your Sign= Capricorn

Are you Married= nope, unless you count the time I was five years 
old, when I married myself to the girl down the street.

Have Kids=nope.

Are you Single= Yep.

Do you Dj = Yep... I started "djing" at KZSU as a freshman, where I did an 
indie rock radio show for a while. Then I discovered Jungle about 18 
months ago, got my turntables soon after, and then started doing 
underbrush (http://www-kzsu.stanford.edu/~radon/) 

What is your most listened to Style of Music?= hmmmm.... too hard to 
answer. Today, I've listened to Sunny Day Real Estate, a Bill Laswell 
compilation, De La Soul, Directions In Music, Journeyman's "national 
hijinx", Sonic Youth, and Alec Empire's "Generation Star Wars".

Musician / Artist= I'm trying to get into d'n'b production/hip hop 
production. (isn't everyone?), and am working on some computer 
animation stuff. I agree with all the people who've said, more or less, 
that life is an art and everybody's an artist.

Hobbies= movies, snoboarding, djing, reading, video games, 
dancing/partying, record collecting.

Mission In Life= hmmm.... this is a really hard one. Nothing 
specific, I guess. Maybe: "Do some beautiful/interesting stuff and 
have fun."

Do you go to parties to hear the music or hook up with the oposite
sex?= Seems like I don't go to parties very often anymore. When I did, 
it was mostly to dance. 

This _has_ been a really fun thread, but it's a little bit weird to 
autobiographize yourself into 200 words or less. It seems like I'm 
leaving all the important stuff out...

sfrave-on,

-radon

-----Original Message-----
From: Messiah Wannabe <messiahw@rocketmail.com>

>the thing that i disagree with "morality" based vegitarians about is:
>plants are alive.  i've always felt sure (though i'll never _know_)
>that plants have no more desire to "die" than any other living being,
>although they may not be able to express this to us humans.

I am sure that is true. However, it makes it that much worse when you're
killing something which can actually vocalize its pain and suffering, so
we know 100% for sure that we are hurting something alive.

>so how not to starve, if "vegetables are murder"?  well the hardcore
>jainists (sp?), i believe, only eat fruit that's fallen from trees.
>or something like that.  personally, i figure every living organism,
>with the exeption perhaps of some single celled planktons at the very
>bottom of the food chain, kills other living things to survive.  hell,
>even plants compete for sunlight, with the losers dying in the shade
>of the larger, faster growing winners.  just the way nature works.

Hmm. By that rationale, we should go around killing and eating our younger
brothers, sisters, and anyone else we find vaguely irritating,
Jeffrey-Dahmer
style, because that is how nature works. =) the weak and young must die
out...survival of the species....etc....etc....

I like to think that humans can rise above that to some extent and are
capable of showing more compassion than an animalistic approach.....

Also, from a health-related standpoint, it actually is healthier for you
to eat vegetarian, because like you said, it is starting at the bottom of
the food
chain....

Did you know that the reason why meat and dairy products are listed in the
four food groups could definitely have something to do with the fact that
the National Dairy Association and Meat Farmers association are on the board
who decides them?  (i'm sure i got the specific names of their organizations
a bit off, but that's okay, because you know what i mean)

there was a quote i heard, i can't remember the author, but it goes
something
like this:

"the animals of this world are here for their own reasons. they were not
made
for humans to eat any more than women were made for men, or black people
for whites...."

It actually really is not  healthy to be eating  flesh - it is filled with
fat and other
unhealthy chemicals and increases your chances of heart attack and many
other diseases.....

However, we are brought up to believe that it is healthy, and in fact normal
to eat meat and milk......but if you think about it, it's really kind of
gross, I mean,
why would it be natural for us to drink cow's milk? It wasn't meant for
humans...

i mean, would it be natural for people to go around milking their pet cats
or dogs and then putting the milk on cereal? or killing them and then making
small, round burgers? eew! of course that sounds nasty, but milking a cow
isn't really that much more logical....

It's very easy to forget that something was once alive and feeling sun on
its back
when it's all packaged up in plastic wrap......doesn't even look real
anymore,
just looks like another product...

which is the reason i am vegetarian.......if meat was eaten once in a while,
as a special treat, or something, that would be all right...but it is a
staple food in the
american diet...animals are treated like they are "products"..there to be
used,
killed, and abused for our pleasures....i think that is wrong!

what if human babies had their fingernails and anything else sharp on their
body
ripped out with no anasthetic so they couldn't fight back and were stuffed
into small cages barely large enough to hold them, until they were grown to
adulthood and the females could have their breasts milked roughly at
intervals until the day they
could look forward to being killed and made into Big Macs......

i don't think it is human nature to hurt other living things!

and even if it was, we have the potential to rise above that.

>of course, if i ruled the world i'd also make it a law that you had to
>go to a strip club dressed as santa claus at least once in your life...

*grin* glad to change the subject, i am.....can you explain this santa
thing to me? i think i missed something...i saw your last post and am
still confused....

-kim


From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Dec 17 00:41:36 1997
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 19715 invoked by uid 6000); 17 Dec 1997 00:41:35 -0000
Received: (qmail 19707 invoked from network); 17 Dec 1997 00:41:34 -0000
Received: from dns01.ops.usa.net (204.68.24.137)
  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 17 Dec 1997 00:41:34 -0000
Received: (qmail 15105 invoked by alias); 17 Dec 1997 00:41:32 -0000
Message-ID: <19971217004132.15104.qmail@dns01.ops.usa.net>

  by dns01.ops.usa.net with SMTP; 17 Dec 1997 00:41:30 -0000
Comments: Authenticated sender is <Faro@pop.netaddress.com>
From: "Faro" <Faro@usa.net>

Date: Tue, 16 Dec 1997 16:41:33 +0000
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: Quoted-printable
Subject: NRR: inside  (long)
Reply-to: Faro@usa.net
X-mailer: Pegasus Mail for Win32 (v2.54)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


This is a mix of thoughts and feelings provoked by many of the recent 
SFR threads, but it does not directly relate to any of them.. sit 
back.. relax and enjoy the ride.

	So much of what we get out of life seems to be a direct result of 
how we relate to others.. and how they relate and react to us in 
return..
	We often get frustrated with those around us.. trying to understand 
where they are coming from.. trying to find some common ground but 
seeming to fail miserably so much of the time. How often have you 
heard phrases like: "Women are so confusing..." or "Men don't make 
any sense.." uttered by someone desperately trying to understand the 
opposite sex? Some people never even get that far.. they are so 
afraid of what they might find if they explore the infinite diversity 
of shapes and attitudes that people come in that they insulate 
themselves from all things different.. frantically trying to prove 
their dominance... hiding their fear behind a fa=E7ade strength. They 
lash out at those things the fear.. forgetting that that fear is not 
in the object they are attacking..it is inside them.
	The world is a different place to a young child.. everything is new. 
There is nothing quite like the first time we encounter something 
new... In fact, this is the only time that we really see it for what 
it is. We have no name for it.. no label, if you will. What is it? 
what is its purpose? We have so many questions. Later, after we have 
learned its name.. we lose a part of what it is.. all we see now is 
the name and not what is behind it. An example:
	Everyone close you eyes and picture a flower in your mind.. go into 
as much or as little detail as you like.. Right now.. all 480 or so 
list members are each picturing what a flower is in their mind... and 
I can guarantee you that they are all different.. we each have a 
different experience of what a flower is, and that experience shapes 
how we see a flower. Luckily a flower is a physical object.. we can 
all go pick one out of the garden.. and pretty much agree on whether 
it is a flower or not. All things are not, however, so clear... when 
we are dealing with abstractions like 'Love' or 'Hate' or 'Good', we 
have no physical object to base our view of what it is on. You can't 
go down to the store and pick up a pound of Love on sale for $3.98 a 
pound. and if everyone on the list had a different view of what a 
flower is.. think how radically different our views are on what 
'Love' is.  
	... Getting back to the label thing now... another example with the 
flower again:
	If someone says "I got some flowers.." What does this tell you 
about what they got? I don't just mean whether they got roses or 
daisies either.. these are also just labels. How many petals did they 
have? What colors were they? What did they smell like? How did they 
make you feel? When you attach a label to something some of the 
detail.. some of what is important is lost.

	There is always a fear, an uncertainty, inside us. It is very easy 
to look at the world and see all the ways that we have been wronged 
by it. It seems we always have to look out for people who seem to be 
unfairly judging us.. attaching their labels to us, and not really 
seeing who we are. We do it ourselves.. it is almost as though we 
can't help it. We learn by associating new things we encounter 
with those we already know. Besides.. Who has the time to get to know 
each and every person anyhow? 
	The thing that we forget though, is that despite our infinite 
diversity, there are common threads of humanity running through each 
of us. Just as we are afraid of being judged by others, they too are 
afraid of us judging them.. the distance between us grows as little 
by little we build walls of security around ourselves because we are 
so sure that they are going to attack us...In reality they are 
waiting just as desperately as we are for someone to fill the gap 
between us. It is not judgment you see in the eyes of those around 
you, it is need.. a need to be noticed and cared about.
	People want to be able to tell their stories.. One time an older man 
very drunk..  and still drinking came up to me at abut 3am while I was 
waiting for MUNI at a bus stop.. he was singing a bit.. and I joined 
him in a few lines of "Las Mananitas" (it's amazing what you can 
learn in High School spanish classes ;-)). And while waiting for the 
bus, which was late as usual, and didn't end up showing up for a 
couple of hours we talked. He told me about Mexico and how living 
there affected him.. and made him who he was today... we started 
discussing politics.. and I learned a thing or two about why the 
mexican people do not have the voice that they should... I could have 
reacted very differently to this strange drunk mexican coming up to 
me at three in the morning and I would have missed out on all that he 
had to offer. When the bus finally did come, he thanked me for 
staying to talk with him... but there was no need. The pleasure had 
been all mine.

-Faro

	I have read a few posts regarding militant vegetarians =P and 
although I do admit to being a veggie, it's not like you have to be 
a meat-hating activist to be a vegetarian.  I have lots of friends who
eat meat -- hell, my whole *family* is basically a group of carnivores,
but that's their choice, so what's the big deal here? I can understand
those peeps who don't eat meat for political or animal-rights reasons
or whatever and I totally understand and support their cause, but for 
me personally, I try not to judge others based on what they eat and 
why.  I eat fish and dairy but no poultry or red meat, so i suppose I
am a "vegetarian by design"....personally, it seems unfair for someone
to impose their beliefs upon someone else ...especially when it comes
to lifestyle choices...

Just my 2 cents  =P

> I like to think that humans can rise above that to some extent and are
> capable of showing more compassion than an animalistic approach.....

actually, very few animals will kill other members of it's own
species.  two lions fighting over territory won't actually fight to
the death, often their's some ritualistic instinctual "goal" - when
one animal pins down the other, or whatever (one species of snake
fights till the loser touches the ground with it's head - the film
footage of the "fight" was a trip) the loser slinks off, beaten but
alive.  man, as i understand it, is one of the few higher order
animals to kill it's own species.  we are particularly vicious
animals...

> which is the reason i am vegetarian.......if meat was eaten once in
a while,
> as a special treat, or something, that would be all right...

here's my idea:  in metropolitan areas, you have a species of deer
which wanders around the city, eating food from special deer-feeders. 
make it an attractive, housetrainable species that can run _almost_ as
fast as a human.  if you want to eat meat that day, you have to find,
run down, and kill with your bare hands one of these deer.  i think
this would not only be healthier for us humans (you have to exercise
to eat meat), but also nicer to the animals, and just generally more
"natural"...

-messiah wannabe

<<I also agree with you on vegetarians.  I don't 
have a problem with them.  But they can be just
as pushy as some Bible-thumping Christians! 
All my g-friends have been vegetarians.  This
leads to trouble if you can't deal well under pressure.... >>

>I have read a few posts regarding militant vegetarians =P and 
although I do admit to being a veggie, it's not like you have to be 
a meat-hating activist to be a vegetarian.>

I wasn't making reference to the non-militant vegetarians.
i was referring to the militant vegetarians...  A lot of my friends
are vegetarian and I have absolutely no problem with it.  I eat
vegetarian quite often myself.  I empathise with them but
don't share the same resolve.  I like a little meat every once in
a while.  I don't mean to offend anyone.  I am a selective eater.
I don't eat fast food meat.  It's scary!  Especially McD's!!!  

Please don't get me wrong, I love animals and am not defending 
the meat industry in any way.  

I prefer to eat vegetarian most of the time.  I eat at White Lotus 
every once in a while.  Eat a lot at fresh choice and Thai and
Indian cuisines...  Even at meat-serving restaurants I usually
eat vegetarian.  Especially at Italian restaurants...  I love 
cheese and bread!!!  I love to sit under the stars on a blanket 
and eat a warm loaf of sourdough bread and some cheese 
and a cool bottle of Henry Weinhard's Root Beer.  Anyone want 
to join me?  J/K!!!  I have the best of both worlds when it comes
to food.  I love both roadkill cafe' and rabbit delight.  

So to make a long story short... I love vegetarians...They just
don't always love me.  

Your Jedi Bitch,
Jedi666Boy

~Grubbing heartily on Cheese Tortellini and Alfredo sauce... 
Homemade, mind you!

Another questionaire to learn about each other and 
to help create better partys and to celebrate solstice.

What are the things you liked about partys this year?

What are the things you experienced that you liked 
and would like to see more of?

What were your favorite/worst partys and why?

What are the things you didnt like and woukd like to see 
less of or not at all.

If you could have anything you wanted at a party, what would it be?

What do you want to create in the community, at partys
or just in general this coming year?

What would you like to give to the community this year?



Ps. there is a ritual where you sit in a dark room or out in nature
and reflect on the past year and think about those things you 
no longer need and get rid of them. Then light a red candle
 to welcome back the light and think about the things you want in the
coming year.  Then you have a big feast and party til dawn.
And if you are the kind that believe that the sound
of rules breaking
is sweet music to the ears, then you can party past dawn.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

Interesting to see people getting steamed about vegatables.

According to Webster: vegitarian
 "A person whose diet includes mainly plant and plant
products and who eats no meat." 
It possible that eating only plants would
tend to make one vegetative. 
Vegetating is defined as:   
 To sprout or grow as a plant does. 

Possibly 
a vegetarian is someone who 
eats only plant products 
who sprouts all kinds of ideas,
 which may be rooted in reality (or not). 
Vegetarians may have
 unlimited growth (plantlike), 
think like a tree, 
have green blood, 
 hair that turns red or gold, or brown 
which falls out at the
autumnal equinox.  
Horses and cows are vegetarians:
They are tremendously strong, 
have beautiful eyes, 
never start wars 
but certainly get killed in them.  
One wants to stay out of their way, 
as when startled they can trample one.
  They don't know about stars,
But stars are named
for them.

I wonder who was the first guy that walked up to a cow
and grabbed her utters and said hey im thirsty i think
i will drink what ever come out when i squeeze her.

I am a vegitarian because it feels good and tastes great.
I have discovered so many great tasting foods since i 
expanded my diet beyond big macs and fries as a meal.
And my doctors are always amazed at how i am not a real
active person and yet i have the readings of a top athlete,
sometimes better. 

But i believe that there are more impoertant issues than
what one eats. Diet obviously affects our health and america
does have a health problem and people clogging our medical
and economic and enviormental systems due to unhealthy eating
and overeating need to be held responsible in the same way as any
other addict.

And one final thought is that i think what goes into your 
mouth is not nearly as important as what comes out of it.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

<kim's attempt at mc'ing begins>

I ain't trying to preach, just trying to express
the vibe that i feel and the thoughts that i possess
most people don't share it, but that doesn't make it dumb
i can only speak from where i'm coming from
in my world there would be a global nation
of friendly faces, a love vibration
we all are different with our own way to be
i'm not saying yours is better or worse than me
but my personal belief is that we should give
the freedom to others to "live and let live"
and since it is not necessary to eat meat to survive
i think we should try to leave the animals alive!

my problem is not even just with the eating of meats
but by the way our society as a whole treats
living things as products, 
thinking it is funny,
to use and abuse creatures in order to make money.

When I turn on tv and see people objectified
Stereotypes flaunted and consumerist pride
I see a nation based around bucks
Happy to take advantage of another's bad luck.

If meat was treated like a living soul,
rather than a way for us to take control
over something smaller, that has no choice
no way to fight back, no human voice

if we treated it like it was a living thing
rather than an object with money to bring
then i would not think that it was wrong
but many don't respect that, hence my silly song.

It goes beyond right/wrong morality,
but using lives for money just bothers me.

please don't take my replies personally,
and live your life however you feel free....
just explaining why i am the way i like to be.

On Tue, 16 Dec 1997, steve wrote:

> Here's a tip:  Guys LIKE it when women come up and strike up a
> conversation.  And most guys don't assume that you're trying to
> get them in the sack just because you say "Hi".
> 
> Steve.
> 

Pervert! 





(just kidding)

I love this "I wish we could get the other sex to understand" bit... you
get some pretty damn cool insights spending time with bi, gay and lesbian
folk, as you'll realize it's not "men are screy" or "women are screwy"...
it's more along the lines of... love and compansionship are hard to find
(or "people as a whole are screwy", but I'm trying to stay positive
today).

In this world, we can have a thousand jobs, we can be a thousand ways,
have a thousand hobbies, make love/make whoopee/boink/rut a thousand ways,
have a thousand favorite foods, and see the world through a thousand
different eyes from a thousand backgrounds... 

And we will generally only find a couple of those combinations attractive
in others.

A guy named Matt Johnson once said, "if you can't change yourself then,
change the world."  Ask yourself just how fair that is... perhaps those of
us who are shy have a lesson to learn (I'm one by the way... get me away
from a terminal, and I'm a quirky, lanky, ackward kid who never really
figured out social graces, or how to brush his hair so that it does
something cohesive, or dance "right", and have to go to the bathroom
really bad/get faint/run around the block a couple times before every time
I spin in front of people)...

We need to take back living, rather than spectating.

Sometimes things are handed to you, and sometimes you need to take the
risks and hand yourself to someone or something else.  Ask yourself what
you want... and be honest about it.  Be honest about how you could tell if
somebody else was looking for those things.

If what you really want is a person to walk up and start a conversation
with you, than prepare to spend a lot of time hanging out, because it's
rare... and keep in mind you're asking someone you haven't even met yet to
do something you're not willing to do.  How fair is that? 

Peace.
Andy

> -----Original Message-----
<Snip Snip for brevity..>
> It actually really is not  healthy to be eating  flesh - it is filled with
> fat and other
> unhealthy chemicals and increases your chances of heart attack and many
> other diseases.....

Hey now.. Since when is Fat an "unhealthy chemical"????
People seem to get brainwashed by all the 'Fat Free' advertising that 
is out there.. While it is true that it is unhealthy to have too much 
fat, it is a normal and necessary part of our bodies.. That is the 
method that our bodies use to store energy away for later use.

 
> However, we are brought up to believe that it is healthy, and in fact normal
> to eat meat and milk......but if you think about it, it's really kind of
> gross, I mean,

Hey now.. Since when is it not normal for humans to drink milk?
Last I checked.. the Female members of our species produces it 
naturally in order to nourish our young.. Should we slap a label on 
every womans breast saying "WARNING: it is unhealthful to drink milk 
from here!!??"   

> why would it be natural for us to drink cow's milk? It wasn't meant for
> humans...
> 
> i mean, would it be natural for people to go around milking their pet cats
> or dogs and then putting the milk on cereal? or killing them and then making
> small, round burgers? eew! of course that sounds nasty, but milking a cow
> isn't really that much more logical....

<Another Snip Snip for brevity> 

> 
> i don't think it is human nature to hurt other living things!

Hey now.. Last I checked plenty of people aren't to worried about 
killing other people.. much less animals etc.. And what is "Human 
Nature" anyway? I'm having a hard time coming up with a definition 
for it.  

> 
> and even if it was, we have the potential to rise above that.

Very True :).. It is this potential that makes life interesting.. Now 
we just have to encourage everyone to do their best to  live up to 
that potential.

:         Humble people do not ravers make.
:

What's that suppost to mean? What do ravErs make?
 
:     Ravers are louder people, I think.  People who don't give a shit
about
: stepping into the middle of a dancefloor and totally letting loose.
: 
:     Crazy happy people that run up to eachother and hug eachother
laughing.
: 
:     Ka-pee-sh?
: 


Yea.. But...

 Alot of people just "ACT" all happy and joyfull at ravEs. That's all good
n'all, even to act is not bad...Someone has to boost moral from time to
time..
 But if I was to have had a really, really bad childhood or something.. And
if I so happen to come off alittle less gay and care-free as most
ravers...Does that make me a bad person? Or NOT a ravEr?
 I am 25... When I was 19, all I could think about was getting laid and
taking drugs. Let's say that, maybe while I was growing up in this life
stile.. I encountered ALOT of problems with girls, myself, and my
perceptions..
 These problems from my past make me a more shy and quiet person today..
Should I not goto ravEs if I am going to have trouble communicating with a
large scale social croud?

 I always thought ravEs were cool because everyone got along. I haven't
been to school in a long time, so I don't know how things go there anymore.
But back when I was in high school...It was alot like being at a ravE...
All differences were set aside in class..You can't go spouting off your
narrow opinions and starting fights in class right? You need to just except
that the people around you are there too. That's how it seemed (at 1st) at
the ravEs. Everyone just got along and excepted one another...And I guess
you can say the music is the autority of it all. It keeps everone in line..
 But it turned out to be more like high school than I first assumed. People
hang in packs, people talk trash about other packs, and they outcast people
still. That is not right. The happy joyfull ravers full of love..sometimes
streight up HATE the more cut edge crouds.
 It's still a freaked out social mess.. If it weren't for the music. People
would be at each others throats.


This might sound negetive to you, but I assure you it is coming from the
most positive person you will ever talk to.
 I guess you can say the ravE scene broke my heart in a way. And it's all
because of people that think "EVERYONE" in this case "ravers" are all the
same.. If you go around thinking ALL ravers are happy and LOUD.. Your going
to be disapointed when you see me! And who gets hurt? Not you....You just
brush me off your back as if I am a flook in your party, and I get to
consume all your negitive feelings towards me, without you even knowing
what you did.

Does this make any sence to you?
Ok.. I got to get crackin though! Nice chatting.

 =]:. ... ....
Jeff
