Ahhh shucks, gotta share my thoughts about this one.


I grew up vegan.  Yup, no cheese, no milk, no eggs, no flesh for food
or clothing.  Don't feel like I missed out on anything really, but
then again my parents were really cool about letting all of us (Myself
and four brothers) decide what we ate.  They didn't freak out if one
of them decided to have bacon and eggs one morning, we just knew we
had to cook them ourselves.  It's all about your own PERSONAL choices
my little kittens!


I moved to Italy 2 months after I graduated from high school. My God,
how could a good little Vegan girl resist such cheesy temptation?  I
gave in, I became a cheese whore I admit it.  My parents don't hold it
against me at all. I'm still welcomed into the house, and I even think
they got me the kick ass Bastard board I've been begging for X-Mas. 
If I were to unwrap that beautiful gift while munching on a chicken
liver sanmich, they'd still love me, they just wouldnt' kiss me.


I personally would have no ethical problem drinking milk or eating
cheese produced by a small dairy where they treat their animals in a
humane way.  Unfortunately that doesnt' bring in the big bucks....

Hell, if I had a bigger backyard I'd have my own dairy cow named Gerta
and milk her myself, then we could have a butter churning party at my
house!


I Love Moo All!

Tabitha

Jeff you make puercfect sense!
i've always hated trying to spell when my email system is lagging and ic
ant see what i type./
;)

anyway, back to the comments Jeff had.. he's right..
the scene breoke myheart too..
i've seen soooooooo many  kidz.. trying to be the perfect raver..
striving sooo hard...
to know the right people (djs., promoters)
know the right tracks.
act the right way
dress the right way
PLUR fuzzy smiles and happiness with a loud beat and non-stop perfect
happy vibes with a 100% kind positrive soul

that they forget...
to be real...
and that irks the living shit out of me.

but then, there are an incredible amount of individuals out there that
make the scene dear to my heart..
people who aren't afraid to shout their differing opinion into the crowd
of sheep..
people who dance, act, look, breathe, etc... the way they want, no matter
what.

so i hate the scene
and i love the scene

ahh relationships are a bitch, aren't they?
but life would be so boring without the roller coaster ride they provide
for us.
xo n respect :)
lara

Subject: Re: Modern state of djing

             <01bd0ab5$5df2e640$bcec86cd@default> 
Date: Wed, 17 Dec 97 01:16:04 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

>     So how long (in the quest of perfection) do you think it'll be before
> there's a wire coming out of the mixer into the deck's that beatmatches
> automatically?

some UK company makes a product (red-somethingorother) which takes a
sound input w/ beats and generates MIDI clock from it. one could use
this to sync up a beatbox/groovesynth (e.g. Roland MC303) to a
live-playing LP or CD and keep your synthesized beats in sync w/ the
live stuff.

i could also imagine getting two of these redsomethingorothers to
listen to the output of two 1200's (or CD players) and feed a circuit
which generates a difference voltage based on the phase difference of
the two midi-clocks output by the two redsmothingorother boxes. this
difference could then feed another circuit to simulate electrically
(e.g. via an FET txistor) the output of the pitch potentiometer on your
turntable/cd-deck. The circuits would self-correct the pitch for a
matched BPM between decks. Basically, a phase-locked loop for BPM 
matching.

I'd imagine that just as with any phase-locked-loop circuit, it would
be somewhat suceptible to transients, and might produce some annoying
pitch changes and oscillating overshoot/undershoot of pitch between
the matcher and the matchee...

Also, the reality is that BPM counters don't always work very well... 
especially for interesting/realworld/funky music. Ultimately you need a
human brain to understand it. Of course, w/ some particulary metronomic
gabber, house, or trance, all you need is a tweaker to understand it,
and we all know tweakers have no brains.

PLEASE CROSS POST THIS TO ANY GROUPS THAT YOU THINK WOULD BE INTERESTED!!


The 4th Annual 24 Hour Music Marathon is on for this weekend featuring the
best talent from the San Francisco Bay Area.

We will be cybercasting this event live from Internet alfredo at 7th and
Brannan in San Francisco from Saturday/Sunday at 00:01 to 23:59 PST.

$6 Donation at the door gets you a "day pass" where you can come down, hang
with every one and surf the web while the event is going on.

The updated line up is as follows: (not necessarily final but kinda close:)
NOTE: THIS LINE UP WILL MOST LIKELY CHANGE OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS!!
CHECK THE WEBSITE LATER ON IN THE WEEK FOR THE FINAL LINE-UP!


00:00	Performing live, Astral Matrix (O.O.B.E. Music)
01:00	Ethan (Friend & Family)
03:00	Unknown
04:30	Sub.Cmdr Lycos (CyberTribe)
06:00	Blackstone (Club Universe)
07:30	Matty B. (XLR8R)
09:00	Galen (Pacific Sound System)
10:30	Preston (Stompy Stomp)
12:00	Abstract
13:30	Troy
15:00	Bhuna (Culture}
16:30	La Ron (Culture)
18:00	Spun (Pure Space)
19:30	Markie Mark (Wicked)
21:00	Tracy (Mixology)
22:30	Jeno (Wicked, ComeUnity)

We also need some volunteers to do crowd control/security and other tasks.
If you can help, send e-mail to geoffw@cybertribe.com or call (415)541-5632

We are in need of folks with DAT players who would be willing to help us
tape the entire broadcast (we have the tape we just need the Recorders), if
we get enough, then easch recorder won't have to do too much work.

The contact point for the cybercast is http://www.cybertribe.com

We will be using realmedia 5.0 so update your players!
We will be serving out a Stereo 28.8 feed and a DUAL ISDN STEREO feed for
those with ISDN or greater bandwidth.


We will also broadcast on FM in SF so stay tuned!

At 05:40 PM 12/16/97 -0800, The Venerable Messiah Wannabe wrote:

>actually, very few animals will kill other members of it's own
>species.  two lions fighting over territory won't actually fight to
>the death, often their's some ritualistic instinctual "goal" - when
>one animal pins down the other, or whatever (one species of snake
>fights till the loser touches the ground with it's head - the film
>footage of the "fight" was a trip) the loser slinks off, beaten but
>alive.  man, as i understand it, is one of the few higher order
>animals to kill it's own species.  we are particularly vicious
>animals...

That may be, but...  
Male lions eat unprotected cubs fairly often, seemingly without reason.  Sometimes they even eat their own offspring.  Big cats will also do their best to kill other kinds of cats that stray into their territory.   Adult Lions know better than to fight each other to the death, the winner would be injured to the point of being helpless....   

Rattle Snakes don't kill Rattle Snakes, Garter Snakes don't kill Garter Snakes, but certain snakes feed almost exclusive on... other snakes.  Some Apes and monkeys kill and eat each other as well.  Animals may not kill members of their own race, but they sure as hell don't pass up the opportunity to kill creatures only slightly different.  

One of the laws of nature is that you don't really want to get into a life and death struggle with someone who's an even match.  The reason being that, while the looser may become breakfast, the winner will likely die of his wounds later...

Interesting contrast... Most crime in our society is INTRA-racial.  White on white, black on black.

>here's my idea:  in metropolitan areas, you have a species of deer
>which wanders around the city, eating food from special deer-feeders. 
>make it an attractive, housetrainable species that can run _almost_ as
>fast as a human.  if you want to eat meat that day, you have to find,
>run down, and kill with your bare hands one of these deer.  i think
>this would not only be healthier for us humans (you have to exercise
>to eat meat), but also nicer to the animals, and just generally more
>"natural"...

I see your logic, but... Is genetically hobbling a species any better than farm raising cows?  In a bare handed cage match of Deer vs. Man, the deer wins hooves down.  Deer do kill impatient hunters who don't wait for them to die before running over to gloat over their trophy.  You'd have to make one weak ass deer to be able to catch and kill it, bare handed.   Granted, I have serious issues with hunting large mammals for sport but, if you were a deer, would you rather be ripped apart by some hungry, slobbering hominid, of killed by a single shot to the head? (Nether, obviously)

Is it lunch time yet?

--ChrisP




Chris Porter
Master of All Things
Customer Support
Explore Technologies
408-654-3846, 8-5 PST.

This isn't a post to bring all of your spirits down, although it hasn't 
done much for mine. It's a plea to be safe. This weekend, a wonderful 
friend of mine (and many others) was killed. He and his wife were at a 
party up in Napa and he had been drinking. He wanted to drive, but his 
wife, thinking she was doing the right thing, wouldn't let him. They 
fought, and he got angry and took off running. They figured they'd let 
him sober up and calm down. 3 hours later they went looking for him and 
found him on the side of the road, dead. He had been run down by someone 
and left there. Please please please... just because you may not be 
driving drunk, others are. Be rational in the decisions you make and 
know that others that may try to stop you are just being the best 
friends they can. My friends and I are so deeply saddened by this and 
our lives will never be the same. Neither will his beautiful wife's.
He was only 22.
-TRACY

after an exellent indian meal w/ leslie, hai-la, maya, gary, and sara,
(hi y'all) we headed to liquid for booze and sTaTiC.  arrived at maybe
10:30 or so, i've never been to liquid that early before.  hung with
the gang for a while, but they all pooped out by midnite.  i was glad
i stayed, though, right around that time a trumpet player plugged into
the board and started blowin.  the mix was kind of rough, and there
were some patches where it sounded a little off, but there's really
sumthin about live improvization that adds a super cool energy to a
set.  there were some real moments of stellar beauty across the night
- strange loops of trumpet tones rising and falling over bleeps and
bloops, a great jungle duet between live and vynil horns, some
haunting techstep with brass whalesounds...

i was lost in the moment...  but it made me sad at the same time...  i
was gonna make a demo of myself playing trumpet through my effects box
over beats and give it to these very same dj's this summer, but never
did...  sometimes i think maybe i should lay off the clubs a little,
spend more time making music...  but then, i wouldn't have been
reminded of my intentions if i hadn't gone clubbing last night... 
hmmmm...

messiah w

The trumpet player was an unexpected treat.  I didn't even know he was
going to be there.  I assumed he was just a local musician who dropped in.
As it turns out, his name is Graham Haynes and he is a very well known and
respected jazz musician from NYC signed to Polygram records.  He is also
the son of legendary jazz drummer Roy Haynes.  He actually has quite a few
albums out and is currently working on some projects which fuse live jazz
with drum and bass.  Being the techno snob that I am, I usually can't stand
live musicians over electronic beats, but I thought he was absolutely
amazing last night...  

Starting in January after our one year anniversary, we are going to try our
best to have at least one live performance or one dj from out of town every
month.  '98 should be a good year for Static...

Seth

here's a related poem I'm sure many of you have read.

DEATH OF AN INNOCENT

  I went to a party, Mom, I remembered what you said.
  You told me not to drink, Mom, so I drank soda instead.
  I really felt proud inside, Mom, the way you said I would.
  I didn't drink and drive, Mom, even though the others said I should.
  I know I did the right thing, Mom, I know you are always right.
  Now the party is finally ending, Mom, as everyone is driving out of
  sight.

  As I got into my car, Mom, I knew I'd get home in one piece.
  Because of the way you raised me, so responsible and sweet.
  I started to drive away, Mom, but as I pulled out into the road, the
  other car didn't see me, Mom, and hit me like a load.
  As I lay there on the pavement, Mom, I hear the policeman say,
  the other guy is drunk, Mom, and now I'm the one who will pay.
  I'm lying here dying, Mom.  I wish you'd get here soon.

  How could this happen to me, Mom?  My life just burst like a balloon.
  There is blood all around me, Mom, and most of it is mine.
  I hear the medic say, Mom, I'll die in a short time.
  I just wanted to tell you, Mom, I swear I didn't drink.
  It was the others, Mom.  The others didn't think.
  He was probably at the same party as I.
  The only difference is, he drank and I will die.

  Why do people drink, Mom?  It can ruin your whole life.
  I'm feeling sharp pains now.  Pains just like a knife.
  The guy who hit me is walking, Mom, and I don't think it's fair.
  I'm lying here dying and all he can do is stare.

  Tell my brother not to cry, Mom.  Tell Daddy to be brave.
  And when I go to heaven, Mom, put "Daddy's Girl" on my grave
  Someone should have told him, Mom, not to drink and drive.
  If only they had told him, Mom, I would still be alive.

  My breath is getting shorter, Mom.  I'm becoming very scared.
  Please don't cry for me, Mom.  When I needed you, you were always
  there.
  I have one last question, Mom, before I say good bye.
  I didn't drink and drive, so why am I the one to die?

It would not be very hard to do this with CD mixers... you could standardize
a CD-DJ format that would store tempo and beginning-of-phrase data in with
the music... maybe even data on what key the track is in (to automatically 
sync up the pitch)  This would not be the end of DJs... it would be the 
beginning of a new type of musician.  With this kind of technology, CD's could
become more minimalistic... and the "dj" could create complete tracks
on the fly from very small bits of musical data.  The DJ could make their own
peices of tracks and trade them on the Internet with other DJ's bits.  A live
set could consist of mixing your own peices, and peices from other dj from
around the world.  Oh, the future will be fun.

-troy 

> 
>     So how long (in the quest of perfection) do you think it'll be before
> there's a wire coming out of the mixer into the deck's that beatmatches
> automatically?
> 
> 
>     Keeping that in mind...
>

Hey, thanks for the Beta Lounge plugs, everyone... just wanted to let you
all know that the Beta Lounge is VERY SOON now going to be completely
independent of HotWired. Sometime in January you will no longer be able to
get to the Beta Lounge through HotWired - you'll have to go to the main URL
at <http://www.betalounge.com/>. Bookmark that one! Because that's where
we'll be at. Look for a new design, and more live music in '98. Also, all
of the DJs who have played at the beta lounge since July of 97 can be
accessed through the pull-down menu at http://www.betalounge.com/live.html
- this will be fixed in the new design, all of the archives will be
accessable from one location.

By the way, for those folks who missed Graham Haynes on cornet at Static
last night, you can listen to his set from last Thursday at the Beta Lounge.

Go to:  http://www.betalounge.com/live.html .

He played live over a great jungle set from Beta Lounge resident DJ Sifu.

>Well here's an alternative way to think of x-mas!
>
>sat kriya

(snip snip snip)



Without singling someone out (which is I guess unavoidable in this case)
.... I would like to remind the folks on here that this is a list of more
than 450 people, all with different tastes, experiences and interests..

what we have in common is our love of raving.....  but beyond that, one
should expect that these many strangers are going to appreciate one's
secret quirks.

to me, a post like this is not appropriate in this forum.  there are young
teenagers on here, there are people of different religions and all sorts of
lifestyles....

sexually graphic materials may be welcome and/or appropriate on other lists
and in other situations....

however, i would like to request that -- cute, funny, satirical or whatever
-- we do not post blatantly sexual material on this list... particularly
when it has nothing whatsoever to do with raving, and most particularly
when the material is as controversial as b&d and fetish oriented.

perhaps this is an instance where a list of one's personal friends would
have been the appropriate mailing address to use, rather than sending this
to a list that includes a few friends and many many strangers.

please, folks, whenever you're tempted to post what is clearly bound to
offend certain people, think twice and treat us with as much respect in the
cyber world as you would in the real world.

love,

leslie

oh boy, another questionaire!  i gotta make up one of these things
myself one of these days...



> What are the things you liked about partys this year?

open skies, fog flowing in, the sound of the surf with distant beats
rolling underneath...  lazers caressing green leaves a mile away... 
the boundless youthful energy of the kids surrounding me seeping into
my old bones, making me dance like i was eighteen again...  friendly,
open vibes, smiles from strangers...  kisses from girls i'd never met
before and never saw again...  oddly coherant conversations with
strangers around the dimming campfire...

> 
> What are the things you experienced that you liked 
> and would like to see more of?

shadow couples projected onto white sheets grooving grinding kissing
fucking...  bodies covered in dayglo fingerpaint and nothing else as
the 303 goes mad...  fire, art, explosions...  good, clean san
francisco ecstacy...  that green dreadlocked girl i was flirting with
by sunrise on the dunes above happy kids...

> 
> What were your favorite/worst partys and why?

favorite:  happy kids beach party - sand, vibes, sand in my shoes,
sand on the dancefloor, pretty girls, vibes, jungledawn, vibes, fog,
lights, vibes, vibes, happy kids...

worst:  happy kids halloween - spent weeks putting together the best
messiah wannabe costume ever!  bought tickets for myself and all my
friends too!  lonely but lookin sharp!  high but comepletely lucid! 
got stuck on the castro and missed the map point, never found the
party...

> What are the things you didnt like and woukd like to see 
> less of or not at all.

sfpd.
 
> If you could have anything you wanted at a party, what would it be?

an orgy.

> What do you want to create in the community, at partys
> or just in general this coming year?

exitement, shock, disbelief... free feasts... guerilla art
happenings... diy sculpture in the middle of the dance floor...

> What would you like to give to the community this year?

a new religion...


-messiah wannabe

I like this one :o)

 What are the things you liked about partys this year?
--This year i think i found another side of partys than what i had been seeing
before, i had the oppertunity to go by myself and meet people i would have
never met being with my friends, also this year, a lot more than previous,
Jungle has been everywhere *YAY*
 
 What are the things you experienced that you liked 
 and would like to see more of?
 --I saw more of seperation this year between UGs and massives, the types of
people and their reason for going seemed to put them in the right place...I
saw more DJs which is always nice, i saw smiles and all the good things that
keep me coming back :o)
 
What were your favorite/worst partys and why?
--I would have to say that Freedom and True Love tie for best partys. Theres
nuthin like stairing a a big mountain with crazy lazers all over it and
spending four hours in the shower the next day finding dirt EvErYwHeRe!!! The
DJs kicked all nite long and i have never watched a more unified sunrise. True

sober one was they were never really sure

As a general rule, I make my tapes 60 minutes (30 minutes a side).

I figure this gives folks enough to listen to without it feeling too 
overbearing (Hey, 30 solid minutes without a 4-on-the-floor beat is 
really hard for some folks to take!), and it also helps keep costs down at 
the duplication joint.

:)

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


> to me, a post like this is not appropriate in this forum.  there are young
> teenagers on here, there are people of different religions and all sorts of
> lifestyles....
> 
> sexually graphic materials may be welcome and/or appropriate on other lists
> and in other situations....
> 
> however, i would like to request that -- cute, funny, satirical or whatever
> -- we do not post blatantly sexual material on this list... particularly

Well, to me, the fwded message was just as "relevant" to raving as all
the posts cataloguing people's drug use/abuse, or all the posts talking
about vegetarianism, or ... whatever. I don't see you coming out
against people talking about drugs, but it's pretty clear that drug
abuse is far more harmful to "young teenagers" than, say, dildo abuse.
 
Basically, I don't agree that it is appropriate to single out
Satkriya's post and stand it up and give it a public spanking. 

And quite frankly, I'm sick of this "we're doing it for the children"
bullshit that has become a popular political means by which to  make
fascism, censorship and thought-control palatable to the masses. By the
same line of reasoning that you use to censor Satkriya, someone else
could say that all information about "raving" is inapprorpiate "for the
children"... 

Ultimately, if parents are worried about what their children are doing,
then perhaps they should be spending more time with them and teaching
them how to respond to messages they don't understand or perplex them,
rather than censoring. Censorship just indicates that children should
take special interest in the taboo subject matter, and that, if
anything, is what creates warped adults.

Besides, i'm sick of a culture that finds it perfectly acceptable to
condone various forms of drug use/abuse (incl. alchohol and tobacco),
blood & violence, war, greed, dominance/slavery/power etc. But when it
comes to anything dealing with sex, the human body, or even "weird"
behavior related to sex, well, that's just too freaky for "young
teenagers"... better take their mind off that subject by showing some
decapitations, clinical closups of gunshot wounds, or a still-beating
hearts ripped from the chest.... make war not love.

As far as I'm concerned, I'd rather see a butt-plug or a strap-on
glorified in the mass-media, but instead we glorify and accept guns and
killing-machines. But wHat can one expect from a society that glorifies
war and treachery against one's fellow humans.

But, hey, it's all "for the children" so it must be all right. Besides,
those violence-warped, sex/love-starved kids make for good cannon
fodder once they turn 18 and a war breaks out. it's all good.

 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==>> Niels Mayer (mayer@netcom.com) <<>> http://www.cybertribe.com/mayer <<==
 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Hi folks,

I think that this should have been marked NRR for sure,
however, I agree with Niels. We will blab about drugs
all day long, but the second someone says "dildo"
everyone runs for cover.

should not be the ones to dictate what is correct to
post or incorrect. Censorship of any-kind is a pretty

Well the standard is a 90 on a chrome tape duped in a
pro place with a nice J-card. Doh!! was that the
party promoter in me Talking?? Well a nice Maxell XL
2 90 is the best and a nice recorder if you don't
have the mega bucks to put a "Pro tape" together. But
the bad thing about this is a lot of promoters just
want to get a free tape and can give a shit about
what is on it or who you are. At least that has been
my experience. So screw them go with a 60. Sorry list
as you can see I am still working through some shitty
promoter issues. :P~
it is funny cause I think I have only got one gig
from actually having a tape. But no matter 60 or 90
make sure the tape is good quality like Maxell or one
of the others.

Peace,
Macadio

In a message dated 12/16/97 10:56:10 PM, you wrote:

What are the things you liked about partys this year? great music as always,
maybe i'm getting old but it seems that i'm not so interested in crowded
overpacked poorly ventilated spaces, so i attended mostly massives and was
very impressed with what i saw  & heard

What are the things you experienced that you liked 
and would like to see more of?  Friendly security...and more people throwing
parties not for the $ but for the music and for the benefit of the scene here

What were your favorite/worst partys and why? 
The best? Gosh, it's hard to judge like that because each party has elements
which both disappoint and impress.  Explicit House was WAY up there...I
remember DUNE way back when...now THAT was the best of all time....um...HK was
too much like sardines packed in a box with no room to even move or dance

What are the things you didnt like and would like to see 
less of or not at all?
	What I  don't like? OD's at raves, kids abusing themselves and the space,
peeps who treat the UG like a business instead of a community 

If you could have anything you wanted at a party, what would it be?  Hahaha
Very funny question.  I think I'll plead the 5th on this one :)

What do you want to create in the community, at partys
or just in general this coming year?  An even stronger sense of family and
unity...less exploitation of the scene and greater awareness of the deeper
connection between music and (MY) sanity...

What would you like to give to the community this year?
Ummm, is this like the "what can you do for your country" line??
I think that being present as a positive influence is most important...
acceptance and understanding are also key, as are sharing hugs, smiles, and
long philosophical talks....(we all suddenly become philosophers in the wee
hours of the morn...=)

Happy holidays to all...be safe!

love
cryshia

Hey all!

I have a question for the list, just a general info.  Feel free to respond
to me personally if you'd rather not spam the list with the answers,
otherwise, feel free to post aloud and let the world know. :)

What do /you/ wear to Raves?

Does it depend on where the Rave is?

Does it depend on what your friends are wearing?

Do you go for comfort, or 'style'?

Feel free to tack on any other info you think is relevant.

Peace and love,
Haze

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 25719 invoked by uid 6000); 18 Dec 1997 19:05:28 -0000
Received: (qmail 25705 invoked from network); 18 Dec 1997 19:05:26 -0000

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 18 Dec 1997 19:05:26 -0000
Received: from ccnet3 (byroni@ccnet3.ccnet.com [192.215.96.11])
	by mailhub1.ncal.verio.com (8.8.7/8.8.7) with SMTP id LAA29149;
	Thu, 18 Dec 1997 11:05:24 -0800 (PST)
Date: Thu, 18 Dec 1997 11:05:24 -0800 (PST)
From: *byroni* <byroni@ccnet.com>
X-Sender: byroni@ccnet3
To: Haze <haze@netgate.net>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: What do /you/ wear to a rave?
In-Reply-To: <199712181854.KAA13678@u2.netgate.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.95.971218105651.25039H-100000@ccnet3>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Here goes.... :)

> What do /you/ wear to Raves?
> 

Usually cybertropical/70s wear, modern stuff, or baggies.

> Does it depend on where the Rave is?
>

Yes. Outdoor parties are always more tribal. House parties are all about
the funk, techno/trance is new wave/spacey wear. Jungle is baggies and
earth colors. Or whatever is comfy.

> Does it depend on what your friends are wearing?
>

Nope. But it's fun to go dressed in a "mood" as a group. Wait until the
cybertropix crew goes all about.. hehe. :)

> Do you go for comfort, or 'style'?

Both.

I think external appearance is pretty nice. I like to look good at
parties, because it's a direct reflection of my feelings inside. I want
people to know I feel good about myself when I'm groovin'... and by them
knowing this they will be more prone to pick up the good vibes I try to 
share with others.

Also... my *favorite* music to dance to at parties is definately DEEEP
house. It has to be really soulful, emotional, jazzy and fun. It has to
have a lot of depth and emotion. It has to pull me in. You know
what'I'mean...? :) House House House.....

**What kinda music do you guys like most at parties?? If you stayed in one
room all night what would it be? And what DJ would it be...?

It would be House for me, and I'd love to hear DJ Sneak spinning an 8 hour
set... hehe.

Love,
Byron

> 
> Feel free to tack on any other info you think is relevant.

> Peace and love,

another deep space transmission from... ..  .

Haze wrote:
> I have a question for the list, just a general info.  Feel free to respond
> to me personally if you'd rather not spam the list with the answers,
> otherwise, feel free to post aloud and let the world know. :)
> 
> What do /you/ wear to Raves?

Something that's clean (usually) that I can move in that's not too
hot or constricting.  Layers are good so I can shed/don clothing
to regulate body temperature.  Jewelry is rare, cuz it's just begging
to get lost, unless I have a lucky-talisman-of-the-week, in which
case it dosen't leave my sight.

> 
> Does it depend on where the Rave is?

In a way . . .  If it's in Detroit in the winter, I wear a coat . . .
But that's not the question.  For some reason, I like wearing a 
hockey jersey to a drum & bass party.  Don't ask me why, but it
just seems to fit.

> 
> Does it depend on what your friends are wearing?

Not really.

> 
> Do you go for comfort, or 'style'?

Comfort<-X------------------------------------>Style
That is, as comfortable as possible without looking like a dork.

> 
> Feel free to tack on any other info you think is relevant.

comfortable footwear is also important, since I'm often on my feet for
extended periods of time.  Barefoot is preferrable, but not always
feasable.  I also wear underwear (boxers) without any holes in it,
even though it's not going to show.

Well, you asked . . .

Steve.

http://www.compare.net/
Information is Power

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: gold kisses
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

THE GOLD BOX

We often learn the most from our children. Some time ago a friend of
mine punished his 3-year-old daughter for wasting a roll of gold
wrapping paper. Money was tight, and he became infuriated when the child
tried to decorate a box to put under the tree. 

Nevertheless, the little girl brought the gift to her father the next
morning and said, "this is for you daddy". He was embarrassed by his
earlier over reaction, but his anger flared again when he found that the
box was empty. He yelled at her, "Don't you know that when you give
someone a present, there's supposed to be something inside of it?" 

The little girl looked up at him with tears in her eyes and said,
"Oh, daddy, it's not empty. I blew kisses into the box. All for you,
Daddy".

The father was crushed. He put his arms around his little girl, and he
begged her forgiveness. My friend told me that he kept that gold box by
his bed for years. Whenever he was discouraged, he would take out an
imaginary kiss and remember the love of the child who had put it there.
In a very real sense, each of us as parents has been given a gold
container filled with unconditional love and kisses from our children.
There is no more precious possession anyone could hold.

==================

a bittersweet story that i recieved this morning.
I think i will send a few gold boxes this year also...full
of hugs and kisses.

	><{{{">   <"}}}><

		foolish fish

I used to be indecisive, now im not sure.

Coast.  Did not get to rave at all, but still had
an awesome time.

So like I'm back, bored, have not been to a rave since Happy Kids on
Halloween and I want to party (Sober).

I went out with my old crew, The Backwon family ( I know I probably
misspelled that, but oh well, LIVE WITH IT  J/K ) and had an awesome time.
We went to Christmas in the Park, in San Jose.  We starred at the people
ice scatting, but none of us went on the ice.

I started seeing my ex again (as friends, I am so totally hoping for more,
but at least I have her friendship!!!, after trying to fight my self and
telling my self I don't love her, but DAMMIT!!!!! I DO!!!!!!! )

So now I hope to Rave a little bit more with her and all you wonderful !!!
kiddies !!!, before I take off to Europe in January for 6 weeks.....  ;-<

See all of you soon,

>>> mounted, transformed into a shrine; halls decked with boughs of holly;
>>> stockings hung by the chimney, with care.
>>>
>>> You really think someone's been here?
>>>
>>> Someone ... or something.
>>>
>>> Mulder, over here-it's a fruitcake.
>>>
>>> Don't touch it!  Those things can be lethal.
>>>
>>> It's O.K.  There's a note attached: "Gonna find out who's naughty and
>>> nice."
>>>
>>> It's judging them, Scully.  It's making a list.
>>>
>>> Who?  What are you talking about?
>>>
>>> Ancient mythology tells of an obese humanoid entity who could travel
>>> at
>>> great speed in a craft powered by antlered servants.  Once each year,
>>> near the winter solstice, this creature is said to descend from the
>>> heavens to reward its followers and punish disbelievers with jagged
>>> chunks of anthracite. But that's legend, Mulder-a story told by
>>> parents
>>> to frighten children.
>>>
>>> Surely you don't believe it?
>>>
>>> Something was here tonight, Scully.  Check out the bite marks on this
>>> gingerbread man.  Whatever tore through this plate of cookies was
>>> massive-and in a hurry.
>>>
>>> It left crumbs everywhere.  And look, Mulder, this milk glass has been
>>> completely drained.
>>>
>>> It gorged itself, Scully.  It fed without remorse.
>>>
>>> But why would they leave it milk and cookies?
>>>
>>> Appeasement.  Tonight is the Eve, and nothing can stop its wilding.
>>>
>>> But if this thing does exist, how did it get in? The doors and windows
>>> were locked.  There's no sign of forced entry.
>>>
>>> Unless I miss my guess, it came through the fireplace.
>>>
>>> Wait a minute, Mulder.  If you're saying some huge creature landed on
>>> the roof and came down this chimney, you're crazy. The flue is barely
>>> six inches wide. Nothing could get down there.
>>>
>>> But what if it could alter its shape, move in all directions at once?
>>>
>>> You mean, like a bowl full of jelly?
>>>
>>> Exactly.  Scully, I've never told anyone this, but when I was a child
>>> my
>>> home was visited.  I saw the creature.  It had long white shanks of
>>> fur
>>> surrounding its ruddy, misshapen head.  Its bloated torso was red and
>>> white.  I'll never forget the horror.  I turned away, and when I
>>> looked
>>> back it had somehow taken on the facial features of my father.

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 18 Dec 1997 19:41:47 -0000
Received: from [38.248.198.65] ([38.248.198.65] (may be forged)) by netcommunications.net (10.1/8.7.3) with ESMTP id LAA10770 for <sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org>; Thu, 18 Dec 1997 11:56:24 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <l03110702b0bf1a64d5db@[38.248.198.65]>
In-Reply-To: <199712181138.DAA03992@netcom8.netcom.com>
References: Your message of "Wed, 17 Dec 97 15:07:16 PST."            
 <l03110705b0be08e2de5c@[38.248.198.53]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 18 Dec 1997 11:41:53 -0800
To: sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Re: A Few of my favorite things.... (fwd)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

wow.

for those of you who weren't around a couple of years ago, neils p. meyer
told me years ago that he had created a filter to screen out all of my
messages .... guess that has changed.


>Well, to me, the fwded message was just as "relevant" to raving as all
>the posts cataloguing people's drug use/abuse, or all the posts talking
>about vegetarianism, or ... whatever. I don't see you coming out
>against people talking about drugs, but it's pretty clear that drug
>abuse is far more harmful to "young teenagers" than, say, dildo abuse.


perhaps that filter *is* working, and you just haven't read my messages,
becaue i have spoken out many many times about posts supporting and
glamorizing drug use and abuse.  i have also responded privately many times
to posts that i felt were inappropriate for a number of reasons, including
glamorizing drug use and things that were sexually inappropriate in my
opinion.  i also speak out against what appears to be sexist or racist
comments, either publicly or privately.

Additionally I am the mother of a teenager, and I have personal friendships
with many of the young people on this list .... as well as older people on
this list who for religious or personal reasons, are very likely to find
sexually graphic posts offensive and inappropriate.

and i don't think your analogy of drugs and dildoes holds up .... drugs are
a part of the rave culture, like it or not.  however, i don't recall seeing
many sex toys at parties of late.

i am on other rave-oriented lists where this would not have seemed
inappropriate because of the ages and personal relationships of the list
members.... but on sfraves, i strongly believe that *every* member needs to
be treated with respect, and that means not posting things that are far
off-topic and sexually explicit, because we are such a diverse group.
sorry, but i feel strongly about that.

then neils said...

> And quite frankly, I'm sick of this "we're doing it for the children"
> bullshit that has become a popular political means by which to  make
> fascism, censorship and thought-control palatable to the masses. By the
> same line of reasoning that you use to censor Satkriya, someone else
> could say that all information about "raving" is inapprorpiate "for the
> children"...

sorry, you're barking up the wrong tree here... i think that my consistent
presence as a supportive figure in the rave community, as well as my
willingness to defend raving on national television, trying to speak up as
a positive voice for young people and the rave community in general in the
face of media disinformation, speak for who i am and what i am about...
calling my reasoning "fascism, censorship and thought control" is
laughable.

folks, to me there is a huge difference between censorship and
self-control.  i strongly believe that one of the most important personal
rules of behavior a responsible adult can have is to be aware of the
effects of their actions on others.

just as most of us would choose, out of respect and knowing what is
appropriate behavior, not to curse in front of our grandmothers, or to
smoke pot in front of our 6-year-old brother, we should be aware that
sfraves is like a family or a community, and that it's a public forum, it
is not the privacy of your own home.

i'm not saying "do it for the children" .... i'm saying remember where you
are, you are not at home in the privacy of your bedroom... you are, in
effect, in a room with 450 people, most of whom are not like you except
that they like raving, and when you take the stage, think about who you're
talking to, and use the same judgment in deciding what to say online that
you would if you were on that stage.

leslie



From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Dec 18 19:54:02 1997

Well, on the nw-raves list we have a variety of subject codes
people use to decide which messages to dump and which to keep.
It automatically puts a [NWR] on the message to begin with...then they have:

[EVT] - for event information
[REV] - for party reviews
nrr, of course
[TECH] - for specific "gear talk"

so you can look at the subject of the message and tell immediately if you
want
to read it....
i have mixed feelings about this however. I understand what it can be like
to wade through massive amounts of email (i am on three lists! eek!) but
at the same time, it kind of makes it seem like certain messages are
important
and certain ones are not....If you aren't reading all the messages on the
list
then you might be missing out on something really cool.....on the other
hand,
they can be handy....

love kim
.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.
the purpose of this record is to demonstrate by tone
the ability of your pickup to stay in contact with the
groove modulation. In other words, to track the groove.
http://www.pulpfiction.com/rave/groovinkim/events.html
seattle rave and club night listings =) ICQ #2388692
http://www.pulpfiction.com/rave
Raverbooks - the world's first raver bookstore!
.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.

Not listed her is a special Rave related crafts fair with Bullet Proof, 
Faster Bamboo, XLR8R, ummm and about 10 other artists not counting the 
50 artists of non dance culture mediums. And my project "Santa 
Worship-The All Santa Crash Worship Cover Band.

D.J.s will be sopinning all day.
The Dance Culture Crafts Fair was organized by Toph One who spins tonite 
at Liquid.


Naughty Santa's Bizarre Bazaar

Sunday, December 21st, from 3-11pm
SOMAR Gallery 934 Brannan St. @ 8th in SF
$5-15 sliding scale

Info: http://www.laughingsquid.com/santa/naughty/

Oh no! Only four days 'til Christmas! Is it too late to order the usual
fruit arrangement for Aunt Gladys and Uncle Porcupine? Man, can the 
pears
and come on down to the second annual Naughty Santa's Bizarre Bazaar! 
Your
friends already have everything? No problem, Naughty Santa has 
everything
else!

This year there are even more artists and oddities, fabulous
entertainment, great food and libations (beer from Brewery Atlantis),
video projections, and cushy lounges -we've filled the entire SOMAR
Gallery to overflowing!  Art, fashion, flatware, zines, videos, unusual
jewelry, music and more.  Who wouldn't love a bubblewrap bustier? [Other
than Uncle Porcupine!] How about two tables of official Burning Man
paraphenelllia? Autographed Christian socks! Nowhere else but Naughty
Santa's.

San Francisco luminaries will be in attendance including: the Space
Cowgirls (as seen on CNN) and their new outrageous clothing line, Brian
"Defenestration" Goggin, Philo "Art Car Mogul" Northrup, and Michael
"Danger Ranger" Mykal will be hosting the Twisted Toy Making Table, The
Cyberbuss, The Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence, Michael Peppe, and those
are only the ones we'll tell you about ahead of time!

Even if you already have your shopping done there's plenty of fun at
Naughty Santa's. Thrill to videos documenting outrageous events from
S.F.'s alternative to the alternative curated by Laughing Squid
Productions. Chill in the Black Light Video Lounge brought to you by 
Museo
Contempo, and drink the heavenly Nub Chai. Explore the groove in The 
Funk
Side as DJ Toph hosts a wild terrain of artists, writers, magazines and
DJ's spinning and selling music and stuff from SF's hot hip-hop based
beathead Kultcha!

In addition to the DJ's-which include Deena Davenport, Alvin-A-Go-Go,
Otto, and John Hell-you'll be wowed by the Yule-tribal drumming of Santa
Worship.  And if you're wondering what awaits you under the tree this
year, visit Prophesies Unlimited, our team of pagan prognosticators. We
advise getting your picture taken with Naughty Santa and Mistress Clause
at the Bazaar, to verify your whereabouts and assure you get what's 
coming
to you!

http://sfstation.com/city_events/naughtysanta.htm

Precedence: bulk

>What do /you/ wear to Raves?

Usually whatever I am wearing that day, plus an additional ounce of glitter
and i color my hair (i have neon orange and red hair paints)

However, my normal clothes are : some type of giant pants (preferably
in a strange and funky fabric and color), a smaller t-shirt (preferably with
weird drawings or writing on it) and platform sneakers.

So in a sense I am dressed up all the time, 'cause my "normal" clothes
kind of look like party clothes anyway.

I tend to change sneakers before parties because platforms are fun to wear
but impossible to dance in. I find that airwalks and vans make good dancing
shoes.

On the subject of shoes - Why do I see so many ravers wearing Nike? That
really bothers me.

>Does it depend on where the Rave is?

Well, if it's a dirty warehouse I won't wear my pants with the white fur at
the bottom
because they'd get dirty....

It doesn't really matter where it is...

>Does it depend on what your friends are wearing?

Not at all, most of my friends don't dress like me....

>Do you go for comfort, or 'style'?

Aren't they the same thing? How can you feel good if you're not comfortable?
I don't really have any uncomfortable clothes.....

Here's my additional question:

Where do you guys shop for clothes online? I like the following stores:

http://www.alloyonline.com
(big pants, sweaters, stickers)
http://www.girliewear.com
(cute girlie tees and underwear)

love kim

We all have our beliefs on what is right and what is wrong(I'm not
talking about large scale things like murder, for those on this list
who have trouble reading between the lines).  One of my beliefs is that
censorship is total hypocracy.  With censorship you are trying to FORCE
your beliefs onto someone else who obviously doesn't beleive the same
thing you do.  But there is nothing wrong with voiceing your opinion to
especially to see if everyone else agrees.  I'm not trying to preach to
you, I think too much of that has been done on this list already.  I'm
basically saying that this list is all about fun and those poems were all
in good humor I thought they were great.  I realy don't see much of a
difference between clit clips and E anyway.  They both effect the mind and
cause the body to be touched, and I've seen both in public in SF and not
at RAVES.  So lighten up and have some fun, that is all this list is about
anyway.

Razor

On Thu, 18 Dec 1997, Leslie Ayres wrote:

> wow.
> 
> for those of you who weren't around a couple of years ago, neils p. meyer
> told me years ago that he had created a filter to screen out all of my
> messages .... guess that has changed.
> 
> 
> >Well, to me, the fwded message was just as "relevant" to raving as all
> >the posts cataloguing people's drug use/abuse, or all the posts talking
> >about vegetarianism, or ... whatever. I don't see you coming out
> >against people talking about drugs, but it's pretty clear that drug
> >abuse is far more harmful to "young teenagers" than, say, dildo abuse.
> 
> 
> perhaps that filter *is* working, and you just haven't read my messages,
> becaue i have spoken out many many times about posts supporting and
> glamorizing drug use and abuse.  i have also responded privately many times
> to posts that i felt were inappropriate for a number of reasons, including
> glamorizing drug use and things that were sexually inappropriate in my
> opinion.  i also speak out against what appears to be sexist or racist
> comments, either publicly or privately.
> 
> Additionally I am the mother of a teenager, and I have personal friendships
> with many of the young people on this list .... as well as older people on
> this list who for religious or personal reasons, are very likely to find
> sexually graphic posts offensive and inappropriate.
> 
> and i don't think your analogy of drugs and dildoes holds up .... drugs are
> a part of the rave culture, like it or not.  however, i don't recall seeing
> many sex toys at parties of late.
> 
> i am on other rave-oriented lists where this would not have seemed
> inappropriate because of the ages and personal relationships of the list
> members.... but on sfraves, i strongly believe that *every* member needs to
> be treated with respect, and that means not posting things that are far
> off-topic and sexually explicit, because we are such a diverse group.
> sorry, but i feel strongly about that.
> 
> then neils said...
> 
> > And quite frankly, I'm sick of this "we're doing it for the children"
> > bullshit that has become a popular political means by which to  make
> > fascism, censorship and thought-control palatable to the masses. By the
> > same line of reasoning that you use to censor Satkriya, someone else
> > could say that all information about "raving" is inapprorpiate "for the
> > children"...
> 
> sorry, you're barking up the wrong tree here... i think that my consistent
> presence as a supportive figure in the rave community, as well as my
> willingness to defend raving on national television, trying to speak up as
> a positive voice for young people and the rave community in general in the
> face of media disinformation, speak for who i am and what i am about...
> calling my reasoning "fascism, censorship and thought control" is
> laughable.
> 
> folks, to me there is a huge difference between censorship and
> self-control.  i strongly believe that one of the most important personal
> rules of behavior a responsible adult can have is to be aware of the
> effects of their actions on others.
> 
> just as most of us would choose, out of respect and knowing what is
> appropriate behavior, not to curse in front of our grandmothers, or to
> smoke pot in front of our 6-year-old brother, we should be aware that
> sfraves is like a family or a community, and that it's a public forum, it
> is not the privacy of your own home.
> 
> i'm not saying "do it for the children" .... i'm saying remember where you
> are, you are not at home in the privacy of your bedroom... you are, in
> effect, in a room with 450 people, most of whom are not like you except
> that they like raving, and when you take the stage, think about who you're
> talking to, and use the same judgment in deciding what to say online that
> you would if you were on that stage.
> 
> leslie
> 
>

>What do /you/ wear to Raves?
as little as I can get away with ( it gets really hot), this usually
consists of baggy pants and a small top.  No skirts or dresses though, I
have seen to many guys getting way to friendly with those that do where
them. No thank you!!  

>
>Does it depend on where the Rave is?
Outside beach parities, or wherehouse parties  I do the opposite, layers,
layers, long underwear, and more layers. 
>
>Does it depend on what your friends are wearing?
Not at all.

>
>Do you go for comfort, or 'style'?

I always think of comfort above all  and my own personal style.  I like
to wear collars, spiked or chains, I don't usually see many ravers
wearing those ( the only I can think of is Squeeze, what ever happened to
him?) .  I don't go out much, and that includes raving (only about once a
month) so when I do I love  to get as nutty as I can.  Holloween is my
favorite holiday and I will go all out with out blinking an eyelash.>


>Feel free to tack on any other info you think is relevant.
Sometimes I wear glitter  and sometimes I don't, sometimes (like on
Holloween) I get really dressed up and wear my sparkly pants and shirt
with tassels, and sometimes I where my plastic pants.  In other words I
were  what I want , at all times.  I enjoy making little things to put in
my hair, and accessorize with  my out fits. (flowers, or little glow in
the dark things, little fish, eyeballs,  anything that would make
somebody else smile)  I don't go to attract the opposite sex, even though
I might be wearing very little clothing but like I said before it get
damn hot most of the time, I choose to be comfortable.. Sometime I have
to out of my way to make sure people don't get that idea, and I have to
admit it still doesn't always work.>

RLove

maybe next year I will get burning man and try no clothes and see how I
like that.


>

In a message dated 97-12-18 15:27:39 EST, you write:

<< What do /you/ wear to Raves?
I like to wear clothes that Teresa makes for me =)
I like to wear glitter and glow toys.
I like to wear big pants and fur and holographic/phsychedelic prints.
I like my bracelets and necklaces and stickers
I like cool stripes and piping and backpacks with bright colors on them.
 
 Does it depend on where the Rave is?
I think it depends on the rave.  Usually, I'll just pick out a random outfit,
but for things like Halloween or special occasions, I might create an outfit
with a theme
 
 Does it depend on what your friends are wearing?
 Never has, never will =)  

 Do you go for comfort, or 'style'? >>
I think it's a little bit of both.  ravers definately have their own "style",
but when I pick out a quote/unquote stylish outfit it's most likely gonna have
to be comfy enough to dance in all night.  

 Clothes create a vibe for me.  I get excited all the time when I see someone
wearing pants that I like, or a shirt that I think is cool.  If people didn't
dress so crazy and unique at parties, I don't think I'd have as much fun.
That's not to say that you have to dress a certain way to be a raver, but when
else do you get the chance to?

       Hugs n'stuff,
          'trice the tekno diva

---Messiah Wannabe <messiahw@rocketmail.com> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> 
> > I like to think that humans can rise above that to some extent and
are
> > capable of showing more compassion than an animalistic approach.....
> 
> actually, very few animals will kill other members of it's own
> species.  two lions fighting over territory won't actually fight to
> the death, often their's some ritualistic instinctual "goal" - when
> one animal pins down the other, or whatever (one species of snake
> fights till the loser touches the ground with it's head - the film
> footage of the "fight" was a trip) the loser slinks off, beaten but
> alive.  man, as i understand it, is one of the few higher order
> animals to kill it's own species.  we are particularly vicious
> animals...
> 
> > which is the reason i am vegetarian.......if meat was eaten once in
> a while,
> > as a special treat, or something, that would be all right...
> 
> here's my idea:  in metropolitan areas, you have a species of deer
> which wanders around the city, eating food from special deer-feeders. 
> make it an attractive, housetrainable species that can run _almost_ as
> fast as a human.  if you want to eat meat that day, you have to find,
> run down, and kill with your bare hands one of these deer.  i think
> this would not only be healthier for us humans (you have to exercise
> to eat meat), but also nicer to the animals, and just generally more
> "natural"...
> 
> -messiah wannabe


and plus, dear meat taste good especailly when healthy.......

just kidding - I've read some Vedic literature that reducing the
tendancies of eating animals will lessen the urge for violence in
human nature, this is ofcourse a truncated explanation. Talk to your
local Hari Krishna and you'll get a better story.

*yAy*!!! theze r good questionz!!!... :)

>>What do /you/ wear to Raves?

~~~* i usually wear my snazzy festive wear.... big baggy jeanz n' a 
little happy tee n' uv course running shoez.... cuz u never know when u 
just mite have 2 outrun tha police!!! :) he he ...n' lotz uv glitter, 
glow-in-tha dark thingiez, n' stickaz!! :) ~*yAy!!*~

>>Does it depend on where the Rave is?

~~~* well... i suppoze so.... i wouldn't wanna freeze my butt off or 
nuthin.... so i dress according 2 tha 4-cast 4 tha evening!!! :)

>>Does it depend on what your friends are wearing?

~~~* nah.... who'd wanna dress like thoze loserz?... he he just 
kidding!!! :) on tha serious vibE tho... i dress completely different 
from my friendz... so it wouldn't really matter!! :)

>>Do you go for comfort, or 'style'?

~~~* 4 me.... comfort equalz style... if i can run, jump, or play in 
it... it'z a winnEr!!! :) style *iz* attitude!!! :)

>Where do you guys shop for clothes online? 

~~~* i don't or should i say haven't actually ordered clothes online... 
i've only bought rekkidz... mebbe i should, eh?! hmmm... i think i just 
found anutha way 2 drive myself more in2 debt..!!! he he :)

have a happy day kidz.... n'
Happy "Candy Kane" Holidayzzz!!....
MuchLuuuuv'n'MadKrazyHugzzzz....
dEnisE

The Gathering (6 years!) looks like the biggest party of the weekend,
with Sunshine Daydream leading into it (during the day on Saturday).
For a bit smaller crowd, try the Imperial Dub party or Candyland or Revival.
On Sunday, I believe the music marathon will be netcast as well on 
www.cybertribe.com. 

Next week's calendar will be out on Tuesday or Wednesday due to the
holiday on Thursday.

   The Red Lion Inn, 1401 Arden Way, Sacramento. 916.484.3706
   
   Twist - Deep and Swing House w/DJs Christopher, weekly guests.
   10pm-2am, 21+, $5. the Beer Cellar, 685 Sutter @ Taylor, SF.
   415.317.1754
   
   the Bulletproof Social - jazz, soul, latin, house, disco, dub, jungle
   w/DJs kevin, george, jayson, richard, kirsten, guests. 9pm-2am, 21+,
   Free. nickie's, 484 haight st, SF.
   
   The Basement Lounge - house w/DJs Miguel "Migs", rotating deep dj's
   weekly. Club 1028, 1028 Geary @ Polk, SF. 415.376.1176
   
   sofalize - ...next level loungin' w/DJs rotating DJs. donations
   appreciated...bring i.d. and please respect the space.
   full coffee bar / literature.
   9pm-. 415.789.8308
   
   the Vinyl Treetmnt - house, jungle, techno w/DJs guests weekly. 21+,
   $3. the Top, 424 Haight St, SF. 415.522.2343
   
   Mr Frisky - Mike LeFebvrier, Toph (Royal Jelly). 10pm- $6. Infusion,
   555 2nd St b/w Bryant & Brannan., SF. 415.346.SPOT
     _________________________________________________________________
   
                                 Info Lines
                                      
     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.569.3300
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
     _________________________________________________________________
   
                             Radio/TV/Net Shows
                                      
     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 11:30pm-2:30am - "Conscious Groove" - a show all
       about ambientdowntempojungletechnotrancedrumnbasstriphop love and
       more with weekly guest DJs. Free Radio Berkeley 104.1 (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Thursday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Friday 10am-3pm - weekly DJ netcasts. x-radio.
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "House Nation" w/"Anthems Mix", Top 10s from
       guest DJs and "London Connection w/DJ Doubt". 2am-4am, WILD 94.9
       SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a search interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
                            Administrative Notes
                                      
   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org

(by the way, I like the suggestiong of a [tech] header for gearhead posts :)

At 02:40 PM 12/17/97 -0800, Troy Sheets wrote:
>It would not be very hard to do this with CD mixers... you could standardize
>a CD-DJ format that would store tempo and beginning-of-phrase data in with
>the music... maybe even data on what key the track is in (to automatically 
>sync up the pitch)  This would not be the end of DJs... it would be the 
>beginning of a new type of musician.  With this kind of technology, CD's
could
>become more minimalistic... and the "dj" could create complete tracks
>on the fly from very small bits of musical data.  The DJ could make their own
>peices of tracks and trade them on the Internet with other DJ's bits.  A live
>set could consist of mixing your own peices, and peices from other dj from
>around the world.  Oh, the future will be fun.

Envision: A box with two side-by-side DVD-ROM drives, a mixing console on
top with two jog/shuttle wheels and various searching/looping controls, and
a flat screen attached like a laptop screen, with a video out so what's on
the monitor can be displayed by a projector or something.  Now on each
home-burned DVD-ROM would be just hours and hours and hours of
128kbit-compressed audio (MPEG, liquid audio, whateva) that would be
multitrack versions of songs.  The beat, basslines, hi-hats, and five or
six melody lines would all be separate tracks, composed together using MIDI
or some other file format.  The interface would allow you to segue from one
track to the next sequentially - cut out song 1's beat, cut out song1's
melody, drop in song 2's beat, drop back in song 1's melody, drop in song
2's melody, drop out other parts of song 1, etc.  Add a few other pieces of
software like Rebirth and maybe a sampling tool, and you'd have a live
performance box which would completely blur the line between DJ and
musician forever.  Best of all, I think a box like this could be
mass-produced TODAY for under $1000 - DVD-ROM drives are already like $180
each, PC hardware is getting cheaper all the time.  The only real limit is
that artists typically don't release multitrack versions of their songs,
and there aren't any DVD-ROM burners yet.

I just brought home a CD-R burner I've had attached to the new Hyperreal
for the last couple months, and am in the process of burning my vinyl to
CD.  The software I'm using removes clicks and pops and scratch sounds too,
so the stuff ends up sounding pristine.  And, blank CD-R's are now down
below $2 each in bulk.  Maybe someday soon I'll have a vinyl sale. :)

	Brian

At 01:32 PM 12/17/97 -0800, Seth wrote:
>As it turns out, his name is Graham Haynes and he is a very well known and
>respected jazz musician from NYC signed to Polygram records.  He is also
>the son of legendary jazz drummer Roy Haynes.  He actually has quite a few
>albums out and is currently working on some projects which fuse live jazz
>with drum and bass.  Being the techno snob that I am, I usually can't stand
>live musicians over electronic beats, but I thought he was absolutely
>amazing last night...  

A party a few years ago ('93?) held down on Mission near Army: a trumpet
player named "Blow" and a DJ named Doc Martin kicked mucho ass.  The
trumpet player had a roaming mic too so you'd be dancing and next thing you
know you'd see this guy playing the song you were grooving hard too.  Doc
picked some great music to use as a base for it too; very light on the
highs and melodies, and sparse so as to let the trumpet player improvise
freely.  Tons of fun.

>Starting in January after our one year anniversary, we are going to try our
>best to have at least one live performance or one dj from out of town every
>month.  

Woohoo!

	Brian

Whad 'ap People?!

I have secured a condo in Tahoe for the week of New Years and would very 
much like somebody to spin New Years eve at a gathering I am having. What 
do you get? All of the free booze you can handle, some free grinds, 
interaction with a cool crew and free lodging if you don't mind sharing the 
floor, hot tub, etc! There might be some cash in it or some other perks, 
 but I can't make any promises as the condo is quite expensive. I don't 
mean to offend anybody but when you look at $2800 for the condo alone, and 
lord knows how much for the other stuff, there just ain't a lot of 
expendable dough left over.

Expecting anywhere from 30 to 60 people, perhaps more. It's in South Lake 
Tahoe conveniently located near casinos and resorts. Thick fresh pow so wax 
your rig, strap in and hit it!

Of course any of you lovely gravy ravy gals are encouraged to attend too 
(o: There is a small cost associated to help cover expenses except to the 
DJ. This is not an open party.

EMAIL if interested.

> for those of you who weren't around a couple of years ago, neils p. meyer
> told me years ago that he had created a filter to screen out all of my
> messages .... guess that has changed.

well, dahling, it's cuz you keep changing e-mail addresses.

actually, i've removed all the personal filters from SFR, and just
apply interactive thread and/or name killers during the mail-reading
process as time and interest permits. My mail filters now fight SPAM,
which is the true Jihad that needs to be fought right now.

> perhaps that filter *is* working, and you just haven't read my messages,
> becaue i have spoken out many many times about posts supporting and
> glamorizing drug use and abuse.  i have also responded privately many times
> to posts that i felt were inappropriate for a number of reasons, including
> glamorizing drug use and things that were sexually inappropriate in my
> opinion.  i also speak out against what appears to be sexist or racist
> comments, either publicly or privately.

I'm sure you've spoken out about something.... but, I don't see the
need for a net.cop. Besides, what makes your opinion any more "right"
than mine which says it isn't? Or is the person that complains the most
automatically right?

> and i don't think your analogy of drugs and dildoes holds up .... drugs are
> a part of the rave culture, like it or not.  however, i don't recall seeing
> many sex toys at parties of late.

I've seen semi-nekkid girlz dancing in cages w/ whips at massive (all
ages) raves even recently... what kind of image is that portraying to
the kids? Is talk of a dildo on sfraves worse for a young teenager than
the gauntlet of drug-dealers you pass through at every massive (all
ages) rave?? Or is that some quiet secret that we all know and just
don't talk about?

Basically "parties of late" have sucked. Raves are just not as freaky
as they used to be, and people are getting more and more fucked up on
wack drugs. Raving and club culture used to be really fringe, too
fringe for massive dollars to flow in from Buffy and Biff of the
high-school social set. Now it's mainstream, with mainstream,
lowest-common-denominator, milquetoaste values. This is sad, especially
given that raving came from an even freakier and fetishistic milieu... 
I guess you never went to any underground parties in SF in the 85-88
timeframe. I went to some pretty kinky parties in my time, back when
drag queens and weirdoes of all sorts could "do their thing" and "strut
their stuff" unmolested (unless they wanted to be) and unjudgled. These
were not really much different from raving during it's peak -- in fact
raving has done nothing other than mainstream (and straighten) an
underground dance-club culture that has been going on for a long time.

Bottom line is that the notion that music/culture/media needs to be
censored "for the children" is a very old concept. The story has 
always been about sexual values that did not coincide with mainsteeam
culture of the time, and that these sexual values would pervert the
minds of young innocent teenagers luring them towards the ravages of
decadence. The story is as old as Jazz, Rock-and-Roll, Disco, and
Raving, and it's been a losing battle every time. If you're worried
about such real-world influences affecting your children, then take
control and provide the moral and ethical leadership that your child
needs. But don't censor/control other people just because american
parenting refuses to take responsibility for itself. That's the real
problem here -- that parents think that government and society is
responsible for raising their children, rather than themselves.

> but on sfraves, i strongly believe that *every* member needs to 
> be treated with respect, and that means not posting things that are far 
> off-topic and sexually explicit, because we are such a diverse group.
> sorry, but i feel strongly about that.

there's so much NRR on this list that some humourous post about fetish
toys sung to "my favorite things" hardly seems to be something to get
stressed about. perhaps i am INSULTED and AFFRONTED by the postings 
discussing raver fashion tips, but I would not presume to censor people
simply because I think raver fashion is stupid. Besides, it was a hell
of a lot more interesting/humorous to read that post than many a post
to this list.

> sorry, you're barking up the wrong tree here... i think that my consistent
> presence as a supportive figure in the rave community, as well as my
> willingness to defend raving on national television, trying to speak up as
> a positive voice for young people and the rave community in general in the
> face of media disinformation, speak for who i am and what i am about...

I personally don't think there is much to defend w/r/t raving. It's
track record speaks for itself. We all know exactly what goes on at
raves, we all know that unsafe sex, wack drugs, inebriated driving, and
other acts of stupidity happen, and that these are attractive acts of
stupidity for young people. But if people weren't getting their yaya's
out on raving, they'd be doing it with rock-and-roll, or disco, or
hip-hop, or jazz or whatever cultural youth movement happened prior to
raving. To me there's no difference, except for a different fashion,
dance, and music.

Like I said before, you seem to have a false image of your role on that
tabloid tv show -- whether it was your intent or not, you became part
of that melodrama and hype-mongering dog-and-pony show by lending what
seemed to be a voice-of-reason to a lineup of circus-freaks and
druggies. It made the ridiculous and sensational statements made by
others seem like "just another opinion" because you were there to give
the illusion that they were providing balanced information and fair
reporting. But fact is that you were outnumbered many-to-one by voices
saying that raving is a cult that will swallow your children whole and
turn them into drug-snarfling, parent-disobeying,
sneak-out-of-the-house-at-midnight  delinquents.  And it probably will.
In fact, I think you were being disingenuous by not telling the truth
that *SOME* people do use drugs at raves, just like *SOME* raver's
parents used drugs at rock-and-roll events, just like raver's
grandparents used drugs at jazz/dance events ...

> calling my reasoning "fascism, censorship and thought control" is
> laughable.

I never called your reasoning "fascism, censorship and thought
control". However, the "we're doing it for the children" line of
reasoning IS being used for just those purposes, right now, in national
political maneuverings that will limit our free-speech use of the
internet as a communications medium. The move to abridge these rights
is a central part of the communications decency act which has now been
repackaged into legistlative motions that will not be  easy to defend
from a constitutional and freedom-of-speech standpoint. "were doing it
for the children" is equally a part of the national fight by the FBI to
outlaw private and secure communications, which directly conflicts with
our constitutional rights to virtual peacable assembly, freedom from
virtual search and seisure, and our right-to-bear cryptographic-arms
against a government that is no longer representing the will of the
people. These constitutional rights are fundamental to securing
whatever vestiges of democracy remain in our nation, and by allowing
them to be abridged, we are opening the door to fascism.

 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==>> Niels Mayer (mayer@netcom.com) <<>> http://www.cybertribe.com/mayer <<==
 =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Here goes.... :)

> What do /you/ wear to Raves?
> 

Usually cybertropical/70s wear, modern stuff, or baggies.

> Does it depend on where the Rave is?
>

Yes. Outdoor parties are always more tribal. House parties are all about
the funk, techno/trance is new wave/spacey wear. Jungle is baggies and
earth colors. Or whatever is comfy.

> Does it depend on what your friends are wearing?
>

Nope. But it's fun to go dressed in a "mood" as a group. Wait until the
cybertropix crew goes all about.. hehe. :)

> Do you go for comfort, or 'style'?

Both.

I think external appearance is pretty nice. I like to look good at
parties, because it's a direct reflection of my feelings inside. I want
people to know I feel good about myself when I'm groovin'... and by them
knowing this they will be more prone to pick up the good vibes I try to 
share with others.

Also... my *favorite* music to dance to at parties is definately DEEEP
house. It has to be really soulful, emotional, jazzy and fun. It has to
have a lot of depth and emotion. It has to pull me in. You know
what'I'mean...? :) House House House.....

**What kinda music do you guys like most at parties?? If you stayed in one
room all night what would it be? And what DJ would it be...?

It would be House for me, and I'd love to hear DJ Sneak spinning an 8 hour
set... hehe.

Love,
Byron

Given our recent discussions on being non-offensive, I thought this was
appropriate... :-)



>"Happy Holidays!  Season's Greetings!
>
>I wish you all a Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year.  Put
>another way: 
>
>"Best wishes for an environmentally conscious, socially
>responsible, low stress, nonaddictive, gender neutral,
>winter solstice holiday, practiced within the most
>joyous traditions of the religious persuasion of your choice,
>and with respect for the religious persuasions of others or
>their choice not to practice a religion at all; a
>fiscally successful, personally fulfilling, and medically uncomplicated
>recognition of the generally accepted calendar year 1998, but not
>without due respect for the calendars of choice of other cultures whose
>contributions to our society have helped make America great, without
>regard to the race, creed, color, religious, or sexual preferences of
>the wishers."
>
>(This greeting is subject to clarification or withdrawal. It
> implies no promise by the wisher to actually implement any of
> the wishes for her/himself or others.  It is in no way to be
> construed as effecting a contractual obligation of any sort on
> the part of either the wisher or wishee.)
>
>Your mileage may vary!  Have a beautiful solstice!"
>
