Received: (qmail 20733 invoked from network); 19 Dec 1997 19:11:05 -0000
Received: from web1.rocketmail.com (205.180.57.67)
  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 19 Dec 1997 19:11:05 -0000
Message-ID: <19971219190418.91.rocketmail@web1.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [205.180.227.143] by web1; Fri, 19 Dec 1997 11:04:18 PST
Date: Fri, 19 Dec 1997 11:04:18 -0800 (PST)
From: Messiah Wannabe <messiahw@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Re: [tech] Modern state of djing
To: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.org>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



heck, as long as we're at it, might as well pipe in some live
improvisation from bangladesh via isdn, like the fsol/robert fripp
duets on their virtual us tour.  as for multitracked music (where you
can bring in one or more elements from a song and mix it on top of
elements from other songs), you can already download from the web
tracks composed on the rebirth program (which is basically 2 303's an
808 and a 909 faithfully reproduced on a pc), or get cdroms with
multitracked compositions from various artists.  then throw in a
loopman synced to the beat (again this technology is already available
fairly cheaply) and you can sample loops from old soul albums of "the
tibetan monks" or diologues from your favorite movies and thrown them
in as well....

of course there are lots of other cool ways to use technology
available now.  my own ideal setup would be a laptop with rebirth and
a sequencer, one of those paperback-sized roland samplers you can get
for $400, and a pocket sized efects unit, all run through a tiny mixer
into a pair of small powered speakers and a dat walkman.  i've seen
all this technology in stores, it's not that expensive either (if you
have a laptop already the rest of the stuff would cost about as much
as 2 techniques a mixer and flight cases...) - and could all fit in a
briefcase.   i see myself using such a setup for two purposes.  one
would be to set it up on a street corner at midnight and play trumpet
over long strethes of acidy hip hop or jungle or what have you.  
second, i could carry it with me overseas, thus enableing me to
(possibly) become the third-world pop star/producer i've always wanted
to be (i hear jakarta has a pretty decent local club scene...)  or
maybe just do cool electronic/organic jams with peeps in remote
hymalayan villages...

-messiah


---Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.org> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> (by the way, I like the suggestiong of a [tech] header for gearhead
posts :)
> 
> At 02:40 PM 12/17/97 -0800, Troy Sheets wrote:
> >It would not be very hard to do this with CD mixers... you could
standardize
> >a CD-DJ format that would store tempo and beginning-of-phrase data
in with
> >the music... maybe even data on what key the track is in (to
automatically 
> >sync up the pitch)  This would not be the end of DJs... it would be
the 
> >beginning of a new type of musician.  With this kind of technology,
CD's
> could
> >become more minimalistic... and the "dj" could create complete tracks
> >on the fly from very small bits of musical data.  The DJ could make
their own
> >peices of tracks and trade them on the Internet with other DJ's
bits.  A live
> >set could consist of mixing your own peices, and peices from other
dj from
> >around the world.  Oh, the future will be fun.
> 
> Envision: A box with two side-by-side DVD-ROM drives, a mixing
console on
> top with two jog/shuttle wheels and various searching/looping
controls, and
> a flat screen attached like a laptop screen, with a video out so
what's on
> the monitor can be displayed by a projector or something.  Now on each
> home-burned DVD-ROM would be just hours and hours and hours of
> 128kbit-compressed audio (MPEG, liquid audio, whateva) that would be
> multitrack versions of songs.  The beat, basslines, hi-hats, and
five or
> six melody lines would all be separate tracks, composed together
using MIDI
> or some other file format.  The interface would allow you to segue
from one
> track to the next sequentially - cut out song 1's beat, cut out
song1's
> melody, drop in song 2's beat, drop back in song 1's melody, drop in
song
> 2's melody, drop out other parts of song 1, etc.  Add a few other
pieces of
> software like Rebirth and maybe a sampling tool, and you'd have a live
> performance box which would completely blur the line between DJ and
> musician forever.  Best of all, I think a box like this could be
> mass-produced TODAY for under $1000 - DVD-ROM drives are already
like $180
> each, PC hardware is getting cheaper all the time.  The only real
limit is
> that artists typically don't release multitrack versions of their
songs,
> and there aren't any DVD-ROM burners yet.
> 
> I just brought home a CD-R burner I've had attached to the new
Hyperreal
> for the last couple months, and am in the process of burning my
vinyl to
> CD.  The software I'm using removes clicks and pops and scratch
sounds too,
> so the stuff ends up sounding pristine.  And, blank CD-R's are now
down
> below $2 each in bulk.  Maybe someday soon I'll have a vinyl sale. :)
> 
> 	Brian
> 
> 
> 
> 
>
--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=--
> specialization is for insects	brian@apache.org	 brian@hyperreal.org
>

******************************** TONIGHT************************************

                        friday december 19th, 1997

                   s  t  i  r -  f  r  i  -  d  a  y

free lunch* at san francisco's best place for local and international cuisine
drum&bass + hip hop + house + dub + funk + rare grooves + soul + jazz + beatz

                        Last Stir-fri-day of 1997!!!

We will be off for the holidays but will be back the first friday of '98
with Matt Valenz (LoveWorks, Toontown). So, everyone have a great break and
let's end the year right! Hope to see you at Minna in 1998!

Remember: The Om Records Christmas party is also tonight at 111 Minna. So
if you can't make happy hour, be sure to come by the always groovin' Om
party!

Tonights Menu:

starter:

Maneesh the Twister
Some Indian flava in your ear... Baked and dubbed to perfection, this
treat has been sought after for ages. So light and tasty, you'll be craving
for more...

entree:

Felix The Dog (Black Diamond, Splendid)
Aldente (tough to the bite) - spicy, saucy, hot and tangy. This dish is
known for its prime cuts, lean beats and massive portions. Enjoy!

dessert:

Jason Fluid
Specially picked oolong experimental hip hop and electro, baked in soul
with a generous helping of surprise treats to tease yo tongue...


ALL OF THIS AND MORE CAN BE FOUND AT THE CITY'S PREMIER HAPPY HOUR FOR THE
      NEWEST EXPERIMENTAL DANCE MUSIC ON EARTH... STRI FRI-DAYS

             every fri-day @ the minna street gallery
    1 1 1  m i n n a ( btwn. mission / howard / new mont. / 2nd )
                      f r o m   5  to  9  p m

                  all you can eat ! and it's free !




* DISCLAIMER
( lunch not actually free, unless you're on a strict diet of great music ! )

silent records                          (name)@silent.org
340 bryant st.                          www.silent.org
3rd floor east                          415-957-1320
san francisco, ca 94107                 fax:957-0779

                         ***UPCOMING RELEASES***

Call Sang Hwang or Matt Valenzuela for more specifics...
Thanks to all the writers/reviewers for their continued support !

*VA-Big Shots                          SR9719     December 8    2X12"/CD
label: Silent / XLR8R Tracks
Silent Records is proud to announce the fourth offering from XLR8R
magazine's excellent label.   " Big Shots " is a milestone in the evolution
of American drum and bass, with a list of Bay Area artists ranging from
Sharp Scientific to Rec Orc, from DJ Abstract to High Steppers.  Learn the
sound that is emerging from the underground depths of San Francisco's drum
'n' bass community.




                       ***PAST AND CURRENT RELEASES***

*Westside Chemical - Phibsborough      SR9732      out now      CD
label: Silent / Domestic
The long awaited release from Domestic Recordings.  Westside Chemical are
preparing to take control of your mind an speakers with their unique brand
of drum and bass.  Slightly psychedelic, melodic, and definitely influenced
by a heavy dose of dub, theirs is a totally original vibe in a world full
of imitators and bandwagoneers.  Behold the new school of the San Francisco
underground.

*Astral Matrix - Secret Broadcast      SR9731       out now        CD
label: Silent / O.O.B.E.
 In '91, Andrew Johnson came across a Roland 303.  This integral piece of
equipment ultimately helped him in the creation of both his music and his
label.  Now, nearly seven years later, Astral Matrix has become one of the
most in demand producers and performers of intelligent techno on the West
Coast & North America.  Finally, Astral Matrix's acclaimed live set is now
available on a full length CD.

*Lower Haight High Hitters-House Demon      SR9716 (Silent) out now       12"
label: Silent
Ragtag, renegade house music from Ben David, Davidson, and McDavid, more
strange pseudonyms of the notorious Hardkiss boys.  Here San Francisco's
most widely known exports operate undercover to secretly deliver to Silent
a slab of dancefloor weaponry.
LIMITED EDITION TEST PRESSINGS !!!  SOLD OUT !!!

*VA-Spesh Spins Trip 'n' Spin     SR9725 (Trip 'N Spin)     out now       CD
label: Silent / Trip 'n' Spin
' Spesh Spins Trip 'n Spin ' is the culmination of five years of hard labor
from one of San Francisco's original house music labels, Trip 'N Spin
Recordings.  This live DJ mix contains both classic and current styles from
the truly underground collective that is Trip 'N Spin.  This CD is a rare
chance to hear the sound of the label from it's inception to present-day,
in one continuous live mix.  Start trippin !

*Darkhorse-Darkhorse E.P.        SR9717 (Three-Sixty)       out now        12"
label: Silent / Three-Sixty
' Three-Sixty are back with their third release !  After driving through
Death Valley and hitting Vegas, the Three-Sixty crew have split up to evade
Federal Investigators seeking them out for swindling casinos out of towels
and alcohol... '.  A quote from Three-Sixty itself, which when translated
means an more gritty funk and drum 'n bass madness from SF's newest and
most outrageous experimental dance label.

*User-Habit Form E.P.            SR9723 (Organised Noise)   out now        12"
label: Silent / Organised Noise
This is the second release from San Francisco's Organised Noise and is the
debut EP from User.  User is an alias of Jon Williams and Darin Marshall,
and this record is a slice of techno-funk guaranteed to rock floors and
minds.  From the title track to the b-sides ' Reckless Zoom ' and '
Urgionomics ', Organised Noise is attaining the level of similar quality
techno labels from Detroit to London and beyond.

*Tim 'Love' Lee-Confessions of a Selector
SR9718                                                   out now           CD
label: Silent / Three-Sixty
SF's 360 & Tim Love Lee has gotten their act together on this CD. Funky,
melodic, and sometimes just twisted, "Confessions Of A Selector" is the
90's soundtrack for life in the 70's.  As one reviewer put it, " '
Confessions ' makes me want to get naked and watch Bullitt at 6am with a
tall boy of ice cold Coors and Hunter S. Thompson at my side..."  The
effect will be different for some, but the groove is universal.

*Astral Matrix-#6                SR9718               out now          12"
label: Silent / O.O.B.E.
Straight outta San Francisco's underground, Astral Matrix's sixth 12" adds
another thumpin' chapter to the OOBE catalog.  A solid four tracker, '
Number Six ' covers a lot of territory.  From the lush technological cut '
Bass Faerie ' to the darkly percussive and minimal track ' Triangles ',
this EP is yet another achievement for this excellent local artist.

*Jondi & Spesh-We Are Connected  SR9722                out now          12"
Inspired by the Sweet! parties and ' Live at Half moon Bay ' show, this is
the second EP in the collaboration between Trip 'N Spin and Silent.  Floor
rocking trancey house with a left-coast feel.  Remixes by NovaBass.

*VA-Combine EP                 SR9714                    out now         12"
label: Silent / Organised Noise
Some of the best straight up techno west of Carl Craig, Stacey Pullen, Ian
Pooley, Derrick May, etc. All of whom are dropping it in their sets...

*VA-East Bay Conspiracy EP     SR9713                    out now          12"
label: Silent / Trip 'n Spin
Featuring the likes of ETI, Jondi & Spesh, Nick Kelly & Cave Dwellers...
A intense contribution to the San Francisco/West Coast House Movement
Deconstruction meets Hardkiss

*Various Artists-Skampler      SR9708                   out now         CD
label: Silent / Skam
ONLY PLACE TO GET AUTCHERE'S GESCOM, ET.AL. ON CD
Autechere=Warp (the label)= released by TVT= Gescom=Owners of SKAM

*Epsilon-The Black Hole SR9712                          out now          12"
label: Silent / SoundSphere Recordings
Wicked brit-style dark jungle by the artist that has surprised most
junglist with his debut appearance on several UK playlists... No U-Turn
meets Penny Black

*Mammal-The Big Ten-Four EP    SR9711                    out now         12"
label: Silent / Three-Sixty
Speaking of wicked... Thomas of Wicked Productions presents us with the
debut release as Mammal... Downtempo funk with raw/intelligent grooves

*Various Artist-Drum Kicks EP   SR9710                    out now         12"
label: Silent / XLR8R Tracks
Hot Sequel to Bad Brakes EP; more of that soothing ;) west coast sound with
a wee bit of attitude for good measure...

*Various Artists-BAD BREAKS EP  SR9709   12"              out now         12"
label: Silent / XLR8R Tracks
Mutha Beep-Beep by Professor Smith has charted in the UK; CMJ RPM and Jackpot
Reviews by Deep Dish (favorable) in MixMagUS;
1ST PRESSING SOLD OUT!!!

*Makyo-Rasa Bhava: sr9606
label: Silent
Incredibly powerful piece/includes a Bill Laswell remix... referred to this
new sound as Indihop and zen dub... Write-ups in the Wire, Fix, etc.
Reviews as shown plus...

*Various Artist-Land of Baboon (an illclectic brooklyn collection): sr9607
label: Silent
in cover stories by Option and the Wire/ranging from Dub to jungle to
trip-hop to ambient-dub/write-ups (artists and/or release) in the Wire,
Option, etc

WARNING
the following might offend someone...why it would i dont know.
Its just some seem to have forgotten that being occasionally offended
is part of the price we pay for free speech. So if you are the type
that pops a blood vessel everytime someone says something offensive
then press delete now.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

=========================================

On the 12th day of the Eurocentrically imposed midwinter festival, my 
potential-acquaintance-abuse-survivor gave to me,

 TWELVE males reclaiming their inner warrior through ritual drumming,
 
 ELEVEN pipers piping (plus the 18-member pit orchestra made up of
 members in good standing of the Musicians Equity Union as called for
 in their union contract even though they will not be asked to play a
 note...),
 
 TEN melanin-deprived testosterone-poisoned scions of the patriarchal
 ruling class system leaping,
 
 NINE persons engaged in rhythmic self-expression,
 
 EIGHT economically disadvantaged female persons stealing milk-products
 from enslaved Bovine-Americans,
 
 SEVEN endangered swans swimming on federally protected wetlands,
 
 SIX enslaved fowl-Americans producing stolen nonhuman animal products,
 
 FIVE golden symbols of culturally sanctioned enforced domestic
 incarceration,
 
 (NOTE: after a member of the Animal Liberation Front
 threatened to throw red paint at my computer, the calling birds,
 French hens and partridge have been reintroduced to their native
 habitat. To avoid further animal-American enslavement, the remaining gift
 package has been revised.)
 
 FOUR hours of recorded whale songs,
 
 THREE deconstructionist poets,
 
 TWO Sierra Club calendars printed on recycled processed tree carcasses,
 
 and a Spotted Owl activist chained to an old-growth pear tree.
 
==========================================================

	Recently I went to guitar center and the salesman totally talked me into
buying Roland's new DJ-70mkii, a performance sampler.  You can load while
play (all 30 some odd keys at once/seperate), it does on the fly
timestretching, and it hooks up to a hard or ZIP drive.  Sweet ass machine,
so I ordered one, then went home and looked at my computer.

	Does the same damn thing.

	The only difference is that it's not a keyboard so I am not playing it
"live" per say. 

	But neither is the Roland DJ-70mkii, it's a computer disguised as a
keyboard!!!  The only reason to buy it is so you can fool people when your
up on stage "performing".

	So be careful, my friends, the only equipment you will need to make
electronic music is a computer (that's all ANY synth/sampler/module is). 
We just have to wait a bit for the software to get there.

MIME-Version: 1.0
To: elf <elf@sirius.com>
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org, Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Re: [tech] Re: Modern state of djing
References: <199712200056.QAA18291@mail1.sirius.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

elf wrote:

> 
>         So be careful, my friends, the only equipment you will need to make
> electronic music is a computer (that's all ANY synth/sampler/module is).
> We just have to wait a bit for the software to get there.

The beauty of samplers is that they are *dedicated* to sampling.  Sure,
a computer will do the same thing, but at the same time, would you
rather carry a computer, mouse, keyboard, and monitor to a gig or a two
space rack mounted sampler?  The other draw back is that a computer
tends to crash because of all it's extraneous programs in the operating
system, while samplers have a streamlined operating system that make it
much less prone to crash.  True, one day there will be software that
rivals that of the best samplers so that you could play a whole show
from a laptop, but right now nothing beats samplers such as the DJ-70
mkII for live performance.

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Dec 20 03:19:01 1997
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 1196 invoked by uid 6000); 20 Dec 1997 03:19:01 -0000
Received: (qmail 1185 invoked from network); 20 Dec 1997 03:18:59 -0000
Received: from mole.slip.net (HELO mole) (207.171.193.16)
  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 20 Dec 1997 03:18:59 -0000
Received: from sf-pm4-19-179.dialup.slip.net [207.171.197.179] 
	by mole with smtp (Exim 1.73 #2)
	id 0xjFRF-0004YN-00; Fri, 19 Dec 1997 19:18:55 -0800
X-Sender: hatfyr@pop.slip.net
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.1.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Here Are The Facts You Requested <hatfyr@slip.net>
Subject: Tape Review-Uncle Noah: Sprung (Spring '97)
Message-Id: <E0xjFRF-0004YN-00@mole>
Date: Fri, 19 Dec 1997 19:18:55 -0800
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

DJ: Uncle Noah
Mixtape: Sprung (Spring '97), Abduction Productions, 1997
Contact: unclenoa@netcom.com

Last Spring, Uncle Noah flew up from Southern California to play at one of
the SF undergrounds...(was it SuperLove?...one of those parties at the
Cyborganic venue).  

Anyway, toward the end of his set I looked up to check out Uncle Noah, and
the boy was nowhere to be seen.  Did he duck down to snatch the next record?
Or maybe Carlos was filling in for him for a song or two?  Nah. The unmanned
turntables were still kicking out beats,  and Uncle Noah was bouncing around
the dancefloor, tossing out free copies of "Sprung"  to the broke masses.
I've been wanting to do a review of it ever since, but I'm only just getting
around to it now.

The tape opens up with a sample lifted from KDBS Radio (Univ. Cal)-a warning
about listener discretion.  The tape grabbed my heart right away, because
I'm a big fan of Dj's who dig for samples.   But the listener discretion is
important too,   because Uncle Noah proceeds to kick the shit out of you.
He leaps out of the right-hand corner like a kickboxer on crack, punching
and kicking out a barrage of breakbeats.

I know this description makes it sound a little aggro--and it doesn't help
that breakbeat has a reputation for attracting the tuffguys and the
scowlers.  My own experience with breakbeat is that it is the best music for
the full-body workout--it's the only music that gives my arms and legs an
equal test.
And anyone who says that breakbeat ain't cute, wait til you hear
"1-2-3-4-5-6-7-8"  by DJ Icey.  Perhaps the cutest song I've heard from the
electronic music category.

But "Sprung", though it offers kickage of the ass, dominates the land of
happiness.   There are hints of the postmodern drifting through the
programming. Noahs breakbeats sometimes take the chance to describe our
'70's childhoods...a remix of a 70's TV theme (I wish I could pinpoint
it--Charlies Angels?  Columbo?).  A Charlie Brown sample of a kid trying to
solve a math problem (complete with the Teacher speaking  the "Wa-Wah"
tongue),  hints at the
brainwracking  mathematics of mixing beats.  Also keep your ear open for the
familiar Michael Jackson "I'mma-say I'mma sah a mah-coosah" sample.  

The tape ends with a brilliantly placed sample (perfectly synched with the
end of the tape) from that burned out duo, Cheech & Chong, closing out their
radio show.  

I'm particularly interested in what's happening here, at the end of the
tape, because this is something that I experimented with on my last tape.
The end of the tape (Cheech and Chong Radio sample)  leads right back to the
beginning of the tape (the Cal University radio sample).   By referring back
to the very beginning,  there's a sort of continuity.  Or at the very least,
a closure that hasn't forgotten  where the mixtape began.

Mixing skills: fine.  absolutely no problems to my ear(and breakbeat is the
hardest!)
Programming:  Wonderful.  Creative.  Intriguing.

And the final test--
As a soundtrack for knockin boots:  Hard, strong rhythm. Testosterone beats
with a soft edge in theme and lyrical content.

Uncle Noah is a SoCal Boy, but he's on SFRaves and it's not unusual to see
him in the Bay Area.  Keep 'em coming, Noah!

b))merang

Want your mixtape reviewed? Send me a tape.  I'll review it. 
Disclaimer:  I do these reviews as a listening and a writing exercise. My
own beatmatching skills are ridiculous.  But I have a pretty good ear, as
long as my fidgeting fingers don't get in the way.  I represent Joe Raver,
not The Collective Family of Flawless DJs.  This is not to say that I won't
review flawless DJs.  But all we can do is our best, so send me yours!

Send your tape (and a letter about yourself and your vision of your music-)  to:

boomerang
elevator pop gallery
3033 yolo ave
el cerrito, ca, 94530

At 11:41 AM -0800 12/18/97, Leslie Ayres wrote:
(snip)
>sorry, you're barking up the wrong tree here... i think that my consistent
>presence as a supportive figure in the rave community, as well as my
>willingness to defend raving on national television, trying to speak up as
>a positive voice for young people and the rave community in general in the
>face of media disinformation, speak for who i am and what i am about...
>calling my reasoning "fascism, censorship and thought control" is
>laughable.
(snip)

So, do you really think that simply because you support the majority of the
community that it gives you permission to request just a "little"
censorship of the minority with whom you happen to disagree?

Come on...  that's like saying you're just a "little" pregnant.  It doesn't
really work like that.

Either you are... or you're not.
And I think you are.
Megan

	Well, we end up at Nikita Fri PM and I'm all psyched cuz DAN is
spinning and I was with some really kewl peeps and we're all jolly
with holiday chEEr and such.
	The vibe was spotty at first, then evened out as the night went on, but
overall, I wasn't really too impressed with Dan's (or simon's) set.  I mean, 
everyone looked like they were having a blast and I had hella fun, but the 
tunes were often just too "disco-ey" and the set was pretty flat as far as 
energy went.  Perhaps I'm just into harder stuff lately, but his music just
didn't take me where I wanted to go, if ya know what I mean
None of those earth-shattering "OHMIGODthisisincredible" kind of tunes...
maybe he's just better when he spins at raves?   
	Well, I still had a kewl time (hi Hai!!) and met some incredibly awesome and
wacky peeps (Hi Andy , Hi Junior!), and I finally got to meet Leslie!!  =))
Was anyone else there?  Similar opinions ?

Have a Merry Holiday break everyone!

luv n jumbo-size hugs,
natasha

Hell folks,

As some of you may have figured out, I ended up being forced into going 
to the edge last night as I was with some 18+ friends who insisted on 
going to a club, (rather then a party, or doing anything else.) SOooo, I 
decided to go because i hadn't seen them in a long time, and 
thought...well...I'll keep an open mind about the Edge...maybe it won't 
be that bad, maybe everyone was just exagerating about how bad of a club 
it was........

that is the WWWRRROOONNNGGGG ANSWER!

Let me tell you a little something about my experience last night. First 
of all...the vibe there SUCKED...were talking HARDCORE SUCKAGE! It was 
shallow...It was shallower then the deep end of one of those plastic 
KIDDIE POOLS...the music was LIGHTCORE...NON-ENERGETIC house, and the 
crowd was a ton of drunken "freakers" all try to do the butt with all my 
friends....I was pissed off. The vibe in the main room was soooo bad 
that I was forced to dance to eighties music all night! Which wouldn't 
have bothered me if it weren't for all the SLUTS in the 80's room giving 
me nasty looks, and for those of you who jest by saying something along 
the lines of "you should have gone for that!"...let me tell you, I would 
rather be strapped to a chair and forced to watch the home shopping 
channel for the rest of my life.

Anywayz, I know I haven't said any real constructive critisism about the 
place, but truely it's a waste of my breath...everyone says the place is 
horrible...so I'll throw my ballot in with the rest...I VOTE SUCKS, if 
you're planning on going...listen to the masses, they know what there 
talking about...don't go...save yourself a night of frustration.

-Matt-

ah the edge, such fond memories of time past.  i don't go there often
anymore but know a couple of top guns (one is a cofounder) there
through a good friend.  they are cool to me.

but other than those two people, i couldn't say much about the edge
other than that it had served my purpose as a young lad while going to
school.  now my memories of the edge is dim except for a couple of
events.  

one time one of the guys mentioned above gave me a couple of vip
cards, two gals saw the process, they came right over and tried to
charm me for my the cards.  one worker came along and handed a couple
of free cd's to the gals, and to me, not even a look.  hey don't i
look pretty enough.  well seemed like you gals have been spoiled
enough already so i'll keep my vip cards, which i ended up never use. 
next week at a rave some dj was throwing out mix tapes and i waved at
him.  zzzzoooip, a mix tape came my way.  now how cool was that.  and
i didn't even have my makeup on that night.

and then there were my beers.  i seem to spill and waste them on my
own enough times already but the securities had to throw two of my
bottles 1/3 full away for me when i wasn't looking, in just one night.
 they thought i was done with them.  talked to the bartender and she
gave me the bad vibe.  no more tips tonight.  two weeks ago i was at
static and the bartender inadvertently threw away my bottle 1/2 full
and there was one i spilled on my own (see), he came right back with a
couple of fresh ones, for free.  guess where i made good use of the
tips that i had saved up from the edge?  now how cool was that.

merry goofy christmas everybody.. 

hugs,
hai

> 	So be careful, my friends, the only equipment you will need to make
> electronic music is a computer (that's all ANY synth/sampler/module
is). 
> We just have to wait a bit for the software to get there.

it's here, check out rebirth - like i was saying, 2 303's, an 808 and
a 909 in one software package...

you can also get soundcards for your computer, and not just a dinky
ol' soundblaster.  i've got a couple of digidesign soundboards in my
mac, one's a high end digital recorder/editor, the other a 32-voice
sampler with loadsa cheap ram on it.  or you can get boards like
roland's sound canvas, and i think also korg and yamaha and a few
others make synthesisers you can plug right into a slot on your
computer.

the only thing i'd want outboard would be a phat analog synth,
preferably midi-able.  that technology is bulky by nature, too bulky
to fit in your computer...

-messiah

	by dilbert.ucdavis.edu (8.8.8/UCD3.11.23) with SMTP id OAA17654
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Sun, 21 Dec 1997 14:16:19 -0800 (PST)
Date: Sun, 21 Dec 1997 14:16:19 -0800 (PST)
From: Satkriya Khalsa <satkhalsa@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: satkriya@dilbert.ucdavis.edu
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: revival review, long and sappy
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.971221134427.16351A-100000@dilbert.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Well, I made the choice, with no money last night me and my friends
decided to head to revival and hope for the best.
Though the process of getting there was a trip in and of itself when we
got there (very early, we were desperate for music) there were only 10 or
so people.  The location was great, reminded me of the Minna location from
happy kids (June).  There was plenty of room and rooms with cool
decorations and a smallish but sweet sound system.

The music was great from right off.  And I started to get excited.
However, by 12, or 1230 my hopes for the party started to waver
dramatically.  There was maybe 65-90 people if that and everyone was kind
of shocked at the lack of energy.  But we all tried, really hard to create
that vibe we have all become addicted to.

The saving grace, and the most important thing is that the dj's were
beautiful.  There were definately waves to the party, with Joey's set
starting them off.  His was definatley rocking, and his scratching
skills killed me!  Pistachio's set(s) kicked ass.  And you could see that
despite the lack of people the dj's loved thier music and loved to spin,
and it showed.  If there was any lack of enthusiasm on thier part it
certianly (SP) didn't translate over the tables.

I have never been to a party that desolate, but though I noticed, of
course, and missed the people incredibly, every one there was trying thier
hardest.  The people that I saw on the dance floor just knew good music
when they heard it and enjoyed the experience of seeing them spin.  During
the night a thought occured to me, this(revival) is what it could have
been like when raving first started to appear, a couple of people who
heard some damn good music and just had to dance, it wasn't a given that
there would be lots of parties every weekend they were before the
standard, set the standard and gave us the scene we have today, and for
every successful rave there is thier are plenty that don't such is life.

Though I will always have mixed feelings about that party, it has helped
me appreciate the vibe alot more, taught me what I really want in a party
and music, and I will think of it with a sm:)e!



See you at harmony!

sat kriya

Hmmm..
 The Edge.

That's where I pretty much grew up..
 Next time your their. Goto Brian, the bartender up top. He really
appreciates tips. He always puts any extra beers I get for friends, on the
house.
 The place IS jam packed full of snobs.. But the management is alright.
 I remember one night there when it was way to packed. I was walking
through the place and this lady gently pushes me and says, "hey! what the
f$#k is your problem dumb ass? Why don't you watch the f@#k where your
going" I decide to stop, turn around and say, "hey! what boat did you just
come off biotch? This is a CLUB, people tend to bump into one another" Then
while I am walking off, her tall dark and retarded boyfriend comes up
behind me, politely taps me on the shoulder to say, "you know..I don't like
the fact you call me girl friend a bitch" I look back at him and realize,
going to the restroom is more importiant then knocking sence in to him. He
taps me on the shoulder again, but before he could say anything security
comes over and asks me if there is a problem. I didn't even have time to
say "no problem" before bimbo's boy friend butts in and trys to speak.
 Security goes, "hey! I was asking Jeff, not you" and security then pulls
them both outside to talk. Never saw them again.


 Hmmm.. Probably a year later, at probably my third or fourth ravE. I am
walking around alone in search of whatevah, at a WAY to crouded ravE inside
the Oak50 building. Just walking along with minimal bodily contact
involved. This guy yells out at me. "Hey! What does this fudcing look like?
A fncking walk way??" So I stop, look at him and say, "fudc yea!! WooHoo!
This whole ravE looks like the yellow frickin brick road to me brother! I
go where I please..."
 I see the same Mr Attitude guy about fifty ravEs later.. I walk past him
inside the Home Base hallway, he is talking to two teenage girls. Once I
pass by him he says, "yea that's right, you best not turn around asshole."
So I turn around, laugh at him, and keep walking.. I then hear him saying
something like, "aw man! I told you! err!"

 I liked that guy. He was comedy.
 Jeff

Hey folx, I just came to inform all the HH fans that there is a party in

plenty stuff for the junglists too:

_SubSonic Underground's One Year Anniversary_
December 26th, 1997
(916) 484-4040
$10 before midnight

Featuring some talented out-of-towners:
-Golgo 13 (LA)--jungle
-Phunckateck (Noel & UFO) on 4 turn-tables (SF)--mo jungle
-Simon Apex (UK) & The Mind Controller (LA) on 4 tables--happy hardcore!!!

certain lil joint which shall remain unnamed, but I will say that if it is,
I _hate_ this location.  It's an OK club but a very poor space for
raves/parties.  Plus it will be cold as hell in the outside "room."  If it
does end up being there, I think that will be a drawback, but I firmly
believe the music will make up for that (it has before).

come out and support diversity en la musica here, since Sac parties are
usually strictly house.  If you come, look for the chica negra w/ the short
short hair & the sfraves laminate and say hello.

Happy Holidays!  Cheers to all of us who survived finals!

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199712221044.CAA28270@well.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Obligatory 1997 Review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

The traditional, obligatory, opinionated, arbitrary end-of-the-year
review . . .

While 1997 certainly wasn't the worst of years for dance music, it didn't
light any fires for me.  Maybe it would have been more exciting if the
dire predictions many (including me) made about the "electronica" boom had
actually come to pass.  Electronica now seems to be about every kind of
electronic pop music *except* traditional house, techno, bass and jungle,
at least in the eyes of the Music Industry and the millions of ears they
control.  Basically, electronica has been defined as the kind of music that
people sit down and listen to, or else consume as an audience.

I had a moment of enlightenment this year at a show at the venerable old
Kaiser Auditorium in Oakland.  For starters, The Orb performed a great
warmup set that was mostly lost on a crowd who had no conception of who these
upstarts were.  In between acts, we had the spectacle of a DJ playing an
almost unrecognizable "Fools Gold" amped into a muddy, rumbling roar, later
to be joined by a guitarist wearing shiny metallic pants and playing pointless
solo lines along with the vinyl.  Finally, during the main act, the crowd
rushed the stage just like in a regular rock concert when the MTV rotation
hit comes up.  Except this time it was when the Chems did "Setting Sun."
This was my moment of Zen-electronica realization.  We have entered into a
new era of unknown dimensions.


House.  Production values have improved enormously, but at the cost of
emotional impact.  It also must be admitted that after nearly 15 years,
it's hard to find new melodic or instrumental ideas, though it never
fails to amaze me how many new ones do get on record.  But house is now
sectored into stand-pat categories fitting the economic configuration of
the club world.  Thus, we hear of "peak hour tracks" and "6 am tracks"
and tracks designed for particular types of clubs.  What's next - "works
well with the Nike crowd, but a bit dodgy with the Adidas"?  House seems
to be considered a purely commercial musical style now, and that's a shame.

Techno.  The widest speciation of styles seems to have occurred here,
and the distance between them only gets greater.  Trance and hardcore
go on and on, but for the life of me I haven't heard new ideas there
for years.  On the more abstract side, Detroit is already starting to
move on and it's been two years since the last Basic Channel record,
but the new BC and Jeff Mills soundalike mixes keep showing up every
single week.  On the plus side, the most ferment of all is occurring
under the surface, whether it's "tech house" or some of the other
noteworthy experiments out there.  Most interestingly, a new group of
live techno performers is starting to emerge.

Jungle.  A year of splintering, with numerous subgenres emerging and
the essential cross-fertilization of styles disappearing almost entirely.
I suppose they call this progress.  On the other hand, the lack of
good new sonic ideas in a genre highly dependent on rapid innovation
is starting to show.

Speed Garage.  This is what happens when a music industry desperate for
something to hype blows up a nice little scene with a bit of gumption
but no particular grand new idea.  It was predictable that garage vocals
and drum&bass rhythm sections would meet, but it took concerted pushing
by the PR apparatus to turn it into a national frenzy, as it sort of
is in the UK.

The Scene.  The clubbing and "rave" scenes are like they were, except
moreso.  More fashion-conscious, more drug-oriented, more commercial,
more separate from each other -- more everything except music-aware.
However, there is a real underground still out there in the making, though
it has the added burden of fending off the accumulated weight of 15 years
of behavioral patterns.


The disappointing feeling of 1997 is that it was really the first year
in a long time where it felt like we were marking time instead of making
history.  The records are better produced and the covers have more gloss
than ever before, there are videos galore and some notice in the trade and
general circulation press, but no real excitement.

The good news is that there is a whole new generation of record makers
out there who are stalled behind the effort to commercialize yesterday
and today's leading lights.  And the Internet may yet prove to be the
next field for the evolution of electronic dance music in ways that are
only dimly perceived now.

So don't pay too much attention to the jaded old bystanders like yrs
truly.  As much as we like to recall how it was back in the day, we keep
moving forward because it's the only direction we know.


Stuff I Liked In 1997


First Hour
----------

BLAKDOCTOR - I Believe So Strong (Moonshine)
  All Doc Martin needed was the right production partner: Mark Blakkat Bell

D'LAREG - Better Way/Don't Wanna Come Down (Simply Soul)
  Another of the many hidden gems of Detroit house

JAN DRIVER - Arp Impression (Solid State of House)
  Read the Funky Manual

DUBTRIBE SOUND SYSTEM - We Used to Dance (Imperial Dub)
  My social calendar circa 1992

GLENN UNDERGROUND - 70's Trip (Cajual)
  I've been caning this for *months* and it never gets stale

MARSHALL JEFFERSON - Move Your Body, Adonis remixes (Trax)
  Takes measure of the classic and honors it completely with a modern sound

OCTAVE ONE - The Living Key (430 West)
  Fluid, deep, essential

DJ RASOUL - Themes for a Rainy Day (Subwoofer)
  Gee's tracks have always been good, these are great

SPANK SPANK - Your Inspiration (Nite Grooves)
  The real Pierre+Spanky deal

SUPERNATURE - Comin On (Shindig)
  Big build up, big crescendo, delivers like an anthem should


Second Hour
-----------

ASTRAL MATRIX - 6 (OOBE)
  AndyJ's Detroit-influenced excursion really works

CHIBA - Time Flies (Lightning)
  Sunscreem builds a stunner from their own sample

DJ DEEON - Boody Mover (Dance Mania)
  What track better summarizes driving around on Friday night?

DENEUVE - Never Give Up (Telepathic)
  People think Fred Gianelli is an "up and comer" -- hello, pay attention!

DETROIT ELECTRO ORCHESTRA - 1977 EP (Hydraulic)
  Bass still in ya face, and don't ya forget it

JAYDEE - You Got It (Danza)
  Yeah, it's a remix of you-know-what, and you know what? it kicks hard

KORSAKOV - Deep in Space (Muller)
  Goes well beyond the cliches of modern dub

THE MARTIAN - Red Planet 8 (Red Planet)
  A message that needs no words

MCP 21 - Leaving Town (Analog)
  Proves that you can still do effective things with an A-line

TEKNOTIKA - When the Planets Align (Eye Q)
  Words fail me, as usual, when Gary Martin is on his game


The above reflect my preferences as a *dance* DJ, and are not intended
to slight the other excellent releases that came out in 1997.  In particular,
there were a slew of really good albums, including Larry Heard, Kenny Larkin,
John Beltran, Kenny Dixon Jnr, Stacey Pullen, Dan Curtin, Mark Farina's
remix CD of Dubtribe, and on and on.  Maybe it says something that so
many talented musicians and producers are focusing more on album projects
than trying to break dance singles in an overcrowded, fad-driven series of
pigeonholed markets.


Fred Heutte
phred@well.sf.ca.us

21 December 1997

I originally wasn't going to hop on the band wagon with this, but it 
being 2:30am I decided what the hell!

Name= Ivan

What is your Age= 21

Birthday= 9/1/76

What is your Sign= Virgo 

Are you Married= Nope

Have Kids= Thankfully no

Are you Single= Yes, just got out of one of those "it was too long 
relationships" and want to stay single for a while!

Do you Dj= Um, Nope

What is your most listened to Style of Music? = It changes week to week, 
seems to cycle from Jungle to Trance to Classical to a little House to 
anything that seems to groove at the time, hey and if I can find 'em 
those CDs that have the music from cool video games, in other words 
anything and everything that touches my soul.

Musician / Artist= Well I have been creative at times, I think everyone 
is an artist in there own way, life would be so boring w/o the simple 
little works of art(visual, auditory, or language, etc) from somebody 
you least expected it from.

Hobbies= dodging trucks that are in front of me at 70-80 MPH on 101(long 
story), teaching myself and others new things about computers 
(languages, programs, I either take a class or teach myself and then try 
to teach others who want to learn) , reading, doing silly things(try it, 
just do something absolutely silly, it's good for bringing a smile to 
your face), anything that makes me smile and have those funny goose 
bumps run up my back, Learning about massage(I am way out of practice 
though), touch if done with care and good intentions has a wonderful 
healing effect!

Favorite Sexual Position=Undecided, um, it's also NYOB!

Ideal Party Line up= Dan, my buddy Marco (w/o allergies[anybody who 
knows Marco/Vivid knows what I'm talking about]), Mars, and this cool 
trip hop DJ that spun at the harmony 3 year who I can't remember the 
name of.

Favorite Food= A pesto and artichoke heart pizza (I have only had this 
made perfectly once, and I don't remember who it was that made it)

Favorite DJ= No fave at this time, if you feel you have reached this 
recording in error, please check the number, and try again later.

Do you represent the Scene Negatively or Positively?= Positively when 
possible

How?= Depends on my frame of mind, I try to do my best to bring a 
positive mood to those around me. Sometimes when I take breaks from the 
scene I don't represent it at all.

Do you go to parties to hear the music or hook up with the opposite sex? 
= been there, done that, bought the t-shirt! I go to hear good grooves, 
in a social environment.

sent with hopes of happy holidays,
-idw
"have a good vibe day!"

Hi guys.

Well, after moving for over 16 hours I decided to head out to the
gathering at 1:00am... :) I got there with my buddy Jeff at about 1:30am
and proceded to the HOUSE room. Lets see.... then I went to the chill room
for a bit and ran into Rodrigo and his special lady. Chilled with them for
a bit discussing all the lovely things that we must share with one another
while melting in the chill room. ;) It was nice to chat with this
wonderful cupple and absorb their good vibes. 

The I started to journy around the spot and ran into various other
earthlings and Sfravers (we're earthlings too... I think.. :) ) such as
Baby Huey (grooving to Honey-B), Mr. 2 (whatup brutha?), FOOLISH FISH
(finally get to meet you.... ), ummm.... that's about all that I can
remember this fine monday morning.... (ssoooorrry)

It was a beautiful party with a fantastic vibe and setup. I'm so glad they
made the space seem smaller and more intimate by making corridors...
instead of leaving that BIG, WIDE, unused space open for people having bad
trips to feel even less happy... Martin thought of those kids and went the
distance to avoid past bad experiences by other promoters using this spot.
(From the people I've talked to, most people used to hate this spot).

Overall the music was dynamo.... Dan was spinning house.... then came
Tony... and then I caught the end of Mark Farina....    what a line up.
Thanks be to the power that placed me in this awesome party area.....
called the Bay Area.

Have a good week.... 

another deep space transmission from... ..  .

(byroni)
TheSPACEcowboy

Article below is from the L.A. Times Sunday Calendar
Sunday, December 21, 1997
===========================================

POP'S NEXT BIG THING

What in the World Happened to Techno?
1997 was supposed to be the year that electronic dance music saved
the foundering record industry. It didn't turn out that way. But the
genre's pulse is still beating.

By ROBERT HILBURN


    The fortunes of techno music rose and fell as sharply as the
stock market during much of 1997: sky-high early in the
year, when the music was widely tabbed as the Next Big Thing, to a
virtual fire sale these days, when you can find only two pure techno
collections on the list of the year's 200 best-selling albums.
    It's a rise and fall that tells us as much about the workings of the

record industry--and the difficulty of predicting public response--as
it does about the commercial potential of techno itself.
    At the start of the year, there wasn't any reason to think of
techno as a major sales force--until the industry's search for
something to jump-start sluggish sales led, unexpectedly, to techno's
door.
    Expectations quickly soared after MTV, looking to boost its
own sagging ratings, announced that it was going to move away
from its reliance on alternative rock and rap videos because viewer
surveys showed fans were tiring of the styles. Those sounds, along
with country music, have been the backbone of the industry in the
'90s, generating almost $8.5 billion in sales in 1996 alone.
    Though MTV said it was also going to add more pop videos to
its programming, the industry zeroed in on the fact that the cable
channel introduced "Amp," a weekly video show devoted to
techno--or electronica, as the dance music is also called--to its
lineup.
    Even though "Amp" was placed in the ungodly 2 a.m. Saturday
time slot, the industry picked up on techno. The idea of more pop
videos on MTV--from the novelty of the Spice Girls to the polite
musings of Jewel--seemed too mainstream and old- fashioned for
an industry that likes to think of itself as cutting-edge.
    Besides, techno had an energy and imagination, a style far more
sophisticated and diverse than old-fashioned disco. And the music
had become the dominant sound on the British club scene, where a
group of new acts was bringing personality to what had long been a
faceless genre. Stars such as Prodigy, the Chemical Brothers and
Goldie were profiled alongside traditional rock groups in the British
pop papers. Some, notably Prodigy, even brought a sense of song
structure to the music, thanks to such tunes as "Firestarter," a hit
around the world.
    Aware of all this, record execs in the U.S. started having
daydreams of MTV's new "Amp" doing for techno what "Yo! MTV
Raps" had done earlier for rap: open the sound to the mainstream
rock audience.
    By spring, however, in a Calendar report about the potential of
techno, executives were having serious second thoughts about the
millions they were pouring into signing and promoting techno acts
here and in England.
    Despite the sometimes seductive lure of techno, there was an
anonymity in the whiplash beats and silky, ambient sounds that
made it a hard sell on record. Songs are the key to building careers,
executives reminded themselves, and most techno doesn't have
songs in the traditional pop sense.
    Still, the industry took notice in April when the Chemical
Brothers' "Dig Your Own Hole" became the first album from the
hard-core English dance field to enter the U.S. pop charts in the
Top 20. The album, which registered at No. 14, sold 48,000
copies in that first week, and it went on to be certified gold
(500,000 sales).
    But the future of the Chemical Brothers appears limited. On
stage, the group was unable to overcome the anonymous sound of
the music. The show was about as exciting as a crew of sidewalk
construction workers.
    That shifted attention to Prodigy, which made history in July by
entering the U.S. charts at No. 1, selling 201,000 copies of its "The
Fat of the Land" album, according to SoundScan. The album has
gone on to sell more than 1.5 million, making it one of the year's
Top 30 sellers.
    Unlike the Chemical Brothers, Prodigy proved to be a knockout
live--but in ways that didn't necessarily augur well for the
commercial future of techno.
    Prodigy is as much a rock band--in terms of attitude and
approach--as it is a techno band. You see a lot of the Sex Pistols'
Johnny Rotten in the wardrobe and sneer of frontman Keith Flint,
and you hear a lot of the independence and rebellion of the Who
and other classic rock groups in such songs as "Firestarter."
    The success of Prodigy ultimately reinforced the idea that
techno's future in the commercial mainstream is as an influence, not
as a dominant style.
    In that way, techno's place in pop history may be similar to the
role of punk. Despite such great groups as the Sex Pistols and the
Clash in the '70s and early '80s, punk was never a major, consistent
seller around the world. But punk's youthful fervor and
do-it-yourself spirit inspired virtually every rock band of note over
the last two decades, from U2 and R.E.M. to Nirvana and Pearl
Jam.
    Prodigy and the Chemical Brothers didn't start a stampede to
techno. Garth Brooks' "Sevens" album probably sold more in three
weeks in the U.S. (2 million copies) than all the techno albums
released here during 1997 combined, except for those two groups.
    And MTV's "Amp" remains in its 2 a.m. Saturday slot.
    An incident that gives evidence of the low standing of techno's
stock these days came when Goldie opened for Jane's Addiction at
the Universal Amphitheatre earlier this month. It was the perfect
setting for this star of the British dance scene to showcase his sound
before a young, tastemaker audience.
    After two numbers, the energy level was so low in the room that
Goldie moved to the edge of the stage and tried to peer out into the
darkness. "Los Angeles, are you out there?" he finally asked.
The truth was Los Angeles--or at least 90% of the 6,000 fans
who came to see Jane's Addiction--wasn't out there. They were
either out in the lobby or sightseeing along CityWalk. They hadn't
even bothered to see Goldie. And many of those who were in their
seats at the start of the show left after a couple of numbers.
    So what are we to make of techno?
    Ironically, the commercial fizzle this year may be the best thing
that could have happened to it. If the Chemical Brothers and
Prodigy tours had prompted fans to rush to the stores in search of
other techno albums, record companies would have started signing
acts with even greater gusto. This would have brought all sorts of
opportunists into the music, contributing to recycled and repetitive
sounds.
    But the fact that techno didn't explode commercially means that
only artists with a genuine love of the music will likely gravitate
toward it. The opportunists will form more ska bands--the most
successful but least interesting trend of the year.
    The one bright spot in all the success of ska and novelty records
this year is that a flock of sing-along hits, including Chumbawamba's
"Tubthumping" and Smash Mouth's "Walking on the Sun," caught
the ear of a preteen crowd, easing fears that today's youngsters
might be so enamored of video games that they would never care
about records. The best sight of the year, one retailer said, was
parents being pulled into stores by grade-schoolers.
    If "Tubthumping" and the rest can get the kids listening to music,
they'll eventually graduate to more substantial fare. And those
sounds seem to be arriving from England, where there has been a
revitalization of British rock, thanks to a new generation of artists.
Oasis' Noel Gallagher, the Verve's Richard Ashcroft, Blur's Damon
Albarn and Radiohead's Thom Yorke, among others, understand
the importance of songwriting and don't shy away from mass
acceptance.
    "The future of pop lies with songwriters," Gallagher said in an
interview this year. "It doesn't matter which style or whether they're
playing guitar, piano or the world's biggest synthesizer. A great song
is a great song."
    In the end, the problem this year wasn't techno, but the
expectations put on it. Think of hard-core techno as a great
resource library. At its best, techno is smart, exciting, even
revolutionary music. There will be collections of it that will
occasionally connect with mainstream audiences the same way
some of the Clash's albums did during the first era of punk. But the
primary audience is likely to remain a subculture.
    Eventually, however, a great young songwriter will likely be
excited by it the same way U2's Bono and Nirvana's Kurt Cobain
were excited by punk. Then, we can start talking about the Next
Big Thing in earnest.
                                              - - -

Robert Hilburn Is The Times' Pop Music Critic


===========================================
Article above is from the L.A. Times Sunday Calendar
Sunday, December 21, 1997

I sent Megan a private note, then realized that her post was to the list,
not just me, so wanted to send an edited version of what i sent her .... we
may be near the "dead horse being beaten" point here, though, so apologies
for more on a mostly closed topic...


>So, do you really think that simply because you support the majority of the
>community that it gives you permission to request just a "little"
>censorship of the minority with whom you happen to disagree?
>
>Come on...  that's like saying you're just a "little" pregnant.  It doesn't
>really work like that.
>
>Either you are... or you're not.
>And I think you are.
>Megan

hi megan,

to me, my post was not censorship  (how could it be? i have no authority to
screen what gets posted on sfraves, i'm just a member with the same rights
and limitations as everyone else)....

my post was, rather, like saying "excuse me, but is this really the place
to say this? have you considered that this is likely to offend many of the
people to whom you sent this message?"

that's about respect to me, and i do think that someone has to speak up
when people cross what seem to be the lines of appropriateness...  i'd say
the same thing in person if i felt someone had crossed bounds and made
others uncomfortable without their permission ...

i'm not requesting censorship, i'm requesting that people remember that
this list has all kinds of people, and we're not all into the same things,
and some things can be predicted to be offensive.  racist, sexist and
explicitly sexual topics among them.  and to me, these things don't belong
on sfraves.

so, whatever it is you think i am (pregnant?), i'm not.  and i don't think
that thinking before you speak, is censorship, i think it's respect ....

i do worry that sometimes, in the desire to protect free speech, we lose
sight of respectful behavior... just because a person has a right to say
something doesn't mean that it's the right thing to say.

leslie

Hi Leslie, the following is my opinion and nothing
more. I mean no dis-respect.


> i'm not requesting censorship, i'm requesting that
>people remember that
> this list has all kinds of people, and we're not
all >into the same things,

Exactly! Honestly Leslie, it is the request of 
censorship. Think about what your saying, you say
that there are "all kinds of people, and we're not
all into the same things!" If you said, "Hey I think
this is
slop and this is why." That would be an opinion. The
second you say "you should" or "you shouldn't" post
this because, its becoming more than an opinion. If
you read your post it leans towards that. 


> and some things can be predicted to be offensive. 
>racist, sexist and
> explicitly sexual topics among them.  and to me, 

The key words here are "to me" so you really shouldn't
suggest, what should or should not be included in posts
just state that this is how you feel. I know this is
just an opinion as well but it sounded a lot like you
were telling us not to post this stuff. A lot of people
thought that the post in question was funny. I
personally don't care. I do care that we have the right
to write whatever the fuck we want. That doesn't mean
I won't get flamed into oblivion. But I live in this
country for that specific right. Freedom of Speech

>these things don't belong
> on sfraves.

Says who? I think if its marked NRR you decide if it
belongs in your mailbox with the tap of a delete
button. Nobody is twisting your arm to read a
particular post. Is it your place to say what belongs
on sfraves and what doesn't? I mean come on now.

 
> so, whatever it is you think i am (pregnant?), i'm
>not.  and i don't think
> that thinking before you speak, is censorship, i
>think it's respect ....

This has nothing to do with respect. This is an open
forum if someone doesn't like what you write, the
intelligent folks on this list will let you know 
promtly 8) If I want to put a joke up I should mark
it correctly, (which wasn't done here I know) and
if you don't like it tell me so. But don't tell me
not to post it.

 
> i do worry that sometimes, in the desire to protect
>free speech, we lose
> sight of respectful behavior... just because a
person >has a right to say
> something doesn't mean that it's the right thing to
say.

The amendments to the Constitution were created for
this purpose. You have to give everyone the right to
state what THEY FEEL is right. Your right, just
because someone has something to say, does not mean
that it's the right thing to do, but what each
person perceives to be right, may not be what you
perceive to right. There are some down right evil
things that people write supporting bigotry, sexism,
and a number of other things. I don't let them in my
life. But its my right to choose whether or not I want
them there and I am damn grateful for that.  


Layne

On Mon, 22 Dec 1997, Leslie Ayres wrote:

> i'm not requesting censorship, i'm requesting that people remember that
> this list has all kinds of people, and we're not all into the same things,
> and some things can be predicted to be offensive.  racist, sexist and
> explicitly sexual topics among them.  and to me, these things don't belong
> on sfraves.

This statement is contradictory. You are requesting that people not post
certain messages on S.F. Raves. You have decided what is and is not 
appropriate to the list and are requesting people not post things
that meet your personal criteria of inappropriate.   

The question I ask myself when I see people questioning the
"appropriateness" of a post is "Who does it hurt?"  Not who does it
*offend*. 

Racist and sexist posts clearly fall under the definition of being
hurtful, or having the ability to be so. However, when I see a post like 
the one in question, I can't think of anyone it might prove *hurtful* to. 
Offensive to some perhaps. 

> i do worry that sometimes, in the desire to protect free speech, we lose
> sight of respectful behavior... just because a person has a right to say
> something doesn't mean that it's the right thing to say.

I worry that in the rush to be non-offensive to everyone that the world
will become a very, very dull place to be.

I think what is really in question here is how do we run this listing and
have a little fun here without pissing someone off?  We can't...that is a
fact of life in any situation.  I learned a long time ago that, in a
professional setting, you don't make jokes about sex, sexism, racism, or
religion.  but this is not work or a professional setting (for most of us)
we are here to feed our desires (techno related of course).  We are all
out to have fun and some of these jokes are fun for the majority of us.
The only thing we can do now is label the subject corectly and stop all
this preaching, I think this horse is sufficiently dead.

Razor

Brian Behlendorf wrote:

> The only real limit is that artists typically don't release multitrack
> versions of their songs,
> and there aren't any DVD-ROM burners yet.

Reason #1 to believe brian could actually make this happen:

Setting:  a small party on a big roof.  It's five am, and our gracious
host is taking his turn on the tables.  He throws in a video about alien
abductions, hosted by Scotty - and two cds, one of which is spoken
word.   This dj matches the cds to the hundreth *and* includes the
soundtrack from the movie.  AND it WORKS - there are three individual
tracks which match the video images and the ghestalt is unbelieveable.

He's just f*cking around.  It's five am, and he has been celebrating
with friends, dancing and trancing to  insect vs. virus, ethan miller,
joe rice and jon santos

<pause for orgasmic response to the caliber of artists>

There's this woman lying on a big pillow, entranced.  She tells the dj
"my g*d, do you realize how many variables you have going?  And you're
not really maxing out, are you?  You're not actually challenged by this,
are you?"

And he says 'well, i didn't really have a lot of time to think about
this, and i'm using a lot of new cds'.

now *that's* multimedia.
*that's* Brian Behlendorf

From: glittergirl@value.net (eeneR)
Subject: Research Study on MDMA
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

There is a study on the long-term effects of Ecstacy on users that I
thought some of you might be interested in.  You will not be administered
any MDMA in this study, but you do get $500 for participating, plus you get
a free trip to Maryland and you will be helping Ecstacy reasearch.  I
thought I'd pass this information along in case anyone is interested.

>
>Thank you for your interest in the study. The study lasts from a Monday
>morning until a Friday afternoon and requires that the participants stay
>at the hospital for the whole five days and four nights. The study is
>conducted at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland and at the
>National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland. The study is ongoing,
>so we have weeks available throughout the year.
>        The point of the study is to investigate the long term effects
>Ecstasy has on brain serotonin neurons. Participants receive $500 in
>compensation and travel expenses for MDMA users are paid by Hopkins.
>        In order to determine eligibility, we need to have possible
>participants go through a phone screening. If you are interested in
>participating please contact me at 410-550-2588 (M-F 9 AM - 5 PM) or send
>me an e-mail with your phone number and when it is best to try to
>contact you. You could also contact Victoria at 301-496-4874 if you can't
>get ahold of me. During the phone interview I can answer any specific
>questions you may have about the study and explain the testing that occurs
>during the week. Also, if you know of anyone else who might be interested
>in the study - please give them my number and e-mail address. Thank you.
>
>                Kelly A. Lowe   klowe@welchlink.welch.jhu.edu

Subject: Re: [604] L.A. Times: What in the World Happened to Techno? (fwd)
X-Mailer: Siren Mail for Macintosh 4.0 a17

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET="US-ASCII"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hey Troy...you posted an article from LA Times that gladdened my heart...

-* snippetty snip *_

~~     Despite the sometimes seductive lure of techno, there was an
~~ anonymity in the whiplash beats and silky, ambient sounds that
~~ made it a hard sell on record. Songs are the key to building careers,
~~ executives reminded themselves, and most techno doesn't have
~~ songs in the traditional pop sense.

Hum... this is interesting...its almost as if "mainstream" America needs that
"Cult of Personality" behind music. Its almost as if the music itself doesn't 
stand alone without some ego up on a stage being a "rock star". People either
want to be worshipped, or to have someone to worship instead of just getting
into the music for its own sake.

~~     Still, the industry took notice in April when the Chemical
~~ Brothers' "Dig Your Own Hole" became the first album from the
~~ hard-core English dance field to enter the U.S. pop charts in the
~~ Top 20. The album, which registered at No. 14, sold 48,000
~~ copies in that first week, and it went on to be certified gold
~~ (500,000 sales).
~~     But the future of the Chemical Brothers appears limited. On
~~ stage, the group was unable to overcome the anonymous sound of
~~ the music. The show was about as exciting as a crew of sidewalk
~~ construction workers.

They all want a show, the razzamattaz.

~~     But the fact that techno didn't explode commercially means that
~~ only artists with a genuine love of the music will likely gravitate
~~ toward it. 

Ahmen to that.

~~     In the end, the problem this year wasn't techno, but the
~~ expectations put on it. Think of hard-core techno as a great
~~ resource library. At its best, techno is smart, exciting, even
~~ revolutionary music. There will be collections of it that will
~~ occasionally connect with mainstream audiences the same way
~~ some of the Clash's albums did during the first era of punk. But the
~~ primary audience is likely to remain a subculture.

Yay!

~~     Eventually, however, a great young songwriter will likely be
~~ excited by it the same way U2's Bono and Nirvana's Kurt Cobain
~~ were excited by punk. Then, we can start talking about the Next
~~ Big Thing in earnest.

In my opinion the Cult of Personality is a BIG (excuse the french) WANK. I"m
glad that we are moving away from it. It should be all about the music.

L & L, Meri

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Mon, 22 Dec 1997 20:17:24 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: "John S. Lee" <jsl@twenty-hz.com>
Subject: VSF: Case closed.
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

This saga ended around 11 am today.

Anyway all the parties got together, and my case and other cases, were
brought to VSF for discussion.  My allegations were supposedly brought
before the manager by P (not the owner) of VSF (I thought he was going to
have a meeting with the  owner, but I guess I was mistaken).  The manager
indicated that it was the bar that had me ejected.  Funny, the only
bartender who was waiting on me was off his face.  Anyway that's their
story.  No more drinkie, no more dancing, time to go.  I still cannot
reconcile this with what the security told me , the stories didn't jibe.
Anyway there is no proof of any overt action, and even if there were it was
it has probalby been handled now.  Or so I am told.  All of this was told
to me so I guess that's the conclusion of the parties, not me, the other
parties.  Still a vague story.  I could put some convoluted pice together
and that would be as plausible as anything else, since no story so far has
been corroborated.

So I'll accept it , after all what else can I do: :)
-I wrote the owner a letter
-I did research into violations

And there we're none, no violations.  That's that, and although I disagree
with it, I'll accept it.

I do take some small satifaction at being told the following:
-Some security was "no longer needed" and let go from VSF (I guess the
stories of their ever agressive behaviour may have gotten the best of them).
-VSF security will be more cool in the future.

Now all of this I cannot corroborate, since I wasn't there.  I guess the
proof will be in the pudding, by other people's positive experiences, or
whenever I decide to go back to VSF again.  That, I assure you, will not
happen anytime in the foreseeable future.

Well this took alot of time, and I'm looking forward to putting this thing
behind me.  It was fun, and I learned quite a bit, about how things work
especially the strong business dynamic in all equations.

Anyway P invited me back to his club and closed this drama out.

Peace,
Happy New Year,
Happy Hanukka,
Merry XMas,
John


"The first casualty of war is truth." - Rudyard Kipling

Beautiful People.  I'll be wearing probably, odd for a Rave (I guess,

Greetings Sub-Culturians  (and proud of it!)

At 11:46 22/12/97 -0800, Troy Sheets wrote:
>Article from the L.A. Times Sunday Calendar, Sun, Dec 21, 1997
>What in the World Happened to Techno?

It failed to meet the flash-gimick factor required for success in the comemrcial "McDonalds Music" scene, and so returned to the underground where it can flourish and grow steadily & healthily, rather than being subjected to a forced steroid injection by the music "executives", only to die a sad death a few years later when the next "big thing" hits..

>had become the dominant sound on the British club scene, where a
>group of new acts was bringing personality to what had long been a
>faceless genre. Stars such as Prodigy, the Chemical Brothers and
>Goldie were profiled alongside traditional rock groups 

"Personality".. Hah !  Personality is for the average man in the street who listens to his music with two wooden ears and is too musically deaf to hear personailty in the _music_.  They need an "image" wrapped around it.  So that it's not about the music as such, but about the person who wrote it, and their marketability and fashion.   Keep the superstar phenomenon to yourself please.

Techno music is about the people on the _Dance floor_, NOT about the people on the stage..  It is for YOU to enjoy yourself and dance YOUR dance to.  Not for you to blindly worship some superstar prancing about on show..

>anonymity in the whiplash beats and silky, ambient sounds that
>made it a hard sell on record. Songs are the key to building careers,
>executives reminded themselves, and most techno doesn't have
>songs in the traditional pop sense.

Exactly.. which is the good thing about it.  "Building Careers" can be translated into "Marketing for Money", which has nothing to do with MUSIC.  The mainstream music "Industry" is about _making money_.  Which has nothing to do with producing good music.

>    Prodigy is as much a rock band--in terms of attitude and
>approach--as it is a techno band. You see a lot of the Sex Pistols'
>Johnny Rotten in the wardrobe and sneer of frontman Keith Flint,

Exactly why most techno enthusiasts (myself included) do not class the prodigy as a techno group anymore.  They have obviously decided that money is more important to them than their music..  fine by me.. everybody needs money I suppose..  but I find it sad that they would stoop to following the pop formula of building an image with attitude, on stage gimicks and other razzamatazz just so they can make it in the mainstream music world.  Their choice..  I hope they find satisfaction when they have their millions of $$, and have forgotten why they started writing music in the first place..

>    Ironically, the commercial fizzle this year may be the best thing
>that could have happened to it. If the Chemical Brothers and
>Prodigy tours had prompted fans to rush to the stores in search of
>other techno albums, record companies would have started signing
>acts with even greater gusto. This would have brought all sorts of
>opportunists into the music, contributing to recycled and repetitive sounds

Exactly what I said in a message sometime ago.  In an industry that thrives on 5-minute sensations, if you really want your music to survive the test of time, the answer is NOT a sudden explosion in popularity.  Sit back, enjoy your quality tunes, and watch as the mainstream culture goes through one-hit-wonder after another..

>But the fact that techno didn't explode commercially means that only 
>artists with a genuine love of the music will likely gravitate toward it.

Cool..  We'll have the _artists_ please.. the pop culture can have the wanna-be superstars with little talent all to themselves.

>    "The future of pop lies with songwriters," Gallagher said in an
>interview this year. "It doesn't matter which style or whether they're
>playing guitar, piano or the world's biggest synthesizer. A great song
>is a great song."

For 5 minutes until the next great song comes out.  and says exactly the same thing that the song before the last great song did.  As someone else recently said..  99% of all "great songs" are "Baby I want your love", "I'm so pissed about <X>", "Everything is great", or one of a very limited number of repeating themes said over and over again.   There is infinitely more variety in MUSIC and emotional expression, which the real artists can express themselves with.

<Phew.. we survived being "Pop"ularized, now we can go back to grooving away and enjoying ourselves..  See you on the dance floor !?


---
Brett Paulin : Trance DJ Spock, Electronic Engineer & Gyrocopter Pilot
For DAT trading, DJ Spock & Techno Magic - http://home.mira.net/~rando
       "Rotor pilots don't fly. They BEAT the air into submission"
       THINK for yourself, QUESTION Authority   - ICQ Id# 5879520

i would like to leave sfraves on a truly happy note.  lately i have
realized that most of the things i have to say should be saved for
some other lists or just to myself.  i would like to thank my friends
for their love, friendship, supports, and of course hugs mmmm...  and
in addition i would like to thank everyone else for sharing thoughts
with me.  i hope in some ways i have brought smiles to your days.  i'm
proud of the fact that i have not posted anything negative to sfraves
or to anybody, and the fact that everything i have written thus far
are straight from this crazy heart of mine.

i have learned so much and met so many people from sfraves in just a
little over the past 4 months.  incredible.  i would stay on longer
but i don't have the time, and besides, i'm not an email guy, although
contradictorily i program for a living.  that is my lunacy, what's
yours?  although the dancing and hugging have improved in my own mind,
the reading and more importantly the sports that i used to do are
lacking.  i i'm t'tired of in stutter telling the kids at the courts
that i have a career ending knee surgery hehhehh..

i guess this is it.  we'll be in touch.  see you all under the smiling
sun.

merry christmas & hugs, 
hai

In a message dated 97-12-23 18:31:12 EST, you write:

<< > Of those of you who /do/ try to meet people and possible 
 > SOs/datees/whateveryouwannacallit, or have in the past, when you choose
 > not to try to get to know someone, what are the main reasons?

Basically, I won't make the effort if the person is stupid.  I hate stupidity.
In the crowd I run with, the people who do the most drugs are the dumbest.
They have lost all there brain cells to something or another.  And trying to
get with a guy who has no brain is like destroying the chance to be with
someone who is actually worth it.  I have come to the conclusion, after this
weekend, that any boy who does drugs, to the certain extent of being high
almost every waking moment and being a bitch when he's not, is not worth my
precious time.  I would rather sit at home and pick my nose than be with one
of those.  Boys like that are reserved for friendship only.

 > Likewise, 
 > if someone tries to get to know you, without the 'cheese' lines, and you 
 > turn them down, why do you do so? Be brutally honest.

Anyone who says looks don't play a major part in the getting to know someone
process is pretty naive.  All you know as well as I that when you first see
someone, you are taken by their looks, whether it be postitively ar
negatively.  Generally if a guy picks up on me, with or without the cheese
lines I turn them down.  This is because I choose not to date, for the most
part.  When I do, I realize what a big mistake I have made and retreat into my
own happy world of not having to deal with the fragility and stress of a "love
relationship."  I have had guys try to give me their numbers, my reply to them
is... "honestly, I wouldn't use it."  I chose their friendship if they are
genuine towards me, and in this process, if we get to know each other
everything is good.  If they are not sincere in their attempts then they will
not even try to know me as a friend.

 > I'm genuinely 
curious as to the variety of reasons people may have. >>

the variety of reasons are for the variety of people.

Ms. K1dd
