-----Original Message-----
From: Haze <haze@netgate.net>

>> Or how about the poor women who spend their entire time at some sort of
>> social event (Rave, what have you) and /never/ get picked up on?  How
come
>> this is all about the ones who get picked up on and turn them down all
the
>> time instead of the ones who never or very rarely get picked up on?

I think it's less irritating to be ignored than it is to be constantly
harassed.
I mean, if other people aren't hitting on you, you can always go hit on
them.
*grinning* But, it seems like the people I would want to be with, would
never
hit on me in the first place....it all depends though.

>> Of those of you who /do/ try to meet people and possible
>> SOs/datees/whateveryouwannacallit, or have in the past, when you choose
>> not to try to get to know someone, what are the main reasons?  Likewise,
>> if someone tries to get to know you, without the 'cheese' lines, and you
>> turn them down, why do you do so? Be brutally honest.  I'm genuinely
>> curious as to the variety of reasons people may have.

 I don't turn people down who want to get to know me as far as being
my friend. I will basically be friends with anyone, but I try to avoid
people
who are fake, and try to pretend to be something they are not, as well
as those who are excessively negative. (however, i rarely run into
excessively negative people at raves.......but i have run into some fake
ones.)

I also try and avoid people who just want to date me/sleep with me and
aren't into being friends. If I get that vibe off anyone, I tend to run as
fast as possible.
if people hit on me in a blatant way, i am usually flattered and not
offended.
but if they pressure me into hanging out with them, it often scares me.

I disagree with whoever posted that physical appearance is important. Well,
I suppose to an extent..but it's more the way they present themself. You
could
be not necessarily the most physically blessed person....but if you are
beautiful
inside, it totally shows through like a light....while if a person is way
fly but
there's nothing within......they won't be attractive at all.

-kim
oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.
the purpose of this record is to demonstrate by tone
the ability of your pickup to stay in contact with the
groove modulation. In other words, to track the groove.
http://www.pulpfiction.com/rave/groovinkim/events.html
seattle rave and club night listings =) ICQ #2388692
http://www.pulpfiction.com/rave
Raverbooks - the world's first raver bookstore!
.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.

for all of you wondering why you're the only one on #sfraves ..
you're probably on UNDERNET..
therea re a few different networks.

#sfraves is on EFnet.
you gotta go to a server on EFnet to get to the SFR channel.
type /server irc.psinet.net or something, i don't know many EFnet servers
i'm an undernet chile' myself.
so if you find yourself on UNDERNET accidentially, do a /whois sk3
or /join #rave
and i just might be on :)
hehehe
xo
lara

Hello all!  There's a few things going on this weekend, even though
a lot of you are probably out of town.  The Harmony party on Saturday
should be pretty cool.  Mostly though, I think people are getting
ready for New Year's.  There's a bunch of listings already, and there
are a few more parties if you ask around...  Next week's calendar
will probably be sent out next Tuesday, the day before New Year's Eve.

                                 Info Lines
                                      
     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.569.3300
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
     _________________________________________________________________
   
                             Radio/TV/Net Shows
                                      
     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 11:30pm-2:30am - "Conscious Groove" - a show all
       about ambientdowntempojungletechnotrancedrumnbasstriphop love and
       more with weekly guest DJs. Free Radio Berkeley 104.1 (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Thursday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Friday 10am-3pm - weekly DJ netcasts. x-radio.
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "House Nation" w/"Anthems Mix", Top 10s from
       guest DJs and "London Connection w/DJ Doubt". 2am-4am, WILD 94.9
       SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

                            Administrative Notes
                                      
   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

<SFRavers> Hi Uncle Noah.

I know that a few of you are travelling/have ventured to SoCal for the 
holidays and I wanted to remind you that this little group I'm involved 
with, UpBeat Productions, is running our Friday night weekly, Energy 
Project in a lovely, intimate Hollywood location on Friday nights 
(including 12/26 and 1/2!!)  If you're in the area, please come by!  
We've got great DJs lined up including Thomas Lann, Doran, 725, JBondy, 
Mr. Annand and others (including a specail surprise guest on 12/26!!).  
Cover is 10 bucks and the info line is 310-285-3347

are!!!! :)

-----Original Message-----
From: jovian f. <jfrancey@orca.bc.ca>
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.org <nw-raves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Tuesday, December 23, 1997 4:48 PM
Subject: [NWR] Merry XMAS [SILLY]


> 
>                       The Set Before Christmas
>                         or A Visit from DJ Nicholas
>                     (apologies to Clement Clarke Moore) 
>
>       'Twas the night before Christmas, and the party was phat,
>       All the groovers were jumping, no one was on crack;
>       The bassbins were blasting the fresh funky sounds,
>       In hopes DJ Nicholas soon would be 'round; 
>
>       The tunes filled the warehouse with positive vibes,  
>       While visions of glowsticks danced in our eyes;
>       My friends with their tablets, and I with a cap,
>       Had just settled down, way too couched to chat, 
>
>       When beneath the black lights there arose such a beat,
>       I sprang from the rave sludge and onto my feet.
>       Away to the speakers to hear better the grooves,
>       Whipped out my earplugs and busted some moves. 
>
>       The Technics had a plate on the slipmat so dope,
>       It rotated at +8 and filled me with hope,
>       When, what to my shade-wearing eyes should I see,
>       A DJ dropping tracks with squealing 303. 
>
>       With a cut and a backspin, so lively and quick,
>       I knew in a moment it was DJ Nick.
>       More rapid than heartbeats his white labels came,
>       The kids whistled, and shouted, and all went insane;
>
>       "Now, JUNGLE! now, GOA!  HOUSE and FUNKY BREAKS!
>       He gets the crowd pumping whatever it takes!
>       If the music's da shit then he'll play 'em all!
>       He keeps the floor shaking, we dance 'till we fall!" 
>
>       Spotters gathered 'round to check his mad skills,
>       But ol' Nick has a sound that tickles and thrills,
>       Soon they couldn't help dancing to beats going down,
>       Faces plastered with grins, not the usual frowns. 
>
>       And then, through the dry-ice, I heard a loud thump,
>       Nicholas was snoozing, his body a lump,
>       "Wake up, DJ Nick!," was the entire crowd's plea,
>       Nick's drink had been spiked with heavy GHB. 
>
>       In his red and white tracksuit he so soundly slept,
>       The grumpy old ravers laughed and called him inept;
>       But his nose worked the faders, and he snored to the beat,
>       Ever the pro, Nick could mix in his sleep.  
>
>       His eyelids -- they twitched! He was finally awake!
>       His pupils dilated as he dropped the next break!
>       This DJ, with goatee as bleached white as snow, 
>       Had the crowd blown away with his kickin'-ass show;
>
>       The stump of a pipe he held tight in his teeth,
>       And he filled up the bowl with prime bud, shake and leaf.
>       Then just as he'd gotten 3 tables to lock,
>       A low voice shook the room, "This party must stop!"
>
>       He was chubby and plump, a right scary old cop,
>       And it seemed that the evening might end with a flop;
>       But ol' Nick knew the score, he went over to talk,
>       And gave me to know I'd no reason to sulk; 
>
>       Nick reached in his pocket and then with a flash,
>       Brought out his wallet and a big wad of cash.
>       The cop gave it back, said "If it's all the same,
>       I'd rather go off to Hawtin or Richard D. James" 
>
>       He sprang to his decks, spun the requested tracks,
>       And when he was finished, disappeared with his wax.
>       But I heard him exclaim, as he hopped in his jet,
>       "PLURRY CHRISTMAS TO ALL, AND TO ALL A GOOD SET!"
>
>- jove
>---
>drop modulation - we make music for dizzy giraffes
>next gig - Pam's New Year's (B-Day) Party - Dec.31, 1997
.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.oOo.
the purpose of this record is to demonstrate by tone
the ability of your pickup to stay in contact with the
groove modulation. In other words, to track the groove.
http://www.pulpfiction.com/rave/groovinkim/events.html
seattle rave and club night listings =) ICQ #2388692
http://www.pulpfiction.com/rave
Raverbooks - the world's first raver bookstore!

At 11:19 PM 12/23/97 PST, you wrote:
>I want to go to beautiful people but I'm training for my new job that 
>night and the next day, there is no way! oh well, u kidz(young and old) 
>have fun and keep out of trouble! Happy Holidays!!!!!!!!!!!

I am sorry you'll miss this one, but there is always next time ; )
>
>Question, will there be more harmony parties in this upcoming year or 
>will it be like '97?? just curious.
>
Well, that is a good question... Our scene is changing, as are we (the
crew)... For me personally, my time is very valuable, and I don't really
want to throw parties that might get busted (like ones in S.F.) It is a
real downer to have to go home early. Not to mention that it is hella
dangerous from some people to have to leave early. So I (as well as the
rest of the Harmony Crew) am focusing on doing parties that don't get
busted. That is why we are doing this party in Oakland with permits (they
are so expensive), and consequentially that is why this party costs $20
instead of $15 or even $10. Next summer we will be doing some free outdoors
events, as well as stuff up in Santa Rosa (Sonoma County). I really hope
that you guys all support us with this whole $20 party thing. It really
sucks that we have to charge that much, but that is the reality of the rave
scene now. But we are planning to have a "Freaky People" party on Friday
Feb. 13th, and Friday March 13th. of next year. After that, who knows? I do
know that we are going to plan a weekend campout for our anniversary party.
That will be summertime. But we will still be trowing parties and putting
our energy into keeping this scene alive. See ya in the future!

Peace and love,

Greg = )

>
>-idw
>"Why is there brail at the drive thru ATMs??"
>idw@hotmail.com
>
>
>
>

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


Okay, after dabbling in the world of propmotions for a while, I feel that 
I can talk on this subject a little.  There are a lot (and I mean *a 
lot*) or people out there trying as hard as they possibly can to bilk as 
much money as they possibly can out of The Scene.  And this is everybody 
from space owners/managers who at the last minute (literally) will up 
their prices by $2000 to the folks downtown who want five different 
permits that all cost $500 each, lighting folks who won't work for less 
than a grand, sound systems that cost a couple of grand, and then DJs 
that expect to receive anywhere from $200 - $1000 for spinning and hours 
worth of records.

It all starts addidng up really really quick when you do a "big" party.

I'm not saying it's right, but it happenes and it happens really easily.  
It's no hard to put together a "big-name" DJ lineup or to get a hold of 3 
argon lasers or to get a million watts of sounds... the hard part is 
getting all those people the money that they're expecting to receive.

For me, though, I'd rather be at a small, fun party. :)

Happy Holidays!!!

it's a permited party... with so many undergrounds getting popped....
it's the one of the few things left to do.  would you rather pay $10-$15
for a party with the possibility of the party getting busted at
midnight... so you just paid $10-$15 for an hour or two of partying, or
pay $20 (not $25 or $30 mind ya =) ) and know that you'll be able to
party all night and if you do drugs, you don't have to worry about
having to drive around until your sober. just in recent days people have
gotten huge fines and some arrests have been made, not to party goers,
but to the people involved with throwing the party.

you've gotta look at this from all sides.... not just from the party
goers perspective.

peace.jer - @spire


see ya at Beautiful People

I think you have taken a big leap by construing things out of my post that
I did not say. I was in no way condeming or casting aspersions on Greg or
Harmony for his choice to provide his customers a safe, permitted party.
However, IMO permits and $20 admissions(within reason) have traditionally
been the mark of a massive. And although the name would indicate
otherwise, "massive" does not always refer to size, at least to me.

The U.G. has been around for quite a while, and it will continue.

					Black Adder

On Fri, 26 Dec 1997, Noah Apodaca wrote:

> much money as they possibly can out of The Scene.  And this is everybody 
> from space owners/managers who at the last minute (literally) will up 
> their prices by $2000 to the folks downtown who want five different 
> permits that all cost $500 each, lighting folks who won't work for less 
> than a grand, sound systems that cost a couple of grand, and then DJs 
> that expect to receive anywhere from $200 - $1000 for spinning and hours 
> worth of records.

In defense of sound people...I think they are highly *under* rated.  When
you rent sound, don't forget that you are not only renting a sound system,
worth lots of money probably, you are *hiring* a person to come watch the
system all night.  Even at $30/hour that's about $300 for one party.
$30/hour for a sound tech is pretty cheap too.  Usually the sound is also
deliverd and picked up.  

I'm a dj...but imho it's the djs' that tend to raise the price of larger
parties...gimme a break someone charging $1500 for 2 hours of spinning,
that's a joke. 


love drenalin

the reason why "legit" parties in Oakland are so expensive is due to the
price for the cops, plus medical people ... Greg noted that he didn't want
to do a party in SF that would get busted, and although most UGs in SF
don't get busted, there's always a chance, and there hasn't been a
permitted rave there for awhile, so you have to go to Oaktown and pay for a
bunch of cops (and for medical people on hand as well, just in case we
ravers forget to take care of ourselves) ... it's a delicate balance to
juggle "legality" and affordability, and sometimes to make sure a party
won't get busted you have to spend beaucoup bucks ... I try to stay away
from massives, but once in awhile there's something to be said for knowing
a party will go all night, so at least it's Harmony's version of a
not-too-large party where you KNOW the music and vibe will be phat

my $20 worth,

leftjab

I would just like to say that there is a huge difference between a
massive and a crap party. We are not going to mention names here, but we
all know that there are massives which we hate or do not like. And there
are some that always seem to bring a good vibe, such as: SF House
Collective, Choice, and Tribal Funk, as well as others. There are all
those massives that hardly ever have a good vibe. We know which ones
those are. I think the same goes for undergrounds. I have been to a few
undergrounds that were sorta shitty with bad vibes. People need to
remember that it's not whether it is a massive or underground, it's
wether its gonna be a good vibe party with good music and good people.

Love,
Paul*E*Wog

just jer wrote:
> 
> here's a related poem I'm sure many of you have read.
> 
> DEATH OF AN INNOCENT
> 
>   I went to a party, Mom, I remembered what you said.
>   You told me not to drink, Mom, so I drank soda instead.
>   I really felt proud inside, Mom, the way you said I would.
>   I didn't drink and drive, Mom, even though the others said I should.
>   I know I did the right thing, Mom, I know you are always right.
>   Now the party is finally ending, Mom, as everyone is driving out of
>   sight.
> 
>   As I got into my car, Mom, I knew I'd get home in one piece.
>   Because of the way you raised me, so responsible and sweet.
>   I started to drive away, Mom, but as I pulled out into the road, the
>   other car didn't see me, Mom, and hit me like a load.
>   As I lay there on the pavement, Mom, I hear the policeman say,
>   the other guy is drunk, Mom, and now I'm the one who will pay.
>   I'm lying here dying, Mom.  I wish you'd get here soon.
> 
>   How could this happen to me, Mom?  My life just burst like a balloon.
>   There is blood all around me, Mom, and most of it is mine.
>   I hear the medic say, Mom, I'll die in a short time.
>   I just wanted to tell you, Mom, I swear I didn't drink.
>   It was the others, Mom.  The others didn't think.
>   He was probably at the same party as I.
>   The only difference is, he drank and I will die.
> 
>   Why do people drink, Mom?  It can ruin your whole life.
>   I'm feeling sharp pains now.  Pains just like a knife.
>   The guy who hit me is walking, Mom, and I don't think it's fair.
>   I'm lying here dying and all he can do is stare.
> 
>   Tell my brother not to cry, Mom.  Tell Daddy to be brave.
>   And when I go to heaven, Mom, put "Daddy's Girl" on my grave
>   Someone should have told him, Mom, not to drink and drive.
>   If only they had told him, Mom, I would still be alive.
> 
>   My breath is getting shorter, Mom.  I'm becoming very scared.
>   Please don't cry for me, Mom.  When I needed you, you were always
>   there.
>   I have one last question, Mom, before I say good bye.
>   I didn't drink and drive, so why am I the one to die?
>

Michael Standish wrote:
> 
> Quoth Scott Nelson:
> >I'm a dj...but imho it's the djs' that tend to raise the price of larger
> >parties...gimme a break someone charging $1500 for 2 hours of spinning,
> >that's a joke.

Let's do the math....2 hours of spinning plus 2000 hours of practise, maybe $1,000 
a year on records, plus a slew of free shows, being ripped off by some promoters the 
list go's on.  A DJ charging 80$ might make .07 to 13 cents an hour while that 1500$ DJ
might make from $2 to $15 an hour.

 
> They're not just being paid to spin; they're being paid for their draw.
> When it comes to fees, a DJ's ability to bring in people is at least as
> important as their skills on the turntables.

Dont forget the value one could place on the vibe that DJ creates. When a DJ transports 
you out of your body into some aural nirvana are you thinking "how much money does this 
guy deserve?
 
> Sir Ulrich Knight of the Turntables

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sun Dec 28 16:06:39 1997

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 28 Dec 1997 16:06:36 -0000
From: JD4150171 <JD4150171@aol.com>
Message-ID: <71d5e9b1.34a678ef@aol.com>
Date: Sun, 28 Dec 1997 11:06:04 EST
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject:  sasha review (sorta long)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
Organization: AOL (http://www.aol.com)
X-Mailer: Inet_Mail_Out (IMOv11)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Happily my last event of 97 turned out to be one of the best of late. 

Started out shakey as I anticipated obstacles to overcome:

1. Lamer than normal crowd at Nikita due to Christmas holiday
2. Most of my friends out of town/too poor from xmas to cough up $15
3. I'm not big on trance,
4 I had yawned my way through a Sasha set once before, (overseas a couple of
years ago -it seemed 2 of the 3 hrs were beat-less breakdowns that only served
to accentuate aching feet and overall physical ickiness -luckily Carl Cox
followed and I was feeling no pain - only music that MADE me dance, like a
voodoo doll or something)

For various reasons I had always missed Sasha here in SF, but always heard
after the fact how amazing he is. Given my personal experience, I couldn't
understand all the fuss. But I figured I'd give it another shot, especially
after reading somewhere that he had cooled it with the 30 minute "epic"
breakdown non-music segments.

WOW! The only thing I can really say is now I get it. It's still not my
absolute favorite music, or even my favorite style of mixing, but that guy
certainly is tops at what he is doing. He defined the word "effortless".
There were a few short breakdowns towards the beginning of the set, but not
enough to really throw off the pace or distract your dancing rhythm. The rest
of the set was dance dance dance!  Some familiar old tunes, mostly fresh ones.
Crowd was pretty responsive and excited, and not too bad for a commercial-y
club like Nikita, at Christmas holiday no less.Sasha kept a good eye on the
crowd and even was dancing/jumping around a bit himself.  There were a few
times he'd build and build and build, pause just long enough, then just SLAM
an amazing finish, using the EQ to really accentuate the bass where before
there had seemed none, or vice versa. 
As usual, the visual crew was unparalleled. The lasers (colors and patterns)
seem to be changed frequently so as not to get boring, and the lights, giant
balloons and netting (and fog, but not too much) make for amazing sights to
complement the music.
In closing I'll just add none of the above observations were chemically
enhanced - it all stood up in its own right. (Although I think I might have
had a bit of a contact high vibing off most of the crowd!!)
Not that he needs any more, but Sasha gained another fan Friday.
What did anyone else think? How did it compare to his previous visits here?
Or at Twilo?   Keep dancing in 98!    JD   :)

Hello all...

I've been dieing to see SASHA for quite some time and let me tell you that
I had a really good time. I always like his style and had a really good
time. His set was clean, smooth and creamy... I found myself dancing all
over the place and smiling a lot. He is definately one of the best DJs
I've ever heard. THe best I can remember....  fantastic...  very UK... a
lot of build-ups (which I like)... which allow you to chill for a few and
then blow up again... it was beautiful. Sent me hovering high above and
into the heaves... the sweet sounds...  

when you listen to a DJ you can't always be too technical... because music
is pure emotion... spend less time analysing and more time absorbing...
very nice.. Thanks 'Sasha 

another deep space transmission from... ..  .

(byroni)

Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk

I was there. The last time I heard 'The Man Like Sasha' was in '92. He was
playing all the rave/house hits of the day(Bomb the Bass, M17, Melissa Morgan,
Nush), he wasnt mixing very well and there was this MC on top of him saying
stuff like, "Nice and easy lemon squeezy!"

I got to Nikita and it was packed. I still dont know why people complain about
the crowd. I was totally expecting older people in suits and martinis in hand,
judging from everyone's descriptions in the past. But it wasnt. I don't care
what any die hard raver says, the folks who go to Nikita are real. You know
why? 'Cuz they go to the club, get on the dancefloor, and dance their asses
off. They dont worry about who's got what laminate on, what anyone is wearing
or anything superficial like that. They're there to get down. I wish I could
play to a crowd like that! 

Now, what I found most fascinating about the night was the music. Not that it
was unusual or anything; Sasha was playing straight-up hard trance. He was
behaving as what I identify as a typical english DJ would(Not much movement
behind the decks, not a lot of personal connection to the crowd, and seemingly
not much desire to). What I found interesting though was WHO was there,
listening to this music. There were folks there who I'm friends with who
would'nt be caught dead in a club playing this kind of music under any other
circumstances. I mean, some of the long-time Wicked crew- 'proper house'-crowd
was in full effect, going nuts to this guy's tracks. But if 'The Man Like'
would have taken a bathroom break and Jon Carel or Ethan would've gotten in
there and started playing, The music would've been similar, if not better. But
do you see any of those folks at FnF or Gateway jams? No, you don't.
Interesting.

In any event, I'm glad I got to check it all out.

--Monty

have ever heard on a 2X4..I couldn't even move during their set i was
so entranced in the music...jsut sat right in front of the left front

experience.  For those of you that weren't...we'll see you at teh next

In a message dated 97-12-28 20:10:24 EST, drenalin@salinas.net writes:

<< Don't forget the value of how the sound sounds?  What good is a great dj
 set if it sucks because the sound system suck my ass? >>

I'm so glad there's others who notice the huge gap in effort, quality, money,
between sound and everything else.  Why is it Bay Area promoters (clubs,
massives, UG whatever) seem to spend at twice as much on printing three
different versions of  fliers than on a soundsystem, to the detriment of the
event/night etc. Why is this, when almost all DJs at all levels aren't shy to
tell anyone  (and many ravers, clubbers. party-goers agree)- that <<the SOUND
is THE most crucial element to a good party>>.

 I've had more potentially great nights become only mediocre ones because of
poor sound quality or equipment set up etc, and I don't even know anything
about it, other than when I can hear my neighbors conversation better than the
music, or when all you hear is a fuzzy jumble that maked you keep checking if
you're still wearing your hat (and earplugs!).

Had to add my 2 cnts because its one of my favorite subjects to gripe
about...:)  jd

Alright then, nice opinion.  Sir, let me breifly state that marijuana is the
best herbal pain reliever we have found, no additives.  It helps in releaving
pain of all sorts and was even used by the queen of england in the 1800's.
Until approx 1930, marijuana was used legally as a pain reliever.  It is one
of the earliest forms of pain relief, documented over 5000 years ago by the
chinese.  The reason marijuana was used less frequently as a pain reliever
comes from the invention of hypodermic needles.  Drugs, such as morphine,
could be disolved into a liquid and injected into the body, giving a quicker
form of pain relief.  Also, in the 30's some stupid fuck (Henry Anslinger of
the federal bureau of narcotics) decided to make pot illegal.  He started anti
marijuana propaganda that said people became crazy when smoking the herb, with
homocidal tendencies and the like, from this statement, such movies like
reefer madness were made.
    Marijuana has been proven an effective pein reliever for those suffering
from glaucoma, cancer and AIDS.  It alleviates the pain, but it also helps
people to eat (you know, MUNCHIES)

From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)

Cc: Rave Friends <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi rave friends,

        It's true, I'm addicted... I can't stay away from this list even
though it takes way too much of my time to engage properly!  So after being
off a good part of this year, I'm back... and naturally I'm prepared to
spout off once again!  8)
        As always, I love to see people debating questions like this,
especially when it is done civilly and respectfully.  I think that such
discussions can only help us clarify our values, and when we know what our
values are, we can conciously act in accordance with them, which is,
frankly, a much better way to live.

        The question of how much money DJs should make isn't an isolated
question, but part of a dilemma this scene and other alternative scenes
have long struggled with:  How to preserve our subcultural identity in the
face of the larger culture.
        I believe it comes down to the fact that most of us seem to have a
couple different values which come into conflict when confronted with
issues of money.
        On one hand, we tend to value creativity and freedom.  We believe
that if an artist creates something, the artist has an absolute right to
reap the rewards of his/her creation, and we are not prepared to limit
these rewards by curtailing our own consumption of the desired products.
        On the other hand, we also tend to believe that there is something
fundamentally wrong with having the dollar-chase be a priority in one's
life, especially if the dollars are garnered from the rave community.
        How can these beliefs be reconciled?  Not easily, that's for sure!
But that doesn't mean whatever someone decides to do is okay...
        If I were a DJ getting offers of $1500 for 2 hours of spinning, I
hope that I would make it my practice to go by the intention of the
promoters I play for in setting my prices.  In other words, for someone
throwing a commercial event with the obvious intention of making a lot of
money, or for someone looking to enhance their image by having a lot of
big-name acts, I would charge what the market will bear.  But I would also
be sure to play friendly, humble, non-commercial events for little or
nothing, knowing that the vitality of the scene depends heavily upon the
vibe created by promoters not seeking money or power.
        Top DJs who play exclusively or nearly exclusively for large,
commercial events should not be considered part of the rave scene, in my
opinion.  Because they are there to draw audience, these DJs receive big
billing which makes them celebrities.  To borrow an old slogan, I think it
is easier for a camel to fit through the eye of a needle than for a
celebrity to be a raver.  The culture of raves and the culture of
performer-centered entertainment do not mix, in my opinion.
        It's hard to maintain the idea that everyone is a star when 4 or 5
people have their names splashed across a flyer and are making hundreds of
dollars an hour when everyone else is paying $20 to get in.
        This producer-consumer/entertainer-entertained dynamic works well
in many industries, and clearly it can work for dance parties too.  But
we've seen how beautiful rave culture can be when it's love-based, not
profit-driven or ego-driven, so why settle for less?  I wanna take it
higher!  8)  Th-th-th-that's all folks...

May the bass be with us,
                                        <<< Starchild >>>

>love drenalin

Dear Melissa,

        One person I would be remiss not to mention was a lovely
blue-winged Tooth Fairy who came up out of the blue and handed me a
quarter!  Her wand with a big stuffed tooth on the end was not to be
missed!
        Other than that, I will echo the praise for the decorations... they
were beautiful, and the Harmony crew obviously put in a lot of work on
them.
        For those concerned about the cost of the party, let me note for
the record that at least one uniformed police officer was present, despite
the fact that Harmony had their own security and there was no disturbance
of any kind that I'm aware of (in fact Greg thanked everyone remaining at
the end of the night for how trouble-free the event was).
        Can you say "government extortion"?

May the bass be with us (and may the cops leave us the *%$# alone),

It is all to true what Doreen said about promoters throwing $20 
parties!! If people will pay they will throw them, simple logic!

I don't think $20 is too much to pay for a GOOD party, if you concider 
the fact that you get a GOOD 6 - 8 hour dose of GOOD music & good 
visuals, granted you may spend more on things to alter or enhance your 
party experience, but that is not what a promoter has agreed to provide 
you with, they have there expences, and when I go to a massive and spend 
my hard earned $20 I expect to hear good beats and see cool things up in 
the air and on the walls

Essentialy massive raves are much different from the small UG style 
parties, but you can control if you go or not, but how often is a sound 
system that much better at a massive when compared to the sound sys at 
small parties.

I used to go to Funky Techno Tribe events up in sac which cost $25 at 
the door, and I felt it was well worth it, because there was good music, 
good people (the ones that I met or knew already), and good vibes. On 
the other hand I went (foolishly) to Planet New Year last new year (same 
cost) and felt I got no where near the same or equal value for my money. 
End result I will never attend another cool world party unless there is 
some drastic change in the vibe there parties present(um not likely).

The rave/party scene/culture/society is yours to shape ,promote ,destroy 
,enhance ,create ,put down ,and change to what you see fit. I know 
several people that don't agree with Hamony's way of doing things, so 
they don't attend harmony parties anymore, I haven't been to a hamony 
event since 4x4 which granted I had an okay time at but I'm still 
willing to go to ther events because of the wonderful time I had at the 
spring massive. I feel that people should not stand by and let this 
scene go in a direction they don't want it going in, remember that DJs, 
promoters, lighting people, and promotion groups are made up of people 
just like you and me, if you don't like what you are seeing happening to 
your scene do something, get involved, or a part of the scene you do 
like and try your best to preserve it. Perhaps one day you will be 
sitting, dialed in to netcom telling people why you and your crew are 
charging $20 or even $25 for the next party your throwing.

-idw
"Isn't it funny when you get chrismas cards postmarked the 26th of 
December??"
idw@hotmail.com

SugeR wrote:
> 
> hmm... let's see... $20 parties...
> 
> i don't get it... if your going to throw a massive with soo many folks
> showing up to ''support'' you... then why you need to charge soo much...
> 
> i didn't think the party was supposed to be about how much you had in yer
> pocket when you went home... Perhaps...  some of the promoters need to be
> reminded...
> 
> Have a safe... and fun... New Year...
> 
> SugeR


Because it costs 2-3 times as much.
Big DJ A who normally commands $4-500 a spin damands $1,500-$2000 on
NYE.
Big band B who normally gets $4,000 a gig wants $10-$12,000 on NYE.
Sound company who usually wants $5-700 an evening wants $1,500-$2,500 on
NYE.
Anybody who works for you from cashier to sound tech wants 2-3 times as
much.
"Economy of scale."  I don't know which came first. The promoter
charging a ton more on NYE or the talent wanting a ton more but either
way it sucks.  I've done NYE parties for the last 4 years and every year
it gets worse and worse.  
-SUNNY
P.S. Oh yeah, try to increase the value of your party by getting your
DJs to play exclusively at you event = increase price by another 25%. 
Take a look at the line-ups for NYE.  Some DJs are playing at 3-4
events.

Quoth blkadder@value.ne:
>You make a very good point Michael. However, anyone worried about paying
>DJ's for their "draw" is most likely running a business, and is not
>just throwing parties for friends...

Erm...duh. Tell me comrade, what's so bad about running a business? NEways
there's a whole shitload of gray area. I can think of only one promoter who
I would say is just in it for the money. There are many many promoters who
are out to make a well deserved buck, and support the scene they love.
Promoters put hours of work, hundreds (more likely thousands) of dollars on
the line every time they throw a rave. If they make a buck, fine they took
they risk, and did the work. That my friend is the entrepreneurial spirit
that makes America great, and gave us the Silicon Valley which begat the
good stuff that we're using to geek out right now.

PS why do people whinge about what DJs and promoters make, but not about
what drug dealers make?

Sir Ulrich Knight of the Turntables



From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Dec 29 18:40:53 1997

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 29 Dec 1997 18:40:49 -0000
Received: from [38.248.198.53] ([38.248.198.53] (may be forged)) by netcommunications.net (10.1/8.7.3) with ESMTP id LAA29050 for <sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org>; Mon, 29 Dec 1997 11:01:11 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <l03110703b0cd94a8c034@[38.248.198.53]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 29 Dec 1997 10:41:10 -0800
To: sfraves@qmail.hyperreal.org
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Thank You Beautiful People!!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Good morning, all!

I would like to thank every single amazing person who came out to Beautiful
People Saturday night... this party was ALL GOOD!!!  and that is because of
the people who were involved in creating it, and the people who came to
contribute their energy to everyone's good time!  you all rock!

Setup was so smooth and easy, it was like the space was welcoming us ...
and shortly before the doors opened, i went outside and saw the mellow and
wonderful people who were waiting to get in, and knew it was going to be a
special night.. and it was.

>From beginning to end, everyone I saw was smiling, dancing, happy, enjoying
themselves.  We didn't have one incident requiring medical attention, and
Karma Patrol's corner had only one real guest, a girl who had a short bout
with the stomach flu.

It was never too crowded (except in the hall occasionally), and you could
go pretty much anywhere on the dance floor and have room to let yourself
dance freely.  It got hot in a few corners, but you could move near a door
and cool down quickly.  It did get a little smoky, but hey, maybe i'm
sensitive to that since i quit a month ago and still have those cravings!

All you crazy kids who dressed up looked so amazing, all bright and
sparking and smiling and happy, passing out your candy and toys (Haze, that
toy scorpion's going on my computer) ...

And i got to see so many many people who i love to see out.... for every
person who i missed because they were out of town for the holidays, there
was one who had moved away in the past year, but was back for the holidays
and came out to party with us...

I got to meet so many sfravers i hadn't before .... and was wishing i had
the money and energy to create a sfrave booth with a photo wall.... if we
had a polaroid camera, each sfraver could sort of "sign in" at the booth
when they came, and have their photo taken, and we could post it up with
their name on a wall.... so that everyone could see who was there, and know
exactly what to look for, wouldn't that be cool?  (anyone who has the
energy to do this, go for it!!!)

to echo what greg said in the morning (after that great group hug!), this
party showed how wonderful responsible raving can be, and we all hope that
this is a taste of what the next year of partying holds for us.

I know that lots of people think $20 is a lot for a party.... and while i
wish it didn't have to be that way, it's important to recognize that it is
more and more difficult to throw underground parties that don't get
busted... i partied for 2-1/2 years before i was at a party that got busted
(FnF last halloween)... and sadly, now i'm so used to it that i feel
grateful at little undergrounds when we make it until morning.

And that is why a permitted party was the priority for harmony.  Yes,
throwing legal parties is expensive, and it does mean we have to have
security and the police will be around.  But it also means that we can
dance and be together safely and securely, and i think that's worth a whole
lot more than the extra $5 or so.

There was a uniformed cop who strolled through the party a few times the
other night.... two different people told me that they were nervous about
him, and went up and asked him if he was going to shut us down... he said
"no, i'm being paid to be here."  and they asked him what he thought....
and he looked at the dance floor filled with happy people dancing under
words that said  things like "respect" and "self-esteem" and "friendship"
and the crazy harmony letters and banners and he said "it's pretty great"
....  and that's something he will take with him, as another level of
understanding about what raving can be about.

And a special thanks to the crew.  every single person on this crew kicked
butt, worked their ass off, and had a great time doing it!  you guys are
amazing!!  and this time my daughter worked with us too, and that was so
great for me.

So if I didn't get a chance to say it personally to all of you who were
there, thank you for coming and making Beautiful People a night to always
remember.  My favorite moment was dancing in front of Brian and Brad from
Moontribe on 2x4, they were spinning the sickest trance and loving the
people dancing in front of them, and Greg was actually *dancing* to my
left, all candied out in his freaky party clothes and crazy white knit hat,
and i looked around the room and realized i was surrounded by people i know
and love, and we were grooving together.  Yep, *that* is what it's all
about, and that is magic.

much love to everyone, thanks for being part of my life in 1997,

leslie

From: Michael Standish <standish@sirius.com>


>Quoth blkadder@value.ne:
>>You make a very good point Michael. However, anyone worried about paying
>>DJ's for their "draw" is most likely running a business, and is not
>>just throwing parties for friends...
>
>Erm...duh. Tell me comrade, what's so bad about running a business?

Nothing.  Businesses are all good.  A rave is not a business.

Raves are not concerts. One thing I love about parties is that
it's more of an interactive experience....if you pay a lot of money for an
event
it separates the "performers" from the "audience"...and I don't like that.

It makes it seem as though the djs and promoters are on a different "level"
than the people going to the party.

I feel that raves and money-making should be kept separate. Throwing a party
in my opinion should not be a business venture.

If you are at an event that you are throwing, and you are not having fun,
what's
the point? I think running around worrying about "losing money" is
lame....and
takes away from the party.

There are many many promoters who
>are out to make a well deserved buck, and support the scene they love.

I would say that if someone is out to make a buck, they might be supporting
the scene THEY love, but it is not the scene _I_ love.

>Promoters put hours of work, hundreds (more likely thousands) of dollars on
>the line every time they throw a rave.

It really shouldn't have to cost hundreds or thousands of dollars to throw a
party.
You can throw a perfectly fun, exciting and creative party for very cheap.

It's just easier to do things the standard way (lots of oversized, multi
colored flyers,
big name djs, standard visual people) etc. which of course is expensive.

If more promoters dared to do something out of the ordinary, they could save
a lot
of money and massives would be more exciting.

That my friend is the entrepreneurial spirit
>that makes America great, and gave us the Silicon Valley which begat the
>good stuff that we're using to geek out right now.

Pardon my french, but fuck that!

People wanting to make money is not what makes america great, and it is in
fact one of the things that causes me to be most ashamed of the U.S., that
so
many people will treat other living things poorly in order to make a buck.

For example, is using workers in third-world countries and paying them $4 a
day
or less like Nike a good example of the entrepreneurial spirit? After all,
Nike
sure profits from it....

>PS why do people whinge about what DJs and promoters make, but not about
>what drug dealers make?


Perhaps because drug dealers don't claim to be "supporting their scene" or
pass out flyers that say "Peace Love Unity Respect - only $30 each"

They don't get an attitude and walk around saying "Yeah, I sell <insert name
here>"
like that makes them better than the average person somehow.....

They don't expect to get in free to parties just because they sell
drugs.....or become
bellligerant (sp?) if they are forced to pay (i have seen that happen with
numerous
djs and promoters)

*giggling*

also, maybe the people who don't mind the amount drug dealers make
 are anarchists and like the idea that they are supporting
something illegal, whereas most massives are permitted and therefore
"bowing down to the man" so to speak?

and i also honestly feel that the average person selling drugs you see at a
party,
is not making anywhere near as much as the dj spinning records in front of
them....
or the massive promoter.

-kim

Well..what can i say???  this was one of the best parties that i have
been to in a long time.

Great decorations and TONS of beautiful people.  I was sober the whole
night, but got such a rush from all of the wonderful people there. 
This reminded me of why i rave and was reminiscent of some of the old
party's that i used to go to.  I like the fact that the spce wasn't
too crowded.  thank u!

The music was great too, brian and brad tore shit up...it was cool to
watch 2 dj's who were so in tune with each other.  And Maiz also tore
shit up in the second room, anyone who was in there can atest to this.
 and an honorable mention to urn, who laid down a nice hard house
groove in the morning.

=)
micron

On Mon, 29 Dec 1997, Michael Standish wrote:

> Quoth blkadder@value.ne:
> >You make a very good point Michael. However, anyone worried about paying
> >DJ's for their "draw" is most likely running a business, and is not
> >just throwing parties for friends...
> 
> Erm...duh. Tell me comrade, what's so bad about running a business? 

Please, let's not degenerate into a pissing match. There is nothing wrong
with "running a business," as long as you are honest about it. I have said
this before and I will continue to say it: If you want to run a business,
run a business, but don't put a bunch of B.S. "we are trying to gather
people from all walks of life and you will experience a spirtual mindfuck"
when what you are trying do is make a living.  

> PS why do people whinge about what DJs and promoters make, but not about
> what drug dealers make?

When was the last time someone went to prison for twenty years for
throwing a party?

					Black Adder

Well what can I say? or where to start. 
This party was sooo goood. They had a nice oak
location with full on permits. Decor what be said
they were excellent as always it was like the harmony
of old not to crowded not to hot just right nice mix
of people. The music where to begin??? it was
excellent I am not sure if greg or who is in charge
of the lineups but it was a excellent blend through
out the night brian and brad rocked it. So did Mr.
Greg himself Nice to see a new kid of out from Santa
Rosa by the name of URN he was real good played a
nice blend of progressive hard house it is nice to
see good Jocks that don't play out that often it
keeps the scene fresh and alive. I could go on and on
about the party but I will not waste bandwith it was
a excellent party. The only bad thing is even with
all the nice stuff and nice vibe those kids barely
broke even if that. I have not heard the confirming
reports but I know that party budget had increased in
the final days before. It is sad that these kids
worked so hard put on a good party and they were not
able make a little money. I know it is about the vibe
love music etc.. but they should be able to reap a
reward for all the hard work. Good job guys 

Thanks,

>From Reagan;

>  BA is not saying that pot is a bad choice to use as medicine..he sees 
it 
>as wrong to use medicine as an excuse to legalize pot.

 While I highly respect Patricks opinion I am in diasagreement here with 
him and would like to point out that he sounds a tiny bit bitter in his 
comments on Dennis Peron (this coming from someone who knows how to 
sound bitter).

 Pot is (IMO) an effective medication for some ills. Getting Pot to a 
legal status *despite the intentions involved* is a step foward for 
those who are suffering. Not only in the relief of a persons suffering 
but especially as it gives the individual power over their medication. 
The patient can grow their own rather than relying on huge corporations 
(who care only about the dollar, not someones health) to provide relief. 
And typically the corporations supply addictive and dangerous (when 
compared to Pot) drugs to ill people.

 Dennis did a lot of people a favor by writing 215 and the voters of 
California bear as much responsibility in it's passage as Dennis.



>.these are *2
>seperate issues* which are wanting 1) the legalization of pot for only
>medical use and wanting 2) the legalization of pot just to be able to 
get
>high!

 And what if a person *just wants to get high* (oh the horror). Is that 
so terrible? Particularly when it involves one of the safest drugs 
known??? And what if wanting to get high is a form of self-medication? I 
would rather be a mellow person from Pot smoking than from taking 
Prozac!



>...CBC has mixed the issues and are now paying for it!

 Not really. The order to stop selling Pot is not set in stone and even 
if does become so, Pot can still be distributed free of charge. It just 
can't be sold.

 A useful thing to remember is that we are all different. Some people 
seem to operate in this world better when they are stoned. Others seem 
to operate better when they are sober. Dennis has provided us not only 
with a choice, but has also opened up research on medical pot. I thank 
him for that.

hugz,


Ran D. Dreams

On Mon, 29 Dec 1997, Ran D. Dreams wrote:

>  While I highly respect Patricks opinion I am in diasagreement here with 
> him and would like to point out that he sounds a tiny bit bitter in his 
> comments on Dennis Peron (this coming from someone who knows how to 
> sound bitter).

I am not "bitter." I am pissed. Big difference.

>  Pot is (IMO) an effective medication for some ills. Getting Pot to a 
> legal status *despite the intentions involved* is a step foward for 
> those who are suffering. 

Sorry, I don't buy Machavellian reasoning. The ends do not justify the
means. If you lie and misuse people in order to acheive what
otherwise might be a "noble" purpose, you lose all credibility and become
no better than the people that are lying and making false statements to
keep it illegal.

> Not only in the relief of a persons suffering 
> but especially as it gives the individual power over their medication. 
> The patient can grow their own rather than relying on huge corporations 
> (who care only about the dollar, not someones health) to provide relief. 
> And typically the corporations supply addictive and dangerous (when 
> compared to Pot) drugs to ill people.

This is a totally seperate and distinct issue from what the CBC has been
doing, which is handing pot to people that have absolutely no medical need
for it. 

>  Dennis did a lot of people a favor by writing 215 and the voters of 
> California bear as much responsibility in it's passage as Dennis.

Californians bear responsibility for being lied to? Sorry, I don't follow
your line of reasoning. 

What Dennis Perone did is put the whole movement for the legitimate use of
medical marijuana *at risk* through lying and misusing the ill as a front
for his own quasi-legal drug cartel.   

You have to understand that I have *0* problem with the use of marijuana,
for medicinal or for any other reason. What I object vehemently to is the 
misuse of the ill as a front. Ultimately, when it is found that this moron
has been distributing marijuana to anyone who wants it, the people that
stand to lose the most are those with a medical condition for which it
could prove useful. The people that 215 was obsentisbly supposed to help.   

					Black Adder

> From: Fumbler151 <Fumbler151@aol.com>
> Subject: I need help finding a track!!
> 
> hey everyone,
>      a friend of mine on the east coast told me that rabbit in the moon did a
> remix of the tori amos song "precious things". i want to know if any of you
> have heard it or seen it in any of the record stores out there. any help would
> be greatly appreciated.
> 
> thanks,
> dorena 

  I think the answer is "sort of." There's a Rabbit in the Moon record
called "Phases of an Out-of-Body Experience", which uses a piano riff from
"Precious Things" as one of its main themes. It's on Hardkiss, which is
based here in San Francisco. Some of the vocal snippets on the record
might be from Tori Amos too, but they might not. The piano sample isn't
acknowledged - she doesn't get credit - and the song is longer and more
complex than just a remix. I think it may be something that started as a
remix and then turned into something else.
  Kinda funny that you mentioned this - I just got back from Santa Fe,
where I spent Christmas with my family at a ranch house which my parents
are renting half of. One of my parents' housemates had the Urb compilation
CD, which has about 5 minutes of "Phases" under the title "O.B.E." Long
story short, I was listening to that song all week long. (I have the whole
thing, but it's on vinyl, and I don't have a record player any more.)


                          *                     *  *
                         *                     *  *
                        *  giles@bowkett.com  *  *
                         *                     *  *
                          *                     *  *

stayed longer but I needed to see my little bird.

the '80's!   And some of my best friends are 20yrs. old. Cheers y'all. Happy

To: Rave Friends <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)
Subject: Re: Dennis Peron/Pot (NRR)
Cc: <blkadder@value.net>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

 Hi rave friends...

        BlackAdder (Patrick) says the end -- re-legalizing marijuana --
doesn't justify the means of moving toward legalization under the auspices
of the Medical Marijuana Law, which some (not all) Californians voted for
on a narrower basis.

        But Patrick seems to feel that the ends DO justify the means when
the end is guaranteeing marijuana to the gravely ill who need it, by means
of cooperating with the drug warriors in restricting the access of everyone
else to this wonderful drug.

        While I have compassion for those who need pot for conditions like
cancer and AIDS, I also have compassion for the thousands if not millions
of people currently wasting their lives in jail because they sold or used
marijuana.

        Because the presence of marijuana for any use makes those who argue
that the plant has no value look ridiculous, medical marijuana patients
will have no secure guarantee of legal protection until the value of pot is
widely recognized, which means re-legalization.

        Therefore those of us who believe what you put into your body
should be your choice are ultimately in this together.  We must not allow
our movement to be divided by a short-sighted defense of marijuana on
narrow medical grounds, a position which is not sustainable.  We must not
abandon our brothers and sisters in jail out of fear of losing what we have
gained so far, which is merely a small step.

        I strongly encourage all ravers to stand up for the fundamental
human right to use any and all drugs, for whatever reason.  It's your
life... if you're not harming others shouldn't it be your choice?

May the bass be with us,
                                <<< Starchild >>>


>On Mon, 29 Dec 1997, Ran D. Dreams wrote:
>
>>  While I highly respect Patricks opinion I am in diasagreement here with
>> him and would like to point out that he sounds a tiny bit bitter in his
>> comments on Dennis Peron (this coming from someone who knows how to
>> sound bitter).
>
>I am not "bitter." I am pissed. Big difference.
>
>>  Pot is (IMO) an effective medication for some ills. Getting Pot to a
>> legal status *despite the intentions involved* is a step foward for
>> those who are suffering.
>
>Sorry, I don't buy Machavellian reasoning. The ends do not justify the
>means. If you lie and misuse people in order to acheive what
>otherwise might be a "noble" purpose, you lose all credibility and become
>no better than the people that are lying and making false statements to
>keep it illegal.
>
>> Not only in the relief of a persons suffering
>> but especially as it gives the individual power over their medication.
>> The patient can grow their own rather than relying on huge corporations
>> (who care only about the dollar, not someones health) to provide relief.
>> And typically the corporations supply addictive and dangerous (when
>> compared to Pot) drugs to ill people.
>
>This is a totally seperate and distinct issue from what the CBC has been
>doing, which is handing pot to people that have absolutely no medical need
>for it.
>
>>  Dennis did a lot of people a favor by writing 215 and the voters of
>> California bear as much responsibility in it's passage as Dennis.
>
>Californians bear responsibility for being lied to? Sorry, I don't follow
>your line of reasoning.
>
>What Dennis Perone did is put the whole movement for the legitimate use of
>medical marijuana *at risk* through lying and misusing the ill as a front
>for his own quasi-legal drug cartel.
>
>You have to understand that I have *0* problem with the use of marijuana,
>for medicinal or for any other reason. What I object vehemently to is the
>misuse of the ill as a front. Ultimately, when it is found that this moron
>has been distributing marijuana to anyone who wants it, the people that
>stand to lose the most are those with a medical condition for which it
>could prove useful. The people that 215 was obsentisbly supposed to help.
>
>                                        Black Adder

thank you to harmony and greg for another great party... the location was
interesting, one big room, one small room, and a long hallway... what was
that place anyway? i have to say, at first having the police there made me
feel strange but as the night went on and i spoke with some of them and they
were friendly, i felt very safe... i guess this is the way it has to be if
you want to go the above-ground legal route. the decorations were up to the
usual harmony high standards, lots of lights and banners...

the DJs were great. li really brought my energy level up. but the
bomb-DJ-of-the-night award goes to moontribe team, brian and brad. they tore
it up for HOURS, i was constantly thinking, "i love this track" and then
"hey, wait, that sample isn't on it!" as they mixed EVERYTHING... i didn't
spend a lot of time in the small room, but the times i cruised through it
sounded good...

it was great to see so many of you that i haven't seen for so long... please
appreciate the beautiful scene you are a part of here! it is so rare to
find... only now do i realize how much i've missed it, and i can't wait to
see you all again on new years eve...
=)

. . . . . . .
benchun@mit.edu
http://mdma.mit.edu/

	by mail1.sirius.com (8.8.7/Sirius-8.8.7-97.08.12) with ESMTP id UAA06137;
	Mon, 29 Dec 1997 20:36:07 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: standish@pop.sirius.com
Message-Id: <v03130300b0cdf7952d32@[205.134.235.191]>
In-Reply-To: <01bd148e$12904c00$6056dad0@groovinkim.connectexpress.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 29 Dec 1997 20:35:51 -0800
To: ".oOo.oOo.oOo." <groovinkim@connectexpress.com>, <blkadder@value.net>
From: Michael Standish <standish@sirius.com>
Subject: Re: raving=business?was:Expensive Parties
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Quoth kim:
>Nothing.  Businesses are all good.  A rave is not a business.

Kim, before I begin, let me say that I have always, and continue to have
the great admiration and respect for you. However, "A rave is not a
business."? That's well... silly. There is business going on throughout the
rave scene: rekkid stores, clothing stores, flyer designers, drug dealers,
glow stick sellers, all but perhaps 10% of promoters.

>Raves are not concerts. One thing I love about parties is that
>it's more of an interactive experience....if you pay a lot of money for an
>event it separates the "performers" from the "audience"...and I don't like
>that.
>It makes it seem as though the djs and promoters are on a different "level"
>than the people going to the party.

Hmmm, I don't see the connection. This is just my experience but: I've spun
at massives where I was running out from behind the decks to hug people,
and met people after my set and gave them hugs and candy, and I've been to
free parties where I hung out behind the decks with all the cool people.

>I feel that raves and money-making should be kept separate. Throwing a party
>in my opinion should not be a business venture.

That may well be so, but the reality is that most raves are business ventures.

>If you are at an event that you are throwing, and you are not having fun,
>what's the point? I think running around worrying about "losing money" is
>lame....and takes away from the party.

Even a $5 UG has to worry about losing money.. The party may get busted
early, or only a few people show up, because the big party down the street
had all the right DJs. The rent still has to be paid. The sound system
still needs to be paid for, unless you happen to know someone with a phat
system, but that system would exist, because it works other shows for
money. Even free renegades run the risk of having the sound system
confiscated. Worrying about losing money sucks, but it's not gonna go away.

>I would say that if someone is out to make a buck, they might be supporting
>the scene THEY love, but it is not the scene _I_ love.

Then I guess that the scene you love is only a small fraction of the rave
scene. I like massives and UGs. I have not found that the size of the party
or the promoters motives are indicators of how good a party will be.

>It really shouldn't have to cost hundreds or thousands of dollars to throw a
>party.

It shouldn't have to, but it does. I have worked on $5 UGs with budgets in
the thousands.

>You can throw a perfectly fun, exciting and creative party for very cheap.

Yes, it can be done, but not for many more than 400 people. And if you keep
throwing phat parties for 400 people, more and more people will want to
come, and then you have to be selective about who gets tickets, and then
you get a rep for being all stuck up and elitist. (yes I've seen it happen.)

>People wanting to make money is not what makes america great, and it is in
>fact one of the things that causes me to be most ashamed of the U.S., that
>so many people will treat other living things poorly in order to make a buck.

There are ways to make money without fucking people over. Just because
nearly all large corporations are evil, doesn't make everyone who tries to
make a buck evil.

>For example, is using workers in third-world countries and paying them $4 a
>day or less like Nike a good example of the entrepreneurial spirit? After all,
>Nike sure profits from it....

Nike are not "a person who organizes and manages a business undertaking,
assuming the risk for the sake of the profit"(Webster's NewWorld
Dictionary) Nike are a big evil corporation from hell.

>They don't expect to get in free to parties just because they sell
>drugs.

Too true, although they sometimes try to pay in drugs. I had a hippy crack
dealer try to get in for a few balloons once. Fuck that! Tanks don't get
past this doorman.

>bellligerant (sp?) if they are forced to pay (i have seen that happen with
>numerous djs and promoters)
>*giggling*

Ha ha ha, no shit. That brings me back to sooooo many door shifts. It's
kinda fun telling them to sit down and shut up until the promoter gets back.

> whereas most massives are permitted and therefore
>"bowing down to the man" so to speak?

And as a result providing good value because they don't get busted.

Sir Ulrich Knight of the Turntables

Quoth blkadder@value.net:
>Please, let's not degenerate into a pissing match.

OK but can we have an argument with some good natured ribbing?

> There is nothing wrong
>with "running a business," as long as you are honest about it. I have said
>this before and I will continue to say it: If you want to run a business,
>run a business, but don't put a bunch of B.S. "we are trying to gather
>people from all walks of life and you will experience a spirtual mindfuck"
>when what you are trying do is make a living.

Yeah I feel funny about all that cute crap on flyers for massives, but I
could go either way on this issue. On one hand it's may not be genuine, and
on the other, it may be the only place that new ravers here about PLUR and
stuff. Sure it's marketing hype, but it's marketing hype with a good, and
important message.

>When was the last time someone went to prison for twenty years for
>throwing a party?

When was the last time somebody died from a party?

Sir Ulrich Knight of the Turntables

-----Original Message-----
From: Michael Standish <standish@sirius.com>


>Quoth kim:
>>Nothing.  Businesses are all good.  A rave is not a business.
>
>Kim, before I begin, let me say that I have always, and continue to have
>the great admiration and respect for you. However, "A rave is not a
>business."? That's well... silly. There is business going on throughout the
>rave scene: rekkid stores, clothing stores, flyer designers, drug dealers,
>glow stick sellers,

ahh, but those are not raves...those are rave related businesses....

>all but perhaps 10% of promoters.

well, then i guess it's those 10% that i think are throwing raves....the
rest
are throwing imitation raves. *giggling*

like diet soda..what's the point? =)

>>Raves are not concerts. One thing I love about parties is that
>>it's more of an interactive experience....if you pay a lot of money for an
>>event it separates the "performers" from the "audience"...and I don't like
>>that.

>Hmmm, I don't see the connection.

well, if some people get into the party for free (guest listed, etc) whereas
other people have to pay $20 or more, it sucks! it makes it seem like
everyone
is not on the same level......

This is just my experience but: I've spun
>at massives where I was running out from behind the decks to hug people,
>and met people after my set and gave them hugs and candy,

you are awesome =) but a lot of djs unfortunately are not like that =(

> and I've been to free parties where I hung out behind the decks with all
the cool >people.

i'm not saying that just because a party is free means it will be good, and
just
because a party costs $20 or more means it will be bad.

I'm talking about the intentions of the promoter, because I really feel that
is shows
through in the event, in every detail, from the decorations to the flyer, to
the order
of the djs and music chosen, etc....if their heart is in the music and the
vibe it
shows through......but if it is not, it's painfully obvious....

A party that cost $20 where the promoter put 100% of their effort into
making it
creative, fun, and a good value, could be cool......if they were doing it
because
they loved it and not because they wanted to make loads of cash....

However, I unfortunately nearly always walk away from larger parties feeling
like
it was a waste ...like people just following the same old formula over
and over with little or no creativity...a stagnant process....i.e. "insert
big name
dj here, insert cheesy flyer with fractal here, insert standard relatively
well known local djs here..." like they just take a cookie cutter mold and
chop
out a party....all following each other's leads as though there is only one
way
to do an event....

however, i am talking about parties in seattle...since i rarely get to party
in sf
(unfortunately)  the massives there might be totally different. but here, i
feel that
they are formulated.....hopefully i will get to check out some good ones
while
i am in sf :) (i leave tomorrow! woo! )

>>I feel that raves and money-making should be kept separate. Throwing a
party
>>in my opinion should not be a business venture.
>
>That may well be so, but the reality is that most raves are business
ventures.

i disagree...maybe it's the word "rave" that i am disagreeing with....
i prefer raves that have no money involved and are illegal, free, and all
djs/sound
is for free...

if you had said "massive" rather than rave i would agree...

>There are ways to make money without fucking people over. Just because
>nearly all large corporations are evil, doesn't make everyone who tries to
>make a buck evil.

i agree, but i don't think throwing "raves/massives/whatever" is a good way
to make a living because it is so risky that people who are basing their
income
on it will basically advertise anywhere in order to be sure of making enough
to cover costs...

love kim

Hmmm, 

I was taught that two wrongs don't make a right.  Just because we might
feel that our government lies and oppresses us does not mean that we
should do the same.  So the war on drugs turned out to be a bad idea but
how can we overcome the stupid decisions of the past if we use the same
means to achieve goals we assume to be loftier?  We need to be different,
creative, and honest, not redundant.    

Tina


On Mon, 29 Dec 1997, Starchild wrote:

>  Hi rave friends...
> 
>         BlackAdder (Patrick) says the end -- re-legalizing marijuana --
> doesn't justify the means of moving toward legalization under the auspices
> of the Medical Marijuana Law, which some (not all) Californians voted for
> on a narrower basis.
> 
>         But Patrick seems to feel that the ends DO justify the means when
> the end is guaranteeing marijuana to the gravely ill who need it, by means
> of cooperating with the drug warriors in restricting the access of everyone
> else to this wonderful drug.
>

> cancer and AIDS, I also have compassion for the thousands if not millions
> of people currently wasting their lives in jail because they sold or used
> marijuana.
> 
>         Because the presence of marijuana for any use makes those who argue
> that the plant has no value look ridiculous, medical marijuana patients
> will have no secure guarantee of legal protection until the value of pot is
> widely recognized, which means re-legalization.
> 
>         Therefore those of us who believe what you put into your body
> should be your choice are ultimately in this together.  We must not allow
> our movement to be divided by a short-sighted defense of marijuana on
> narrow medical grounds, a position which is not sustainable.  We must not
> abandon our brothers and sisters in jail out of fear of losing what we have
> gained so far, which is merely a small step.
> 
>         I strongly encourage all ravers to stand up for the fundamental
> human right to use any and all drugs, for whatever reason.  It's your
> life... if you're not harming others shouldn't it be your choice?
>

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: NRR shawnee wisdom
Message-ID: <19971229.221018.8999.0.foolish_fish1@juno.com>
X-Mailer: Juno 1.38
X-Juno-Line-Breaks: 0-10,12-19,21-28
From: foolish_fish1@juno.com
Date: Tue, 30 Dec 1997 01:01:38 EST

Precedence: bulk

hope you dont mind if i share a little story someone sent me for
new years. In joy

	><{{{">   <"}}}><

		foolish fish

So live your life that the fear of death can never enter your heart.
Trouble no one about their religion; respect others in their view, and
demand that they respect yours.
Love your life, perfect your life, beautify all things in your life.
Seek to make your life long and its purpose in the service of your
people.
Prepare a noble death song for the day when you go over the great divide.
Always give a word or a sign of salute when meeting or passing a friend,
even a stranger, when in a lonely place.
Show respect to all people and grovel to none.
When you arise in the morning give thanks for the food and for the joy of
living.
If you see no reason for giving thanks, the fault lies only in yourself.
Abuse no one and no thing, for abuse turns the wise ones to fools and
robs
the spirit of its vision.
When it comes your time to die, be not like those whose hearts are filled
with the fear of death, so that when their time comes they weep and pray
for a little more time to live their lives over again in a different way.
Sing your death song and die like a hero going home."

                                      Chief Tecumseh, Shawnee Nation
