On Mon, 29 Dec 1997, Starchild wrote:

>  Hi rave friends...
> 
>         BlackAdder (Patrick) says the end -- re-legalizing marijuana --
> doesn't justify the means of moving toward legalization under the auspices
> of the Medical Marijuana Law, which some (not all) Californians voted for
> on a narrower basis.

You really need to do a better job reading what people write. 

The CBC and their ilk aren't "moving towards legalization under the
auspices of the Medical Marijuana Law," they have been lying, misusing
and attempting to hide behind the law in order to distribute marijuana to
anyone who wants it. That is a far, far different thing from "moving
towards legalization." 

And I would amend your "some (not all)" to read *most*(not all). If it
were indeed only some, then Dennis Perone and company would not had to
have hid behind the facade of helping the ill.  

>         But Patrick seems to feel that the ends DO justify the means when
> the end is guaranteeing marijuana to the gravely ill who need it, by means
> of cooperating with the drug warriors in restricting the access of everyone
> else to this wonderful drug.

What I feel is that the CBC is seeing the result of their lies. And the
truly sad thing is that the ill are suffering because of the lies. 

>         While I have compassion for those who need pot for conditions like
> cancer and AIDS, 

Do you? Really? Seemingly you endorse the utter misuse of 215, so much in
fact that it risks the availability of medical marijuana to the people
with cancer and AIDS. I would hardly classify this as compassion.
Selfish and self-serving would be more appropriate terms. 

> I also have compassion for the thousands if not millions
> of people currently wasting their lives in jail because they sold or used
> marijuana.

Where is the legislation to free them? Where is the legislation to
legalize pot for anyone for any reason? I will gladly sign both of them. 
But that was not what the writers of 215 stated that their propostion was
for. That is not what the text of the propostion stated either. 

>         Because the presence of marijuana for any use makes those who argue
> that the plant has no value look ridiculous, medical marijuana patients
> will have no secure guarantee of legal protection until the value of pot is
> widely recognized, which means re-legalization.

So where's the bill? I haven't seen it. 

>         Therefore those of us who believe what you put into your body
> should be your choice are ultimately in this together.  

Most certainly not. I do not consider falsehoods and using the ill as
human shields in this battle to be acceptable behaviour and have no
respect for those that would do so. 

> We must not allow our movement to be divided by a short-sighted defense
> of marijuana on narrow medical grounds, a position which is not
> sustainable.  

You might start by encouraging those that have been abusing the law that
they help create to use it for the purpose it was intended: helping the
ill. This would at least give them some credibility and at least the
appearance of legitimacy, properties which the seem to be sorely lacking. 

> We must not abandon our brothers and sisters in jail out of fear of
> losing what we have gained so far, which is merely a small
> step.

"One step forward. Two steps back." 

>         I strongly encourage all ravers to stand up for the fundamental
> human right to use any and all drugs, for whatever reason.  It's your
> life... if you're not harming others shouldn't it be your choice?

And I would add:

"If you choose to use deception as a tool in order to assert this right, 
be prepared to wake up one day and wonder why you are so much like the
people you despise."

In a message dated 97-12-29 15:08:15 EST, randdream@hotmail.com writes:

<< From Reagan;
 
 >  BA is not saying that pot is a bad choice to use as medicine..he sees 
 it 
 >as wrong to use medicine as an excuse to legalize pot.
 
  While I highly respect Patricks opinion I am in diasagreement here with 
 him and would like to point out that he sounds a tiny bit bitter in his 
 comments on Dennis Peron (this coming from someone who knows how to 
 sound bitter).
 
  Pot is (IMO) an effective medication for some ills. Getting Pot to a 
 legal status *despite the intentions involved* is a step foward for 
 those who are suffering. Not only in the relief of a persons suffering 
 but especially as it gives the individual power over their medication. 
 The patient can grow their own rather than relying on huge corporations 
 (who care only about the dollar, not someones health) to provide relief. 
 And typically the corporations supply addictive and dangerous (when 
 compared to Pot) drugs to ill people.
 
  Dennis did a lot of people a favor by writing 215 and the voters of 
 California bear as much responsibility in it's passage as Dennis.
 
 
 
 >.these are *2
 >seperate issues* which are wanting 1) the legalization of pot for only
 >medical use and wanting 2) the legalization of pot just to be able to 
 get
 >high!
 
  And what if a person *just wants to get high* (oh the horror). Is that 
 so terrible? Particularly when it involves one of the safest drugs 
 known??? And what if wanting to get high is a form of self-medication? I 
 would rather be a mellow person from Pot smoking than from taking 
 Prozac!
 
 
 
 >...CBC has mixed the issues and are now paying for it!
 
  Not really. The order to stop selling Pot is not set in stone and even 
 if does become so, Pot can still be distributed free of charge. It just 
 can't be sold.
 
  A useful thing to remember is that we are all different. Some people 
 seem to operate in this world better when they are stoned. Others seem 
 to operate better when they are sober. Dennis has provided us not only 
 with a choice, but has also opened up research on medical pot. I thank 
 him for that.
 
 hugz,
 
 
 Ran D. Dreams >>


Thank you for putting in these words.  More power.

In a message dated 97-12-29 15:28:02 EST, blkadder@value.net writes:

<< You have to understand that I have *0* problem with the use of marijuana,
 for medicinal or for any other reason. What I object vehemently to is the 
 misuse of the ill as a front. Ultimately, when it is found that this moron
 has been distributing marijuana to anyone who wants it, the people that
 stand to lose the most are those with a medical condition for which it
 could prove useful. The people that 215 was obsentisbly supposed to help.

Though I agree it is wrong to use the sick as a scapegoat, 215 did benefit
some of these people.  Then again I could always go into a new age docta's
office and say I have extremely bad cramps and the only thing that helps is
marijuana.  Who knows.  Damn, if it were legal, medically, industrially and
recreationally, there would be less crime in  the US, and we, as a country
would benefit greatly.  Though I do believe regulations should be held on the
recreational aspect, such as those held on alcohol, I don't believe minors
should have easy access to this substance.
What Dennis Peron plans to do if he is elected to office is pardon all those
held in prison for marijuana crimes.  Is that so wrong?  Even though part of
that is for his own personal benefit.
We all just have to ask ourselves, who is the lesser of the two evils?
Ms. K1dd

Sounds real good. Just joined the list. Sort of on tour. I'm currently
touring about 8 lists with almost 180 emails/day.  I'm working on a
script with some people form Austin about raves. I'll keep you posted if
you are interested and want to provide "constructive" feedback on the
story we are developing.

>From Toron-toe. Been to SF on a work trip to S-valley during the summer
and planning to revisit in March. Well, it's 4am and time for da Hen to
take off his pvc silvers and crash out.

But I just wanted to say I'm really enjoying this list. South African
one is really fun, too. "Friendly" is the keyword.

Bye for now friends.

da Hen                            http://www.interlog.com/~hen

Leslie Ayres wrote:

> Good morning, all!
>
> I would like to thank every single amazing person who came out to
> Beautiful
> People Saturday night... this party was ALL GOOD!!!  and that is
> because of
> the people who were involved in creating it, and the people who came
> to
> contribute their energy to everyone's good time!  you all rock!
>
> Setup was so smooth and easy, it was like the space was welcoming us
> ...
> and shortly before the doors opened, i went outside and saw the mellow
> and
> wonderful people who were waiting to get in, and knew it was going to
> be a
> special night.. and it was.
>
> >From beginning to end, everyone I saw was smiling, dancing, happy,
> enjoying
> themselves.  We didn't have one incident requiring medical attention,
> and
> Karma Patrol's corner had only one real guest, a girl who had a short
> bout
> with the stomach flu.
>
> It was never too crowded (except in the hall occasionally), and you
> could
> go pretty much anywhere on the dance floor and have room to let
> yourself
> dance freely.  It got hot in a few corners, but you could move near a
> door
> and cool down quickly.  It did get a little smoky, but hey, maybe i'm
> sensitive to that since i quit a month ago and still have those
> cravings!
>
> All you crazy kids who dressed up looked so amazing, all bright and
> sparking and smiling and happy, passing out your candy and toys (Haze,
> that
> toy scorpion's going on my computer) ...
>
> And i got to see so many many people who i love to see out.... for
> every
> person who i missed because they were out of town for the holidays,
> there
> was one who had moved away in the past year, but was back for the
> holidays
> and came out to party with us...
>
> I got to meet so many sfravers i hadn't before .... and was wishing i
> had
> the money and energy to create a sfrave booth with a photo wall.... if
> we
> had a polaroid camera, each sfraver could sort of "sign in" at the
> booth
> when they came, and have their photo taken, and we could post it up
> with
> their name on a wall.... so that everyone could see who was there, and
> know
> exactly what to look for, wouldn't that be cool?  (anyone who has the
> energy to do this, go for it!!!)
>
> to echo what greg said in the morning (after that great group hug!),
> this
> party showed how wonderful responsible raving can be, and we all hope
> that
> this is a taste of what the next year of partying holds for us.
>
> I know that lots of people think $20 is a lot for a party.... and
> while i
> wish it didn't have to be that way, it's important to recognize that
> it is
> more and more difficult to throw underground parties that don't get
> busted... i partied for 2-1/2 years before i was at a party that got
> busted
> (FnF last halloween)... and sadly, now i'm so used to it that i feel
> grateful at little undergrounds when we make it until morning.
>
> And that is why a permitted party was the priority for harmony.  Yes,
> throwing legal parties is expensive, and it does mean we have to have
> security and the police will be around.  But it also means that we can
>
> dance and be together safely and securely, and i think that's worth a
> whole
> lot more than the extra $5 or so.
>
> There was a uniformed cop who strolled through the party a few times
> the
> other night.... two different people told me that they were nervous
> about
> him, and went up and asked him if he was going to shut us down... he
> said
> "no, i'm being paid to be here."  and they asked him what he
> thought....
> and he looked at the dance floor filled with happy people dancing
> under
> words that said  things like "respect" and "self-esteem" and
> "friendship"
> and the crazy harmony letters and banners and he said "it's pretty
> great"
> ....  and that's something he will take with him, as another level of
> understanding about what raving can be about.
>
> And a special thanks to the crew.  every single person on this crew
> kicked
> butt, worked their ass off, and had a great time doing it!  you guys
> are
> amazing!!  and this time my daughter worked with us too, and that was
> so
> great for me.
>
> So if I didn't get a chance to say it personally to all of you who
> were
> there, thank you for coming and making Beautiful People a night to
> always
> remember.  My favorite moment was dancing in front of Brian and Brad
> from
> Moontribe on 2x4, they were spinning the sickest trance and loving the
>
> people dancing in front of them, and Greg was actually *dancing* to my
>
> left, all candied out in his freaky party clothes and crazy white knit
> hat,
> and i looked around the room and realized i was surrounded by people i
> know
> and love, and we were grooving together.  Yep, *that* is what it's all
>
> about, and that is magic.
>
> much love to everyone, thanks for being part of my life in 1997,
>
> leslie




From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Dec 30 10:40:18 1997

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 30 Dec 1997 10:40:15 -0000
Received: from [208.196.121.147] (sf-ip-2-124.ziplink.net [208.196.121.124])
	by ziplink.net (8.8.7/8.8.7) with SMTP id FAA11829;
	Tue, 30 Dec 1997 05:40:02 -0500 (EST)
X-Sender: dreamer@pop3.ziplink.net
Message-Id: <v01530503b0ce66847df9@[208.196.121.147]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 30 Dec 1997 02:42:22 -0800
To: Rave Friends <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)
Subject: Re: raving=business? was:Expensive Parties
Cc: Michael Standish <standish@sirius.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi rave-friends,

        Some (lengthy) thoughts on Kim & Michael's conversation...

>Quoth kim:
>>Nothing.  Businesses are all good.  A rave is not a business.
>
>Kim, before I begin, let me say that I have always, and continue to have
>the great admiration and respect for you. However, "A rave is not a
>business."? That's well... silly. There is business going on throughout the
>rave scene: rekkid stores, clothing stores, flyer designers, drug dealers,
>glow stick sellers, all but perhaps 10% of promoters.

        Then blessed be the 10%!  And blessed be those rave-oriented
businesspeople who frequently think about the good of the scene as well as
their bottom line...
>
>>Raves are not concerts. One thing I love about parties is that
>>it's more of an interactive experience....if you pay a lot of money for an
>>event it separates the "performers" from the "audience"...and I don't like
>>that.
>>It makes it seem as though the djs and promoters are on a different "level"
>>than the people going to the party.
>
>Hmmm, I don't see the connection. This is just my experience but: I've spun
>at massives where I was running out from behind the decks to hug people,
>and met people after my set and gave them hugs and candy, and I've been to
>free parties where I hung out behind the decks with all the cool people.
>
>>I feel that raves and money-making should be kept separate. Throwing a party
>>in my opinion should not be a business venture.
>
>That may well be so, but the reality is that most raves are business ventures.
>
>>If you are at an event that you are throwing, and you are not having fun,
>>what's the point? I think running around worrying about "losing money" is
>>lame....and takes away from the party.
>
>Even a $5 UG has to worry about losing money.. The party may get busted
>early, or only a few people show up, because the big party down the street
>had all the right DJs. The rent still has to be paid. The sound system
>still needs to be paid for, unless you happen to know someone with a phat
>system, but that system would exist, because it works other shows for
>money. Even free renegades run the risk of having the sound system
>confiscated. Worrying about losing money sucks, but it's not gonna go away.

        This is where charging according to motive comes in (a concept I
mentioned in my recent message about DJ income).  If I were a sound system
owner, I would charge the going rate to promoters throwing parties as
business ventures, but I would let non-commercial friendly vibe promoters
use it for little or nothing, perhaps merely loaning it on condition they
replace it if damaged or confiscated.
        Promoters can return the favor of getting talent and equipment on
the cheap by giving exposure to up-and-coming DJs and sound and visuals
people, and maybe turning them on to better-paying opportunities.
>
>>I would say that if someone is out to make a buck, they might be supporting
>>the scene THEY love, but it is not the scene _I_ love.
>
>Then I guess that the scene you love is only a small fraction of the rave
>scene. I like massives and UGs. I have not found that the size of the party
>or the promoters motives are indicators of how good a party will be.

        I have not found the size of the party to be a good indicator of
how good it will be, although *very* large parties are rarely among the
best, in my experience.  However I have found the intentions of the
promoters to be an *extremely good* indicator.  Admittedly I don't have any
way of looking inside their minds or really knowing anyone's true motives,
but then again I don't think this is really necessary in most cases to have
a pretty good idea of what kind of party it will be.
        A friend and I had a conversation recently about how cool it would
be if someone was able to develop a scientific instrument to measure the
vibe.  I'm not saying this is possible, because a lot of what makes a party
"good" is subjective.  But I think many of us have also experienced that a
lot of it isn't.  There are parties where it is very difficult not to enjoy
yourself!
        And it's my belief that it starts with the promoters.  A promoter
with a good vibe and good intentions is more likely to have friends with
similar attitudes, and the opposite is also true.  And the
friends/acquaintances of the promoters usually make up a good fraction of
the attendance at any party.
        These people in turn bring their friends, often others of like
spirit, through word of mouth, and the vibe, or lack thereof, of the party
is largely established before anyone ever arrives.
        Another way a promoter's intentions make a difference:  Someone
who's throwing a party as a business venture is going to be more worried
about the outcome, financially speaking.  If their primary goal is making
money, rather than spreading joy and helping people have fun, they won't
care as much if their security guards act like thugs.  In fact, better to
have thuggish, intrusive security guards, because that means less chance of
someone bringing something inside that could cause damage or create a
disturbance and get them busted.
        If the promoter's concern is money, not fun, it won't bother them
that much if people have to wait outside a while in the cold -- after all,
a long line outside may attract more paying customers to the event.
        And making people pour out their water before entering increases
the chances they'll plunk down $3 for the bottled water you're selling
inside.  All these things, of course, contribute to bringing peoples'
spirits down.  If you have a mega-watt sound system and their favorite DJs
on tap, and they take good drugs, it may not matter too much.  People may
still have a darn good time, and be willing to come back again.  Maybe
that's what you're counting on.  But how much better it can be <sigh>...

>>It really shouldn't have to cost hundreds or thousands of dollars to throw a
>>party.
>
>It shouldn't have to, but it does. I have worked on $5 UGs with budgets in
>the thousands.
>
>>You can throw a perfectly fun, exciting and creative party for very cheap.
>
>Yes, it can be done, but not for many more than 400 people. And if you keep
>throwing phat parties for 400 people, more and more people will want to
>come, and then you have to be selective about who gets tickets, and then
>you get a rep for being all stuck up and elitist. (yes I've seen it happen.)

        Isn't it strange that it should be *more* expensive per person to
put on a bigger event?  With economy of scale, it should work the other
way.  You have certain fixed costs, like space rental, security, medical,
DJs, sound, lights, decorations, and whatever other fun stuff like free
fruit or bouncy castles you want to have to enhance peoples' experience, so
the more people attending, the less you should have to charge per person.
Right?  Yes, until the authorities step into the picture!
        Of course if you aren't doing it to make a buck, you're more likely
to get one or more of the above necessities at reduced or zero cost.
That's because there ARE people who charge according to motive.  8)

>>People wanting to make money is not what makes america great, and it is in
>>fact one of the things that causes me to be most ashamed of the U.S., that
>>so many people will treat other living things poorly in order to make a buck.
>
>There are ways to make money without fucking people over. Just because
>nearly all large corporations are evil, doesn't make everyone who tries to
>make a buck evil.

        Very well said, and I couldn't agree more.  The profit motive may
have a negative impact on the rave scene, but for civilization as a whole,
I think it's been very good.  I don't particularly want to go back to
living in grass huts without heat or electricity and scavenging for my
food.

>>For example, is using workers in third-world countries and paying them $4 a
>>day or less like Nike a good example of the entrepreneurial spirit? After all,
>>Nike sure profits from it....

        Unless they are slaves, which does happen and is a different
situation entirely, the person working at Nike making $4 a day chose to
work there because it was the best job around.  The argument that "they
have to work there, or they would starve" just doesn't wash, because it
leaves unanswered the obvious question of how they were surviving before
Nike came along.
        Companies making goods overseas also have to pay taxes (and
sometimes extortion money, just the way promoters here have to buy
bust-free parties by paying for permits and/or hiring cops for security!)
to their host countries, and tariffs to the U.S. government, if they bring
the goods back here to sell, not to mention corporate income tax.  Although
there are significant expenses like fancy ad campaigns and ridiculous CEO
salaries that a company can control, government payoffs represent a huge
chunk of cash that Nike, et.al. are forced to spend just to stay in
business.
>
>Nike are not "a person who organizes and manages a business undertaking,
>assuming the risk for the sake of the profit"(Webster's NewWorld
>Dictionary) Nike are a big evil corporation from hell.
>>They don't expect to get in free to parties just because they sell
>>drugs.
>
>Too true, although they sometimes try to pay in drugs. I had a hippy crack
>dealer try to get in for a few balloons once. Fuck that! Tanks don't get
>past this doorman.

       Not even Sherman tanks?  You must be massive indeed!  ;)

>>bellligerant (sp?) if they are forced to pay (i have seen that happen with
>>numerous djs and promoters)
>>*giggling*
>
>Ha ha ha, no shit. That brings me back to sooooo many door shifts. It's
>kinda fun telling them to sit down and shut up until the promoter gets back.
>
>> whereas most massives are permitted and therefore
>>"bowing down to the man" so to speak?
>
>And as a result providing good value because they don't get busted.

        I'll bet many businesspeople said something like that about doing
business with non-Jews in Germany around the time the Nazis started
cracking down, too...
        If you don't think it's a comparable situation, then how much
repression is too much?  You gotta draw a line somewhere.  Personally I
think being forced to pay anything to assemble on private property for a
peaceable party is too much.  Indeed being forced to pay (or more
frequently, busted when we weren't even given the option of paying) for
using public land like a beach at night when no one else is using it and we
are taking effective measures to clean up after ourselves is equally wrong.
        Aren't drugs and raves (among other things) scapegoated for social
ills the way the Nazis scapegoated Jews?  If the answer is no, why are so
many ravers afraid to let their bosses know what they do on weekends?

Rave on,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

Dear Tina,

        A good point, and I'm not truly comfortable with people doing the
right thing if they were misled into doing it either.  But surely doing the
right thing for the wrong reason is better than doing the wrong thing?
Right?  Got it?   ;)

                                <<< Starchild >>>
>Hmmm,
>
>I was taught that two wrongs don't make a right.  Just because we might
>feel that our government lies and oppresses us does not mean that we
>should do the same.  So the war on drugs turned out to be a bad idea but
>how can we overcome the stupid decisions of the past if we use the same
>means to achieve goals we assume to be loftier?  We need to be different,
>creative, and honest, not redundant.
>
>Tina
>
>
>On Mon, 29 Dec 1997, Starchild wrote:
>
>>  Hi rave friends...
>>
>>         BlackAdder (Patrick) says the end -- re-legalizing marijuana --
>> doesn't justify the means of moving toward legalization under the auspices
>> of the Medical Marijuana Law, which some (not all) Californians voted for
>> on a narrower basis.
>>
>>         But Patrick seems to feel that the ends DO justify the means when
>> the end is guaranteeing marijuana to the gravely ill who need it, by means
>> of cooperating with the drug warriors in restricting the access of everyone
>> else to this wonderful drug.
>>
>>         While I have compassion for those who need pot for conditions like
>> cancer and AIDS, I also have compassion for the thousands if not millions
>> of people currently wasting their lives in jail because they sold or used
>> marijuana.
>>
>>         Because the presence of marijuana for any use makes those who argue
>> that the plant has no value look ridiculous, medical marijuana patients
>> will have no secure guarantee of legal protection until the value of pot is
>> widely recognized, which means re-legalization.
>>
>>         Therefore those of us who believe what you put into your body
>> should be your choice are ultimately in this together.  We must not allow
>> our movement to be divided by a short-sighted defense of marijuana on
>> narrow medical grounds, a position which is not sustainable.  We must not
>> abandon our brothers and sisters in jail out of fear of losing what we have
>> gained so far, which is merely a small step.
>>
>>         I strongly encourage all ravers to stand up for the fundamental
>> human right to use any and all drugs, for whatever reason.  It's your
>> life... if you're not harming others shouldn't it be your choice?
>>
>> May the bass be with us,

Precedence: bulk

I must say that this is one of the rare times that I actually agree with the
man known as the Black Adder. I have always felt that the campaign to legalize
Pot was in danger of being subverted due to the often times careless attitude
of some of the measures' supporters. After attending numerous rally's in
support of the issue(I dont puff weed--it heightens my already acute sense of
paranoia and anxiety), it became clear to me that either many of its
supporters are foolish in believing their actions would lead to a positive
outcome, or that the movement had been infiltrated by individuals attempting
to subvert the movement.
--Monty

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Dec 30 18:36:30 1997

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Re:  Re: Dennis Peron/Pot (NRR)
In-Reply-To: <7821d121.34a92ce1@aol.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


I also agree with Patrick, though he certainly has more vitriol in his
comments than I would use :)  If you talk to the folks working to set up
medical marijuana dispensaries in other counties, such as Santa Clara,
Santa Cruz, or San Mateo, you'll see a WORLD of difference in their
attitude, procedures, and approach than Peron's.  They are working with
local governments, local and state law enforcement, following zoning laws
and business regulations for medical institutions, and are following the
wording of 215 to the letter and making conservative interpretations where
necessary.  Peron's SF CBC doesn't even pay business taxes or business
registration fees to the city of SF.  SF as a city might have a higher
tolerance for this type of protest business than Santa Clara, but the fact
is that Peron's CBC is the biggest target of the anti-215 politicians, and
it threatens the existance of all the other medical marijuana establishments.

It doesn't concern me one whit that Peron wrote 215 and also wants pot
legalized for non-medical use.  I may even vote for him.  But he needs to
clean up the CBC and the attitude that 215 means that anyone with a cough
can name them their primary provider and thus get access.  

	Brian

sees this film!
a great way to start a new year!

if you've never heard about this film~~>
it's highly visual, thought provoking, and mind expanding...
an introspective high!
no conventional dialogue... just a beautiful sound track and astounding
visuals!

go by yourself... bring a friend... just go!  Go!  GO!


the calender said that it was playing until jan 5th!
at the red vic on haight street
every night 7:15 & 9:30pm

BARAKA
Dec 25 -30

Dir. Ron Fricke
In making Baraka, director/cinematographer Ron Fricke spent five years and
traveled to 24 countries exploring the meaning of the Sufi word "baraka,"
which rougly translates as "the essence of life from with the evolutionary
process unfolds." Tues-Thurs 7:15, 9:30
Additional shows: Thurs, Sat & Sun 2, 4:15

I also agree that using deception and exploiting sick
people to further your personal ambitions is the wrong approach
with this. I do believe that all substances should be legal and
regulated along with help for those that abuse them.
 I have mixed opinions about Peron. What ever you may think
of him...he IS a rebel and i happen to like rebels...america
was built by rebels. 

What if you applied the following logic to raves? You could
also say that undergrounds that are not permitted and violate
many laws are messing up the scene for those that want to do 
it legally. You could say that undergrounds, because they violate the
law and often result in police activity are giving raving
a bad name. I dont agree with that argument, just stating it
as a comparison to saying that Peron's tactics are messing
up the movement that wants to follow the law as regards medical 
marijuana.

If i had a choice i would choose someone besides Peron to lead
the fight to end the drug wars...but he seems to be the only
game in town as far as i know.

		foolish fish


Brian Behlendorf wrote:
> 
> I also agree with Patrick, though he certainly has more vitriol in his
> comments than I would use :)  If you talk to the folks working to set up
> medical marijuana dispensaries in other counties, such as Santa Clara,
> Santa Cruz, or San Mateo, you'll see a WORLD of difference in their

> and business regulations for medical institutions, and are following the
> wording of 215 to the letter and making conservative interpretations where
> necessary.  Peron's SF CBC doesn't even pay business taxes or business
> registration fees to the city of SF.  SF as a city might have a higher
> tolerance for this type of protest business than Santa Clara, but the fact
> is that Peron's CBC is the biggest target of the anti-215 politicians, and
> it threatens the existance of all the other medical marijuana establishments.

For what it's worth  . . .

>  "And then the programmers came to Jesus and asked:  'Master, which is
>  the greatest language of them all?'   And Jesus responded, saying
>  'The greatest language is the Language of Love.'
> 
>  And lo, the programmers did scoff and bicker among themselves,
>  because they had never heard of this language.  They had used COBOL
>  and Fortran and even PowerBuilder, and did not see how a language
>  they had never used could be better than all the languages they had
>  studied all their lives.
> 
>  So they confronted Jesus in an effort to trick Him and asked 'In this
>  new language called love, what are the most powerful commands
>  available to You?' And Jesus answered them, saying 'The language has
>  but two commands altogether:  Love God and Love Man.'
> 
>  And the programmers were further incensed and proclaimed to one
>  another:  'Perhaps he has developed a new RISC system with an
>  instruction set of two?  But how can these two instructions, which we
>  have never used before, be so much better than all the instructions
>  we have spent our lives learning and which we use every day?'
> 
>  And so they confronted Jesus again, and said:  'How is it that Your
>  two-instruction language can be so powerful?  Our languages have many
>  instructions, with many variables associated with each instruction.
>  The more instructions available, the more combinations of
>  instructions you can create and the more you can accomplish.  What
>  can You accomplish with only these two commands?'
> 
>  Then Jesus asked the programmers:  'If a man truly loves God with all
>  his heart and soul and mind, and truly loves his brother as much as
>  he loves himself, is there anything that such a man cannot
>  accomplish?'  And the programmers were sore perplexed and confused,
>  for they had never thought of it that way before.
> 
>  As the programmers continued to debate and discuss these issues,
>  Jesus asked:  'Are there those among you who would like to learn this
>  language called love?'
> 
>  And one programmer spoke right up, saying 'What is the training
>  schedule for this language?  Surely with only two commands, we can
>  learn this language in a matter of weeks, or with off-site training,
>  only a few days!'
> 
>  But Jesus responded:  'I can place the basic principles of this
>  language into your life in the blink of an eye, but to master the
>  language will take you a lifetime.'
> 
>  And a great uproar was heard among the programmers, for these were
>  bright programmers  and could master any set of commands in a short
>  time.  The roar turned to laughter as they joked about how foolish
>  anyone would be to start learning a language that took them so long
>  to master.  Then they slapped each other on the back and sauntered
>  back to their cubicles, knowing that this language must not be for
>  real, or if it was for real, it was not for them.'
> 
>  [VERY loosely based on Matthew 22:34-46]

-- 
And now, a shameless plug for my workplace!
Before you buy:
http://www.compare.net/
Information is Power

 ----------
From: Brian Behlendorf
I also agree with Patrick, though he certainly has more vitriol in his
comments than I would use :)  If you talk to the folks working to set up
medical marijuana dispensaries in other counties, such as Santa Clara,
Santa Cruz, or San Mateo, you'll see a WORLD of difference in their
attitude, procedures, and approach than Peron's.
 -=-=-==-
this is way true, at a recent summit of many of the delivery groups the
distinction between prop 215 and legalization-for-all was made quite
clear and, I believe, most groups affirmed that they didn't want to be
in the place of Peron of being the most obvious fast & loose dealer (&
media darling).

They are working with local governments, local and state law
enforcement, following zoning laws
and business regulations for medical institutions, and are following the
wording of 215 to the letter and making conservative interpretations
where
necessary.
 -=-=-=
well, some are, there is room for interpetation & experimentation but
there are plenty of groups who are to the letter & are forming
non-profits and other groups who only come close.

Peron's SF CBC doesn't even pay business taxes or business
registration fees to the city of SF.  SF as a city might have a higher
tolerance for this type of protest business than Santa Clara, but the
fact
is that Peron's CBC is the biggest target of the anti-215 politicians,
and
it threatens the existance of all the other medical marijuana
establishments.
 -=-=-==--=
probably the two biggest issues with peron's club are that it's
operating as a social center/nightclub/caberet AND undocumented users
can purchase without proof of medical need (Peron has seemingly always
dealt to second-hand dealers)

It doesn't concern me one whit that Peron wrote 215 and also wants pot
legalized for non-medical use.  I may even vote for him.  But he needs
to
clean up the CBC and the attitude that 215 means that anyone with a
cough
can name them their primary provider and thus get access.
 -==-=-=-=-
I wouldn't hold your breath - he isn't about to change anytime soon; his
tactics have kept him out of prison and his club is still open and he's
making loads of money, still.

I admire a lot that he has done but I hope that he isn't risking
patient's wellness by his carelessness; his certainly has done more with
in-your-face activism than thousands of folks who've been happy with
whatever laws are imposed on them.

sister kitty

On Tue, 30 Dec 1997 fish1111@pacbell.net wrote:

> 
> What if you applied the following logic to raves? You could
> also say that undergrounds that are not permitted and violate
> many laws are messing up the scene for those that want to do 
> it legally. 
> You could say that undergrounds, because they violate the
> law and often result in police activity are giving raving
> a bad name. I dont agree with that argument, 

I am glad that you would not agree with that argument, as the "logic" you
apply to the situation is not directly applicable. 

1) A promoter obtaining permits and paying off the establishment(legally)
   is in no way affected by those throwing illegal parties. 

2) The "undergrounds" in your hypothetical senario did not choose to work
    within the framework of the law by getting legislation passed to help
   the ill through their parties and then misusing that legislation,
   jepordizing the health and well-being of those they were supposed to
   be helping through their own selfishness. 

> just stating it as a comparison to saying that Peron's tactics are
> messing up the movement that wants to follow the law as regards medical 
> marijuana.

Again it isn't a good comparison. 

The problem with Peron is that now all the anti-drug folks now have
something to point to and say "See, you were lying, we knew this isn't
what you were about." And you know what? They are absolutely right. And
this severely undermines the credibility of the *entire* legalization
movement. 

And instead of getting the fool out of there, people want to vote for him
for governor. What a pitiful choice. The anti-drug movement couldn't have
a better ally than in Dennis Peron, because he has no chance of success
due to his irresponsibility. 

> If i had a choice i would choose someone besides Peron to lead
> the fight to end the drug wars...but he seems to be the only
> game in town as far as i know.

He isn't the only game in town. He has the most recognition, which is a
far different thing.

From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)

Cc: Rave Friends <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

        Well Patrick, "to distribute marijuana to anyone who wants it" from
a legal club is de facto legalization, which I would say is indeed, "moving
towards legalization."

        Although I think you are *probably* right that most people voting
for Prop. 215 did not vote with the intention of moving toward
legalization, a significant number did, including myself.

        If I recall correctly, the percentage of Californians who say in
surveys that they favor pot legalization is around 25%.  I think we can
assume that nearly all those in favor of legalization who voted, voted yes
on 215.  Also, I think there were other "yes" voters who opposed immediate
re-legalization, but who favored 215 as a more gradual solution, with the
goal being eventual legalization if the approach seemed to work.  Given
these factors, it seems likely to me that a *very* significant part of the
pro-215 vote was a pro-legalization vote.

        Personally I have always been outspoken about re-legalizing drugs,
and I don't think I deceived anyone regarding Proposition 215 -- I remember
consistently talking about it as a means to help end the War on Drugs.

        More to the point however, why should someone like myself who
believes in civil disobedience when it comes to drug laws feel they have to
obey the letter of Proposition 215 when it says only persons with a medical
need should get marijuana?  Such a restriction is as immoral and
unconstitutional as the rest of the War on Drugs, and many of us have felt
this way from the beginning.

        Allow me to make an analogy:  Someone I don't know steals $100 from
me for no good reason, and a friend of mine knows who took it and says to
them, "Just return $10 of the money and everything will be cool."  My
friend tells me the thief has agreed to return $10 of the money, and wants
to know if that's okay with me.  "Sure," I say, figuring getting $10 back
is better than nothing.  Let's say my friend assumes that my consent to
getting the $10 back means I won't try to get the other $90 also when I
find out who took it, even though I explicitly never agree to this.  Let's
say that based on what my friend tells him, the thief also believes he can
return $10 and everything will be cool.  Should I make sure and let my
friend know otherwise?  Frankly, I don't care about my friend's
relationship with the thief -- I think he'd be better off not having
friends like that.  And if he's my friend, he should be glad to see me get
my money back without involving him in a lie.  Deceptive?  Yeah.  But if
the thief comes by with $10, and I make him give me back the other $90 as
well, is justice served?  You bet!

        If it wasn't obvious, in the analogy I'm the people who want to use
pot recreationally, my friend is the people who want it for medical use
only, and the government is the thief.

        I hope this has helped you understand how I feel about it.  And I
don't think I'm in danger of waking up just like the people I despise,
because I have no intention of putting people in jail for living lifestyles
I don't approve of. "Despise" is too strong a word anyway -- I don't hate
anyone, I just believe some people can be extremely dangerous and
misguided.

        And if you agree that our goal should be legal protection of drug
use as a fundamental human right, then might I suggest that we focus most
of our energy on that, instead of fighting with each other about the
tactics we use to get there?

Much love,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

>fact that it risks the availability of medical marijuana to the people

>You might start by encouraging those that have been abusing the law that
>they help create to use it for the purpose it was intended: helping the
>ill. This would at least give them some credibility and at least the
>appearance of legitimacy, properties which the seem to be sorely lacking.

Dear Rave friends,

        In Dennis Peron's defense, I do not think he is "exploiting" sick
people.  Dennis worked long and hard to make medical marijuana legal.
Whatever you think of how he has handled 215 as law, without him it might
not *be* the law.  He is gay, and lost a lover to AIDS, who was able to
ease some of his suffering by the use of pot.  He works around sick people
who need pot for medical reasons all the time.  If you ever hear the man
speak, you can tell he is coming from a very emotional and heartfelt place.
Maybe it is his excessive compassion that makes him somewhat of a loose
cannon politically...
        But then, you could have said the same thing about Gandhi.  When he
was trying to free India from the British, I'm sure people felt his methods
were too radical and were hurting the cause of the Indian people by
threatening to make the colonial rulers crack down harder...
        I'm not saying Dennis is perfect, or that he's comparable to
Gandhi.  But there is a long, proud tradition of radical political action,
and you know what?  When you look back at history, more often than not the
radicals were right.  Dennis Peron may simply be broad-minded enough, at
least in the case of pot, to understand this.

From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Re: Dennis Peron/Pot (NRR)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

i am another who is in agreement with patrick on the peron/medical
marijuana topic.  my personal view is that marijuana should be legal, but
that the same laws should apply as alcohol (i.e. driving while stoned) for
the protection of others.

but when the voters passed 215, they were passing a bill to allow growing
and dispensing marijuana to people with a medical need.

while many may have had a deeper agenda to move toward complete
legalization, that was not what the bill said, and it was not what they
voted on.

i, too, have been in situations where is was very clear to me that the
cannibis action movement has been using the shield of medicinal use as a
foot in the door to total legalization, such as attending a meeting where
the medical use issue was never mentioned, and little was accomplished
because the attendees were so stoned that there was little participation or
discussion in the real issues.  (true quote:  "At last month's meeting, we
came to three conclusions.... but I can only remember two of them... can
anyone remember all three?"  .... total silence in a smoky room....)

and i have personally seen the loose controls that have allowed large
quantities of pot, theoretically sold under "compassionate use" protection,
walk out the door of the cannibis club into the hands of people who are
*not* the ones the law was meant to provide for.

like it or not, pushing the limits of this law, while shouting
"compassionate use" is dishonest, and puts the entire issue completely at
risk.

if prop 215 was meant to be the first step on the road to legalization,
then it must be respected as such... one foot in the door doesn't mean you
can just push the door down because you think have the leverage.

while many of us would have voted for a bill to completely legalize
marijuana, the reality is that it probably would not have passed.  so we
supported what was available to us, and what we felt was the right thing to
do for the people the bill was meant to help.

starchild, i tried to and failed to follow your analogy about having
someone steal from you.... i'd suggest that this one may be more similar:

your entire state is living under a 10:00 pm curfew, which most of you
think is ridiculous.  you'd like to change that curfew, but instead of
trying to get it completely abolished, because that might fail, and leave
you where you started, you instead negotiate that certain needy people are
allowed be exempt from any curfew, based on very specific criteria.

but then someone starts issuing the passes to stay out all night to all
sorts of people who don't fit that criteria, and the powers that be are
pretty upset by it, because they see this as abusing the deal that was
negotiated.  The risk is now that they may decide to rescind the deal
entirely, even to the truly needy people, and just go back to how it was
before.

i think if you say you're willing to take your incremental win, you should
respect the terms of it.... and then when it's time, you can renegotiate
and go for midnight, or 1am, and when people are used to that, then you are
ready to abolish the curfew entirely.

this is what working within the system is all about....  and changing laws
means having the strategic mindset and honesty to work within the system,
whether it's to take steps to gradually legalize pot, or to throw parties
that don't get shut down by the police because you have ignored the laws.

you have the choice to take the risks of doing it outside the system if you
want to, certainly, but don't think that doing that is ever going to make
any real progress within the system...  and when you are trying to change a
law, if you're not trying to do it within the system, you have no chance of
success.

leslie

>>[starchild said....]        Allow me to make an analogy:  Someone I don't
>>know steals $100 from
>>me for no good reason, and a friend of mine knows who took it and says to
>>them, "Just return $10 of the money and everything will be cool."  My
>>friend tells me the thief has agreed to return $10 of the money, and wants
>>to know if that's okay with me.  "Sure," I say, figuring getting $10 back
>>is better than nothing.  Let's say my friend assumes that my consent to
>>getting the $10 back means I won't try to get the other $90 also when I
>>find out who took it, even though I explicitly never agree to this.  Let's
>>say that based on what my friend tells him, the thief also believes he can
>>return $10 and everything will be cool.  Should I make sure and let my
>>friend know otherwise?  Frankly, I don't care about my friend's
>>relationship with the thief -- I think he'd be better off not having
>>friends like that.  And if he's my friend, he should be glad to see me get
>>my money back without involving him in a lie.  Deceptive?  Yeah.  But if
>>the thief comes by with $10, and I make him give me back the other $90 as
>>well, is justice served?  You bet!
>
>[leslie said....]  starchild, i tried to and failed to follow your analogy
>about having
>someone steal from you....

I think that Starchild's analogy is working under the assumption that we
have the innate right to "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" as
long as our actions do not infringe unduly upon the rights of others to do
the same.  When the government instated laws that did not allow us the
freedom to life our lives as we like (i.e. took away our right to use
drugs), they stole something from us -- in Starchild's analogy, the person
stole the $100 from us.  Our friend (those who support legalizing marijuana
for medical use) have negotiated with the theif (the government) to get
back some of the innate rights that have been taken from us.  But if we are
able to force the theif to return the rest of the rights that are owed to
us, why shouldn't we?  If we have an innate right to liberty, shouldn't we
defy a law that attempts to take those rights away?

>>>[starchild said....]        Allow me to make an analogy:  Someone I don't
>>>know steals $100 from
>>>me for no good reason, and a friend of mine knows who took it and says to
>>>them, "Just return $10 of the money and everything will be cool."  My
>>>friend tells me the thief has agreed to return $10 of the money, and wants
>>>to know if that's okay with me.  "Sure," I say, figuring getting $10 back
>>>is better than nothing.  Let's say my friend assumes that my consent to
>>>getting the $10 back means I won't try to get the other $90 also when I
>>>find out who took it, even though I explicitly never agree to this.  Let's
>>>say that based on what my friend tells him, the thief also believes he can
>>>return $10 and everything will be cool.  Should I make sure and let my
>>>friend know otherwise?  Frankly, I don't care about my friend's
>>>relationship with the thief -- I think he'd be better off not having
>>>friends like that.  And if he's my friend, he should be glad to see me get
>>>my money back without involving him in a lie.  Deceptive?  Yeah.  But if
>>>the thief comes by with $10, and I make him give me back the other $90 as
>>>well, is justice served?  You bet!
>>
>>[leslie said....]  starchild, i tried to and failed to follow your analogy
>>about having
>>someone steal from you....
>
and then robin said....

>I think that Starchild's analogy is working under the assumption that we
>have the innate right to "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" as
>long as our actions do not infringe unduly upon the rights of others to do
>the same.  When the government instated laws that did not allow us the
>freedom to life our lives as we like (i.e. took away our right to use
>drugs), they stole something from us -- in Starchild's analogy, the person
>stole the $100 from us.  Our friend (those who support legalizing marijuana
>for medical use) have negotiated with the theif (the government) to get
>back some of the innate rights that have been taken from us.  But if we are
>able to force the theif to return the rest of the rights that are owed to
>us, why shouldn't we?  If we have an innate right to liberty, shouldn't we
>defy a law that attempts to take those rights away?

(hi robin!)

while your description makes it a little clearer, i think my perceptual
problem here is that i think we're dreaming if we think that the
"thief"/government can be likened to someone we can beat up and steal our
money back from (that was what you had in mind, starchild? the "thief"
would appear with the $10 in hand, and you'd knock him over the head or
whatever and demand or steal back the other $90???)...

i don't think that's very realistic, expecially if you're a 2-foot-tall
weakling and the thief is the big bad giant thug who's a hundred times, a
thousand times, a million times, your size, and who has a whole army of
legislation and enforcement behind him, and who will happily use that to
show you who has the power when he realizes you think you set him up.

to me, while i see some of the reasoning in this analogy, it's a little
like the kindergarten kid thinking he's going to beat up the boogy man...
it's dreaming.  you cannot "force" or trick the government into making drug
use legal... and you cannot bluster your way through the current laws.  to
change the rules, you have to work within the system that is set up for
changing the rules.  because the "government" and the "legal system" is
really just people who are enforcing the rules that they are told to
enforce.

i don't like it either, i just have a different viewpoint about who's going
to be the winner in the "steal it back from the thief" scenario...

(there is a separate tangent about whether we truly have "innate" rights,
and what "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness" really protects for
us... but that's another day!)

leslie

Received: from [207.33.94.148] (oak4-148.value.net [207.33.94.148]) by value.net (8.8.7/8.7.4) with SMTP id SAA22653; Tue, 30 Dec 1997 18:09:28 -0800 (PST)

Precedence: bulk

[hi leslie!]

>
>while your description makes it a little clearer, i think my perceptual
>problem here is that i think we're dreaming if we think that the
>"thief"/government can be likened to someone we can beat up and steal our
>money back from (that was what you had in mind, starchild? the "thief"
>would appear with the $10 in hand, and you'd knock him over the head or
>whatever and demand or steal back the other $90???)...

I agree with both you and Starchild.  I think that to create the best
society for everyone, we need to recognize the "innate" right to life and
liberty, but I also think it is difficult to force our government to give
it to us.  Especially when our government has the two-faced attitude of
voicing a belief in liberty, while only endorsing it when it is convenient.
And, of course, most of the populace is willing to sacrifice some freedoms
for the illusion of safety.  However, just because it may be quite
difficult to force the government to give us the liberties we have been
promised, I also think we have to continue to try.  Maybe coming up to the
big monster and trying to knock it over the head is not the best way,
though.  In all those fairy tales where David kills Goliath, where the
tortosie beats the hare, where Hanzel and Gretel kill the witch, where the
golden-haired princess outwits Rumplestiltskin -- each of the strong, bad
monsters was not confronted on the field of it's strength, but was instead
defeated by finding it's Achille's heel.

In-Reply-To: UNIX:IMCEAX400-c=US+3Ba=+20+3Bp=Apollo+20Group+2C+20In+3Bo=CorpExchGtwy+3Bdda+3ASMTP=sfraves-owner-Steven+5FAllas+2Eoramail=apol's message of 12-30-97 18:26

people seem to have a notion that government is deceitful and two faced...let
me just say that I'm sure we don't even know how deep this deception penetrates
our lives...might I suggest a reading of a document called "The Committee of
300" by I believe Dr. Malone...the man spills what he's learned having worked
in the intelligence community and being sickened by their activities of
control through cooperation of a secret society shaping the world's
history...not to induce paranoia but I take it for granted that every piece of
e-mail I send is recorded somewhere...this is not news to anyone...I agree with
the person who said that you must work within the system to change
things...rules will be followed, change the rules and they will be followed no
matter how ludicrous...to the people who are in favor of legalizing drugs, you
say freedom to control one's life and the pursuit of it should be honored...so
you would have legal access to crack, meth, heroin, coke...everything and
anything people want to do?...just a little recreational self-destruction?...I
would loosely quote Derrick May who said, "Fuck the drugs, I don't need it to
feel the vibe.  It all started with the music, drugs don't make it real."...I
suppose there are people who will argue that drugs expand the mind and give
you a broader horizon with different points of view...I can understand that,
but can we look into ourselves and find the humanity and empathy to relate to
our fellow ravers?...or do drugs in various forms have to play a part in
it?...the last massive I went to was Tekno Tribe's Halloween and I saw very
little tweaky freakies there, made me feel good...but maybe it's my wishful
thinking that the music is enough, I do know that music saved my life and still
does from the redundant repetitiveness and blatant brow beating to conform to
society's standards...and I do know for a fact that once when the music was
new and no one knew what techno or house was and it's various evolutions, once
there were people who felt that the music was in and of itself the drug...I say
enough is enough, vibe all night using only your energy and when you're tired,
you know you danced your ass off to the max your body could take...vibe all
night sober, really feel and think about the music...then ask yourself, was
that enough?...if it wasn't and you need to take something to make it better
for you, then the music cannot save your ehtereal life...you've bought in for
the duration...peace...

moki

Hello Sfraves,

Well after sleeping for the last two days I have finally stirred up enough
energy to write this post. So here it is...

Last Saturday, at Harmony's Beautiful People, I was so happy with
everything. (which is hard to do, I am usually the one saying we could have
had more lights, or more this, or less that, etc. ) Everything seemed to
click right into place that night... The Harmony Crew did a fantastic job
setting that place up for what was a completely phat party! A huge thank
you and mad props goes to everyone who helped put that party together. You
all should be very proud of yourselves!!!  

I just wanted to touch on something that I spoke about at the end of the
party... some of you were there remember but for those of you who weren't,
here it is... Our goal for this party was to highten everyones' awareness
of their inner self, and each other. Our props were geared towards all
verbal messages, and words or ideas, which we hoped all of you took home
with you from the party.

Our message to you, was simply to be more conscious of you and your scene.
Be responsible with your parting, and always be safe. You are responsible
for your own happiness, and you can make a party into whatever you want it
to be. So if you want a happy, fun-filled, safe, positive, pure and clean
party... Then you need to make it happen! And at Beautiful People, on
Saturday Dec. 27th... We all created just what we wanted... and it was
AMAZING!!! I can't thank all of you who came enough for making it such an
emotionally successful night. All of you are the best! So thank you, thank
you, thank you!

We all had so much fun at that party... It will go down in my book as one
of the funnest BP parties I have seen so far (and that is a lot... ouch my
back ; ). I thought the djs were great all night long, and it was great to
see some new talent in our little group. 

All in all... It was a totally killer party. and I am glad that it went off
the way it did... And thank you to the so many people that were a part of
it and to those of you that helped create that phat vibe!!! On behalf of
the whole Harmony Crew, take care and we'll see you next year! We love you!

Peace and love,

Greg = )

  Howdy!
 oh lord, I'm turning into my father-ew :P  I just wanted to share some 
thoughts about this last year...
What "last year?"  It went by soo fast, so many new friends, ideas, and 
dreams.  The one thing that stands out more than anything was that I 
went to my first party last Summer.  Since then, I have been completely 
impacted because of raving,  I would spend my $ on parties instead of 
food, clutches, gas, cigs, tires, fuel pumps (I'm finally learning..I 
need a better job :P)  but the money issue was never really that 
important to me, It was worth the revelations and the things that I have 
matured about.  Shoot, I would pay 20$ /week on crap (m&ms, McD's, gum, 
well f00d in general was my only good hobby, now I've just been eating 
all the fudge that we got from our other foodaholic family members)  I 
might as well be meeting people, dancing, and having a great time ya 
know?  
  I'm actually very excited about the new year for once, I've been very 
content with what has happened and all the good that it has brought into 
my life.  Lord knows what will happen this next year...I don't want to 
think about that right now.. ;)

Stay safe tomorrow night, don't use a condom, use a brick (it would 
really toy with the outcome of the relationship He he )  
Another quick note, if you want to hug a tree this new years eve, make 
sure that you aren't in an automobile

Thank you all for a great one, and to all, a great night...tomorrow 
night...the eve...that is...well..you have a good night tonight 
too...and I will also...

Random acts of spazdom
committed by yours truly,
bAByHueY and good friend,

Mr.Slinkymanguydood

On Tue, 30 Dec 1997, Starchild wrote:

>         Well Patrick, "to distribute marijuana to anyone who wants it" from
> a legal club is de facto legalization, which I would say is indeed, "moving
> towards legalization."

Conducting illegal activities from a legal business in no way moves those
illegal activities towards legalization. Has the cause of legalizing
prostitution been aided by escort services?

Further, there is nothing legal about what the CBC has been doing. It is
in no way "legal" in that sense. 

>         More to the point however, why should someone like myself who
> believes in civil disobedience when it comes to drug laws feel they have to
> obey the letter of Proposition 215 when it says only persons with a medical
> need should get marijuana?  

Please point to any time that I stated that you the individual should obey
the letter of the law, if it is injust. 

> Such a restriction is as immoral and unconstitutional as the rest of the
> War on Drugs, and many of us have felt this way from the beginning.

So the question is: Do you have the ability to battle these restriction on
their own merit, or do you find it necessary to attempt to deceive and
misuse people in an effort to reach your goals? 

>         Allow me to make an analogy:  

I wish you wouldn't. Long, drawn out analogies such as the one presented 
tend to add more confusion to the issues rather than offering
clarification. However since you feel the need...

> Someone I don't know steals $100 from me for no good reason, 

Correction: If the thief is the government as you indicate, you *GAVE*
them the $100. 

And since you proceed on a false premise, I feel no need to continue
picking apart the analogy. 

Please, if you wish to discuss the issues, let's discuss them. I think we
are all capable of understanding them.

>         I hope this has helped you understand how I feel about it.  

Not really. It would have been much easier if you had stuck to the issues.

> And I don't think I'm in danger of waking up just like the people I
> despise, because I have no intention of putting people in jail for
> living lifestyles I don't approve of. 

Even if that lifestyle is harmful to others? 

>         And if you agree that our goal should be legal protection of drug
> use as a fundamental human right, then might I suggest that we focus most
> of our energy on that, instead of fighting with each other about the
> tactics we use to get there?

The tactics are paramount in determining the success or failure of any
given venture. 

Dirty tactics result in dirty results.

X-Sender: leftjab@mail.well.com

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Tue, 30 Dec 1997 23:18:04 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: Re: Dennis Peron/Pot (NRR)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

So what if Dennis Peron thinks all marijuana smoking is medical?  That's
not what Prop. 215 says, and at least one of the three Court of Appeals
judges agreed that it is ridiculous to prevent the sale of legal medicine
(do you have to grow your own opium to get painkillers recommended by your
doctor).  To the extent the CBC has pushed the limits of the law of this
state, the courts, the legislature and the authorities will obviously fight
them as much as they can -- just as they've fought more stringent clubs
like Flower Therapy as well, who haven't been as able to defend themselves
as the CBC despite their less controversial methods.  But until the
government steps in to supply medical marijuana through hospitals and
dispensaries, criticism of the distribution methods of those helping people
rings hollow to me.  Do any of you actually grow and distribute medical
marijuana, or teach ill people how to grow themselves?  Would you take that
risk?

One fact remains -- more people have been provided actual and sometimes
safe access to medical marijuana due to 215 than any other legislation
passed in this country.  And it wouldn't have happened without Dennis
Peron, flaws and all.

Guess what folks?  Dennis Peron started out as a pot dealer.  He's taken
bullets from the SFPD to show for it.  And his illegal connections have
obviously benefited desparately needy people, no matter who else has
benefited.  His personal life hardly shows evidence of great wealth from
selling pot at the club at those above-illegal-market prices.  (If you
aren't sick, but can't get pot in SF elsewhere than the CBC, you deserve to
pay their prices).

Those who observe the CBC -- and remember, no one has yet convicted anyone
associated with the CBC for selling pot, the court ruling was an injunction
without the evidentiary stage yet -- and then conclude that there shouldn't
be medical marijuana, should logically suggest ways of getting pot to sick
people as an alternative to the CBC, not recommend that there be no medical
marijuana under 215.  Those who accept the argument that, because some
people believe medical marijuana should apply to all smoking, there should
be no medical marijuana at all, are the only people who will be so turned
off by the CBC that they won't continue to support medical marijuana.  I
don't think that's that big a group -- most people understand the
difference.

The most Dennis can be accused of is tactical arrogance, not some moral
failing threatening the rights of those who truly need medicine.  He did
more to legalize those rights than anyone, and nothing he's accused of
doing now detracts from that a bit.

To paraphrase Animal Farm, even for those who believe that all marijuana
use is medical, some marijuana use is more medical than others.

leftjab

I realize this is not marijuana related but thought
i would post it to the list anyway. But just to keep 
it on topic i would like to remind everyone that
a long time ago before microsoft, there were a bunch of
rebels that used some extremely illegal activities
to overthrow the government and declare their freedom.
Some of them even grew marijuana, george washington
for one example. Personally i think its about time we
started thinking a little more about these people as
we move into the new year and think about what we want
to create. So with that in mind here is a bit of british
wisdom to help celebrate the new year. And notice how it
is very similar to our own leaders wisdom.

 
Words of Wisdom from British Politicians of the Conservative Party:
     
  "We are not wholly an island, except geographically." --John Major
     
  "Suicide is a real threat to health."  --Virginia Bottomley
     
  "Anyone would think we were living on some island somewhere."
        --George Walden
     
  "It's not the future I'm talking about, I'm talking about tomorrow."
       --John Gummer
     
  "There's no smoke without mud being flung around."
     --Edwina Currie
     
  "I will never forget the 1981, -- or was it 1982? -- honours
     list."  --Julian Critchley
     
  "The trend in the rise in unemployment is downward."
       --Gillian Shepherd
     
  "The more important things are more important than the less
      important things."  --Stephen Dorrell
     
  "When the IRA plant such bombs, it proves they can scare people,
     it proves they can kill people, it proves nothing."
     -- Peter Bottomley
     
  "We said zero, and I think any statistician will tell you that...
     zero must mean plus or minus a few."  --William Waldegrave
     
  "Who Sadam Hussein kills, dies."  --Jeffrey Archer
     
  "All those people who say that there will never be a Single
   European Currency are trying to forecast history."  Kenneth Clark
     
  "The British public sees with blinding clarity."
     --Michael Hese


happy new year

98 is going to be great!
A year without hate
is the wish 
of this fish

and may a golden star be born in each of our hearts this new years eve.
And let each of those stars connect with a beam of love and gratitude.
Tonight let our hearts beat as one in peace and happiness.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

frustrated. I can't make the money I need to buy bigger systems for those high paying 
jobs. What is worse is a high percentage of the people I have dealt with who want a 
system for cheap or free dont understand the value of the equipment. They dont 
understand if they blow my equipment up I might not be able to make my rent that month.

so thier feelings of responsibility towards my equipment is limited.

towards someone elses.  Believe me, it is sooo much cheaper/easier to pay $20 than it 
is to throw a party(or even volunteer). It would be kinda cool if everyone who 
complained about expensive partys threw thier own free party.

pesky ideals so if you are in a bind call me and I will help you with sound.

The *fact* of the matter is that pot's active ingredient THC cannot
be properly synthesized, so the little tablets (Marinol is the brand
name, I believe) don't do it for a lot of people.  It is possible to
eat pot (in, like, brownies or cookies or whatever), but that takes
a lot of preperation time, and takes a lot longer to work its way into
the system, and, therefore longer to give any pain relief.  So, smoking
is the way to go for a lot of people.

The only reason you haven't heard of a pharmacutical that is smoked
is because marijuana has been illegal since the '30's.  It is the
fastest and most economical way to deliver THC into the bloodstream.

Cheers,
Steve.

On Tue, 30 Dec 1997, leftjab wrote:

> So what if Dennis Peron thinks all marijuana smoking is medical?  

Oh, I dunno, the crazy idea that he is not a doctor, and lacking those
credentials, cannot make such a determination?

> That's not what Prop. 215 says, and at least one of the three Court of
> Appeals judges agreed that it is ridiculous to prevent the sale of legal
> medicine (do you have to grow your own opium to get painkillers
> recommended by your doctor).  

I don't think anyone(myself included) is arguing that point. 

> To the extent the CBC has pushed the limits of the law of this
> state, the courts, the legislature and the authorities will obviously fight
> them as much as they can -- just as they've fought more stringent clubs
> like Flower Therapy as well, who haven't been as able to defend themselves
> as the CBC despite their less controversial methods.  

By all means, then let's focus on the clubs that are playing "by the
rules." These are the ones that are suffering the injustices, and who
should be receiving the attention.

> But until the government steps in to supply medical marijuana through
> hospitals and dispensaries, criticism of the distribution methods of
> those helping people rings hollow to me.  

It isn't an issue of "distribution methods." It is an issue of
distributing it to people that have no need for it, while attempting to
hide behind a law that allows you to distribute it to people that actually
are in need of it. 

> Do any of you actually grow and distribute medical marijuana, or teach
> ill people how to grow themselves?  Would you take that risk?

This is totally irrelevant to to the issue being discussed, which for
the umpteenth time is the distribution of the substance to those *THAT ARE
NOT ILL* by attempting to misuse the law that allows the use of the
substance by those that are actually ill, and the possible
deleterious effects that may result from these actions. If you wish to
discuss the legitimate purpose of 215 which the CBC is totally
disregarding, by all means let's start a seperate thread. 
 
> One fact remains -- more people have been provided actual and sometimes
> safe access to medical marijuana due to 215 than any other legislation
> passed in this country.  And it wouldn't have happened without Dennis
> Peron, flaws and all.

Oh yes, Dennis Peron, one man crusade. Sorry, that falls very, very short. 
As the legislation passed, it is obvious that there was popular support
for the concept, so all you can do is speculate that it would not have
happened sans Dennis Peron.

> Guess what folks?  Dennis Peron started out as a pot dealer.  

And he still is. 

> bullets from the SFPD to show for it.  And his illegal connections have
> obviously benefited desparately needy people, no matter who else has
> benefited.  

In the short term, I would agree. However his lies and irresponsibility
stands to destroy those benefits for *everyone* in the long term. 

> His personal life hardly shows evidence of great wealth from
> selling pot at the club at those above-illegal-market prices.  (If you
> aren't sick, but can't get pot in SF elsewhere than the CBC, you deserve to
> pay their prices).

Again, it isn't relevant to the conversation. Dennis Peron could make a
million dollars from dealing drugs, and I would care one whit except for
the fact that he is hiding behind the ill, and stands to destroy or
severly damage the legalization movement for the forseeable future.

> Those who observe the CBC -- and remember, no one has yet convicted anyone
> associated with the CBC for selling pot, 

Rather they are convicted or not has no relevance to the fact that they
are doing so. 

> the court ruling was an injunction without the evidentiary stage yet --
> and then conclude that there shouldn't be medical marijuana, should
> logically suggest ways of getting pot to sick people as an alternative
> to the CBC, not recommend that there be no medical marijuana under 215.

Again, you have gone off on a tangent. I haven't seen anyone here suggest
that there be no medical marijuana under 215. My comments are directed
specifically towards and about Dennis Perone and the CBC.

> Those who accept the argument that, because some  people believe medical
> marijuana should apply to all smoking, there should be no medical
> marijuana at all, 

Again, who said that? 

> The most Dennis can be accused of is tactical arrogance, not some moral
> failing threatening the rights of those who truly need medicine.  

You are very, very mistaken. It is not only a moral failing, but the
jepardization of a law that he helped create. I'm sorry that you can't see
that using the ill as a front for drug dealing is wrong, but it is.

It is no wonder that with attitudes such as this, *even* among the people
that don't agree with many of the laws governing our society and complain 
about the deceit of politicians, that we have the liars and thieves we do
in government. You are endorsing the same tactics. 

> He did more to legalize those rights than anyone, and nothing he's
> accused of doing now detracts from that a bit.

Short term success, mis-managed and misused will most likely result in
long term failure. And considering that his actions stand to hurt far more
than they will help, he should be prevented from doing further harm.

After spinning at a house party a couple of weeks ago, I was talking to some of the
people about trance.  One girl said, "You know, I can never tell the songs apart.
It all sounds the same.  What are you [DJs] doing?" I told her that it was a good
sign that she couldn't tell when a new record came in...good beat matching, etc.
 Later I was wondering...is it really a good sign that they can't tell the records
apart?  Stylistically, of course.  I mean, shouldn't they be able to tell that a
set has gone somewhere?  I was wondering what y'all thought...
Post if you think others would be interested.  Otherwise, reply straight to me. 

The curiously strong peppermint...

I have agreed with most (not all) of what you have said so far but not this.
I know several that use marijuana for things like nausea, migrains,depression
and various other minor ailments. Why should we have to go to a doctor
everytime we get indigestion or headache? Part of the medical
problem today is that we have given too much athourity to the medical
community that is controlled by the government and drug companies which
by the way are the ones fighting this law. There are so many cases
of people with terminal illnesses that have rejected the AMA and
turned to natural medicine and cured themselves. To me this whole 
issue is one of freedom...freedom to choose your own treatment and
freedom from government control. Doctors using current medical practices
are causing more harm than good because americans are too lazy to 
think for themselves anymore and would rather have some
"expert" or government agency tell us what is good or bad.
