It kind of depends on what kind of music you're spinning.  House tends
to (traditionally, anyway) be more dependant on particular songs,
whereas trance is more seamless and not as geard toward being a "remix"
of a song, but rather something else entirely -- like taking little
bits of song or sound bites or movie dialogue or whatever on top of
beats, other sound effects, keyboard, etc.  For that reason, I tend
prefer trance, because it's easier to get lost in it, since there is
not as many real "transitions".  Naturally, a set should "go somewhere",
but that dosen't mean you have to make sudden or drastic changes.

Well, you asked . . .

Steve.

I have high standards, so up yours.

Hiya all,


.
> 
> Steve.
> 
> I have high standards, so up yours.

Yowza. Glad to see your high standards apply to all of us as well.

Alrighty, here's my $.02.

I think that if you look at a DJ's history and how they came up it sort of
gives an indication of whether they can do high impact transitions from one
song to another. It has been my experience that those that come from a hip
hop/club background are more adept at a taking house/trance/techno tracks and
making the transition, although obvious, an amazing step towards raising the
energy level in a mix.
However, the DJs that come in from only mixing house, trance, etc. don't
really have the ability to mix and change tempo's etc. because they don't
understand how to program music and change things up on a willing crowd. Their
DJ'ing experience is really an incestuous one and doesn't draw from a whole
lot of different (and extremely valuable) perspectives.
In my experience, it is much easier to DJ to a rave/party crowd than a top
40/club crowd. The top 40 crowd is always in your face asking for requests,
etc. and they are completely dependant on your ability to keep their interest
in the music (you are, after all, competing against their next "pick-up" or
their inebriated state).
House music and rave goers, however really depend on a steady groove and they
truly leave you alone (unless you really blow, then all the closet DJs come
out of the closet!). I feel that the prior experience is more valuable in
every DJ's growing resume.
It's the DJ that understands how to successfully work the music, forcing it to
do things w/ turntablist skills, that make for a better DJ.
Otherwise, you are just beatmatching. Just about anyone can do that after a
couple of weeks practice.

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com


> 
> Amber Marie Lawraine Nixon wrote:

On Wed, 31 Dec 1997 fish1111@pacbell.net wrote:

> blkadder@value.net wrote:
> > 
> > On Tue, 30 Dec 1997, leftjab wrote:
> > 
> > > So what if Dennis Peron thinks all marijuana smoking is medical?
> > 
> > Oh, I dunno, the crazy idea that he is not a doctor, and lacking those
> > credentials, cannot make such a determination?  
> 
> I have agreed with most (not all) of what you have said so far but not this.
> I know several that use marijuana for things like nausea, migrains,depression
> and various other minor ailments. Why should we have to go to a doctor
> everytime we get indigestion or headache? 

No. My point is that Dennis Peron is not qualified to determine that all
marijuana smoking is medical and then use that determination in an attempt 
to subvert the law that he helped create. 

And since we are on the topic of smoking, while marijuana may be natural,
I imagine that putting any kind of smoke in your lungs is not good for
you, thus it really is necessary to weigh the possible negative effects
when evaluating the desired effects. 

> Part of the medical problem today is that we have given too much
> athourity to the medical community that is controlled by the government
> and drug companies which by the way are the ones fighting this law.

I have no argument with this. However 215 states that marijuana can be
authorized by a doctors recommendation, not Dennis Peron's, or your own. 
If you want to take back the authority that has been given to the medical
community, then that needs to be done via legislation spelling it out. 

> There are so many cases of people with terminal illnesses that have
> rejected the AMA and turned to natural medicine and cured themselves. 

Do you think the terminally ill that turn away from the advice of their
doctors and die anyways are put in the media? No, it isn't newsworthy. The
*exceptions*, the ones that do survive despite all odds end up in the
press. However, I do agree that in the cases of the terminally ill, they
should be able to try pretty much anything they want.

> To me this whole issue is one of freedom...freedom to choose your own
> treatment and freedom from government control. 

In the broader sense, I agree. However my comments were about the actions
of Dennis Peron and the CBC specifically. 

> Doctors using current medical practices are causing more harm than good

If this was indeed the case, no one be going to them, and they would be
completely unable to obtain malpratice insurance.

While I fully support the use of alternative medicines and healing
practices, they are not a substitute for modern medicine. Ideally, they
would be used in conjunction with alternative practices. And this is
beginning to happen. My HMO for example offers chiropractic, acupuncture,
and courses in *preventitive* medicine. And several of the others I
reviewed offered similar programs.

       daily.

     * Clubline - 415.979.8686

     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
     _________________________________________________________________
   
                             Radio/TV/Net Shows
                                      
     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 11:30pm-2:30am - "Conscious Groove" - a show all
       about ambientdowntempojungletechnotrancedrumnbasstriphop love and
       more with weekly guest DJs. Free Radio Berkeley 104.1 (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Thursday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Friday 10am-3pm - weekly DJ netcasts. x-radio.
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon and guests -
       Beats, Breakz and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford). Also broadcast via
       RealAudio.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "House Nation" w/"Anthems Mix", Top 10s from
       guest DJs and "London Connection w/DJ Doubt". 2am-4am, WILD 94.9
       SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

                            Administrative Notes
                                      
   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

Date: Wed, 31 Dec 1997 13:49:34 -0800

From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Re: Opinions please
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

when i first heard jungle, i thought all the songs sounded the same, and
then someone said (hi reagan!) ... "wow!!! this is my favorite song!!" and
i thought she was out of her mind...  then i learned to listen differently,
and saw the subtleties and learned about the styles, and generally became
more educated...

house is easier, because there are usually some sort of lyrics or
distinctive beat patterns, it's more like a "song" usually ..... but that's
just one end of the spectrum...

i think that anyone who thinks that any genre of music all sounds the same
hasn't really learned to listen to that music yet, and that if they pay
attention, they'll begin to feel it...

a dj shouldn't have to trainwreck just to show that these are two separate
records.... because it's in the mixing, the layering, the gradual
transitions, where two or more pieces of music blend to create something
entirely different, that the truest and most beautiful music is made.


my two cents,

leslie

From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)

Dear Leslie & Rave friends,

        Hi again!  My response to Leslie's post is below...

>>>>[starchild said....]        Allow me to make an analogy:  Someone I don't
>>>>know steals $100 from
>>>>me for no good reason, and a friend of mine knows who took it and says to
>>>>them, "Just return $10 of the money and everything will be cool."  My
>>>>friend tells me the thief has agreed to return $10 of the money, and wants
>>>>to know if that's okay with me.  "Sure," I say, figuring getting $10 back
>>>>is better than nothing.  Let's say my friend assumes that my consent to
>>>>getting the $10 back means I won't try to get the other $90 also when I
>>>>find out who took it, even though I explicitly never agree to this.  Let's
>>>>say that based on what my friend tells him, the thief also believes he can
>>>>return $10 and everything will be cool.  Should I make sure and let my
>>>>friend know otherwise?  Frankly, I don't care about my friend's
>>>>relationship with the thief -- I think he'd be better off not having
>>>>friends like that.  And if he's my friend, he should be glad to see me get
>>>>my money back without involving him in a lie.  Deceptive?  Yeah.  But if
>>>>the thief comes by with $10, and I make him give me back the other $90 as
>>>>well, is justice served?  You bet!
>>>
>>>[leslie said....]  starchild, i tried to and failed to follow your analogy
>>>about having
>>>someone steal from you....
>>
>and then robin said....
>
>>I think that Starchild's analogy is working under the assumption that we
>>have the innate right to "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" as
>>long as our actions do not infringe unduly upon the rights of others to do
>>the same.  When the government instated laws that did not allow us the
>>freedom to life our lives as we like (i.e. took away our right to use
>>drugs), they stole something from us -- in Starchild's analogy, the person
>>stole the $100 from us.  Our friend (those who support legalizing marijuana
>>for medical use) have negotiated with the theif (the government) to get
>>back some of the innate rights that have been taken from us.  But if we are
>>able to force the theif to return the rest of the rights that are owed to
>>us, why shouldn't we?  If we have an innate right to liberty, shouldn't we
>>defy a law that attempts to take those rights away?
>
>(hi robin!)
>
>while your description makes it a little clearer, i think my perceptual
>problem here is that i think we're dreaming if we think that the
>"thief"/government can be likened to someone we can beat up and steal our
>money back from (that was what you had in mind, starchild? the "thief"
>would appear with the $10 in hand, and you'd knock him over the head or
>whatever and demand or steal back the other $90???)...

        Robin summed up what I meant very nicely, but my analogy wasn't
perfect, just the best I could quickly come up with.  In the real world, we
have an extremely important advantage over the thief/bully government:
They're trying to *force* us to do or not do something, we're just trying
to be free.

        That is, we don't have to "get our money back" as in my example.
All we have to do is get them to leave us alone from now on!  Although some
would disagree with me, I'm willing to have a general amnesty for
government officials who have been involved in the War on Drugs, and I'm
also willing to forgive their debt of billions of our dollars that have
been wasted on it.  (We should insist however, that people convicted of
nonviolent drug offenses be freed, and that property siezed in the drug war
be returned.)

>i don't think that's very realistic, expecially if you're a 2-foot-tall
>weakling and the thief is the big bad giant thug who's a hundred times, a
>thousand times, a million times, your size, and who has a whole army of
>legislation and enforcement behind him, and who will happily use that to
>show you who has the power when he realizes you think you set him up.
>
>to me, while i see some of the reasoning in this analogy, it's a little
>like the kindergarten kid thinking he's going to beat up the boogy man...
>it's dreaming.  you cannot "force" or trick the government into making drug
>use legal... and you cannot bluster your way through the current laws.  to
>change the rules, you have to work within the system that is set up for
>changing the rules.  because the "government" and the "legal system" is
>really just people who are enforcing the rules that they are told to
>enforce.

        I believe there are times and means for working within the system,
and times and means for working outside the system.  Again looking at
history, there was a place for the people trying to get slavery legally
outlawed, and there was also a place for John Brown, the white leader of a
group who went around freeing slaves by force and killing slaveowners who
resisted.

        To say that the only way to make change is by following rules set
up by your opponents is to concede way to much.  It's also exactly what
they want you to think!

        Real, successful change very often comes about by breaking rules.
Consider the Free Speech movement at Berkeley, or Emma Goldman's public
speeches on the use of contraceptives which landed her in jail (yes, that
happened in this country, in this century!), but changed society
irrevocably for the better.

        Of course, you may say I'm a dreamer (I know, it's even part of my
email address), but I'm not the only one... In one of my favorite quotes,
Margaret Mead said, "Never doubt that a small, committed group of people
can change the world.  Indeed it's the only thing that ever has."

Love & liberty,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

Dear Brynne,

        Without more information about how much you charge, the cost of
your system, etc., it's hard to say much in response to this.

        However I will say that I get the impression you are trying to make
enough money to pay rent and afford a bigger soundsystem on the basis of
loaning your current system to underground-type events.  Respectfully, I
would suggest that the frustration you experience may be due to your
regarding this activity as a money-making venture.

        On the other hand, if the people you're loaning the equipment to
are really that unsympathetic and careless in their attitude toward you and
your system, maybe you should consider making it available elsewhere.
Surely there are good and considerate promoters who would not take this
attitude.

May the bass be with us,   ;)

                                <<< Starchild >>>


>Starchild wrote:
>>   If I were a sound system
>> owner, I would charge the going rate to promoters throwing parties as
>> business ventures, but I would let non-commercial friendly vibe promoters
>> use it for little or nothing, perhaps merely loaning it on condition they

>broke and

>high paying
>jobs. What is worse is a high percentage of the people I have dealt with
>who want a

>understand if they blow my equipment up I might not be able to make my
>rent that month.
>In thier mind the value of the equipment is((Cheap)), they didnt put any
>effort out and
>so thier feelings of responsibility towards my equipment is limited.
>

>energy. If 20$

>some energy

>might take for

>> blkadder@value.net wrote:
>> >
>> > On Tue, 30 Dec 1997, leftjab wrote:
>> >
>> > > So what if Dennis Peron thinks all marijuana smoking is medical?
>> >
>> > Oh, I dunno, the crazy idea that he is not a doctor, and lacking those
>> > credentials, cannot make such a determination?
>>
>> I have agreed with most (not all) of what you have said so far but not this.
>> I know several that use marijuana for things like nausea, migrains,depression
>> and various other minor ailments. Why should we have to go to a doctor
>> everytime we get indigestion or headache?
>
>No. My point is that Dennis Peron is not qualified to determine that all
>marijuana smoking is medical and then use that determination in an attempt
>to subvert the law that he helped create.

He doesn't make the Doctor's recommendations people need to get pot at the
CBC, so how is he subverting the law?  Human beings are perfectly qualified
to their opinions, but that opinion of his doesn't translate into open pot
sales at the club for non-medical needs, despite what you think.

>
>And since we are on the topic of smoking, while marijuana may be natural,
>I imagine that putting any kind of smoke in your lungs is not good for
>you, thus it really is necessary to weigh the possible negative effects
>when evaluating the desired effects.
>

For people suffering from nausea, smoking is generally accepted as the best
method of administration, because nauseous people have problems taking it
orally.  Pot in edible form is readily available at the club for those who
get better medical effects that way.

And despite what you "imagine" about pot's effects on the lungs, there is
absolutely been no medical connection made between any long term lung
health effects and long term smoking.  Anecdotally, elder Rastas in Jamaica
who have smoked for decades show no additional cases of lung cancer or
emphysema.

>This is totally irrelevant to to the issue being discussed, which for
>the umpteenth time is the distribution of the substance to those *THAT ARE
>NOT ILL* by attempting to misuse the law that allows the use of the
>substance by those that are actually ill, and the possible
>deleterious effects that may result from these actions. If you wish to
>discuss the legitimate purpose of 215 which the CBC is totally
>disregarding, by all means let's start a seperate thread.


>> I defy you to prove this, BA.  No one else can, not even the state
>>government.
>
>I don't have to prove it. I have seen it with my own eyes.

Oh, and what have you seen, exactly?  When and where and how?  If you have
and think it's such a bad thing, go testify against him then, and stop
making public smears on the list (frankly, it's incredibly poor form to
make accusations of illegal behavior on this list anyway).  If it were
true, the government would have some credible allegations by now, given the
tens of thousands of dollars spent investigating the club.

The only way the government people got pot from the club, according to the
civil lawsuit, was to forge doctor's notes, and then staff a phony Doctor's
office with people confirming the recommendations.  In other words, the
club only gave pot to people with doctor's notes confirmed by the "doctor."
Hardly proof of what you're implying.  I also can't see why anyone would go
through the trouble of setting up a phony doctor's office just to get pot
at the club unless they were trying to entrap the club.

>> His personal life hardly shows evidence of great wealth from
>> selling pot at the club at those above-illegal-market prices.  (If you
>> aren't sick, but can't get pot in SF elsewhere than the CBC, you deserve
>> to pay their prices).
>
>The above certainly sounds like you know what is occuring there as well,
>so why the sudden change of story?

Stop telling me what I know.   My point was that if the club were a front
for a full-scale operation, it makes no sense from an economic point of
view, and there's no evidence of ill-gotten gains.  I've heard that people
with medical clearance sometimes buy pot for non-medical people for use
outside the club, which is their fraud, not Dennis'.  This happens with
lots of prescription drugs which have recreational uses .  i've also heard
of pot being used at the club during off-hours for non medical-uses, but I
have no idea where the pot came from.  I don't know what you know or have
seen, given your vague allegations.

>
>If it weren't for the voters such as myself who voted for the legislation,
>the "movement" would be nowhere. Personally, I don't appreciate being lied
>to, no matter how "noble" the intent.

You weren't lied to by the proposition.  It stands (and falls) on its own
language and judicial enforcement.

I'm not going to continue this thread, as it saddens me deeply to hear such
innuendo and vitriol thrown at someone who has helped thousands of sick
people in fact through the club for years.


leftjab

From: Ruth Jennison <ruthj@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: totally rave related!re: E&diabetes
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Funny you should ask. E doesnt cause diabetes if thats what you mean, but
ive had type 1 for a year now, and am just getting back into raving. I used
to be quite a party girl all the way from industrial to mod to punk to goan
hard trance depending upon the mood of the era and my personal predelicitons.
Taking drugs on diabetes is hard. But only the first couple of times. Hell
if youre a diabetic then you know the scientific method of trial and error-
you employ it everytime you give yourself a shot and eat a meal. 
employ this same method for taking drugs. take small amounts, test your
sugar before and during and after. Unfortunately the first few times you do
it you arent allowed to forget that you are a diabetic (which is a drag) but
hell diabetes is a real character builder and for myself extracting a little
blood from my finger and giving myslef a corrective shot in a poorly lit 200
bpm dance enviornment on  two pills is easier that figuring out the ratio of
carbohydrate to insulin in my everyday meals!!
E is kinda tough, becuase it dyhydrates you big time, which is a problem for
diabetics, as dehydrated cells are terribly insulin resistant which in turn
makes then more dehydrated!!! So the dehydration ups your sugar -- I can
maintain a CONSTANT sugar if I dance all night (dancing lowers sugars, and
its not hard to do) and drink lots of water. ITs tricky though, end entirely
personal how it affects you. pot acid opiates- all the downers- produce
almost no effect but coke, e, speed, meth you must experiment with,
hopefully in a controlled setting before you try them in a club. (PS
sometimes its annoying to try and get insulin needles past security) 
make sure you have a friend round who knows the deal and can administer
glucagon if necessary. 
maybe you werent even asking for yourself, but heres my mouthful anyway:)
once you get it figured out, you can establish a routine (maybe you need to
not dance so much, maybe you need an extra shot at 6 am whatever maybe you
need to resist all those free lollipops)....so the hard work pays off and
eventually you can rave without obsessing about your blood sugar. Its weird
when youre a diabetic at a rave, everyone looks so carefree and healthy
(sucking on all those menthols) that it can feel a little alienating to have
a disease that you have to monitor. But diabetics need to live a life and
raving is worth it for me!!

Ruth (age 23, dxd 1996, trance fiend -- looking for good trance this new
years??)


At 02:07 PM 12/31/97 -0800, you wrote:

>diabetes and E?
>
>do they even have any correlation w/ one another?
>
>thanks!
>
>
>

this year, instead of giving up my bad habits, i resolve to cultivate
new ones.  i will try new drugs, and over-indulge in the ones i
already know and love, starting tonight.  i will dance harder, and
more often, despite the pain and stiffness i know i will suffer the
next day.  i will wear clothing that is inappropriate to my age and
station in life.  i will stay up all night on weekdays, and perform
poorly at work the next day.  i will post things to sfraves that are
non-rave related, and not label them as such.  i will continue to
smoke.  i wish ill tidings on those select few i consider my enemies. 
in fact, i resolve to actively seek to make their lives miserable if
at all possible, convenient, and untraceable.  i will give free reign
to my hormones, no matter what a slut people think i am.  i will
attend an orgy.  i will pay someone to spank me.  i will blow my
savings on things i don't really need, like a big, plush,
mid-seventies luxury sedan that will pollute the atmosphere and break
down regularly.  i will get a tattoo i will regret later.  i will
encourage others to behave similarly.  i will start my own religion.

love, messiah w

Dear Patrick,

        It seems from your several recent messages that your real beef with
Dennis Peron is with what you see as his deceptiveness -- you "don't like
to be lied to," in your words.  But can't you see that any deception here
is a direct result of the criminalization of marijuana use, not of an
intent on his part to deceive the public?

        Say you've been engaging in an illegal activity and a cop stops you
to question you about it.  Are you going to tell the truth, knowing your
word one way or the other is the only evidence he has?  I don't think so!
Both of you may know you're lying, but it doesn't matter.  If you tell the
truth, he may feel obligated to bust you, whereas if you lie, he can't.  If
the Cannabis Buyer's Club is ignoring the letter of Proposition 215, then
they're in a similar situation.  When you're as visible as Dennis Peron is,
you can't publicly state that you're breaking or are intending to break the
law -- even an unconstitutional and illegal law against recreational drug
use -- without jeopardizing your ability to continue doing so.

        Frankly, I don't know whether the CBC is selling pot to people
without doctors' prescriptions or not.  I hope they are, and I hope they
continue to do so and get away with it.  Better that people have a safe and
reliable place to buy marijuana than that they risk being ripped off by
shady street dealers, or busted by undercover cops posing as dealers.

        I've read a lot of your posts during the times I've been on this
list Patrick, and even though I can at times find your tone uncivil (which
isn't to say I don't like you as a person; I do), I tend to agree with most
of your opinions.  On this issue though, you've lost me.  You remind me of
people who get mad at Bill Clinton for breaking numerous campaign promises
such as a big middle class tax cut after they voted for him.  What did they
expect?  If you rely on a Democrat to cut your taxes, you're a fool.  While
it would be nice if politicians kept their promises, people should know
enough not to believe what they say.  If you want the real story, look at
their records, look at who they associate with, look at what they do.

        I'm sorry, but anyone who tells me they were deceived by Dennis
Peron on the issue of marijuana I would regard as either naive or just
flinging charges around.  Dennis has stated openly and repeatedly over his
years as a public figure that he believes marijuana should be totally
legal, and what's more, the opponents of Proposition 215 publicized his
pro-legalization attitude and that of other 215 supporters during the
campaign in an attempt to discredit them.  Only someone paying virtually no
attention to the man or the issue would have been deceived into thinking he
was somehow going to change his beliefs and methods if 215 passed.

        Also I might add that the statement that all pot use is medical is
not as ridiculous as it seems, although leftjab's statement about some
marijuana use being more medical than other use is true.  We are learning
more and more about the mind-body connection, and how things like
depression and being stressed out can cause serious medical problems.
(Author and lecturer Deepak Chopra has some fascinating things to say on
this and related topics.)  The correlation between mental states and
physical health shows how occasional pot use could easily come under the
category of preventive health care.

        You say Dennis is not qualified to judge who would and would not
benefit medically from the use of pot because he is not a doctor.  But with
his long experience using and being around people who use pot, I'll bet he
has a hell of a lot more expertise in this area than the vast majority of
medical doctors -- foolish fish was dead-on right about the medical
monopoly in this country.

        And yes, I know what 215 says about needing a doctor's
prescription, but to me it's not an issue of what the law says, but what's
right and wrong.

        Ending the drug war is right -- it will save many lives every year
of people who are killed in drug-related violence due to illegality, many
of them young and healthy with their whole lives ahead of them.  We musn't
become so preoccupied with the suffering of medical marijuana patients that
we lose sight of the larger picture and throw away the chance to save more
lives and ease more suffering in the long run.

Yours in liberty,
                                       <<< Starchild >>>

At 04:48 PM 12/31/97 -0800, Starchild wrote:
>        Say you've been engaging in an illegal activity and a cop stops you
>to question you about it.  Are you going to tell the truth, knowing your
>word one way or the other is the only evidence he has?  I don't think so!

Trust me, the last thing you want to do when a cop is asking you a question
is lie to them.  Lying to a police officer is a felony, having a small
amount of pot on you is a citation at worst, and unless you're a REALLY
good liar, it's going to come out, the cop's going to be pissed, and any
chance you had for on-the-spot clemency is shot.

Just ask the folks who helped throw a recent underground in SF that got
busted.  The promoter of the party was in the crowd but refused to step
forward when the cops arrived due to sound complaints.  The cops, pissed
that no one was coming forward, decided to confiscate the equipment -
somebody had to have owned at least the equipment, and those who did
stepped forward, and one was arrested.  A far worse outcome than if the
promoter had simply stepped forward and handled the cop situation directly.

>Both of you may know you're lying, but it doesn't matter.  If you tell the
>truth, he may feel obligated to bust you, whereas if you lie, he can't.  

I'm sure you're not really as dim as this sentence suggests.

>        Frankly, I don't know whether the CBC is selling pot to people
>without doctors' prescriptions or not.  I hope they are, and I hope they
>continue to do so and get away with it.  Better that people have a safe and
>reliable place to buy marijuana than that they risk being ripped off by
>shady street dealers, or busted by undercover cops posing as dealers.

Even if it means the state government, or the feds (who can simply declare
that 215 doesn't apply to federal regulations on narcotics, which has been
upheld by the Supreme Court before) comes in and shuts down the CBC
permanently, voids 215, and ends up closing other medical marijuana
dispensaries around the state?  Is that really a better option than the
alternative, which is that the dispensaries stay open and truly sell only
to those with a legit notice from a doctor?  Do you think that /won't/
happen if the CBC isn't hardened up?

If you read the newspaper, you'll see that both Governor Wilson and Dan
Lungren recognize that 215 is a mandate from the public to license medical
marijuana dispensaries, and that they are prepared to carry that out.  It
might be with a conservative interpretation of 215, but that's better than
nothing.  

>        And yes, I know what 215 says about needing a doctor's
>prescription, but to me it's not an issue of what the law says, but what's
>right and wrong.

Then why bother with a proposition at all?  

>        Ending the drug war is right -- it will save many lives every year
>of people who are killed in drug-related violence due to illegality, many
>of them young and healthy with their whole lives ahead of them.  We musn't
>become so preoccupied with the suffering of medical marijuana patients that
>we lose sight of the larger picture and throw away the chance to save more
>lives and ease more suffering in the long run.

Since you're a big fan of analogies, let me give a few that I think
illustrate why Patrick's ire is up:

1) Recent tax cuts which were promoted as being "pro-middle-class" because
they gave an extra $500 tax deduction for children, yet also contained
staggering cuts in capital gains and estate taxes.  Overall those with
greater than $150K in household income fared far better than those with
less than $150K.  

2) "Desert Storm" - ostensibly to "restore democracy and autonomy to
Kuwait", yet clearly it was for the purpose of protecting American oil
interests.  Democracy in Kuwait or Saudi Arabia?  Laughable.  Human rights?
 What are those?

3) Recent "fines" levied on big tobacco manufacturers by the feds and
several states; while they sounded staggering (over $1Billion), they are
actually a boon for these companies because it exempts them from liability
from all other class-action lawsuits, *and* it allows them to deduct those
payments from their business taxes directly.  It's a giant shell game - the
public has been conned into thinking "yeah, we showed 'em!" yet the
cigarrette makers were hardly affected.  

In all three cases it's the government lying to the people.  In this case,
it's an "outside" group lying to the people.  To me, each is deplorable, no
matter how transparant it is.

	Brian

I know this wasn't directed to me but..bzzzt! wrong.
Dennis has been knowingly puffin' smoke in any direction needed to be
able to continue his sales. IMO he's also doing WAY cool public service
so many folks don't give a big rip. But don't cloud over the facts, he
doesn't want too many to know that he has thousands of untaxed
unaccountable CASH going through his club every day it's open.

<major snip of very right on ideas>

        Ending the drug war is right -- it will save many lives every
year
of people who are killed in drug-related violence due to illegality,
many
of them young and healthy with their whole lives ahead of them.  We
musn't
become so preoccupied with the suffering of medical marijuana patients
that

more

I agree with most everything you've stated, well put, right on! etc.

I think we all agree that there is some f**ked up laws that effect us
and the entire drug war needs to be re-aligned with common sense &
reality...

the point is the long-term goals and how many folks are not sure what to
do about his F**K the laws I'm going to do what I'm doing attitude and
waiving (mainly) AIDS patients in the face of anyone who disagrees

A lot of good has come out of the work Dennis has done, the concern has
always been that his sloppy disregard for how to run the
service/self-policing and providing to those not covered under the law
will keep at risk the people who are actually sick and will die without
pot.

Each time the club has been shut down the patients are the ones that
suffer. You probably won't get many to go on record against him because
they are the same people that need him every so often. It's like living
with a corrupt sherriff - you need the relationship to remain even
though things are kinda screwy.

IMO he dis-credits all the folks who are doing research & education (and
yes legislation) and have to work twice as hard to be accepted for the
work they do (and unfortunately just distance themselves from him).

At 07:52 PM 12/31/97 EST, you wrote:
>Smoked, it takes effect much quicker than taken orally, as in a tablet or
>cookies/brownies/pasta, etc...  Marijana had been used often until the approx
>1890's, and still used until the 1930's.
>Marijuana started becoming illegal in the advent of MORPHINE!!!  Some food
for
>thought.
*****
thanks for the additional information... I was aware of it.
certainly, it takes longer to take effect orally.. just like *any* pill...
15-20 min if it doesn't have an enteric coating on it... like most
ibuprophen for example...

my point was, that *growing* and *selling* marijuana really doesn't have to
have anything to do with the legalization of it for medical use.  The fact
that an orally ingested  pill will take effect later, and *longer* leads me
to believe it would be the preferred perscription by doctors.  

Not, find a drug dealer, buy some sticky greens.. and smoke up at least 3
times a day for meals, eat an apple if you get the munchies.... oh, and
don't get any of the funky mexican browns, it's stony, but that's not what
i'm perscribing.

peace,
-SolR
